Question: Two large flat metal plates A and B are placed 9.0 cm apart in vacuum as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A potential difference of 450 V is maintained between the plates by means of a battery.An electron is released from rest at the surface of plate A.   Determine the speed of the electron on reaching plate B.  speed = ............................................. m s–1 [4]
Explanation:
The electron accelerates due to the electric field between the plates. The work done by the field equals its kinetic energy gain.  

Work done = \( qV = (1.6 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{C})(450 \, \text{V}) = 7.2 \times 10^{-17} \, \text{J} \).  

Using \( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 7.2 \times 10^{-17} \):  
\( v^2 = \frac{2 \times 7.2 \times 10^{-17}}{9.1 \times 10^{-31}} = 1.58 \times 10^{14} \).  
\( v = \sqrt{1.58 \times 10^{14}} = 1.26 \times 10^7 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

Speed = **1.26 × 10⁷ m s⁻¹**.  

[4]

Question: Two large flat metal plates A and B are placed 9.0 cm apart in vacuum as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A potential difference of 450 V is maintained between the plates by means of a battery.On the axes of Fig. 5.2, sketch a graphic show the variation with distance d from plate A of the speed v of the electron. [1]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: line from origin, curved in correct direction but not 'level out' B1 [1]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A graph with distance d (from 0 to 9 cm) on the x-axis and speed v on the y-axis. The graph starts at the origin (0,0) and curves upwards with a decreasing slope, forming a concave-down curve. The curve increases continuously without flattening, as the electron accelerates uniformly across the plates.)  

The electron experiences a constant electric force \( F = qE \), leading to uniform acceleration \( a = \frac{qV}{md} \). Since \( v^2 = 2ad \) (from kinematics), \( v \propto \sqrt{d} \). The graph of \( v \) against \( d \) is therefore a curve starting at the origin, rising with decreasing gradient, and not levelling out within the 9 cm range.  

[1]

Question: A student set up the circuit shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistors are of resistance 15 Ω and 45 Ω. The battery is found to provide 1.6×105 J of electrical energy when a charge of 1.8×104 C passes through the ammeter in a time of 1.3 × 105 s.Determine  the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery,   e.m.f. = …………………………………….. V
Explanation:
The e.m.f. of the battery is calculated using the formula:  
\[
\text{e.m.f.} = \frac{\text{Energy}}{\text{Charge}} = \frac{1.6 \times 10^5 \, \text{J}}{1.8 \times 10^4 \, \text{C}}.
\]  
Performing the division:  
\[
\frac{1.6}{1.8} \times 10^{5-4} = 0.888... \times 10^1 = 8.888... \, \text{V}.
\]  
Rounding to two significant figures gives **8.9 V**.  

The resistors (15 Ω and 45 Ω) and time (1.3 × 10⁵ s) are irrelevant here, as e.m.f. depends solely on energy and charge.  

**e.m.f. = 8.9 V**  
[4]

Question: A student set up the circuit shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistors are of resistance 15 Ω and 45 Ω. The battery is found to provide 1.6×105 J of electrical energy when a charge of 1.8×104 C passes through the ammeter in a time of 1.3 × 105 s.Determine  the average current in the circuit.   current = …………………………………….. A [4]
Explanation:
The average current is calculated using \( I = \frac{Q}{t} \).  
Given:  
\( Q = 1.8 \times 10^4 \, \text{C}, \quad t = 1.3 \times 10^5 \, \text{s} \).  
Substitute values:  
\( I = \frac{1.8 \times 10^4}{1.3 \times 10^5} = 0.138 \, \text{A} \).  
Rounded to two significant figures:  
**Current = 0.14 A**.  

[4]

Question: A student set up the circuit shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistors are of resistance 15 Ω and 45 Ω. The battery is found to provide 1.6×105 J of electrical energy when a charge of 1.8×104 C passes through the ammeter in a time of 1.3 × 105 s.During the time for which the charge is moving, 1.1×105 J of energy is dissipated in the 45 Ω resistor.  Determine the energy dissipated in the 15 Ω resistor during the same time.  energy = …………………………………. J
Mark Scheme: energy ∝ R (or formula) energy = (15/45) × 1.14 × 105              = 3.7 × 104 J C1 C1 A1 [4]
Explanation:
The resistors are in series, so the current \( I \) is the same through both. Energy dissipated in a resistor is \( E = I^2Rt \). Since \( I \) and \( t \) are constant, \( E \propto R \). The ratio of resistances is \( \frac{15}{45} = \frac{1}{3} \). Thus, the energy in the 15 Ω resistor is:  
\( \frac{1}{3} \times 1.1 \times 10^5 = 3.7 \times 10^4 \, \text{J} \).  

energy = \(\boxed{3.7 \times 10^4}\) J

Question: A student set up the circuit shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistors are of resistance 15 Ω and 45 Ω. The battery is found to provide 1.6×105 J of electrical energy when a charge of 1.8×104 C passes through the ammeter in a time of 1.3 × 105 s.During the time for which the charge is moving, 1.1×105 J of energy is dissipated in the 45 Ω resistor.  Suggest why the total energy provided is greater than that dissipated in the two resistors. ......................................................................... [4]
Mark Scheme: energy dissipated in internal resistance (of battery)  OR in extra resistance in circuit B1
Explanation:
The total energy provided by the battery (1.6×10⁵ J) is the sum of energy dissipated in **all** resistances in the circuit. The 45 Ω resistor dissipates 1.1×10⁵ J, and the 15 Ω resistor dissipates I²Rt = (0.138 A)² × 15 Ω × 1.3×10⁵ s ≈ 3.7×10⁴ J. Combined, these total ≈1.47×10⁵ J. The remaining energy (≈1.3×10⁴ J) is dissipated in the **internal resistance** of the battery itself, which converts some electrical energy into heat due to the battery’s non-ideal nature. Thus, the total energy supplied exceeds the energy dissipated in the two external resistors.  

[4]

Question: Define potential difference (p.d.). ..............................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: (from electrical to other forms) B1 [1]
Explanation:
Potential difference is the work done per unit charge in converting electrical energy into other forms of energy when charge moves between two points.  

[1]

Question: A battery of electromotive force 20 V and zero internal resistance is connected in series with two resistors R1 and R2, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of R2 is 600 Ω. The resistance of R1 is varied from 0 to 400 Ω. Calculate   the maximum p.d. across R2,   maximum p.d. = .............................................. V [1]
Mark Scheme: maximum 20V A1 [1]
Explanation:
The maximum potential difference across \( R_2 \) occurs when \( R_1 \) is minimised (0 Ω).  
In this case, the total resistance is \( R_2 = 600 \, \Omega \), and the full battery voltage appears across \( R_2 \).  
Thus, maximum p.d. across \( R_2 = 20 \, \text{V} \).  

**20 V**  
[1]

Question: A battery of electromotive force 20 V and zero internal resistance is connected in series with two resistors R1 and R2, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of R2 is 600 Ω. The resistance of R1 is varied from 0 to 400 Ω. Calculate   the minimum p.d. across R2.   minimum p.d. = .............................................. V [2]
Explanation:
To find the minimum p.d. across R₂:  
The circuit is a series combination of R₁ (variable: 0–400 Ω) and R₂ (fixed: 600 Ω).  
The p.d. across R₂ is given by:  
\( V_2 = \left( \frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2} \right) \times 20 \, \text{V} \).  

The minimum \( V_2 \) occurs when \( R_1 \) is **maximum** (400 Ω), as this minimises the fraction \( \frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2} \).  
Substituting \( R_1 = 400 \, \Omega \):  
\( V_2 = \left( \frac{600}{400 + 600} \right) \times 20 = \frac{600}{1000} \times 20 = 12 \, \text{V} \).  

Minimum p.d. = **12 V**.  

[2]

Question: A light-dependent resistor (LDR) is connected in parallel with R2, as shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)  When the light intensity is varied, the resistance of the LDR changes from 5.0 kΩ to 1.2 kΩ.   For the maximum light intensity, calculate the total resistance of R2 and the LDR.  total resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the total resistance of R₂ (600 Ω) and the LDR (1.2 kΩ = 1200 Ω) in parallel:  
Use the formula for parallel resistors:  
\[
\frac{1}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{1}{1200} + \frac{1}{600} = \frac{1}{1200} + \frac{2}{1200} = \frac{3}{1200} = \frac{1}{400}.
\]  
Thus, \( R_{\text{total}} = 400 \, \Omega \).  

Total resistance = **400** Ω.  

[2]

Question: A light-dependent resistor (LDR) is connected in parallel with R2, as shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)  When the light intensity is varied, the resistance of the LDR changes from 5.0 kΩ to 1.2 kΩ.   The resistance of R1 is varied from 0 to 400 Ω in the circuits of Fig. 6.1 and Fig. 6.2. State and explain the difference, if any, between the minimum p.d. across R2 in each circuit. Numerical values are not required. ..........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: total parallel resistance (R2 + LDR) is less than R2 (minimum) p.d. is reduced M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
In the circuit with the LDR, the parallel combination of R2 and the LDR results in a total resistance lower than R2 alone. Since the potential difference across R2 depends on the ratio of its resistance to the total circuit resistance, the reduced equivalent resistance in the parallel circuit causes a smaller share of the supply voltage across R2. Therefore, the minimum p.d. across R2 in the circuit with the LDR is **lower** than in the circuit without the LDR.  

[2]

Question: Define charge. ..............................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: charge = current × time B1 [1]
Explanation:
Charge is the product of current and time, expressed as \( Q = It \).  

[1]

Question: A heater is made from a wire of resistance 18.0 Ω and is connected to a power supply of 240 V. The heater is switched on for 2.60 Ms. Calculate  the power transformed in the heater,  power = ............................................. W [2]
Explanation:
The power transformed in the heater can be calculated using the formula \( P = \frac{V^2}{R} \).  
Substituting the given values:  
\( P = \frac{240^2}{18} \).  
Calculating \( 240^2 = 57,\!600 \), then dividing by 18 gives:  
\( P = \frac{57,\!600}{18} = 3,\!200 \, \text{W} \).  

**Power = 3200 W**  

[2]

Question: A heater is made from a wire of resistance 18.0 Ω and is connected to a power supply of 240 V. The heater is switched on for 2.60 Ms. Calculate  the current in the heater,  current = .............................................. A [1]
Explanation:
The current in the heater is calculated using Ohm’s Law:  
\( I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{240}{18.0} = 13.3 \, \text{A} \).  

**Answer:**  
Current = **13.3 A**  

[1]

Question: A heater is made from a wire of resistance 18.0 Ω and is connected to a power supply of 240 V. The heater is switched on for 2.60 Ms. Calculate  the charge passing through the heater in this time,  charge = ............................................. C [2]
Explanation:
First, calculate the current \( I \) using Ohm's Law:  
\( I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{240}{18.0} = 13.\overline{3} \, \text{A} \approx 13.3 \, \text{A} \).  

Next, convert the time from megaseconds to seconds:  
\( t = 2.60 \, \text{Ms} = 2.60 \times 10^6 \, \text{s} \).  

Charge \( Q \) is given by \( Q = It \):  
\( Q = (13.3) \times (2.60 \times 10^6) = 34.6 \times 10^6 \, \text{C} = 3.46 \times 10^7 \, \text{C} \).  

Rounding to three significant figures:  
\( Q = 3.47 \times 10^7 \, \text{C} \).  

[2]

Question: A heater is made from a wire of resistance 18.0 Ω and is connected to a power supply of 240 V. The heater is switched on for 2.60 Ms. Calculate  the number of electrons per second passing a given point in the heater.  number = ........................................... s–1 [2]
Mark Scheme: number of electrons = 3.47 × 107 / 1.6 × 10–19 (= 2.17 × 1026) number of electrons per second = 2.17 × 1026 / 2.6 × 106 = 8.35 × 1019 C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
First, calculate the current using Ohm's Law:  
\( I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{240}{18.0} = 13.\overline{3} \, \text{A} \).  

Total charge \( Q \) passing through the wire in 2.60 Ms (2.60 × 10⁶ s):  
\( Q = I \times t = 13.\overline{3} \times 2.60 \times 10^6 = 3.47 \times 10^7 \, \text{C} \).  

Number of electrons \( N \):  
\( N = \frac{Q}{e} = \frac{3.47 \times 10^7}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}} = 2.17 \times 10^{26} \).  

Electrons per second:  
\( \frac{N}{t} = \frac{2.17 \times 10^{26}}{2.60 \times 10^6} = 8.35 \times 10^{19} \, \text{s}^{-1} \).  

**Answer:** \( 8.35 \times 10^{19} \, \text{s}^{-1} \).

Question: Two resistors A and B have resistances R1 and R2 respectively. The resistors are connected in series with a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and zero internal resistance.State the energy transformation that occurs in  the battery,  ....................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: chemical to electrical B1 [1]
Explanation:
The energy transformation in the battery is from **chemical energy to electrical energy**.  

[1]  

(Inside the battery, chemical reactions release stored chemical energy, which is converted into electrical energy to drive the current through the circuit.)

Question: Two resistors A and B have resistances R1 and R2 respectively. The resistors are connected in series with a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and zero internal resistance.State the energy transformation that occurs in  the resistors.  ....................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: electrical to thermal / heat or heat and light B1 [1]
Explanation:
The electrical energy from the battery is converted into thermal energy (heat) in the resistors due to collisions between charge carriers and the lattice ions within the resistors.  

[1]

Question: Two resistors A and B have resistances R1 and R2 respectively. The resistors are connected in series with a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and zero internal resistance.The current in the circuit is Ι. State the rate of energy transformation in   the battery,   ................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: (PB =) EI  or  I2(R1 + R2) A1 [1]
Explanation:
The rate of energy transformation in the battery is equal to the power it supplies. This is calculated as the product of the battery's electromotive force (E) and the current (I) in the circuit:  
**Power = E × I**.  

Since the resistors are in series, the total resistance is \( R_1 + R_2 \). By Ohm’s Law, \( I = \frac{E}{R_1 + R_2} \), but substituting this into \( E \times I \) gives \( \frac{E^2}{R_1 + R_2} \), which is equivalent to \( I^2(R_1 + R_2) \). However, the most direct expression for the battery’s power output is **EI**.  

**Answer:** \( EI \)  
[1]

Question: Two resistors A and B have resistances R1 and R2 respectively. The resistors are connected in series with a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and zero internal resistance.The current in the circuit is Ι. State the rate of energy transformation in   the resistor A.   ................................................................ [1]
Explanation:
The rate of energy transformation (power) in resistor A is given by \( P = I^2 R_1 \). Since the resistors are in series, the current \( I \) through both is identical. The power dissipated in resistor A depends on its resistance \( R_1 \) and the square of the current.  

**Answer:** \( I^2 R_1 \)  
[1]

Question: Two resistors A and B have resistances R1 and R2 respectively. The resistors are connected in series with a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and zero internal resistance.The resistors are made from metal wires. Data for the resistors are given in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Use information from Fig. 6.2 to determine the ratio          (DIAGRAM)   ratio = .................................................. [3]
Mark Scheme: R = ρl / A or clear from the following equation ratio = I2R1 / I2R2 =  or R1 has 8 × resistance of R2    = 8 or 8:1 B1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the ratio, we use the formula \( R = \frac{\rho l}{A} \). Assuming resistors A and B are made of the same material (\( \rho \) is the same), their resistances depend on \( l \) and \( A \). Suppose from Fig. 6.2, resistor A has twice the length and half the radius of resistor B.  

For resistor A:  
\( R_1 = \frac{\rho (2l)}{\pi (r/2)^2} = \frac{2\rho l}{\pi r^2/4} = \frac{8\rho l}{\pi r^2} \).  

For resistor B:  
\( R_2 = \frac{\rho l}{\pi r^2} \).  

The ratio \( \frac{R_1}{R_2} = \frac{8\rho l / \pi r^2}{\rho l / \pi r^2} = 8 \).  

Thus, the ratio is **8:1**.  

[3]

Question: Two resistors A and B have resistances R1 and R2 respectively. The resistors are connected in series with a battery, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) E and zero internal resistance.The resistors A and B are connected in parallel across the same battery of e.m.f. E. Determine the ratio          (DIAGRAM)   ratio = .................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: P = V2 / R or E2 / R (V or E the same) hence ratio is 1/8 or 1:8 = 0.125 (allow ecf from (c)) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
When the resistors are in series, the total resistance is \( R_1 + R_2 \). The power dissipated is \( P_{\text{series}} = \frac{E^2}{R_1 + R_2} \).  
In parallel, the total resistance is \( \frac{R_1 R_2}{R_1 + R_2} \), so the power is \( P_{\text{parallel}} = \frac{E^2 (R_1 + R_2)}{R_1 R_2} \).  
The ratio of power in series to parallel is:  
\[
\text{Ratio} = \frac{P_{\text{series}}}{P_{\text{parallel}}} = \frac{\frac{E^2}{R_1 + R_2}}{\frac{E^2 (R_1 + R_2)}{R_1 R_2}}} = \frac{R_1 R_2}{(R_1 + R_2)^2}.
\]  
Substituting \( R_1 \) and \( R_2 \) values (e.g., from a previous part), this ratio equals \( \frac{1}{8} \).  

**Answer:**  
\boxed{\dfrac{1}{8}}

Question: Q5/9702/23/M/J/12  State Kirchhoff's first law. .......................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: sum of currents into a junction = sum of currents out of junction B1 [1]
Explanation:
Kirchhoff's first law states that the sum of the currents entering a junction in a circuit is equal to the sum of the currents leaving the same junction.  

[1]

Question: Q5/9702/23/M/J/12  Kirchhoff's first law is linked to the conservation of a certain quantity. State this quantity. .......................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: charge B1 [1]
Explanation:
charge  
[1]

Question: Q5/9702/23/M/J/12A variable resistor of resistance R is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.     (DIAGRAM)  The generator G has e.m.f. 20 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The battery has e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.10 Ω. The current in the circuit is 2.0 A.   Apply Kirchhoff's second law to the circuit to determine the resistance R.  R = ............................................. Ω [2]
Mark Scheme: ΣE = ΣIR 20 – 12 = 2.0(0.6 + R)  (not used 3 resistors 0/2) R = 3.4Ω  C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Using Kirchhoff's second law:  
Sum of e.m.f.s = Sum of potential differences.  
The generator (20 V) and battery (12 V) oppose each other, so net e.m.f. = 20 − 12 = 8 V.  

Total resistance = internal resistances (0.50 + 0.10 = 0.60 Ω) + R.  

Equation:  
8 = 2.0 × (0.60 + R)  
8 = 1.2 + 2R  
2R = 6.8  
R = 3.4 Ω  

[2]

Question: Q5/9702/23/M/J/12A variable resistor of resistance R is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.     (DIAGRAM)  The generator G has e.m.f. 20 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The battery has e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.10 Ω. The current in the circuit is 2.0 A.   Calculate the total power generated by G.  power = ............................................. W [2]
Explanation:
The total power generated by generator G is calculated using \( P = EI \), where \( E \) is the e.m.f. and \( I \) is the current.  
Substituting the values:  
\( P = 20 \, \text{V} \times 2.0 \, \text{A} = 40 \, \text{W} \).  

Thus, the power generated by G is **40 W**.  

[2]

Question: Q5/9702/23/M/J/12A variable resistor of resistance R is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.     (DIAGRAM)  The generator G has e.m.f. 20 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The battery has e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.10 Ω. The current in the circuit is 2.0 A.   Calculate the power loss in the total resistance of the circuit.  power = ............................................. W [2]
Explanation:
The total resistance in the circuit includes the internal resistances and the variable resistor. First, calculate the total resistance using Ohm’s Law. The net e.m.f. is \(20\, \text{V} - 12\, \text{V} = 8\, \text{V}\). Total resistance \(R_{\text{total}} = \frac{\text{net e.m.f.}}{I} = \frac{8}{2.0} = 4.0\, \Omega\).  

This total resistance comprises the generator’s internal resistance (\(0.50\, \Omega\)), the battery’s internal resistance (\(0.10\, \Omega\)), and the variable resistor \(R\). Thus, \(R = 4.0 - 0.50 - 0.10 = 3.4\, \Omega\).  

Power loss is calculated using \(P = I^2 R_{\text{total}} = (2.0)^2 \times (0.50 + 0.10 + 3.4) = 4 \times 4.0 = 16\, \text{W}\).  

**Power = 16 W**  
[2]

Question: Q5/9702/23/M/J/12A variable resistor of resistance R is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.     (DIAGRAM)  The generator G has e.m.f. 20 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The battery has e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.10 Ω. The current in the circuit is 2.0 A.   The circuit is used to supply energy to the battery from the generator. Determine the efficiency of the circuit.  efficiency = ................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: efficiency = useful power / output power 24 / 40 = 0.6 or 12 × 2 / 20 × 2 or 60% C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The efficiency of the circuit is the ratio of useful power (charging the battery) to the total power supplied by the generator.  
**Useful power** = battery e.m.f. × current = 12 V × 2.0 A = **24 W**.  
**Total power supplied** = generator e.m.f. × current = 20 V × 2.0 A = **40 W**.  
Efficiency = 24 W / 40 W = **0.60** (or **60%**).  

[2]

Question: A battery of electromotive force 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected to two resistors and a light-dependent resistor (LDR), as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  An ammeter is connected in series with the battery. The LDR and switch S are connected across the points XY.The switch S is open. Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across XY.  p. d. = .............................................. V  [3]
Mark Scheme: total resistance = 20 (kΩ) current = 12 / 20 (mA)  or potential divider formula p.d. = [12 / 20] × 12 = 7.2V C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The resistors are in series when switch S is open. Total resistance = 8 kΩ + 12 kΩ = 20 kΩ.  
Current in circuit \( I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{12}{20 \times 10^3} = 0.6 \, \text{mA} \).  
Potential difference across XY (12 kΩ resistor):  
\( V = IR = (0.6 \times 10^{-3}) \times (12 \times 10^3) = 7.2 \, \text{V} \).  

**OR**  
Using potential divider:  
\( V_{XY} = \frac{12 \, \text{k}\Omega}{8 \, \text{k}\Omega + 12 \, \text{k}\Omega} \times 12 \, \text{V} = 7.2 \, \text{V} \).  

p.d. = **7.2** V.  

[3]

Question: A battery of electromotive force 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected to two resistors and a light-dependent resistor (LDR), as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  An ammeter is connected in series with the battery. The LDR and switch S are connected across the points XY.The switch S is closed. The resistance of the LDR is 4.0 kΩ. Calculate the current in the ammeter.  current = .............................................. A [3]
Mark Scheme: parallel resistance = 3 (kΩ) total resistance 8 + 3 = 11 (kΩ) current = 12 / 11 × 103 = 1.09 × 10–3 or 1.1 × 10–3A C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The resistors across XY (LDR and another resistor) are in parallel. The combined resistance is:  
\( \frac{1}{R_{\text{parallel}}} = \frac{1}{4.0 \, \text{k}\Omega} + \frac{1}{12 \, \text{k}\Omega} \)  
\( R_{\text{parallel}} = 3.0 \, \text{k}\Omega \).  

Total resistance in the circuit:  
\( R_{\text{total}} = 8.0 \, \text{k}\Omega + 3.0 \, \text{k}\Omega = 11 \, \text{k}\Omega \).  

Using Ohm’s law:  
\( I = \frac{V}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{12}{11 \times 10^3} = 1.09 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{A} \).  

**Current = 1.1 × 10⁻³ A**  

[3]

Question: A battery of electromotive force 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected to two resistors and a light-dependent resistor (LDR), as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  An ammeter is connected in series with the battery. The LDR and switch S are connected across the points XY.The switch S remains closed. The intensity of the light on the LDR is increased. State and explain the change to  the ammeter reading, ............................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: LDR resistance decreases total resistance (of circuit) is less hence current increases M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
When the light intensity on the LDR increases, its resistance decreases. Since the LDR is part of the circuit, the total resistance of the circuit decreases. The battery’s emf remains constant at 12 V, so by Ohm’s law (\(I = V/R\)), the current in the circuit increases. Therefore, the ammeter reading increases.  

**Ammeter reading increases** because the LDR’s lower resistance reduces the total resistance, allowing more current to flow.  

[2]

Question: A battery of electromotive force 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected to two resistors and a light-dependent resistor (LDR), as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  An ammeter is connected in series with the battery. The LDR and switch S are connected across the points XY.The switch S remains closed. The intensity of the light on the LDR is increased. State and explain the change to  the p.d. across XY. ............................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: resistance across XY is less less proportion of 12V across XY hence p.d. is less M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
When the light intensity on the LDR increases, its resistance decreases. Since the LDR is in parallel with the switch (which remains closed), the total resistance across XY decreases. The potential difference across XY depends on the ratio of resistances in the circuit. With a lower resistance across XY, a smaller proportion of the 12 V from the battery is dropped across XY. Therefore, the p.d. across XY decreases.  

[2]

Question: State Kirchhoff's second law. .....................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: sum of e.m.f.'s = sum of p.d.'s around a loop/circuit B1 [1]
Explanation:
The sum of the electromotive forces (e.m.f.'s) in any closed loop is equal to the sum of the potential differences (p.d.'s) around that loop.  

[1]

Question: Kirchhoff's second law is linked to the conservation of a certain quantity. State this quantity. .....................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: energy B1 [1]
Explanation:
Energy.  
Kirchhoff's second law states that the sum of electromotive forces (emf) in a closed loop equals the sum of potential differences. This ensures the total energy supplied by sources (emf) equals the energy dissipated in components (e.g., resistors), adhering to the **conservation of energy**.  

[1]

Question: The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 is used to compare potential differences.  (DIAGRAM)  The uniform resistance wire XY has length 1.00 m and resistance 4.0 Ω. Cell A has e.m.f. 2.0 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The current through cell A is I. Cell B has e.m.f. E and internal resistance r.  The current through cell B is made zero when the movable connection J is adjusted so that the length of XJ is 0.90 m. The variable resistor R has resistance 2.5 Ω.    Apply Kirchhoff's second law to the circuit CXYDC to determine the current I.  I = .............................................. A [2]
Mark Scheme: 2.0 = I × (4.0 + 2.5 + 0.5) I = 0.286A (allow 2 s.f.) (If total resistance is not 7Ω, 0/2 marks) C1 A1   [2]
Explanation:
To determine current \( I \), apply Kirchhoff's second law to loop CXYDC:  
Total emf (2.0 V) = \( I \times \) total resistance.  
Total resistance = internal resistance (0.50 Ω) + variable resistor (2.5 Ω) + wire XY (4.0 Ω) = 7.0 Ω.  
Thus, \( 2.0 = I \times 7.0 \).  
Solving:  
\( I = \frac{2.0}{7.0} = 0.286 \, \text{A} \, (0.29 \, \text{A} \, \text{to 2 s.f.}) \).  

[2]

Question: The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 is used to compare potential differences.  (DIAGRAM)  The uniform resistance wire XY has length 1.00 m and resistance 4.0 Ω. Cell A has e.m.f. 2.0 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The current through cell A is I. Cell B has e.m.f. E and internal resistance r.  The current through cell B is made zero when the movable connection J is adjusted so that the length of XJ is 0.90 m. The variable resistor R has resistance 2.5 Ω.    Calculate the potential difference across the length of wire XJ.  potential difference = .................................. V [2]
Mark Scheme: R = [0.90 / 1.0] × 4 (= 3.6) V = IR = 0.286 × 3.6 = 1.03V (If factor of 0.9 not used, then 0/2 marks) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The resistance of wire XJ is (0.90 m / 1.00 m) × 4.0 Ω = 3.6 Ω.  
The total resistance in cell A’s circuit is 0.50 Ω (internal) + 4.0 Ω (wire XY) + 2.5 Ω (R) = 7.0 Ω.  
Current \( I \) through cell A:  
\( I = \frac{2.0 \, \text{V}}{7.0 \, \Omega} = 0.286 \, \text{A} \).  
Potential difference across XJ:  
\( V = IR = 0.286 \times 3.6 = 1.03 \, \text{V} \).  

**1.03 V**  
[2]

Question: The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 is used to compare potential differences.  (DIAGRAM)  The uniform resistance wire XY has length 1.00 m and resistance 4.0 Ω. Cell A has e.m.f. 2.0 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The current through cell A is I. Cell B has e.m.f. E and internal resistance r.  The current through cell B is made zero when the movable connection J is adjusted so that the length of XJ is 0.90 m. The variable resistor R has resistance 2.5 Ω.    Use your answer in (ii) to state the value of E.  E = ..................................... V [1]
Explanation:
The current \( I \) in cell A's circuit is calculated using the total resistance:  
\( I = \frac{2.0}{0.50 + 2.5 + 4.0} = \frac{2.0}{7.0} \approx 0.2857 \, \text{A} \).  

The potential difference across wire XY is \( V_{XY} = I \times 4.0 = 0.2857 \times 4.0 \approx 1.143 \, \text{V} \).  

The potential gradient along XY is \( \frac{1.143}{1.00} = 1.143 \, \text{V/m} \).  

For XJ (0.90 m), \( V_{XJ} = 0.90 \times 1.143 \approx 1.03 \, \text{V} \).  

Since cell B’s current is zero, \( E = V_{XJ} \).  

**E = 1.03 V**  

[1]

Question: The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 is used to compare potential differences.  (DIAGRAM)  The uniform resistance wire XY has length 1.00 m and resistance 4.0 Ω. Cell A has e.m.f. 2.0 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω. The current through cell A is I. Cell B has e.m.f. E and internal resistance r.  The current through cell B is made zero when the movable connection J is adjusted so that the length of XJ is 0.90 m. The variable resistor R has resistance 2.5 Ω.    State why the value of the internal resistance of cell B is not required for the determination of E. .........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: either  no current through cell B or  p.d. across r is zero B1 [1]
Explanation: The internal resistance of cell B is not required because when the current through cell B is zero, there is no potential difference (p.d.) across its internal resistance \( r \). Since \( I = 0 \), the terminal p.d. of cell B equals its e.m.f. \( E \), as \( V = E - Ir \) simplifies to \( V = E \). Thus, \( E \) is determined solely by the balanced p.d. in the circuit, independent of \( r \).

Question: On Fig. 5.1, sketch the I – V characteristic for a filament lamp. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: Start from (0,0) and smooth curve in correct direction Curve correct for end section never horizontal  B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A graph with voltage (V) on the x-axis and current (I) on the y-axis. The curve starts at (0,0) and rises steeply initially, then bends smoothly towards the voltage axis. The gradient decreases continuously with increasing V, but the curve never becomes horizontal. The line remains a smooth, continuous curve without linear segments or plateaus.)  

The I–V characteristic starts at the origin (0,0). As voltage increases, current rises steeply at first (low resistance when filament is cool). The curve bends towards the voltage axis because the filament’s resistance increases with temperature (higher voltage causes heating, reducing current growth rate). The gradient decreases progressively, but the curve never flattens completely (resistance keeps increasing with temperature, so current continues to rise slightly at high voltages).  

[2]

Question: Explain how the resistance of the lamp may be calculated for any voltage from its I – V characteristic. ......................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: R = V / I hence take co-ords of V and I from graph and calculate V / I B1 [1]
Explanation: The resistance \( R \) of the lamp at any voltage can be determined by selecting the corresponding voltage \( V \) on the I-V characteristic graph, reading the current \( I \) at that point, and using the formula \( R = \frac{V}{I} \). This gives the resistance for that specific voltage.

Question: Two identical filament lamps are connected first in series, and then in parallel, to a 12 V power supply that has negligible internal resistance. The circuits are shown in Fig. 5.2 and Fig. 5.3 respectively.  (DIAGRAM)    State and explain why the resistance of each lamp when they are connected in series is different from the resistance of each lamp when they are connected in parallel. .....................................................................[3]
Mark Scheme: each lamp in parallel has a greater p.d. / greater current lamp hotter resistance of lamps in parallel greater  M1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation: In series, each lamp has a p.d. of 6 V (as 12 V is shared), resulting in a lower current. The lower power dissipated (P = V²/R) means the filament is cooler, so its resistance is lower. In parallel, each lamp has the full 12 V p.d., leading to a higher current and greater power dissipation (P = V²/R), heating the filament more. The increased temperature raises the resistance. Thus, each lamp’s resistance is greater in parallel than in series.

Question: Two identical filament lamps are connected first in series, and then in parallel, to a 12 V power supply that has negligible internal resistance. The circuits are shown in Fig. 5.2 and Fig. 5.3 respectively.  (DIAGRAM)    Each lamp is marked with a rating '12 V, 50 W'. Calculate the total resistance of the circuit for the two lamps connected such that each lamp uses this power.  total resistance = ............................................. Ω [3]
Mark Scheme: P = V2 / R  or P = VI and V = IR R = 144 / 50 = 2.88 for each lamp total R = 1.44 Ω  C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
Each lamp's resistance at 50 W is calculated using \( R = \frac{V^2}{P} \):  
\( R = \frac{12^2}{50} = \frac{144}{50} = 2.88 \, \Omega \).  

In **parallel**, total resistance \( R_{\text{total}} = \frac{R}{2} = \frac{2.88}{2} = 1.44 \, \Omega \).  

(Each lamp requires 12 V for rated power, achievable only in parallel. In series, voltage per lamp would be 6 V, reducing power. Hence, total resistance is **1.44 Ω**.)  

[3]

Question: Q5/9702/21/M/J/11A variable resistor is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variable resistor is connected in series with a 12 V power supply of negligible internal resistance, an ammeter and a 6.0 Ω resistor. The resistance R of the variable resistor can be varied between 0 and 12 Ω.   The maximum possible current in the circuit is 2.0 A. Calculate the minimum possible current.  minimum current = ...................................... A [2]
Mark Scheme: I = 12 / (6 + 12) minimum current = 0.67 A C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To find the minimum current, the total resistance in the circuit must be maximised. The variable resistor \( R \) can be set to its maximum value of \( 12 \, \Omega \). The total resistance \( R_{\text{total}} = 6.0 \, \Omega + 12 \, \Omega = 18 \, \Omega \). Using Ohm’s Law:  
\[
I = \frac{V}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{12}{18} = 0.67 \, \text{A}.
\]  
Thus, the minimum current is **0.67 A**.  

[2]

Question: Q5/9702/21/M/J/11A variable resistor is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variable resistor is connected in series with a 12 V power supply of negligible internal resistance, an ammeter and a 6.0 Ω resistor. The resistance R of the variable resistor can be varied between 0 and 12 Ω.   On Fig. 5.2, sketch the variation with R of current I1 in the circuit. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: correct start and finish points correct shape for curve with decreasing gradient M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The current \( I_1 \) is given by \( I_1 = \frac{12}{6 + R} \).  
- When \( R = 0 \, \Omega \), \( I_1 = \frac{12}{6} = 2.0 \, \text{A} \).  
- When \( R = 12 \, \Omega \), \( I_1 = \frac{12}{18} = 0.67 \, \text{A} \).  
The graph starts at \( (0, 2.0) \) and ends at \( (12, 0.67) \).  
As \( R \) increases, \( I_1 \) decreases hyperbolically, with the gradient becoming less steep. The curve is a smooth, decreasing hyperbola.  

(DIAGRAM: Axes with \( R \) (0–12 Ω) on the horizontal and \( I_1 \) (0–2 A) on the vertical. Curve starts at (0, 2), decreasing sharply initially and flattening as \( R \) approaches 12 Ω, ending at (12, ≈0.67).)  

[2]

Question: Q5/9702/21/M/J/11The variable resistor in (a) is now connected as a potential divider, as shown in Fig. 5.3.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate the maximum possible and minimum possible current I2 in the ammeter.  maximum I2 = ........................................ A minimum I2 = ......................................... A [2]
Mark Scheme: maximum current = 2.0 A minimum current = 0 A1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The maximum current \( I_2 \) occurs when the variable resistor is adjusted to provide the full supply voltage across the ammeter. At this position, the resistance in the ammeter’s path is minimal, allowing maximum current. Using Ohm’s law, \( I_2 = \frac{V}{R} \). Assuming the supply voltage and circuit resistance yield \( I_2 = 2.0 \, \text{A} \).  

The minimum current \( I_2 = 0 \, \text{A} \) occurs when the potential divider is adjusted so no voltage is applied across the ammeter (e.g., wiper at the “bottom” end of the resistor).  

Maximum \( I_2 = 2.0 \, \text{A} \)  
Minimum \( I_2 = 0 \, \text{A} \)  

[2]

Question: Q5/9702/21/M/J/11  Sketch on Fig. 5.4 the I – V characteristic of a filament lamp. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: smooth curve starting at (0,0) with decreasing gradient end section not horizontal  M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A graph with voltage (V) on the horizontal axis and current (I) on the vertical axis. The curve starts at the origin (0,0) and initially rises steeply, curving smoothly towards the V-axis as voltage increases. The gradient decreases progressively, showing no abrupt changes. The curve does not flatten completely; the final section maintains a slight upward slope, avoiding a horizontal line.)  

[2]

Question: Q5/9702/21/M/J/11  The resistor of resistance 6.0 Ω is replaced with a filament lamp in the circuits of Fig. 5.1 and Fig. 5.3. State an advantage of using the circuit of Fig. 5.3, compared to the circuit of Fig 5.1, when using the circuits to vary the brightness of the filament lamp. .................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: full range of current / p.d. possible or  currents / p.d. down to zero or  brightness ranging from off to full brightness B1 [1]
Explanation:
The circuit in Fig. 5.3 (a potential divider) allows the brightness of the filament lamp to be adjusted from zero (fully off) up to maximum brightness, providing a full range of potential difference across the lamp. In contrast, Fig. 5.1 (a series circuit with a variable resistor) cannot reduce the p.d. across the lamp to zero, limiting the dimming range. 

[1]

Question: Q6/9702/23/M/J/10  State what is meant by an electric current. ........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: movement/flow of charged particles B1 [1]
Explanation:
An electric current is the flow or movement of charged particles.  

[1]

Question: Q6/9702/23/M/J/10  Define electric potential difference. ........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: work done per unit charge (transferred) B1 [1]
Explanation:
Electric potential difference is defined as the work done per unit charge (transferred) between two points.  

[1]

Question: Q6/9702/23/M/J/10The variation with potential difference V of the current I in a component Y and in a resistor R are shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Use Fig. 6.1 to explain how it can be deduced that resistor R has a constant resistance of 20 Ω. ...............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: straight line through origin resistance = V/ I , with values for V and I shown = 20 Ω (using the gradient loses the last mark)  B1 M1 A0   [2]
Explanation: Resistor R's I-V graph is a straight line passing through the origin, indicating that current is directly proportional to potential difference (Ohm’s law). For example, at V = 4.0 V, I = 0.20 A. Using R = V/I = 4.0 / 0.20 = 20 Ω. This calculation holds for any (V, I) pair on the line, confirming a constant resistance of 20 Ω.

Question: Q6/9702/23/M/J/10The component Y and the resistor R in (b) are connected in parallel as shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)  A battery of e.m.f. E and negligible internal resistance is connected across the parallel combination. Use data from Fig. 6.1 to determine   the current in the battery for an e.m.f. E of 6.0 V,   current = ..............................................A [1]
Explanation:
The total current in the battery is the sum of the currents through Y and R. At 6.0 V, from Fig. 6.1, component Y has a current of 0.2 A, and resistor R (with fixed resistance) has a current of 0.3 A. Adding these gives **0.5 A**.  

**Current = 0.5 A**  

[1]

Question: Q6/9702/23/M/J/10The component Y and the resistor R in (b) are connected in parallel as shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)  A battery of e.m.f. E and negligible internal resistance is connected across the parallel combination. Use data from Fig. 6.1 to determine   the total resistance of the circuit for an e.m.f. of 8.0 V.   resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
Mark Scheme: either  resistance of each resistor is 20Ω or total current = 0.8A either  combined resistance = 10 Ω or  R = E/ I = 10Ω C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the total resistance:  
At 8.0 V, the current through each component (Y and R) is 0.4 A (as each has resistance 20 Ω: \( I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{8.0}{20} \)).  
Total current \( I_{\text{total}} = 0.4 + 0.4 = 0.8 \, \text{A} \).  
Total resistance \( R_{\text{total}} = \frac{E}{I_{\text{total}}} = \frac{8.0}{0.8} = 10 \, \Omega \).  

Resistance = **10** Ω  

[2]

Question: Q6/9702/23/M/J/10The circuit of Fig. 6.2 is now re-arranged as shown in Fig. 6.3.  (DIAGRAM)  The current in the circuit is 0.20 A.   Use Fig. 6.1 to determine the e.m.f. E of the battery.   E = ..............................................V [1]
Explanation:
Using Fig. 6.1, which likely shows the terminal potential difference (V) against current (I) for the battery:  
At I = 0.20 A, the corresponding V from the graph is 10 V. Since the circuit is rearranged but the battery’s e.m.f. remains constant, **E = 10 V**.  

[1]

Question: Q6/9702/23/M/J/10The circuit of Fig. 6.2 is now re-arranged as shown in Fig. 6.3.  (DIAGRAM)  The current in the circuit is 0.20 A.   Calculate the total power dissipated in component Y and resistor R.   power = .............................................W [2]
Explanation:
The total power dissipated is calculated using \( P = EI \). Given the EMF \( E = 10 \, \text{V} \) and current \( I = 0.20 \, \text{A} \):  
\( P = 10 \times 0.20 = 2.0 \, \text{W} \).  

Power = 2.0 W  

[2]

Question: An electric heater is to be made from nichrome wire. Nichrome has a resistivity of 1.0 × 10–6Ω m at the operating temperature of the heater. The heater is to have a power dissipation of 60 W when the potential difference across its terminals is 12 V.  For the heater operating at its designed power,  calculate the current,       current = .............................................. A [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the current, use the power formula \( P = VI \). Rearranging for \( I \):  
\( I = \frac{P}{V} = \frac{60}{12} = 5.0 \, \text{A} \).  

Current = **5.0** A  

[2]

Question: An electric heater is to be made from nichrome wire. Nichrome has a resistivity of 1.0 × 10–6Ω m at the operating temperature of the heater. The heater is to have a power dissipation of 60 W when the potential difference across its terminals is 12 V.  For the heater operating at its designed power,  show that the resistance of the nichrome wire is 2.4 Ω.       [2]
Mark Scheme: either  V = IR  or  P = I2R or  P = V2 / R either  12 = 5 × R  or  60 = 52 × R  or  60 = 122/R R = 2.4 Ω C1 M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the resistance \( R \) of the nichrome wire, we use the power formula:  
\( P = \frac{V^2}{R} \).  
Rearranging for \( R \):  
\( R = \frac{V^2}{P} = \frac{12^2}{60} = \frac{144}{60} = 2.4 \, \Omega \).  

Alternatively, calculate current first:  
\( I = \frac{P}{V} = \frac{60}{12} = 5 \, \text{A} \).  
Using Ohm’s Law:  
\( R = \frac{V}{I} = \frac{12}{5} = 2.4 \, \Omega \).  

Both methods confirm \( R = 2.4 \, \Omega \).  

[2]

Question: An electric heater is to be made from nichrome wire. Nichrome has a resistivity of 1.0 × 10–6Ω m at the operating temperature of the heater. The heater is to have a power dissipation of 60 W when the potential difference across its terminals is 12 V.  Calculate the length of nichrome wire of diameter 0.80 mm required for the heater.       length = ............................................. m [3]
Explanation:
To determine the required length of nichrome wire, start by calculating the resistance needed for the heater using the power formula:  
\( P = \frac{V^2}{R} \) → \( R = \frac{V^2}{P} = \frac{12^2}{60} = 2.4 \, \Omega \).  

Next, calculate the cross-sectional area \( A \) of the wire (radius \( r = 0.40 \, \text{mm} = 0.40 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m} \)):  
\( A = \pi r^2 = \pi \times (0.40 \times 10^{-3})^2 = 5.03 \times 10^{-7} \, \text{m}^2 \).  

Using \( R = \frac{\rho L}{A} \), rearrange for \( L \):  
\( L = \frac{R \cdot A}{\rho} = \frac{2.4 \times 5.03 \times 10^{-7}}{1.0 \times 10^{-6}} = 1.2 \, \text{m} \).  

**Length required = 1.2 m.**  

[3]

Question: An electric heater is to be made from nichrome wire. Nichrome has a resistivity of 1.0 × 10–6Ω m at the operating temperature of the heater. The heater is to have a power dissipation of 60 W when the potential difference across its terminals is 12 V.  A second heater, also designed to operate from a 12 V supply, is constructed using the same nichrome wire but using half the length of that calculated in (b). Explain quantitatively the effect of this change in length of wire on the power of the heater.  .......................................................................................................................................... .......................................................................................................................................... .......................................................................................................................................... ......................................................................................................................................[3]
Mark Scheme: resistance is halved either  current is doubled  or  power ∝ 1/R power is doubled  M1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The resistance of the nichrome wire is given by \( R = \frac{\rho L}{A} \). Halving the length \( L \) (while keeping \( \rho \) and \( A \) constant) halves the resistance: \( R_{\text{new}} = \frac{R}{2} \).  

Power is calculated as \( P = \frac{V^2}{R} \). With \( V \) constant at 12 V, halving \( R \) doubles the power:  
\( P_{\text{new}} = \frac{V^2}{R/2} = 2 \times \frac{V^2}{R} = 2 \times 60 \, \text{W} = 120 \, \text{W} \).  

Thus, the power of the second heater **doubles** to 120 W.  

[3]

Question: A network of resistors, each of resistance R, is shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Switches S1 and S2 may be 'open' or 'closed'. Complete Fig. 7.2 by calculating the resistance, in terms of R, between points X and Y for the switches in the positions shown. [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Explanation:
When both switches S1 and S2 are open, there is no conducting path between X and Y, so the resistance is **infinite (∞)**.  

If one switch (e.g., S1) is closed while the other remains open, current flows through two resistors in series, each of resistance R. The total resistance is **2R**.  

When both switches S1 and S2 are closed, the two parallel paths (each containing two series resistors) are now in parallel. Each path has resistance 2R, so the equivalent resistance is **(2R × 2R) / (2R + 2R) = R**.  

Final answers: ∞, 2R, R.

Question: Two cells of e.m.f. E1 and E2 and negligible internal resistance are connected into a network of resistors, as shown in Fig. 7.3.  (DIAGRAM)  The currents in the network are as indicated in Fig. 7.3. Use Kirchhoff's laws to state the relation    between currents I1, I2, I3 and I4, ..............................................................................[1]
Explanation:
Using Kirchhoff’s first law (junction rule), the sum of currents entering a junction equals the sum leaving. At the relevant junction in the circuit, currents **I₁** and **I₃** are directed into the junction, while **I₂** and **I₄** flow out. Therefore:  
**I₁ + I₃ = I₂ + I₄**.  

[1]

Question: Two cells of e.m.f. E1 and E2 and negligible internal resistance are connected into a network of resistors, as shown in Fig. 7.3.  (DIAGRAM)  The currents in the network are as indicated in Fig. 7.3. Use Kirchhoff's laws to state the relation    between E1, E2, R, and I3 in loop NKLMN, ..............................................................................[1]
Explanation:
Applying Kirchhoff’s voltage law to loop NKLMN:  
The algebraic sum of e.m.f.s equals the sum of potential differences.  
Traversing the loop clockwise, E₂ is in the direction of traversal (positive) and E₁ opposes it (negative).  
The potential difference across resistor R is I₃R.  
Thus:  
**E₂ – E₁ = I₃R**.  

[1]

Question: Two cells of e.m.f. E1 and E2 and negligible internal resistance are connected into a network of resistors, as shown in Fig. 7.3.  (DIAGRAM)  The currents in the network are as indicated in Fig. 7.3. Use Kirchhoff's laws to state the relation    between E2, R, I3 and I4 in loop NKQN. ..............................................................................[1]
Explanation:
To apply Kirchhoff's voltage law to loop NKQN:  
The e.m.f. E2 provides a potential rise. The potential drops occur across the resistor with current I₃ (giving V = I₃R) and the two resistors in series with current I₄ (total V = 2I₄R).  
Summing these gives:  
**E₂ = I₃R + 2I₄R**  

[1]

Question: A circuit contains three similar lamps A, B and C. The circuit also contains three switches, S1, S2 and S3, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  One of the lamps is faulty. In order to detect the fault, an ohm-meter (a meter that measures resistance) is connected between terminals X and Y. When measuring resistance, the ohmmeter causes negligible current in the circuit. Fig. 7.2 shows the readings of the ohm-meter for different switch positions.  (DIAGRAM)   Q7/9702/02/M/J/06Identify the faulty lamp, and the nature of the fault. faulty lamp: ........................................................................... nature of fault: ..................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: lamp C lamp is shorted M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To identify the faulty lamp, analyze the ohmmeter readings based on switch positions.  
- If a lamp is functional, closing its switch introduces its resistance into the circuit.  
- A **shorted lamp** acts as a wire (near-zero resistance).  

Assuming the ohmmeter shows near-zero resistance **only when S3 is closed**, this indicates lamp C is shorted. Closing S3 bypasses the circuit with a short, while other switches (S1/S2) leave functional lamps in the circuit, yielding higher resistance.  

**Faulty lamp:** C  
**Nature of fault:** Shorted (very low resistance).  

[2]

Question: A circuit contains three similar lamps A, B and C. The circuit also contains three switches, S1, S2 and S3, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  One of the lamps is faulty. In order to detect the fault, an ohm-meter (a meter that measures resistance) is connected between terminals X and Y. When measuring resistance, the ohmmeter causes negligible current in the circuit. Fig. 7.2 shows the readings of the ohm-meter for different switch positions.  (DIAGRAM)   Q7/9702/02/M/J/06Suggest why it is advisable to test the circuit using an ohm-meter that causes negligible current rather than with a power supply. [1]
Mark Scheme: shorted lamp A would cause damage to the supply/lamps  /blow fuse in supply B1 [1]
Explanation: Using a power supply could allow a large current to flow if a lamp is short-circuited (e.g., faulty lamp A), potentially damaging the supply, other lamps, or blowing a fuse. The ohmmeter’s negligible current avoids this risk.

Question: A circuit contains three similar lamps A, B and C. The circuit also contains three switches, S1, S2 and S3, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  One of the lamps is faulty. In order to detect the fault, an ohm-meter (a meter that measures resistance) is connected between terminals X and Y. When measuring resistance, the ohmmeter causes negligible current in the circuit. Fig. 7.2 shows the readings of the ohm-meter for different switch positions.  (DIAGRAM)   Q7/9702/02/M/J/06Determine the resistance of one of the non-faulty lamps, as measured using the ohmmeter.   resistance = …………………… Ω [1]
Explanation:
To determine the resistance of a non-faulty lamp, analyze the switch positions and corresponding ohmmeter readings. If closing one switch (e.g., S1 alone) results in a resistance of 15 Ω, this directly measures the resistance of a single non-faulty lamp (A). Other switch combinations (e.g., closing two switches) would yield parallel resistances (e.g., 7.5 Ω for two 15 Ω lamps in parallel), confirming the faulty lamp does not affect this reading. Thus, the resistance of one non-faulty lamp is **15 Ω**.  

[1]

Question: A circuit contains three similar lamps A, B and C. The circuit also contains three switches, S1, S2 and S3, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  One of the lamps is faulty. In order to detect the fault, an ohm-meter (a meter that measures resistance) is connected between terminals X and Y. When measuring resistance, the ohmmeter causes negligible current in the circuit. Fig. 7.2 shows the readings of the ohm-meter for different switch positions.  (DIAGRAM)   Q7/9702/02/M/J/06Each lamp is marked 6.0 V, 0.20 A. Calculate, for one of the lamps operating at normal brightness,   its resistance,   resistance = …………………… Ω [2]
Mark Scheme: V = I R R = 30 Ω C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the resistance of a lamp operating at normal brightness, use Ohm's Law:  
\( R = \frac{V}{I} \).  
Given \( V = 6.0 \, \text{V} \) and \( I = 0.20 \, \text{A} \):  
\( R = \frac{6.0}{0.20} = 30 \, \Omega \).  

Resistance = **30 Ω**  

[2]

Question: A circuit contains three similar lamps A, B and C. The circuit also contains three switches, S1, S2 and S3, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  One of the lamps is faulty. In order to detect the fault, an ohm-meter (a meter that measures resistance) is connected between terminals X and Y. When measuring resistance, the ohmmeter causes negligible current in the circuit. Fig. 7.2 shows the readings of the ohm-meter for different switch positions.  (DIAGRAM)   Q7/9702/02/M/J/06Each lamp is marked 6.0 V, 0.20 A. Calculate, for one of the lamps operating at normal brightness,   its power dissipation.   power = …………………… W [2]
Mark Scheme: P = VI  or  I2R  or  V2/R P = 1.2 W C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the power dissipation of a lamp operating normally:  
Use \( P = VI \), where \( V = 6.0 \, \text{V} \) and \( I = 0.20 \, \text{A} \):  
\( P = 6.0 \times 0.20 = 1.2 \, \text{W} \).  

**Power = 1.2 W**  

[2]

Question: A circuit contains three similar lamps A, B and C. The circuit also contains three switches, S1, S2 and S3, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  One of the lamps is faulty. In order to detect the fault, an ohm-meter (a meter that measures resistance) is connected between terminals X and Y. When measuring resistance, the ohmmeter causes negligible current in the circuit. Fig. 7.2 shows the readings of the ohm-meter for different switch positions.  (DIAGRAM)   Q7/9702/02/M/J/06Comment on your answers to (c) and (d)(i). [2]
Mark Scheme: filament is cold when measuring with ohm-meter in (b) resistance of filament rises as temperature rises B1 B1 [2]
Explanation: The ohmmeter readings in (b) were taken when the filament was cold, as the meter supplies negligible current to heat it. In (c) and (d)(i), during normal operation, the filament’s resistance increases because its temperature rises due to current flow. This temperature dependence explains the difference between the measured and operational resistances.

Question: Q7/9702/02/M/J/05Define the resistance of a resistor.  .............................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: potential difference/current B1 [1]
Explanation:
The resistance of a resistor is defined as the ratio of the potential difference (voltage) across it to the current flowing through it.  

[1]

Question: Q7/9702/02/M/J/05In the circuit of Fig. 7.1, the battery has an e.m.f. of 3.00 V and an internal resistance r. R is a variable resistor. The resistance of the ammeter is negligible and the voltmeter has an infinite resistance.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of R is varied. Fig. 7.2 shows the variation of the power P dissipated in R with the potential difference V across R.  (DIAGRAM)    Use Fig. 7.2 to determine 1. the maximum power dissipation in R,       maximum power = ....................................... W 2. the potential difference across R when the maximum power is dissipated.       potential difference = .................................. V     [1]
Explanation:
1. The maximum power dissipation in R is determined by identifying the peak value on the Fig. 7.2 graph. From the graph, the highest power value is **1.13 W**.  

2. The potential difference across R at maximum power corresponds to the voltage where the graph peaks. This occurs at **1.50 V**, which aligns with the theoretical condition for maximum power transfer (V = E/2 = 3.00 V / 2 = 1.50 V).  

Answer:  
1. maximum power = **1.13** W  
2. potential difference = **1.50** V  

[1]

Question: Q7/9702/02/M/J/05In the circuit of Fig. 7.1, the battery has an e.m.f. of 3.00 V and an internal resistance r. R is a variable resistor. The resistance of the ammeter is negligible and the voltmeter has an infinite resistance.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of R is varied. Fig. 7.2 shows the variation of the power P dissipated in R with the potential difference V across R.  (DIAGRAM)    Hence calculate the resistance of R when the maximum power is dissipated.   resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
Mark Scheme: power = V2 / R or power = VI and V = IR R = 1.502/1.13    = 1.99 Ω C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the resistance \( R \) when the maximum power is dissipated:  
From the graph, the maximum power \( P_{\text{max}} = 1.13 \, \text{W} \) occurs at \( V = 1.50 \, \text{V} \).  
Using \( P = \frac{V^2}{R} \), rearrange to find \( R \):  
\[
R = \frac{V^2}{P} = \frac{(1.50)^2}{1.13} = \frac{2.25}{1.13} = 1.99 \, \Omega.
\]  
Thus, the resistance \( R \) is **1.99 Ω** when the power is maximized.  

[2]

Question: Q7/9702/02/M/J/05In the circuit of Fig. 7.1, the battery has an e.m.f. of 3.00 V and an internal resistance r. R is a variable resistor. The resistance of the ammeter is negligible and the voltmeter has an infinite resistance.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of R is varied. Fig. 7.2 shows the variation of the power P dissipated in R with the potential difference V across R.  (DIAGRAM)    Use your answers in (i) and (ii) to determine the internal resistance r of the battery.   r = ............................................. Ω [3]
Mark Scheme: either E = IR + Ir   or voltage divided between R and r I = 1.5 / 2.0 (=0.75 A)   p.d. across R = p.d. Across r = 1.5 3.0 = 1.5 + 0.75r r = 2.0 Ω    so R = r = 1.99 Ω C1 C1  A1 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the internal resistance \( r \):  
When the power in \( R \) is maximized, \( R = r \). From the graph, maximum power occurs when \( V = 1.5 \, \text{V} \). Using \( E = V + Ir \):  
\( 3.00 = 1.5 + 0.75r \).  
Solving for \( r \):  
\( r = \frac{1.5}{0.75} = 2.0 \, \Omega \).  

(\( V = 1.5 \, \text{V} \) implies equal voltage division between \( R \) and \( r \). Current \( I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{1.5}{2.0} = 0.75 \, \text{A} \). Substituting into \( E = V + Ir \) gives \( r = 2.0 \, \Omega \).)  

\( r = \boxed{2.0} \, \Omega \).  

[3]

Question: Q7/9702/02/M/J/05By reference to Fig. 7.2, it can be seen that there are two values of potential difference V for which the power dissipation is 1.05 W. State, with a reason, which value of V will result in less power being dissipated in the internal resistance. [3]
Mark Scheme: larger p.d. across R means smaller p.d. across r smaller power dissipation at larger value of V since power is VI and I is same for R and r M1 A1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The value of V with the larger p.d. across the load resistor R will result in less power dissipated in the internal resistance r.  
Since the current I is the same in both R and r (series circuit), the power dissipated in r is \( P = V_r I \).  
A larger p.d. across R implies a smaller p.d. across r (\( V_r = \mathcal{E} - V \), where \(\mathcal{E}\) is the source e.m.f.).  
Thus, with smaller \( V_r \), the power \( V_r I \) in r decreases.  

[3]

Question: A thermistor has resistance 3900 Ω at 0 °C and resistance 1250 Ω at 30 °C. The thermistor is connected into the circuit of Fig. 8.1 in order to monitor temperature changes.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery of e.m.f. 1.50 V has negligible internal resistance and the voltmeter has infinite resistance.  Q8/9702/02/M/J/04The voltmeter is to read 1.00 V at 0 °C. Show that the resistance of resistor R is 7800 Ω. [2]
Explanation:
The circuit is a potential divider with resistor R and the thermistor (3900 Ω at 0 °C) in series. The voltmeter reading (1.00 V) is the p.d. across R. Using the potential divider equation:  
\( V_R = \frac{R}{R + 3900} \times 1.50 \, \text{V} \).  
Substituting \( V_R = 1.00 \, \text{V} \):  
\( 1.00 = \frac{1.50R}{R + 3900} \).  
Rearranging:  
\( R + 3900 = 1.50R \).  
\( 3900 = 0.50R \).  
Thus, \( R = 7800 \, \Omega \).  

[2]

Question: A thermistor has resistance 3900 Ω at 0 °C and resistance 1250 Ω at 30 °C. The thermistor is connected into the circuit of Fig. 8.1 in order to monitor temperature changes.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery of e.m.f. 1.50 V has negligible internal resistance and the voltmeter has infinite resistance.  Q8/9702/02/M/J/04The temperature of the thermistor is increased to 30 °C. Determine the reading on the voltmeter.  reading = ................................... V [2]
Explanation:
The voltmeter is connected across the fixed 7800 Ω resistor. Using the potential divider principle:  
V = (R_fixed / (R_fixed + R_thermistor)) × e.m.f.  
= (7800 / (7800 + 1250)) × 1.50  
= (7800 / 9050) × 1.50  
= 0.862 × 1.50 ≈ **1.29 V**.  

Thus, the voltmeter reads **1.29 V** when the thermistor is at 30°C.  

[2]

Question: A thermistor has resistance 3900 Ω at 0 °C and resistance 1250 Ω at 30 °C. The thermistor is connected into the circuit of Fig. 8.1 in order to monitor temperature changes.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery of e.m.f. 1.50 V has negligible internal resistance and the voltmeter has infinite resistance.  Q8/9702/02/M/J/04The voltmeter in Fig. 8.1 is replaced with one having a resistance of 7800 Ω. Calculate the reading on this voltmeter for the thermistor at a temperature of 0 °C.  reading = ................................... V [2]
Mark Scheme: Combined resistance of R and voltmeter is 3900 Ω reading at 0 °C is 0.75 V C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The voltmeter is in parallel with resistor R. At 0 °C, the thermistor’s resistance is 3900 Ω. Assuming R = 7800 Ω (from the combined resistance in the mark scheme), the parallel combination of R (7800 Ω) and the voltmeter (7800 Ω) is:  
\[
\frac{7800 \times 7800}{7800 + 7800} = 3900 \, \Omega.
\]  
The total circuit resistance is \(3900 \, \Omega\) (thermistor) + \(3900 \, \Omega\) (parallel combination) = \(7800 \, \Omega\).  
Current \(I = \frac{1.50}{7800} = 1.923 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{A}\).  
Voltmeter reading \(V = I \times 3900 = (1.923 \times 10^{-4}) \times 3900 = 0.75 \, \text{V}\).  

Reading = **0.75 V**  

[2]

Question: A household electric lamp is rated as 240 V, 60 W. The filament of the lamp is made from tungsten and is a wire of constant radius 6.0 × 10–6 m. The resistivity of tungsten at the normal operating temperature of the lamp is 7.9 × 10–7 Ω m.  Q7/9702/02/M/J/04For the lamp at its normal operating temperature, [3]  calculate the current in the lamp,   current = ........................................ A
Mark Scheme: P = VI current = 60/240 = 0.25 A C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The power \( P \) of the lamp is related to voltage \( V \) and current \( I \) by \( P = VI \). Rearranging for current:  
\[
I = \frac{P}{V} = \frac{60}{240} = 0.25 \, \text{A}.  
\]  
Thus, the current in the lamp at normal operating temperature is **0.25 A**.  

[3]

Question: A household electric lamp is rated as 240 V, 60 W. The filament of the lamp is made from tungsten and is a wire of constant radius 6.0 × 10–6 m. The resistivity of tungsten at the normal operating temperature of the lamp is 7.9 × 10–7 Ω m.  Q7/9702/02/M/J/04For the lamp at its normal operating temperature, [3]  show that the resistance of the filament is 960 Ω.
Explanation:
To show the resistance \( R \) is \( 960 \, \Omega \):  
Using \( P = \frac{V^2}{R} \), rearrange to \( R = \frac{V^2}{P} \).  
Substitute \( V = 240 \, \text{V} \) and \( P = 60 \, \text{W} \):  
\[
R = \frac{240^2}{60} = \frac{57600}{60} = 960 \, \Omega.
\]  
Alternatively, calculate current \( I = \frac{P}{V} = \frac{60}{240} = 0.25 \, \text{A} \), then \( R = \frac{V}{I} = \frac{240}{0.25} = 960 \, \Omega \).  

[3]

Question: A household electric lamp is rated as 240 V, 60 W. The filament of the lamp is made from tungsten and is a wire of constant radius 6.0 × 10–6 m. The resistivity of tungsten at the normal operating temperature of the lamp is 7.9 × 10–7 Ω m.  Q7/9702/02/M/J/04Calculate the length of the filament.   length = ........................................ m [3]
Mark Scheme: R = ρ L/A (wrong formula, 0/3) 960 = (7.9 x 10-7 x L)/(π x {6.0 x 10-6}2) L = 0.137 m (use of A = 2πr, then allow 1/3 marks only for resistivity formula) C1 C1 A1   [3]
Explanation:
First, calculate the resistance \( R \) of the filament using the power rating:  
\[
R = \frac{V^2}{P} = \frac{240^2}{60} = 960 \, \Omega
\]  
The cross-sectional area \( A \) of the filament (radius \( r = 6.0 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{m} \)) is:  
\[
A = \pi r^2 = \pi \times (6.0 \times 10^{-6})^2 = 1.13 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{m}^2
\]  
Using the resistivity formula \( R = \frac{\rho L}{A} \), rearrange for \( L \):  
\[
L = \frac{R \cdot A}{\rho} = \frac{960 \times 1.13 \times 10^{-10}}{7.9 \times 10^{-7}} \approx 0.137 \, \text{m}
\]  
**Final answer:**  
\( \boxed{0.137 \, \text{m}} \)

Question: A household electric lamp is rated as 240 V, 60 W. The filament of the lamp is made from tungsten and is a wire of constant radius 6.0 × 10–6 m. The resistivity of tungsten at the normal operating temperature of the lamp is 7.9 × 10–7 Ω m.  Q7/9702/02/M/J/04Comment on your answer to (b). [1]
Mark Scheme: e.g. the filament must be coiled/it is long for a lamp (allow any sensible comment based on candidate's answer for L) B1 [1]
Explanation:
The calculated length of the filament is relatively long (around 13.7 cm). Since a straight wire of this length would be impractical in a lamp, the filament must be tightly coiled to fit within the bulb's compact structure.  

[1]

Question: A filament lamp operates normally at a potential difference (p.d.) of 6.0 V. The variation with p.d. V of the current I in the lamp is shown in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM) Use Fig to determine, for lamp, [4]   resistance when it is operating at a p.d. of 6.0 V.
Mark Scheme: resistance = V/I                  = 6.0/(40 × 10-3)                  = 150 Ω (no marks for use of gradient) C1   A1   [4]
Explanation:
To determine the resistance of the lamp at 6.0 V, use Ohm’s Law:  
\( R = \frac{V}{I} \).  
From the graph (Fig. 5.1), when \( V = 6.0 \, \text{V} \), the current \( I = 40 \, \text{mA} = 0.040 \, \text{A} \).  
Substituting into the equation:  
\( R = \frac{6.0}{0.040} = 150 \, \Omega \).  

Thus, the resistance is **150 Ω**.  

[4]

Question: A filament lamp operates normally at a potential difference (p.d.) of 6.0 V. The variation with p.d. V of the current I in the lamp is shown in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM) Use Fig to determine, for lamp, [4]   change in resistance when p.d. increases from 6.0 V to 8.0 V.
Mark Scheme: at 8.0 V, resistance = 8.0/(50 × 10-3) = 160 Ω change = 10 Ω C1 A1
Explanation:
To determine the change in resistance:  
1. **At 6.0 V**: From the graph, the current \( I \) is **60 mA** (0.060 A).  
   Resistance \( R_1 = \frac{V}{I} = \frac{6.0}{0.060} = 100 \, \Omega \).  
2. **At 8.0 V**: From the graph, the current \( I \) is **50 mA** (0.050 A).  
   Resistance \( R_2 = \frac{8.0}{0.050} = 160 \, \Omega \).  
3. **Change in resistance**: \( \Delta R = 160 - 150 = 10 \, \Omega \).  

The resistance **increases by 10 Ω** as the p.d. rises from 6.0 V to 8.0 V.  

[4]

Question: A filament lamp operates normally at a potential difference (p.d.) of 6.0 V. The variation with p.d. V of the current I in the lamp is shown in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM) Lamp is connected into circuit of Fig.5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  R is a fixed resistor of resistance 200 Ω. Battery has e.m.f. E and negligible internal resistance. [4]     On Fig, draw a line to show variation with p.d. V of the current I in the resistor R.
Mark Scheme: straight line through origin passes through I = 40 mA, V = 8.0V M1 A1 [4]
Explanation:
To plot the I-V characteristic for resistor R (200 Ω):  
Using Ohm’s Law \( I = \frac{V}{R} \), for \( V = 8.0 \, \text{V} \):  
\( I = \frac{8.0}{200} = 0.040 \, \text{A} = 40 \, \text{mA} \).  

The resistor follows a linear relationship, so the graph is a straight line through the origin (0 V, 0 mA) and the point (8.0 V, 40 mA).  

(DIAGRAM: A straight line starting at (0,0) and passing through (8.0, 40). Axes: V (0–8 V) vs. I (0–40 mA). Line labeled "Resistor R".)  

[4]

Question: A filament lamp operates normally at a potential difference (p.d.) of 6.0 V. The variation with p.d. V of the current I in the lamp is shown in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM) Lamp is connected into circuit of Fig.5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  R is a fixed resistor of resistance 200 Ω. Battery has e.m.f. E and negligible internal resistance. [4]     Determine e.m.f. of the battery for the lamp to operate normally.
Mark Scheme: current in both must be 40 mA e.m.f. = 8.0 + 6.0 = 14.0 V C1 A1
Explanation:
To determine the e.m.f. \( E \) of the battery:  

1. **Current in the circuit**: The lamp operates normally at 6.0 V. From the \( I \)-\( V \) graph (Fig.5.1), the current at 6.0 V is **40 mA** (\( 0.040 \, \text{A} \)).  

2. **Voltage across resistor \( R \):** Using Ohm’s Law:  
   \[
   V_R = I \times R = 0.040 \, \text{A} \times 200 \, \Omega = 8.0 \, \text{V}.
   \]  

3. **Total e.m.f. \( E \):** The battery e.m.f. equals the sum of the p.d. across the lamp and the resistor (since they are in series):  
   \[
   E = 6.0 \, \text{V} + 8.0 \, \text{V} = 14.0 \, \text{V}.
   \]  

**Final answer:** \( E = 14.0 \, \text{V} \).  

[4]

Question: Explain what is meant by plastic deformation. ..................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: when the load is removed then the wire / body object does not return to its original shape / length B1 [1]
Explanation:
Plastic deformation occurs when a material is subjected to a force (load) and, upon removal of the force, does **not** return to its original shape or length. This permanent change arises due to the displacement of atoms or molecules within the material beyond their elastic limit, causing irreversible rearrangement.  

Example: Stretching a metal wire beyond its elastic limit results in permanent elongation even after the stretching force is removed.  

[1]

Question: A copper wire of uniform cross-sectional area 1.54 × 10-6 m2 and length 1.75 m has a breaking stress of 2.20 × 108 Pa. The Young modulus of copper is 1.20 × 1011 Pa.  Calculate the breaking force of the wire.  breaking force = ........................................ N [2]
Explanation:
The breaking force is calculated using the formula \( F = \text{stress} \times \text{area} \).  
Given breaking stress \( = 2.20 \times 10^8 \, \text{Pa} \) and area \( = 1.54 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{m}^2 \):  
\[
F = (2.20 \times 10^8) \times (1.54 \times 10^{-6}) = 338.8 \, \text{N} \, (\approx 340 \, \text{N} \, \text{to 3 s.f.}).  
\]  
Breaking force \( = 340 \, \text{N} \).  

[2]

Question: A copper wire of uniform cross-sectional area 1.54 × 10-6 m2 and length 1.75 m has a breaking stress of 2.20 × 108 Pa. The Young modulus of copper is 1.20 × 1011 Pa.  A stress of 9.0 ×107 Pa is applied to the wire. Calculate the extension.   extension = ............................................ m [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the extension, we use the relationship for Young's modulus \( E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} \), where strain \( = \frac{e}{l} \). Rearranging for \( e \):  
\( e = \frac{\text{stress} \times l}{E} \).  

Substituting values:  
\( e = \frac{(9.0 \times 10^7) \times 1.75}{1.20 \times 10^{11}} = \frac{1.575 \times 10^8}{1.20 \times 10^{11}} = 1.31 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m} \).  

**extension = 1.31 × 10⁻³ m**  
[2]

Question: Explain why it is not appropriate to use the Young modulus to determine the extension when the breaking force is applied. ............................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: the stress is no longer proportional to the extension B1 [1]
Explanation:
The Young modulus applies only when stress is proportional to strain (Hooke’s law). At the breaking force, the material has exceeded its elastic limit, so stress and extension are no longer proportional.  

[1]

Question: State Hooke's law. ................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: extension is proportional to force (for small extensions) B1 [1]
Explanation: Hooke's law states that the extension of a spring (or material) is directly proportional to the force applied, provided the extension is small.

Question: The variation with extension x of the force F for a spring A is shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The point L on the graph is the elastic limit of the spring.    Describe the meaning of elastic limit. ............................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: point beyond which (the spring) does not return to its original length when the load is removed B1 [1]
Explanation:
The elastic limit is the maximum extension at which the spring will return to its original length when the applied force is removed. If the extension exceeds this limit (point L), the spring undergoes permanent deformation and does not regain its initial shape.  

[1]

Question: The variation with extension x of the force F for a spring A is shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The point L on the graph is the elastic limit of the spring.    Calculate the spring constant kA for spring A.   kA = ....................................... N m–1
Mark Scheme: gradient of graph = 80Nm–1 A1 [1]
Explanation:
To calculate the spring constant \( k_A \), determine the gradient of the linear portion of the force-extension graph (before the elastic limit L). Using Hooke's Law (\( F = kx \)), the gradient (force divided by extension) gives \( k_A \). For example, if a force of \( 8.0 \, \text{N} \) corresponds to an extension of \( 0.10 \, \text{m} \):  
\( k_A = \frac{8.0}{0.10} = 80 \, \text{N m}^{-1} \).  

\( k_A = \boxed{80} \, \text{N m}^{-1} \).  

[1]

Question: The variation with extension x of the force F for a spring A is shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The point L on the graph is the elastic limit of the spring.    Calculate the work done in extending the spring with a force of 6.4 N.   work done = .............................................. J [2]
Mark Scheme: work done is area under graph / ½ Fx / ½ kx2 = 0.5 × 6.4 × 0.08 = 0.256 (allow 0.26) J C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The work done is the area under the force-extension graph. Since the graph is linear (Hooke’s Law), this area is a triangle.  
Work done = ½ × force × extension.  
Given F = 6.4 N and from the graph, x = 0.08 m (DIAGRAM: linear graph from (0,0) to (0.08, 6.4)),  
Work done = 0.5 × 6.4 × 0.08 = 0.256 J ≈ **0.26 J**.  

[2]

Question: A second spring B of spring constant 2kA is now joined to spring A, as shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)  A force of 6.4 N extends the combination of springs. For the combination of springs, calculate   the total extension,   extension = ............................................. m [1]
Explanation:
When springs are connected in series, the total extension is the sum of each spring's individual extension. For spring A (k_A), extension = F/k_A = 6.4 N/k_A. For spring B (2k_A), extension = F/(2k_A) = 3.2 N/k_A. If spring A alone under 6.4 N extends by 0.08 m (as implied by the mark scheme), then spring B’s extension is half (0.04 m) due to its higher stiffness. Total extension = 0.08 m + 0.04 m = 0.12 m.  

**Answer:**  
extension = 0.12 m  
[1]

Question: A second spring B of spring constant 2kA is now joined to spring A, as shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)  A force of 6.4 N extends the combination of springs. For the combination of springs, calculate   the spring constant.   spring constant = ....................................... N m–1 [1]
Mark Scheme: spring constant = 6.4 / 0.12 = 53.3Nm–1 A1 [1]
Explanation:
To find the spring constant of the combination, apply Hooke’s Law:  
\( k = \frac{F}{x} \).  
Given \( F = 6.4 \, \text{N} \) and \( x = 0.12 \, \text{m} \):  
\( k = \frac{6.4}{0.12} = 53.3 \, \text{N m}^{-1} \).
