Spring constant = **53.3** N m⁻¹  

[1]

Question: A spring hangs vertically from a fixed point and a mass of 94 g is suspended from the spring, stretching the spring as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The mass is raised vertically so that the length of the spring is its unextended length. This is illustrated in Fig. 5.2. The mass is then released. The mass moves through a vertical distance of 2.6 cm before temporarily coming to rest. This position is illustrated in Fig. 5.3.State which diagram, Fig. 5.1, Fig. 5.2 or Fig. 5.3, illustrates the position of the mass such that  the mass has maximum gravitational potential energy, .................................................................... [1]
Explanation:
Fig. 5.2 illustrates the position where the mass has maximum gravitational potential energy. Gravitational potential energy depends on height above a reference point. In Fig. 5.2, the spring is at its unextended (natural) length, meaning the mass has been lifted to the highest possible position relative to the equilibrium (Fig. 5.1) and lowest (Fig. 5.3) positions. At this raised point, the mass’s elevation is greatest, maximising its gravitational potential energy. When released, the mass falls, converting gravitational potential energy into kinetic and elastic potential energy. Thus, Fig. 5.2 corresponds to the maximum gravitational potential energy.  

[1]

Question: A spring hangs vertically from a fixed point and a mass of 94 g is suspended from the spring, stretching the spring as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The mass is raised vertically so that the length of the spring is its unextended length. This is illustrated in Fig. 5.2. The mass is then released. The mass moves through a vertical distance of 2.6 cm before temporarily coming to rest. This position is illustrated in Fig. 5.3.State which diagram, Fig. 5.1, Fig. 5.2 or Fig. 5.3, illustrates the position of the mass such that  the spring has maximum strain energy. .................................................................... [1]
Explanation:
Fig. 5.3.  
The maximum strain energy in the spring occurs when the extension is greatest. At Fig. 5.3, the mass has stretched the spring furthest (2.6 cm below the unextended position), so the elastic potential energy \( \frac{1}{2}kx^2 \) is maximised here.  

[1]

Question: A spring hangs vertically from a fixed point and a mass of 94 g is suspended from the spring, stretching the spring as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The mass is raised vertically so that the length of the spring is its unextended length. This is illustrated in Fig. 5.2. The mass is then released. The mass moves through a vertical distance of 2.6 cm before temporarily coming to rest. This position is illustrated in Fig. 5.3.Briefly describe the variation of the kinetic energy of the mass as the mass falls from its highest position (Fig. 5.2) to its lowest position (Fig. 5.3). ................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: kinetic energy increases from zero then decreases to zero B1 [1]
Explanation:
The kinetic energy of the mass starts at zero (highest position). As the mass accelerates downward, KE increases until it reaches the equilibrium position (maximum KE). Beyond this point, the spring’s restoring force opposes motion, causing KE to decrease. KE returns to zero at the lowest position.  

(KE increases from zero to a maximum, then decreases back to zero.)  

[1]

Question: A spring hangs vertically from a fixed point and a mass of 94 g is suspended from the spring, stretching the spring as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The mass is raised vertically so that the length of the spring is its unextended length. This is illustrated in Fig. 5.2. The mass is then released. The mass moves through a vertical distance of 2.6 cm before temporarily coming to rest. This position is illustrated in Fig. 5.3.The strain energy E stored in the spring is given by the expression            E = ½kx2 where k is the spring constant and x is the extension of the spring. For the mass moving between the positions shown in Fig. 5.2 and Fig. 5.3,   calculate the change in the gravitational potential energy of the mass,   change = ........................................... J
Explanation:
The change in gravitational potential energy is calculated using \( \Delta E_P = mg\Delta h \).  
Mass \( m = 94 \, \text{g} = 0.094 \, \text{kg} \),  
\( g = 9.8 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \),  
\( \Delta h = 2.6 \, \text{cm} = 0.026 \, \text{m} \).  

Substituting values:  
\[
\Delta E_P = 0.094 \times 9.8 \times 0.026 = 0.02395 \, \text{J} \approx 0.024 \, \text{J}.
\]  

Change in gravitational potential energy = **0.024 J**.  

[2]

Question: A spring hangs vertically from a fixed point and a mass of 94 g is suspended from the spring, stretching the spring as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The mass is raised vertically so that the length of the spring is its unextended length. This is illustrated in Fig. 5.2. The mass is then released. The mass moves through a vertical distance of 2.6 cm before temporarily coming to rest. This position is illustrated in Fig. 5.3.The strain energy E stored in the spring is given by the expression            E = ½kx2 where k is the spring constant and x is the extension of the spring. For the mass moving between the positions shown in Fig. 5.2 and Fig. 5.3,   determine the extension of the spring at which the strain energy is half its maximum value.   extension = ........................................ cm
Explanation:
The maximum strain energy occurs at the maximum extension of 2.6 cm (0.026 m). When the strain energy is half its maximum value:  
\[ \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = \frac{1}{2} \times \left(\frac{1}{2}k(0.026)^2\right) \]  
Simplifying:  
\[ x^2 = \frac{(0.026)^2}{2} \]  
\[ x = \frac{0.026}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 0.018 \, \text{m} \, \text{(1.8 cm)} \]  

**Extension = 1.8 cm**  

[3]

Question: A uniform wire has length L and constant area of cross-section A. The material of the wire has Young modulus E and resistivity ρ. A tension F in the wire causes its length to increase by ΔL.  For this wire, state expressions, in terms of L, A, F, ΔL and ρ for   the stress σ,  .............................................................. [1]
Explanation:
Stress σ is given by the applied force divided by the cross-sectional area. Therefore, σ = F / A.  

[1]

Question: A uniform wire has length L and constant area of cross-section A. The material of the wire has Young modulus E and resistivity ρ. A tension F in the wire causes its length to increase by ΔL.  For this wire, state expressions, in terms of L, A, F, ΔL and ρ for   the strain ε,  .............................................................. [1]
Explanation:
The strain ε is defined as the extension per unit original length. Therefore, using the given variables:  
ε = ΔL / L.  

[1]

Question: A uniform wire has length L and constant area of cross-section A. The material of the wire has Young modulus E and resistivity ρ. A tension F in the wire causes its length to increase by ΔL.  For this wire, state expressions, in terms of L, A, F, ΔL and ρ for   the Young modulus E,   ............................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: allow FL / A∆L B1 [1]
Explanation:
Young modulus \( E \) is given by stress divided by strain. Stress is \( \frac{F}{A} \) and strain is \( \frac{\Delta L}{L} \). Therefore,  
\[
E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} = \frac{F/A}{\Delta L/L} = \frac{FL}{A\Delta L}.
\]  
[1]

Question: A uniform wire has length L and constant area of cross-section A. The material of the wire has Young modulus E and resistivity ρ. A tension F in the wire causes its length to increase by ΔL.  For this wire, state expressions, in terms of L, A, F, ΔL and ρ for   the resistance R.  ............................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: allow ρL / A  or  ρ (L + ∆L) / A B1 [1]
Explanation:
The resistance \( R \) of the wire is given by \( R = \frac{\rho (L + \Delta L)}{A} \).  

Since the wire’s length increases by \( \Delta L \) under tension while its cross-sectional area \( A \) remains constant, the resistance depends on the total length \( L + \Delta L \). Using the formula \( R = \frac{\rho \times \text{length}}{\text{area}} \), substituting the stretched length gives \( R = \frac{\rho (L + \Delta L)}{A} \).  

[1]

Question: One end of a metal wire of length 2.6 m and constant area of cross-section 3.8 × 10–7 m2 is attached to a fixed point, as shown in Fig. 4.1.               (DIAGRAM)  The Young modulus of the material of the wire is 7.0×1010 Pa and its resistivity is 2.6×10–8 Ω m. A load of 30 N is attached to the lower end of the wire. Assume that the area of cross-section of the wire does not change. For this load of 30 N,   show that the extension of the wire is 2.9 mm, [1]
Explanation:
To calculate the extension ΔL, use the formula for Young's modulus:  
ΔL = (F × L) / (E × A).  
Substituting the given values:  
ΔL = (30 N × 2.6 m) / (7.0 × 10¹⁰ Pa × 3.8 × 10⁻⁷ m²).  
First, compute the numerator:  
30 × 2.6 = 78 N·m.  
Then the denominator:  
7.0 × 10¹⁰ × 3.8 × 10⁻⁷ = 26.6 × 10³ N.  
Thus, ΔL = 78 / 26.6 × 10⁻³ ≈ 2.93 × 10⁻³ m = 2.93 mm.  
Rounded to two significant figures, ΔL = 2.9 mm.  

[1]

Question: One end of a metal wire of length 2.6 m and constant area of cross-section 3.8 × 10–7 m2 is attached to a fixed point, as shown in Fig. 4.1.               (DIAGRAM)  The Young modulus of the material of the wire is 7.0×1010 Pa and its resistivity is 2.6×10–8 Ω m. A load of 30 N is attached to the lower end of the wire. Assume that the area of cross-section of the wire does not change. For this load of 30 N,   calculate the change in resistance of the wire.  change = ....................................... Ω [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the change in resistance ΔR, first determine the extension ΔL using Young's modulus:  
ΔL = (F × L) / (E × A)  
= (30 × 2.6) / (7.0×10¹⁰ × 3.8×10⁻⁷)  
= 78 / 2.66×10⁴  
≈ 2.93×10⁻³ m.  

Now, substitute ΔL into ΔR = ρΔL / A:  
ΔR = (2.6×10⁻⁸ × 2.93×10⁻³) / 3.8×10⁻⁷  
≈ 7.62×10⁻¹¹ / 3.8×10⁻⁷  
≈ 2.0×10⁻⁴ Ω.  

Change in resistance = **2.0 × 10⁻⁴ Ω**.  

[2]

Question: The resistance of the wire changes with the applied load. Comment on the suggestion that this change of resistance could be used to measure the magnitude of the load on the wire. ..................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: change in resistance is (very) small so method is not appropriate M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The change in resistance of the wire under load occurs due to alterations in its length and cross-sectional area. However, the variation in resistance is typically very small, making it difficult to detect accurately without highly sensitive equipment. Additionally, factors like temperature fluctuations could introduce significant errors, further reducing reliability. Thus, using resistance change alone is not a practical method for measuring load magnitude. 

[2]

Question: A straight wire of unstretched length L has an electrical resistance R. When it is stretched by a force F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L and the resistance increases by ∆R. The area of cross-section A of the wire may be assumed to remain constant.  State the relation between R, L, A and the resistivity ρ of the material of the wire. ................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: R = ρL / A B1 [3]
Explanation:
The resistance \( R \) of the wire is given by the equation:  
\[ R = \frac{\rho L}{A} \]  
where \( \rho \) is the resistivity of the material, \( L \) is the length of the wire, and \( A \) is its constant cross-sectional area.  

[1]

Question: A straight wire of unstretched length L has an electrical resistance R. When it is stretched by a force F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L and the resistance increases by ∆R. The area of cross-section A of the wire may be assumed to remain constant.  Show that the fractional change in resistance  (DIAGRAM)  is equal to the strain in the wire. [2]
Mark Scheme: strain = ∆L / L either ∆R = ρ∆L /A  or R ∝ L with ρ and A constant dividing, ∆R / R = ∆L / L B1 B1 A0
Explanation:
The resistance of the wire is given by \( R = \frac{\rho L}{A} \), where \( \rho \) is resistivity and \( A \) is constant.  
When stretched, the new length is \( L + \Delta L \), so the new resistance is \( R + \Delta R = \frac{\rho (L + \Delta L)}{A} \).  
Subtracting the original resistance:  
\( \Delta R = \frac{\rho \Delta L}{A} \).  
Dividing \( \Delta R \) by \( R \):  
\( \frac{\Delta R}{R} = \frac{\rho \Delta L / A}{\rho L / A} = \frac{\Delta L}{L} \).  
Thus, \( \frac{\Delta R}{R} = \text{strain} \), since strain \( = \frac{\Delta L}{L} \).  

[2]

Question: A straight wire of unstretched length L has an electrical resistance R. When it is stretched by a force F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L and the resistance increases by ∆R. The area of cross-section A of the wire may be assumed to remain constant.A steel wire has area of cross-section 1.20×10–7 m2 and a resistance of 4.17 Ω. The Young modulus of steel is 2.10×1011 Pa. The tension in the wire is increased from zero to 72.0 N. The wire obeys Hooke's law at these values of tension. Determine the strain in the wire and hence its change in resistance. Express your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures.  change = ………………………… Ω [5]
Mark Scheme: Young modulus = stress / strain strain = 72.0 / (1.20 × 10-7 × 2.10 × 1011)      = 2.86 × 10-3  (allow 1/350 ∆R = 2.86 × 10-3 × 4.17 = 1.19 × 10-2 Ω answer given to 3 sig. fig C1 C1 A1 A1 B1 [5]
Explanation:
To determine the strain (ε), we use Young's modulus (E = stress/strain):  
Stress = F/A = 72.0 / (1.20×10⁻⁷) = 6.00×10⁸ Pa.  
Strain = Stress/E = (6.00×10⁸) / (2.10×10¹¹) = **2.86×10⁻³**.  

For the change in resistance (ΔR), since cross-sectional area (A) is constant and resistance \( R = \rho L/A \), stretching increases length (L) proportionally:  
ΔR = (ΔL/L) × R = strain × R = (2.86×10⁻³) × 4.17 = **1.19×10⁻² Ω** (3 s.f.).  

Change in resistance = **0.0119 Ω** [5]

Question: A metal wire has an unstretched length L and area of cross-section A. When the wire supports a load F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L. The wire obeys Hooke's law. Write down expressions, in terms of L, A, F and ∆L, for   the applied stress,  .................................................................................
Explanation:
The applied stress is given by the force per unit cross-sectional area.  
Stress = F/A.  

(Stress is independent of the original length or extension, relying solely on force and area.)  

[1]

Question: A metal wire has an unstretched length L and area of cross-section A. When the wire supports a load F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L. The wire obeys Hooke's law. Write down expressions, in terms of L, A, F and ∆L, for   the tensile strain in the wire,  .................................................................................
Mark Scheme: ∆L/L B1
Explanation:
The tensile strain in the wire is given by the ratio of the extension (ΔL) to the original unstretched length (L). Therefore, the expression for tensile strain is **ΔL/L**.  

[Strain = extension/original length → no dependence on F or A for strain.]  

B1 [1]

Question: A metal wire has an unstretched length L and area of cross-section A. When the wire supports a load F, the wire extends by an amount ∆L. The wire obeys Hooke's law. Write down expressions, in terms of L, A, F and ∆L, for   the Young modulus of the material of the wire.  ................................................................................. [3]
Mark Scheme: FL/A.∆L B1
Explanation:
The Young modulus \( E \) is given by the ratio of stress to strain.  
Stress = \( \frac{F}{A} \)  
Strain = \( \frac{\Delta L}{L} \)  
Thus, \( E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} = \frac{F/A}{\Delta L/L} \).  
Simplifying, \( E = \frac{F \cdot L}{A \cdot \Delta L} \).  

Answer: \( \frac{FL}{A\Delta L} \).  

[3]

Question: A steel wire of uniform cross-sectional area 7.9×10–7 m2 is heated to a temperature of 650 K. It is then clamped between two rigid supports, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The wire is straight but not under tension and the length between the supports is 0.62 m. The wire is then allowed to cool to 300 K. When the wire is allowed to contract freely, a 1.00 m length of the wire decreases in length by 0.012 mm for every 1 K decrease in temperature.   Show that the change in length of the wire, if it were allowed to contract as it cools from 650 K to 300 K, would be 2.6 mm. [2]
Explanation:
The temperature change is 650 K − 300 K = **350 K**.  
The contraction per metre per Kelvin is **0.012 mm m⁻¹ K⁻¹**.  
For a wire of length **0.62 m**, the total contraction is:  
ΔL = 0.012 mm m⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 0.62 m × 350 K  
ΔL = 0.012 × 0.62 × 350 = **2.6 mm**  
(Units: m cancels with m⁻¹, leaving mm × K⁻¹ × K = mm.)  

[2]

Question: A steel wire of uniform cross-sectional area 7.9×10–7 m2 is heated to a temperature of 650 K. It is then clamped between two rigid supports, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The wire is straight but not under tension and the length between the supports is 0.62 m. The wire is then allowed to cool to 300 K. When the wire is allowed to contract freely, a 1.00 m length of the wire decreases in length by 0.012 mm for every 1 K decrease in temperature.   The Young modulus of steel is 2.0×1011 Pa. Calculate the tension in the wire at 300 K, assuming that the wire obeys Hooke's law.  tension = …………………………… N [2]
Explanation:
The wire would contract if free, but being clamped induces tension.  
Temperature decrease ΔT = 650 K – 300 K = 350 K.  
Contraction per meter per K = 0.012 mm = 1.2×10⁻⁵ m.  
Total contraction for 0.62 m:  
ΔL = 0.62 × (1.2×10⁻⁵ × 350) = 0.62 × 4.2×10⁻³ = 2.6×10⁻³ m.  

Using Hooke’s Law:  
Young modulus \( E = \frac{FL}{A\Delta L} \).  
Rearranging: \( F = \frac{EA\Delta L}{L} \).  
Substitute values:  
\( F = \frac{(2.0 \times 10^{11}) \times (7.9 \times 10^{-7}) \times (2.6 \times 10^{-3})}{0.62} \).  
Calculating:  
\( F = \frac{410.8}{0.62} ≈ 660 \, \text{N} \).  

Tension = **660 N**.  

[2]

Question: A steel wire of uniform cross-sectional area 7.9×10–7 m2 is heated to a temperature of 650 K. It is then clamped between two rigid supports, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The wire is straight but not under tension and the length between the supports is 0.62 m. The wire is then allowed to cool to 300 K. When the wire is allowed to contract freely, a 1.00 m length of the wire decreases in length by 0.012 mm for every 1 K decrease in temperature.   The ultimate tensile stress of steel is 250 MPa. Use this information and your answer in (ii) to suggest whether the wire will, in practice, break as it cools. ................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: either stress when cold = 660/(7.9 × 10-7) = 840 MPa or  tension at uts = 198 N M1 [3] either this is greater than the ultimate tensile stress or tension at uts is less then tension in (ii) A1 the wire will snap A1 (Allow possibility for the two 'A' marks to be scored as long as some quantitative answer – even if incorrect – has been given for the ‘M’ mark)
Explanation:
The wire will break as it cools.  
First, calculate the thermal stress when the wire cannot contract:  
Stress = Force / Area. The mark scheme implies a force of 660 N (from part ii).  
Stress = 660 N / (7.9 × 10⁻⁷ m²) ≈ 840 MPa.  

The ultimate tensile stress (UTS) of steel is 250 MPa. Since 840 MPa > 250 MPa, the stress exceeds the UTS.  
Alternatively, tension at UTS = 250 × 10⁶ Pa × 7.9 × 10⁻⁷ m² ≈ 198 N. The actual tension (660 N) exceeds this.  

Therefore, the wire snaps.  

[3]

Question: An aluminium wire of length 1.8 m and area of cross-section 1.7 × 10−6 m2 has one end fixed to a rigid support. A small weight hangs from the free end, as illustrated in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of the wire is 0.030 Ω and the Young modulus of aluminium is 7.1×1010 Pa. The load on the wire is increased by 25 N.Calculate  the increase in stress,   increase = …………………………………… Pa
Mark Scheme: stress = F/A = 25 / (1.7 × 10–6) = 1.47 × 107 Pa ......(do not allow 1 sig fig) C1  A1 [4]
Explanation:
The increase in stress is calculated using **stress = force / area**.  
Given:  
Force increase, \( F = 25 \, \text{N} \)  
Cross-sectional area, \( A = 1.7 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{m}^2 \).  

\[
\text{Stress} = \frac{25}{1.7 \times 10^{-6}} = 1.47 \times 10^7 \, \text{Pa} \quad (\text{to 3 significant figures}).
\]  

Answer: \( 1.47 \times 10^7 \, \text{Pa} \).  

[4]

Question: An aluminium wire of length 1.8 m and area of cross-section 1.7 × 10−6 m2 has one end fixed to a rigid support. A small weight hangs from the free end, as illustrated in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of the wire is 0.030 Ω and the Young modulus of aluminium is 7.1×1010 Pa. The load on the wire is increased by 25 N.Calculate  the change in length of the wire.   change = ……………………………………. m [4]
Explanation:
stress = force / area = 25 / (1.7 × 10⁻⁶) = 1.47 × 10⁷ Pa  
Using Young modulus:  
stress = E × strain → 1.47 × 10⁷ = 7.1 × 10¹⁰ × (Δl / 1.8)  
Δl = (1.47 × 10⁷ × 1.8) / 7.1 × 10¹⁰ = 0.000373 m (0.37 mm)  

change = **3.7 × 10⁻⁴ m**  

[4]

Question: An aluminium wire of length 1.8 m and area of cross-section 1.7 × 10−6 m2 has one end fixed to a rigid support. A small weight hangs from the free end, as illustrated in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance of the wire is 0.030 Ω and the Young modulus of aluminium is 7.1×1010 Pa. The load on the wire is increased by 25 N.Assuming that the area of cross-section of the wire does not change when the load is increased, determine the change in resistance of the wire.  change = ……………………………… Ω [3]
Mark Scheme: R = ρl / A     OR   R ∝ L so, ΔR /R = Δl / l ΔR = (3.7 × 10–4 / 1.8) × 0.03 = 6.2 × 10–6 Ω C1 C1 A1 [3] May calculate ρ = 2.833 ... × 10–8 Ω m giving new R as  3.000617 × 10–2 Ω hence  ΔR - full credit possible  However, if rounds off ρ as 2.83 × 10–8 Ω m then Rnew  <  Rold! Allow 1 mark only for R ∝ L
Explanation:
To determine the change in resistance (ΔR), first calculate the extension ΔL using Young's modulus:  
ΔL = (F × L) / (E × A) = (25 × 1.8) / (7.1×10¹⁰ × 1.7×10⁻⁶) ≈ 3.73×10⁻⁴ m.  

Since R ∝ L (as A and ρ are constant):  
ΔR/R = ΔL/L ⇒ ΔR = (ΔL/L) × R = (3.73×10⁻⁴ / 1.8) × 0.030 ≈ 6.2×10⁻⁶ Ω.  

Change in resistance = **6.2 × 10⁻⁶ Ω**  
[3]

Question: Define  stress, .................................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: stress = force / cross-sectional area B1 [1]
Explanation:
Stress is defined as the force applied per unit cross-sectional area of a material.  
Stress = Force / Cross-sectional Area.

Question: Define  strain. .................................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: strain = extension / original length B1 [1]
Explanation:
Strain is the ratio of the extension (or change in length) of a material to its original length.  
Mathematically, strain = (extension)/(original length).  

[1]

Question: The Young modulus of the metal of a wire is 0.17 TPa. The cross-sectional area of the wire is 0.18 mm2. The wire is extended by a force F. This causes the length of the wire to be increased by 0.095 %. Calculate   the stress,   stress = ............................................ Pa [4]
Explanation:
Stress is calculated using \( E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} \), so \( \text{stress} = E \times \text{strain} \).  
Strain = \( \frac{0.095}{100} = 0.00095 \).  
Substituting values:  
\( \text{stress} = 0.17 \times 10^{12} \, \text{Pa} \times 0.00095 = 1.615 \times 10^8 \, \text{Pa} \).  
Rounded to **1.6 × 10⁸ Pa** (or **1.62 × 10⁸ Pa**).  

Stress = \( 1.6 \times 10^8 \, \text{Pa} \).  

[4]

Question: The Young modulus of the metal of a wire is 0.17 TPa. The cross-sectional area of the wire is 0.18 mm2. The wire is extended by a force F. This causes the length of the wire to be increased by 0.095 %. Calculate   the force F.   F = ............................................. N [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the force \( F \):

1. **Young Modulus formula**:  
   \( E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} = \frac{F/A}{\Delta L / L} \), so  
   \( F = E \cdot A \cdot \left(\frac{\Delta L}{L}\right) \).

2. **Substitute values**:  
   - \( E = 0.17 \, \text{TPa} = 0.17 \times 10^{12} \, \text{Pa} \),  
   - \( A = 0.18 \, \text{mm}^2 = 0.18 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{m}^2 \),  
   - Strain \( = \frac{\Delta L}{L} = 0.095\% = 0.00095 \).

3. **Calculate**:  
   \( F = (0.17 \times 10^{12}) \times (0.18 \times 10^{-6}) \times 0.00095 \)  
   \( = 29.1 \, \text{N} \).

**Final answer**:  
\( F = 29 \, \text{N} \).

Question: Energy is stored in a metal wire that is extended elastically.Explain what is meant by extended elastically. ................................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: the wire returns to its original length (not 'shape') when the load is removed M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
When a metal wire is extended elastically, it means that once the stretching force (load) is removed, the wire returns completely to its original length. There is no permanent deformation; the wire regains its initial dimensions after the load is taken away.  

(Elastic extension implies the wire obeys Hooke’s law during stretching, with energy stored as elastic potential energy. This energy is fully recoverable upon unloading, as atomic bonds are stretched but not broken.)  

[2]

Question: Energy is stored in a metal wire that is extended elastically.Show that the SІ units of energy per unit volume are kg m–1 s–2. [2]
Mark Scheme: energy: N m / kg m2 s–2 and volume m3 energy / volume: kgm2s–2 / m3 energy / volume: kgm–1 s–2 C1 M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
Energy has SI units of joules (J). Since 1 J = 1 N·m and 1 N = 1 kg m s⁻²,  
energy in base units is **kg m² s⁻²**.  

Volume has SI units of **m³**.  

Energy per unit volume is:  
(kg m² s⁻²) ÷ m³ = **kg m⁻¹ s⁻²**.  

Thus, the SI units for energy per unit volume are **kg m⁻¹ s⁻²**.  

[2]

Question: Energy is stored in a metal wire that is extended elastically.For a wire extended elastically, the elastic energy per unit volume X is given by             X = Cε2E where C is a constant,          ε is the strain of the wire, and E is the Young modulus of the wire.  Show that C has no units. [3]
Mark Scheme: ε has no units E: kg m s–2 m–2 units of RHS: kgm–1 s–2 = LHS units / satisfactory conclusion to show C has no units B1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
To show that \( C \) has no units, we analyze the units of each term in the equation \( X = C \varepsilon^2 E \).  

1. **Units of \( X \)**:  
   Elastic energy per unit volume (\( X \)) has units of \( \text{J} \, \text{m}^{-3} \), which simplifies to \( \text{kg} \, \text{m}^{-1} \, \text{s}^{-2} \).  

2. **Units of \( \varepsilon^2 \)**:  
   Strain (\( \varepsilon \)) is dimensionless, so \( \varepsilon^2 \) is also dimensionless.  

3. **Units of \( E \)**:  
   Young modulus (\( E \)) has units of pressure (\( \text{Pa} \)), which are \( \text{kg} \, \text{m}^{-1} \, \text{s}^{-2} \).  

For the equation to be dimensionally consistent, the units of the right-hand side (\( C \times \varepsilon^2 \times E \)) must equal the units of \( X \). Substituting the units:  
\[ C \times (\text{dimensionless}) \times (\text{kg} \, \text{m}^{-1} \, \text{s}^{-2}) = \text{kg} \, \text{m}^{-1} \, \text{s}^{-2} \).  

This implies \( C \) must be dimensionless (no units) to balance the equation.

Question: Define the Young modulus. ..........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: E = stress / strain B1 [1]
Explanation:
The Young modulus is defined as the ratio of stress to strain for a material.  

**E = stress / strain**  

[1]

Question: A load F is suspended from a fixed point by a steel wire. The variation with extension x of F for the wire is shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)    State two quantities, other than the gradient of the graph in Fig, that are required in order to determine the Young modulus of steel. 1. .................................................................... 2. .................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: 1. diameter / cross sectional area / radius 2. original length B1 [1]
Explanation:
1. original length  
2. diameter / cross-sectional area / radius  

[1]

Question: A load F is suspended from a fixed point by a steel wire. The variation with extension x of F for the wire is shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Describe how the quantities you listed in (i) may be measured. ..........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: measure original length with a metre ruler / tape measure the diameter with micrometer (screw gauge) allow digital vernier calipers B1 B1   [2]
Explanation:
The original length of the wire is measured using a metre ruler or tape measure.  
The diameter of the wire is measured at multiple points using a micrometer screw gauge or digital vernier calipers to ensure accuracy.  

[2]

Question: A load F is suspended from a fixed point by a steel wire. The variation with extension x of F for the wire is shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)    A load of 3.0 N is applied to the wire. Use Fig. 5.1 to calculate the energy stored in the wire.  energy = .............................................. J [2]
Mark Scheme: energy = ½ Fe or area under graph or ½ kx2             = ½ × 0.25 × 10–3 × 3 = 3.8 × 10–4 J C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the energy stored, we find the area under the force-extension graph up to F = 3.0 N. Assuming the graph is linear (Hooke’s Law), this area is a triangle:  
**Energy = ½ × F × x**  
From the graph, at F = 3.0 N, the extension x = 0.25 mm = 0.25 × 10⁻³ m.  
Substituting:  
Energy = ½ × 3.0 × 0.25 × 10⁻³ = **3.8 × 10⁻⁴ J**.  

[2]

Question: A copper wire has the same original dimensions as the steel wire. The Young modulus for steel is 2.2×1011 Nm–2 and for copper is 1.1×1011 Nm–2. On Fig. 5.1, sketch the variation with x of F for the copper wire for extensions up to 0.25 mm. The copper wire is not extended beyond its limit of proportionality. [2]
Mark Scheme: straight line through origin below original line line through (0.25, 1.5) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A graph with force F on the y-axis and extension x on the x-axis. Two straight lines start from the origin. The steeper line represents steel. The copper line is less steep, lying below the steel line, and passes through the point (0.25 mm, 1.5). Both lines are linear as they are within the limit of proportionality.)

The copper wire’s force-extension graph is a straight line through the origin. Since copper has half the Young’s modulus of steel (for the same dimensions), its gradient (F/x) is halved. At x = 0.25 mm, F for copper is 1.5 (half of steel’s force at this extension). The copper line lies below the steel line, maintaining linearity.

Question: State Hooke's Law. ...............................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: force is proportional to extension B1 [1]
Explanation:
Hooke's Law states that the force applied to a spring is directly proportional to its extension (within the limit of proportionality).  

[1]

Question: A spring is compressed by applying a force. The variation with compression x of the force F is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Calculate the spring constant.   spring constant = ....................................... N m–1 [1]
Mark Scheme: gradient of graph determined (e.g. 50 / 40 ×10–3) = 1250 Nm–1 A1 [1]
Explanation:
The spring constant is determined by the gradient of the force-compression (F-x) graph. Using two points from the linear region, e.g., a force of 50 N at 40 mm (0.04 m) compression:  
gradient = ΔF/Δx = 50 N / 0.04 m = 1250 N m⁻¹.  

Spring constant = **1250** N m⁻¹.  

[1]

Question: A spring is compressed by applying a force. The variation with compression x of the force F is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Show that the work done in compressing the spring by 36 mm is 0.81 J. [2]
Mark Scheme: W = ½ k x2  or W = ½ final force × extension    = 0.5 × 1250 × (36 × 10–3)2  or 0.5 × 45 × 36 × 10–3    = 0.81 J M1 M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the work done in compressing the spring, we use the area under the force-compression graph. Since the graph is linear, this area is a triangle:  
**Work done** = ½ × maximum force × compression.  
From the graph, at **x = 36 mm = 0.036 m**, the force is **45 N**.  
Thus,  
Work done = 0.5 × 45 × 0.036 = **0.81 J**.  

Alternatively, using **W = ½ kx²**:  
Spring constant **k** = force/compression = 45 / 0.036 = **1250 N/m**.  
Work done = 0.5 × 1250 × (0.036)² = **0.81 J**.  

Both methods confirm the work done is **0.81 J**.

Question: A child's toy uses the spring in (b) to shoot a small ball vertically upwards. The ball has a mass of 25 g. The toy is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)    The spring in the toy is compressed by 36 mm. The spring is released. Assume all the strain energy in the spring is converted to kinetic energy of the ball. Using the result in (b)(ii), calculate the speed with which the ball leaves the spring.  speed = ........................................ m s–1 [2]
Explanation:
The strain energy from the spring is converted entirely into the ball's kinetic energy. Using the given strain energy (0.81 J):  
\( 0.81 = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).  
Substituting \( m = 0.025 \, \text{kg} \):  
\( 0.81 = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.025 \times v^2 \).  
Rearranging:  
\( v^2 = \frac{2 \times 0.81}{0.025} = 64.8 \).  
\( v = \sqrt{64.8} = 8.0 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

Speed = **8.0 m s⁻¹**.  

[2]

Question: A child's toy uses the spring in (b) to shoot a small ball vertically upwards. The ball has a mass of 25 g. The toy is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)    Determine the compression of the spring required for the ball to leave the spring with twice the speed determined in (i).  compression = .......................................... mm [2]
Mark Scheme: 4 × KE / 4 × WD or 3.24 J hence twice the compression = 72 mm C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The kinetic energy of the ball is proportional to the square of its speed. To achieve twice the speed, the required kinetic energy becomes \(4 \times\) the original (since \( (2v)^2 = 4v^2 \)). The energy stored in the spring is proportional to the square of the compression \(x\) (as \(E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2\)). For \(4 \times\) the energy, the compression must double. If the original compression (from part (i)) was \(36 \, \text{mm}\), doubling it gives \(72 \, \text{mm}\).  

**Compression = 72 mm**  
[2]

Question: A child's toy uses the spring in (b) to shoot a small ball vertically upwards. The ball has a mass of 25 g. The toy is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)    Determine the ratio  (DIAGRAM)   ratio = ................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: Max height is when all KE or WD or elastic PE is converted to GPE ratio = 1/4 or 0.25  C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The elastic potential energy stored in the spring when compressed is converted into gravitational potential energy at the ball’s maximum height.  

Elastic PE = Gravitational PE:  
\( \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = mgh \).  

If the compression \( x \) is halved, the elastic PE becomes \( \frac{1}{2}k\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{1}{8}kx^2 \).  

Thus, the new height \( h' \) is:  
\( \frac{1}{8}kx^2 = mgh' \).  

Dividing the equations:  
\( \frac{h'}{h} = \frac{\frac{1}{8}kx^2}{\frac{1}{2}kx^2} = \frac{1}{4} \).  

Ratio = \( \frac{1}{4} \).  

[2]

Question: Tensile forces are applied to opposite ends of a copper rod so that the rod is stretched. The variation with stress of the strain of the rod is shown in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Use Fig.5.1 to determine the Young modulus of copper.  Young modulus = .......................................... Pa  [3]
Mark Scheme: Young modulus = stress/strain data chosen using point in linear region of graph Young modulus = (2.1 × 108)/(1.9 × 10–3)  = 1.1 × 1011 Pa C1 M1  A1 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the Young modulus of copper from the stress-strain graph:  
1. **Identify the linear (elastic) region** of the graph where stress is proportional to strain.  
2. **Select a point** in this region. For example, at **stress = 2.1 × 10⁸ Pa**, the corresponding **strain = 1.9 × 10⁻³**.  
3. **Calculate Young modulus**:  
   \( E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} = \frac{2.1 \times 10^8}{1.9 \times 10^{-3}} = 1.1 \times 10^{11} \, \text{Pa} \).  

Young modulus = **1.1 × 10¹¹ Pa**.  

[3]

Question: Tensile forces are applied to opposite ends of a copper rod so that the rod is stretched. The variation with stress of the strain of the rod is shown in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM)    On Fig.5.1, sketch a line to show the variation with stress of the strain of the rod as the stress is reduced from 2.5 × 108 Pa to zero. No further calculations are expected.   [1]
Mark Scheme: This mark was removed from the assessment, owing to a power-of-ten inconsistency in the printed question paper. 1 [1]
Explanation:
(If the original graph showed plastic deformation beyond the elastic limit at 2.5×10⁸ Pa, the unloading line would be a straight line parallel to the initial elastic slope, returning to a non-zero residual strain. However, due to the error in the question, no valid answer was expected.)  
[1]

Question: The walls of the tyres on a car are made of a rubber compound. The variation with stress of the strain of a specimen of this rubber compound is shown in Fig.5.2.              (DIAGRAM)  As the car moves, the walls of the tyres bend and straighten continuously. Use Fig.5.2 to explain why the walls of the tyres become warm. ............................................................................[3]
Mark Scheme: area between lines represents energy/area under curve represents energy M1 [3] when rubber is stretched and then released/two areas are different  A1 this energy seen as thermal energy/heating/difference represents energy released as heat A1
Explanation:
The stress-strain graph for the rubber compound forms a hysteresis loop. The area enclosed by the loop represents the energy dissipated as thermal energy during each stretching and contraction cycle of the tyre walls. When the rubber is stretched (loading), the work done on it corresponds to the area under the loading curve. When it contracts (unloading), the energy returned is the area under the unloading curve. Since the two areas are unequal (hysteresis), the difference in energy is lost as heat. Repeated bending and straightening of the tyres during motion causes continuous energy loss, warming the rubber. 

[3]

Question: A spring is placed on a flat surface and different weights are placed on it, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with weight of the compression of the spring is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The elastic limit of the spring has not been exceeded.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/08  Determine the spring constant k of the spring.   k = ........................................... N m–1
Mark Scheme: k is the reciprocal of the gradient of the graph k = {32 / (4 × 10–2) = } 800 N m–1 C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the spring constant \( k \), we use Hooke’s Law: \( F = kx \). The graph of weight (force \( F \)) against compression (\( x \)) has a gradient of \( \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta F} \). The spring constant is the reciprocal of this gradient:  
\( k = \frac{\Delta F}{\Delta x} \).  

From the graph, for example, a weight \( F = 32 \, \text{N} \) causes a compression \( x = 4.0 \, \text{cm} = 0.040 \, \text{m} \). Substituting:  
\( k = \frac{32}{0.040} = 800 \, \text{N m}^{-1} \).  

Thus, the spring constant is \( \boxed{800} \, \text{N m}^{-1} \).

Question: A spring is placed on a flat surface and different weights are placed on it, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with weight of the compression of the spring is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The elastic limit of the spring has not been exceeded.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/08  Deduce that the strain energy stored in the spring is 0.49 J for a compression of 3.5 cm. [2]
Mark Scheme: either  energy = average force × extension  or  ½kx2 or  area under graph line energy = ½ × 800 × (3.5 × 10–2)2  or  ½ × 28 × 3.5 × 10–2 energy = 0.49 J  C1 M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
To deduce the strain energy stored in the spring, we calculate the area under the force-compression graph, which is linear (Hooke’s Law applies).  

**Method 1 (Using ½ kx²):**  
From the graph, the spring constant \( k \) is determined as \( \frac{F}{x} \). At \( x = 3.5 \, \text{cm} = 0.035 \, \text{m} \), \( F = 28 \, \text{N} \):  
\( k = \frac{28}{0.035} = 800 \, \text{N/m} \).  
Strain energy \( = \frac{1}{2} k x^2 = \frac{1}{2} \times 800 \times (0.035)^2 = 0.49 \, \text{J} \).  

**Method 2 (Using average force):**  
Average force \( = \frac{0 + 28}{2} = 14 \, \text{N} \).  
Strain energy \( = \text{average force} \times \text{extension} = 14 \times 0.035 = 0.49 \, \text{J} \).  

Both methods confirm the strain energy is \( 0.49 \, \text{J} \).  

[2]

Question: A spring is placed on a flat surface and different weights are placed on it, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with weight of the compression of the spring is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The elastic limit of the spring has not been exceeded.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/08Two trolleys, of masses 800 g and 2400 g, are free to move on a horizontal table. The spring in (a) is placed between the trolleys and the trolleys are tied together using thread so that the compression of the spring is 3.5 cm, as shown in Fig. 2.3.  (DIAGRAM)  Initially, the trolleys are not moving. The thread is then cut and the trolleys move apart.   Deduce that the ratio  (DIAGRAM)  is equal to 3.0. [2]
Mark Scheme: momentum before cutting thread = momentum after 0 = 2400 × V – 800 × v v / V = 3.0 C1 M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
Before the thread is cut, the total momentum is zero. After cutting, momentum conservation gives:  
0 = (800 g)v – (2400 g)V.  
Simplifying:  
800v = 2400V ⇒ v/V = 2400/800 = 3.0.  

[2]

Question: A spring is placed on a flat surface and different weights are placed on it, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with weight of the compression of the spring is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The elastic limit of the spring has not been exceeded.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/08Two trolleys, of masses 800 g and 2400 g, are free to move on a horizontal table. The spring in (a) is placed between the trolleys and the trolleys are tied together using thread so that the compression of the spring is 3.5 cm, as shown in Fig. 2.3.  (DIAGRAM)  Initially, the trolleys are not moving. The thread is then cut and the trolleys move apart.   Use the answers in (a)(ii) and (b)(i) to calculate the speed of the trolley of mass 800 g.   speed = ........................................... m s–1 [3]
Mark Scheme: energy stored in spring = kinetic energy of trolleys 0.49 = ½ × 2.4 × (v)2 + ½ × 0.8 × v2 v = 0.96 m s–1 (if only one trolley considered, or masses combined, allow max 1 mark) C1 C1 A1   [3]
Explanation:
The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is converted into the kinetic energy of both trolleys when released. Using conservation of energy:  
Energy stored \( = 0.49 \, \text{J} = \frac{1}{2}m_1v_1^2 + \frac{1}{2}m_2v_2^2 \).  

By conservation of momentum (\( m_1v_1 = m_2v_2 \)):  
\( v_2 = \frac{m_1}{m_2}v_1 = \frac{0.8}{2.4}v_1 = \frac{v_1}{3} \).  

Substitute \( v_2 \) into the energy equation:  
\( 0.49 = \frac{1}{2}(0.8)v_1^2 + \frac{1}{2}(2.4)\left(\frac{v_1}{3}\right)^2 \).  
Simplify:  
\( 0.49 = 0.4v_1^2 + 0.133v_1^2 \).  
Combine terms:  
\( 0.49 = 0.533v_1^2 \).  
Solve:  
\( v_1 = \sqrt{\frac{0.49}{0.533}} \approx 0.96 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

**Speed of 800 g trolley = 0.96 m s⁻¹**  
[3]

Question: Fig. 5.1 shows the variation with force F of the extension x of a spring as the force is increased to F3 and then decreased to zero.  (DIAGRAM)   Q5/9702/02/M/J/06State, with a reason, whether the spring is undergoing an elastic change. ..................................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: no hysteresis loop/no permanent deformation (do not allow 'force proportional to extension') so elastic change M1  A0 [1]
Explanation:
The spring is undergoing an elastic change because the force-extension graph shows no hysteresis loop. When the force is decreased back to zero, the extension returns to the original value, indicating no permanent deformation.  

[1]

Question: Fig. 5.1 shows the variation with force F of the extension x of a spring as the force is increased to F3 and then decreased to zero.  (DIAGRAM)   Q5/9702/02/M/J/06The extension of the spring is increased from x1 to x2. Show that the work W done in extending the spring is given by         W = ½k(x22 – x12), where k is the spring constant. [3]
Mark Scheme: work done = area under graph line OR average force × distance                   = ½Fx      ½(F2 + F1)(x2 – x1) F = kx, so work done = = ½kx2    ½k(x2 + x1)(x2 – x1) work done = ½k(x22 – x12) B1 A1 A1 A0 [3]
Explanation:
The work done in stretching the spring from \( x_1 \) to \( x_2 \) is equal to the area under the force-extension graph between these points. Since \( F = kx \), the graph is linear.  

The area under the graph forms a trapezoid, which can be calculated as:  
\[
\text{Work} = \text{average force} \times \text{extension} = \frac{1}{2}(F_1 + F_2)(x_2 - x_1).
\]  
Substituting \( F_1 = kx_1 \) and \( F_2 = kx_2 \):  
\[
\text{Work} = \frac{1}{2}(kx_1 + kx_2)(x_2 - x_1) = \frac{1}{2}k(x_1 + x_2)(x_2 - x_1).
\]  
Expanding the terms:  
\[
(x_1 + x_2)(x_2 - x_1) = x_2^2 - x_1^2.
\]  
Thus, the work done is:  
\[
W = \frac{1}{2}k(x_2^2 - x_1^2).
\]  

[3]

Question: Fig. 5.1 shows the variation with force F of the extension x of a spring as the force is increased to F3 and then decreased to zero.  (DIAGRAM)   Q5/9702/02/M/J/06A trolley of mass 850 g is held between two fixed points by means of identical springs, as shown in Fig. 5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  When the trolley is in equilibrium, the springs are each extended by 4.5 cm. Each spring has a spring constant 16 N cm–1. The trolley is moved a distance of 1.5 cm along the direction of the springs. This causes the extension of one spring to be increased and the extension of the other spring to be decreased. The trolley is then released. The trolley accelerates and reaches its maximum speed at the equilibrium position. Assuming that the springs obey Hooke’s law, use the expression in (b) to determine the maximum speed of the trolley.  speed = …………………………. m s–1 [4]
Mark Scheme: gain in energy of trolley = ½k(0.0602 – 0.0452) + ½k(0.0302 – 0.0452)                                        = 0.36 J kinetic energy = ½ × 0.85 × v2 = 0.36 v = 0.92 m s–1 C1 C1 C1 A1 [4]
Explanation:
The maximum speed occurs when all elastic potential energy is converted to kinetic energy. Initially, the extensions are 6.0 cm and 3.0 cm. At equilibrium, both are 4.5 cm.  

**Elastic potential energy change:**  
For each spring:  
Initial energy = \( \frac{1}{2} \times 1600 \, \text{N/m} \times (0.060^2 + 0.030^2) \, \text{m}^2 \)  
Equilibrium energy = \( \frac{1}{2} \times 1600 \, \text{N/m} \times (2 \times 0.045^2) \, \text{m}^2 \)  

Net energy transferred to kinetic energy:  
\( \Delta E = \frac{1}{2} \times 1600 \times [(0.060^2 - 0.045^2) + (0.030^2 - 0.045^2)] = 0.36 \, \text{J} \).  

**Kinetic energy equation:**  
\( 0.36 = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.85 \, \text{kg} \times v^2 \).  
Solving:  
\( v = \sqrt{\frac{2 \times 0.36}{0.85}} \approx 0.92 \, \text{m/s} \).  

Speed = **0.92 m/s**.  

[4]

Question: Define pressure. ......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: pressure = force / area (normal to force) A1 [1]
Explanation:
Pressure is the force exerted per unit area, where the force acts perpendicular (normal) to the surface.  

(Expressed as \( P = \frac{F}{A} \), with \( F \) perpendicular to area \( A \).)  

[1]

Question: Use the kinetic model to explain the pressure exerted by a gas. ......................................................................... [4]
Mark Scheme: molecules/atoms/particles in (constant) random/haphazard motion molecules have a change in momentum when they collide with the walls (force exerted on molecules) therefore force on the walls reference to average force from many molecules/many collisions B1 M1 A1 A1 [4]
Explanation:
Gas particles are in constant random motion. When they collide with the container walls, their momentum changes (Δp = 2mv for elastic collisions), exerting a force on the wall (Newton’s second law: force = rate of change of momentum). Each collision contributes a tiny force, but the average force from billions of collisions per second across the wall’s area produces a measurable pressure. Thus, pressure arises from the cumulative effect of many particles colliding with the walls.  

[4]

Question: Explain whether the collisions between the molecules of an ideal gas are elastic or inelastic. ......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: elastic collision when kinetic energy conserved temperature constant for gas B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The collisions between molecules of an ideal gas are elastic.  
In an elastic collision, the total kinetic energy of the system is conserved.  
For an ideal gas, the temperature (and thus the average kinetic energy of molecules) remains constant in the absence of external energy transfer.  
If collisions were inelastic, kinetic energy would be lost, leading to a temperature decrease, contradicting ideal gas behaviour.  

[2]

Question: Show that the pressure P due to a liquid of density ρ is proportional to the depth h below the surface of the liquid. [4]
Mark Scheme: V = h × A m = V × ρ W = h × A × ρ × g P = F / A P = hρg P is proportional to h if ρ is constant (and g)  B1 B1 B1  B1 [4]
Explanation:
To show that pressure \( P \) due to a liquid of density \( \rho \) is proportional to depth \( h \):  

Consider a horizontal surface of area \( A \) at depth \( h \). The volume of liquid above this surface is \( V = hA \). The mass of this liquid is \( m = \rho V = \rho hA \). The weight of the liquid (force exerted) is \( W = mg = \rho hA g \).  

Pressure \( P \) is force per unit area:  
\( P = \frac{F}{A} = \frac{\rho hA g}{A} = \rho g h \).  

Since \( \rho \) and \( g \) are constants, \( P \propto h \). Thus, pressure increases linearly with depth.  

[4]

Question: The pressure of the air at the top of a mountain is less than that at the foot of the mountain. Explain why the difference in air pressure is not proportional to the difference in height as suggested by the relationship in (a). ...............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: density changes with height hence density is not constant with link to formula B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The pressure difference formula \( \Delta P = \rho g h \) assumes air density \( \rho \) is constant.  
However, air density decreases with height as pressure decreases.  
Since \( \rho \) becomes smaller at higher altitudes, the pressure difference does **not** decrease linearly with height.  
The non-constant density invalidates the proportional relationship implied by the formula.  

[2]

Question: Q6/9702/21/M/J/11State two assumptions of the simple kinetic model of a gas. 1. ............................................................................. 2. ............................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: any two of:  large number of molecules / atoms / particles  molecules in random motion  no intermolecular forces  elastic collisions  time of collisions much less than time between collisions  volume of molecules much less than volume of containing vessel B1 + B1 [2]
Explanation:
1. The gas consists of a large number of molecules moving in random motion.  
2. The collisions between molecules and the container walls are perfectly elastic.  

[2]

Question: Q6/9702/21/M/J/11Use the kinetic model of gases and Newton's laws of motion to explain how a gas exerts a pressure on the sides of its container. ................................................................................. [3]
Mark Scheme: molecules collide with the walls change in momentum of molecules implies force (on molecules) molecules exert equal and opposite force on wall pressure is averaging effect of many collisions (any three statements, 1 each) B3 [3]
Explanation: Gas molecules move randomly and collide elastically with the container walls. During each collision, a molecule experiences a change in momentum (Δp = 2mv for a perpendicular collision), which, by Newton’s second law, produces a force on the wall (force = rate of change of momentum). By Newton’s third law, the wall exerts an equal and opposite force on the molecule. Pressure arises as the average force per unit area from the vast number of collisions occurring continuously across the walls. (DIAGRAM: molecules shown colliding with a container wall, arrows indicating momentum changes and equal/opposite forces on wall and molecule.)

Question: Explain what is meant by the internal energy of a substance. ....................................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: sum of (random) kinetic and potential energies of the atoms/molecules of the substance M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The internal energy of a substance is the total sum of the random kinetic energies (due to the motion of its atoms/molecules) and the potential energies (arising from intermolecular forces between these particles).  

[2]

Question: State and explain, in molecular terms, whether the internal energy of the following increases, decreases or does not change.  a lump of iron as it cooled ....................................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: potential energy unchanged as atoms remain in same positions allow 'reduced because atoms slightly closer together'  vibrational kinetic energy reduced because temperature lower so internal energy less M1  M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
As the lump of iron cools, its internal energy decreases.  

Internal energy comprises the kinetic and potential energies of its atoms. In the solid iron lattice, the atoms vibrate about fixed positions. When cooled, the **vibrational kinetic energy** of the atoms decreases because temperature is proportional to average kinetic energy. The **potential energy** of the atoms (from intermolecular forces) remains largely unchanged, as the lattice structure and atomic spacing do not significantly alter during cooling (ignoring minor thermal contraction). Thus, the overall internal energy decreases due to the reduction in kinetic energy.  

[3]

Question: State and explain, in molecular terms, whether the internal energy of the following increases, decreases or does not change.  some water as it evaporates at constant temperature ....................................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: potential energy increases because separation increases kinetic energy unchanged because temperature unchanged so internal energy increases M1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
As the water evaporates at constant temperature, the internal energy increases.  
In molecular terms, the potential energy of the molecules increases because the separation between molecules becomes larger as they transition from liquid to gas, overcoming intermolecular forces.  
The average kinetic energy of the molecules remains unchanged since the temperature (and thus the thermal motion) is constant.  
As internal energy is the sum of kinetic and potential energies, the increase in potential energy leads to an overall increase in internal energy.  

[3]

Question: Define the terms  power,  ..................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: power = work done per unit time / energy transferred per unit time / rate of work done B1 [1]
Explanation:
Power is defined as the work done per unit time, or equivalently, the rate at which energy is transferred.  

[1]

Question: Define the terms  the Young modulus.   ...................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: Young modulus = stress / strain B1 [1]
Explanation:
The Young modulus is defined as the ratio of stress to strain.  

[1]

Question: A crane is used to lift heavy objects, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The motor in the crane lifts a total mass of 1800 kg from rest on the ground. The cable supporting the mass is made of steel of Young modulus 2.4×1011 Pa. The cross-sectional area of the cable is 1.3×10– 4 m2. As the mass leaves the ground, the strain in the cable is 0.0010. Assume the weight of the cable to be negligible.   1. Use the Young Modulus of the steel to show that the tension in the cable is 3.1×104 N. [2]  2. Calculate the acceleration of the mass as it is lifted from the ground.   acceleration = .................................. m s–2 [3]
Explanation:
1. Young modulus \( E = \frac{\text{stress}}{\text{strain}} \). Rearranging, tension \( T = E \times A \times \text{strain} \).  
Substituting values:  
\( T = 2.4 \times 10^{11} \, \text{Pa} \times 1.3 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{m}^2 \times 0.0010 = 3.12 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} \).  
Thus, tension \( T = 3.1 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} \).  

2. Using Newton’s second law:  
\( T - mg = ma \).  
Weight \( W = 1800 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 1.766 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} \).  
Net force: \( 3.12 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} - 1.766 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} = 1.354 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} \).  
Acceleration: \( a = \frac{1.354 \times 10^4 \, \text{N}}{1800 \, \text{kg}} = 7.52 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).  

[2][3]

Question: A crane is used to lift heavy objects, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The motor in the crane lifts a total mass of 1800 kg from rest on the ground. The cable supporting the mass is made of steel of Young modulus 2.4×1011 Pa. The cross-sectional area of the cable is 1.3×10– 4 m2. As the mass leaves the ground, the strain in the cable is 0.0010. Assume the weight of the cable to be negligible.   The motor now lifts the mass through a height of 15 m at a constant speed. Calculate 1. the tension in the lifting cable,      tension = ....................................... N [1] 2. the gain in potential energy of the mass.      gain in potential energy = ............................... J [2]
Explanation:
1. The tension in the lifting cable is equal to the weight of the mass since it is lifted at constant speed (no acceleration).  
   \( T = mg = 1800 \times 9.81 = 1.8 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} \).  

2. The gain in gravitational potential energy is calculated using \( \Delta E_p = mgh \):  
   \( \Delta E_p = 1800 \times 9.81 \times 15 = 2.7 \times 10^5 \, \text{J} \).  

[Answers: 1. \( 1.8 \times 10^4 \, \text{N} \); 2. \( 2.7 \times 10^5 \, \text{J} \)]

Question: A crane is used to lift heavy objects, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The motor in the crane lifts a total mass of 1800 kg from rest on the ground. The cable supporting the mass is made of steel of Young modulus 2.4×1011 Pa. The cross-sectional area of the cable is 1.3×10– 4 m2. As the mass leaves the ground, the strain in the cable is 0.0010. Assume the weight of the cable to be negligible.   The motor of the crane is 30% efficient. Calculate the input power to the motor required to lift the mass at a constant speed of 0.55 m s–1.  input power = ...................................... W [3]
Explanation:
The motor's output power is calculated using \( P = Fv \), where \( F \) is the force (weight of the mass):  
\( F = 1800 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 17658 \, \text{N} \).  
Output power:  
\( P = 17658 \, \text{N} \times 0.55 \, \text{m/s} = 9711.9 \, \text{W} \).  

Since the motor is 30% efficient, input power is:  
\( \frac{9711.9}{0.30} = 32373 \, \text{W} \),  
rounded to \( 32.4 \times 10^3 \, \text{W} \).  

Input power = \( 32.4 \times 10^3 \, \text{W} \).  

[3]

Question: Distinguish between gravitational potential energy and electric potential energy. .................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: electrical potential energy (stored) when charge moved and gravitational potential energy (stored) when mass moved due to work done in electric field and work done in gravitational field B1 B1 [2]
Explanation: Gravitational potential energy is the energy stored when a mass is moved within a gravitational field, arising from work done against gravitational forces. Electric potential energy is the energy stored when a charge is moved within an electric field, resulting from work done against or by electric forces. [2]

Question: A body of mass m moves vertically through a distance h near the Earth's surface. Use the defining equation for work done to derive an expression for the gravitational potential energy change of the body. [2]
Mark Scheme: work done = force × distance moved (in direction of force) and force = mg mg × h or mg × ∆h  M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The work done on the body is equal to the gravitational force (weight = *mg*) multiplied by the vertical distance *h* moved. Since the force and displacement are in the same direction, the gravitational potential energy change is:  
∆U = *mgh*.  

(Work done = force × distance = *mg* × *h*. This equals the gain/loss in gravitational potential energy depending on direction of motion.)  

[2]

Question: Water flows down a stream from a reservoir and then causes a water wheel to rotate, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  As the water falls through a vertical height of 120 m, gravitational potential energy is converted to different forms of energy, including kinetic energy of the water. At the water wheel, the kinetic energy of the water is only 10% of its gravitational potential energy at the reservoir.   Show that the speed of the water as it reaches the wheel is 15 m s–1. [2]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential energy (GPE) of the water is converted into kinetic energy (KE) at the wheel. Since only 10% of the GPE becomes KE:  
0.1 × *mgh* = ½ *mv*².  
Mass *m* cancels out:  
0.1 × 9.81 × 120 = 0.5 × *v*².  
Calculating the left side:  
0.1 × 9.81 × 120 = 117.72.  
Thus,  
117.72 = 0.5*v*² → *v*² = 235.44 → *v* = √235.44 ≈ 15.3 m/s.  
Rounded, this gives *v* ≈ **15 m/s**, as required.  

[2]

Question: Water flows down a stream from a reservoir and then causes a water wheel to rotate, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  As the water falls through a vertical height of 120 m, gravitational potential energy is converted to different forms of energy, including kinetic energy of the water. At the water wheel, the kinetic energy of the water is only 10% of its gravitational potential energy at the reservoir.   The rotating water wheel is used to produce 110 kW of electrical power. Calculate the mass of water flowing per second through the wheel, assuming that the production of electric energy from the kinetic energy of the water is 25% efficient.  mass of water per second = ......................... kg s–1 [3]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential energy (GPE) lost per second by the water is \( mgh \), where \( \frac{m}{t} \) is the mass flow rate.  
KE at wheel = 10% of GPE:  
\( 0.1 \times mgh \).  

Electrical power output = 25% of this KE:  
\( 0.25 \times 0.1 \times mgh = 0.025mgh \).  

Given \( P = 110 \times 10^3 \, \text{W} \):  
\( 0.025 \times mgh = 110 \times 10^3 \).  

Rearranging for \( \frac{m}{t} \):  
\( \frac{m}{t} = \frac{110 \times 10^3}{0.025 \times 9.81 \times 120} \).  

Calculating denominator:  
\( 0.025 \times 9.81 \times 120 = 29.43 \).  

Thus:  
\( \frac{m}{t} = \frac{110,000}{29.43} ≈ 3740 \, \text{kg s}^{-1} \).  

**Answer**: 3740 kg s⁻¹.

Mark Scheme: product of force and distance moved (by force) in the direction of the force M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Work done is defined as the product of the force applied to an object and the distance moved by the object **in the direction of the force**.  

[2]

Question: Define what is meant by  power.  ................................................................................................................................... .............................................................................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: work (done) per unit time (idea of ratio needed) B1 [1]
Explanation: Power is defined as the rate at which work is done, calculated as work done divided by the time taken to do that work.

Question: A force F is acting on a body that is moving with velocity v in the direction of the force. Derive an expression relating the power P dissipated by the force to F and v.        [2]
Mark Scheme: either work/time or power = (force × distance)/time to give power = force × velocity M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Power is the rate of doing work.  
Work done \( W = F \times d \).  
Power \( P = \frac{W}{t} = \frac{F \times d}{t} \).  
Since velocity \( v = \frac{d}{t} \), substituting gives \( P = F \times v \).  

Power \( P = Fv \).  

[2]

Question: A car of mass 1900 kg accelerates from rest to a speed of 27 m s–1 in 8.1 s.  Calculate the average rate at which kinetic energy is supplied to the car during the acceleration.        rate = ………………………. W [2]
Explanation:
The kinetic energy gained by the car is calculated using \( KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).  
Substituting \( m = 1900 \, \text{kg} \) and \( v = 27 \, \text{m/s} \):  
\( KE = \frac{1}{2} \times 1900 \times 27^2 = 692{,}550 \, \text{J} \).  

The average power (rate of energy transfer) is \( P = \frac{KE}{t} \).  
With \( t = 8.1 \, \text{s} \):  
\( P = \frac{692{,}550}{8.1} = 85{,}500 \, \text{W} \).  

**Final answer:** \( 8.55 \times 10^4 \, \text{W} \).  

[2]

Mark Scheme: either for equal increments of speed, increments of EK are different   so longer time (to increase speed) at high speeds  M1 A1 [2] or air resistance increases with speed (M1)   so driving force (and acceleration) reduced (A1)   or P (= Fv) = mav (M1)   (P and m constant) so when v increases, a decreases (A1)
Explanation:
The car's engine provides constant power \( P \), and since \( P = Fv \), the driving force \( F \) decreases as velocity \( v \) increases. Initially, when \( v \) is low, \( F \) is large, resulting in high acceleration \( a \) (\( a = F/m \)). As \( v \) rises, \( F \) diminishes, reducing \( a \). Thus, acceleration cannot remain constant because \( F \) (and hence \( a \)) is inversely proportional to \( v \) under constant power.  

Alternatively, kinetic energy \( KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \) increases quadratically with \( v \). For equal speed increments, the required energy rises at higher speeds. With constant power (\( \frac{KE}{t} \)), more time is needed for each increment, implying reduced acceleration as \( v \) increases.  

[2]

Question: Explain what is meant by the concept of work. ..........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: force  × distance moved  in the direction of the force M1 A1 [2]
Explanation: Work is defined as the product of the force applied to an object and the distance the object moves **in the direction of that force**. For example, if a force of 10 N pushes an object 5 m forward, the work done is \(10 \, \text{N} \times 5 \, \text{m} = 50 \, \text{J}\). Work is only done when there is displacement **parallel** to the force. If the force and displacement are perpendicular, no work is performed.

Question: Using your answer to (a), derive an expression for the increase in gravitational potential energy ΔEp when an object of mass m is raised vertically through a distance Δh near the Earth's surface.  The acceleration of free fall near the Earth's surtace is g. [2]
Mark Scheme: weight / force = mg ΔEp  = mg × Δh  (mo marks for quote of mgΔh) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The gravitational force (weight) acting on the object is \( F = mg \).  
When the object is raised through a vertical distance \( \Delta h \), the work done against gravity (which equals \( \Delta E_p \)) is:  
\( \Delta E_p = F \times \Delta h = mg \times \Delta h \).  

Thus, \( \Delta E_p = mg\Delta h \).  

[2]

Question: An object falls vertically from rest through air. State and explain the energy conversions that occur as the object falls. ............................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: loss in potential energy due to decrease in height (as P.E. = mgh) gain in kinetic energy due to increase in speed (as K.E. = ½ mv2)  special case 'as PE decreases KE increases' (1/2) increase in thermal energy due to work done against air resistance loss in P.E. equals gain in K.E. and thermal energy  (max. 3) (B1) (B1)  (B1) (B1) [3]
Explanation:
As the object falls, gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh) decreases because its height reduces. Simultaneously, kinetic energy (KE = ½ mv²) increases as its speed rises. However, some PE is converted into thermal energy in the object and the surrounding air due to work done against air resistance. Thus, the total loss in PE equals the combined gain in KE and thermal energy.  

[3]

Question: A ball of mass 150 g is thrown vertically upwards with an initial speed of 25 m s–1.  Calculate the initial kinetic energy of the ball.   kinetic energy = .............................................. J [2]
Mark Scheme: kinetic energy = ½ mv2   = ½ × 0.150 × (25)2    = 46.875 = 47J C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The initial kinetic energy is calculated using \( KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).  
Mass \( m = 150 \, \text{g} = 0.150 \, \text{kg} \).  
Velocity \( v = 25 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  
\( KE = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.150 \times (25)^2 = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.150 \times 625 = 46.875 \, \text{J} \).  
Rounded to 47 J.  

**kinetic energy = 47 J**  
[3]

Question: A ball of mass 150 g is thrown vertically upwards with an initial speed of 25 m s–1.  The ball reaches a height of 21 m above the point of release. For the ball rising to this height, calculate 1. the loss of energy of the ball to air resistance,      energy loss = ............................................... J [3] 2. the average force due to the air resistance.      force = .............................................. N [3]
Mark Scheme: 1. potential energy (= mgh) = 0.150 × 9.81 × 21    loss = KE – mgh = 46.875 – (30.9)      = 15.97 = 16J C1 C1 A1 [3] 2. work done = 16J    work done = force × distance    F = 16 / 21 = 0.76N  C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
1. The initial kinetic energy of the ball is calculated as:  
\( KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.150 \, \text{kg} \times (25 \, \text{ms}^{-1})^2 = 46.875 \, \text{J} \).  
The gravitational potential energy at 21 m is:  
\( PE = mgh = 0.150 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{ms}^{-2} \times 21 \, \text{m} = 30.9 \, \text{J} \).  
Energy loss due to air resistance:  
\( 46.875 \, \text{J} - 30.9 \, \text{J} = 15.97 \, \text{J} ≈ 16 \, \text{J} \).  

2. The work done by air resistance equals the energy loss (16 J). Using \( \text{work} = \text{force} \times \text{distance} \):  
\( F = \frac{16 \, \text{J}}{21 \, \text{m}} = 0.76 \, \text{N} \).  

[Energy loss: 16 J; Force: 0.76 N]

Question: Q2/9702/21/M/J/11Explain what is meant by work done. ............................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: work done is the force × the distance moved / displacement in the direction of the force or work is done when a force moves in the direction of the force B1 [1]
Explanation:
Work done is the product of the force applied to an object and the distance the object moves **in the direction of the force**.  
Alternatively, work is done when a force causes a displacement **in the direction** of that force.  

[1]

Question: Q2/9702/21/M/J/11A car is travelling along a road that has a uniform downhill gradient, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The car has a total mass of 850 kg. The angle of the road to the horizontal is 7.5°. Calculate the component of the weight of the car down the slope  component of weight = ............................................. N [2]
Mark Scheme: component of weight = 850 × 9.81 × sin 7.5° = 1090 N (use of incorrect trigonometric function, 0/2) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The component of the weight down the slope is calculated using \( W_{\text{parallel}} = mg \sin \theta \).  
Substituting values:  
\( W_{\text{parallel}} = 850 \times 9.81 \times \sin 7.5^\circ \).  
Calculating \( \sin 7.5^\circ \approx 0.1305 \):  
\( W_{\text{parallel}} = 850 \times 9.81 \times 0.1305 = 1090 \, \text{N} \).  

**Component of weight = 1090 N**  

[2]

Question: Q2/9702/21/M/J/11The car in (b) is travelling at a constant speed of 25 m s–1. The driver then applies the brakes to stop the car. The constant force resisting the motion of the car is 4600 N.  Show that the deceleration of the car with the brakes applied is 4.1 m s–2. [2]
Explanation:
To determine the deceleration, we calculate the net force acting on the car.  
When the brakes are applied, the total resistive force is **4600 N**. From part (b), when the car travelled at constant speed, the driving force balanced the initial resistive force (**1090 N**).  

The net decelerating force is:  
**ΣF = 4600 N (braking) − 1090 N (previous driving force) = 3510 N**.  

Using **F = ma**:  
Deceleration **a = ΣF / m = 3510 N / 850 kg ≈ 4.1 m s⁻²**.  

[2]

Question: Q2/9702/21/M/J/11The car in (b) is travelling at a constant speed of 25 m s–1. The driver then applies the brakes to stop the car. The constant force resisting the motion of the car is 4600 N.  Calculate the distance the car travels from when the brakes are applied until the car comes to rest.  distance = ............................................. m [2]
Mark Scheme: v2 = u2 + 2as 0 = 252 + 2 × – 4.1 × s s = 625 / 8.2    = 76 m (allow full credit for calculation of time (6.05 s) & then s)  C1  A1   [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the stopping distance, we use the kinematic equation \( v^2 = u^2 + 2as \).  
Initial speed \( u = 25 \, \text{m/s} \), final speed \( v = 0 \).  
Deceleration \( a = \frac{F}{m} \). Assuming \( a = 4.1 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) (from force and mass in part (b)):  
\( 0 = 25^2 + 2(-4.1)s \).  
Rearranging:  
\( s = \frac{625}{8.2} = 76 \, \text{m} \).  

**Distance = 76 m**  

[2]

Question: Q2/9702/21/M/J/11The car in (b) is travelling at a constant speed of 25 m s–1. The driver then applies the brakes to stop the car. The constant force resisting the motion of the car is 4600 N.  Calculate 1. the loss of kinetic energy of the car,      loss of kinetic energy = ............................... J [2] 2. the work done by the resisting force of 4600 N.      work done = .............................................. J [1]
Explanation:
1. The loss of kinetic energy is calculated using \( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \):  
\( KE = 0.5 \times 850 \, \text{kg} \times (25 \, \text{m/s})^2 = 265,625 \, \text{J} \),  
which rounds to **2.7 × 10⁵ J** (2 significant figures).  

2. The work done by the resisting force is \( \text{force} \times \text{distance} \). Using the stopping distance from part (b) (75.7 m):  
\( W = 4600 \, \text{N} \times 75.7 \, \text{m} = 348,220 \, \text{J} \),  
which rounds to **3.5 × 10⁵ J**.  

[Answers: 1. \( 2.7 \times 10^5 \, \text{J} \); 2. \( 3.5 \times 10^5 \, \text{J} \)]

Question: Q2/9702/21/M/J/11The car in (b) is travelling at a constant speed of 25 m s–1. The driver then applies the brakes to stop the car. The constant force resisting the motion of the car is 4600 N.  The quantities in (iii) part 1 and in (iii) part 2 are not equal. Explain why these two quantities are not equal. .......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: difference is the loss in potential energy (owtte) B1 [1]
Explanation: The two quantities are not equal because the difference between them corresponds to the change in gravitational potential energy of the car. When the car stops, part of the energy is dissipated through the braking force, and another part is associated with the car’s elevation (or descent) relative to its initial position, leading to a loss (or gain) in potential energy. This accounts for the inequality.

Question: Two planks of wood AB and BC are inclined at an angle of 15° to the horizontal. The two wooden planks are joined at point B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A small block of metal M is released from rest at point A. It slides down the slope to B and up the opposite side to C. Points A and C are 0.26 m above B. Assume frictional forces are negligible.  Describe and explain the acceleration of M as it travels from A to B and from B to C. .................................................................. [3]
Mark Scheme: accelerations (A to B and B to C) are same magnitude accelerations (A to B and B to C) are opposite directions or both accelerations are toward B (A to B and B to C) the component of the weight down the slope provides the acceleration B1  B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
The acceleration of the metal block has the same magnitude in both directions (A to B and B to C) because the component of the gravitational force along each slope is identical (mg sin15°). From A to B, the acceleration is directed down the slope toward B, causing the block to speed up. From B to C, the acceleration remains directed down the slope toward B (opposite to the block’s upward motion), causing it to decelerate. Thus, the acceleration is always toward point B with magnitude g sin15°, resulting in symmetrical acceleration magnitudes in both segments. 

[3]

Question: Two planks of wood AB and BC are inclined at an angle of 15° to the horizontal. The two wooden planks are joined at point B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A small block of metal M is released from rest at point A. It slides down the slope to B and up the opposite side to C. Points A and C are 0.26 m above B. Assume frictional forces are negligible.  Calculate the time taken for M to travel from A to B.   time = ............................................. s [3]
Mark Scheme: acceleration = gsin15° s = 0 + ½ at2  s = 0.26 / sin 15° = 1.0   t = 0.89 s C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The block slides down the incline with acceleration \( a = g \sin 15^\circ \).  
The distance \( AB \) is \( s = \frac{0.26}{\sin 15^\circ} \approx 1.0 \, \text{m} \).  
Using \( s = \frac{1}{2} a t^2 \):  
\( 1.0 = \frac{1}{2} \times (9.81 \sin 15^\circ) \times t^2 \).  
Calculating \( a \approx 2.54 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \),  
\( t = \sqrt{\frac{2 \times 1.0}{2.54}} \approx 0.89 \, \text{s} \).  

Time = **0.89 s**  
[3]

Question: Two planks of wood AB and BC are inclined at an angle of 15° to the horizontal. The two wooden planks are joined at point B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A small block of metal M is released from rest at point A. It slides down the slope to B and up the opposite side to C. Points A and C are 0.26 m above B. Assume frictional forces are negligible.  Calculate the speed of M at B.   speed = ...................................... m s–1 [2]
Mark Scheme: v = 0 + g sin15t  or  v2 = 0 + 2gsin15 × 1.0 v = 2.26 ms–1 (using loss of GPE = gain KE can score full marks)  C1 A1   [2]
Explanation:
The metal block loses gravitational potential energy (GPE) as it moves from A to B, converting it into kinetic energy (KE). Using conservation of energy:  
Loss in GPE = Gain in KE  
\( mgh = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).  

Mass \( m \) cancels out:  
\( v = \sqrt{2gh} \).
