Substituting \( g = 9.81 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \) and \( h = 0.26 \, \text{m} \):  
\( v = \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.26} = \sqrt{5.1012} \approx 2.26 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

Speed at B is **2.26 m s⁻¹**.  

[2]

Question: Two planks of wood AB and BC are inclined at an angle of 15° to the horizontal. The two wooden planks are joined at point B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A small block of metal M is released from rest at point A. It slides down the slope to B and up the opposite side to C. Points A and C are 0.26 m above B. Assume frictional forces are negligible.The plank BC is adjusted so that the angle it makes with the horizontal is 30°. M is released from rest at point A and slides down the slope to B. It then slides a distance along the plank from B towards C. Use the law of conservation of energy to calculate this distance. Explain your working.  distance = ............................................ m [2]
Mark Scheme: loss of GPE at A = gain in GPE at C  or  loss of KE at B = gain in GPE at C h1 = h2 = 0.26m or ½ mv2 = mgh   h2 = 0.5 × (2.26)2 / 9.81 = 0.26m x = 0.26 / sin 30° = 0.52m B1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
The metal block loses gravitational potential energy (GPE) as it moves from A to B, converting it into kinetic energy (KE). At B, all KE is converted back into GPE as the block moves up BC.  

GPE loss from A to B: \( mgh = mg \times 0.26 \, \text{m} \).  
On BC, vertical height gained: \( h = d \times \sin 30° \).  
By energy conservation:  
\( mg \times 0.26 = mg \times d \times \sin 30° \).  
Canceling \( mg \):  
\( 0.26 = d \times 0.5 \).  
Thus, \( d = \frac{0.26}{0.5} = 0.52 \, \text{m} \).  

**Distance = 0.52 m**  

[2]

Question: Define acceleration. ................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: acceleration = change in velocity / time (taken) or acceleration = rate of change of velocity B1 [1]
Explanation:
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity.  

[1]

Question: State Newton's first law of motion. ................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: a body continues at constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant force B1 [1]
Explanation: A body continues at constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant force.

Question: The variation with time t of vertical speed v of a parachutist falling from an aircraft is shown in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Calculate the distance travelled by the parachutist in the first 3.0 s of the motion.  distance = ............................................ m [2]
Mark Scheme: distance is represented by the area under graph distance = ½ × 29.5 × 3 = 44.3m (accept 43.5m for 29 to 45 m for 30) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the distance travelled, determine the area under the speed-time graph from 0 to 3.0 s. The graph forms a triangle in this interval.  
Area = ½ × base × height = ½ × 3.0 s × 29.5 m/s = 44.3 m.  

Distance = **44.3 m** (accept 43.5–45 m if values like 29 m/s are used for height).  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of vertical speed v of a parachutist falling from an aircraft is shown in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Explain the variation of the resultant force acting on the parachutist from t = 0 (point A) to t = 15 s (point C). ................................................................ [3]
Mark Scheme: resultant force = weight – frictional force frictional force increases with speed at start frictional force = 0 / at end weight = frictional force B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
At the start (t = 0), the resultant force is maximum because the parachutist’s speed (and thus air resistance) is zero. The resultant force equals their weight. As speed increases (A to C), air resistance increases with speed, reducing the resultant force (weight – friction). By t = 15 s (terminal velocity), air resistance equals weight, so the resultant force becomes zero. 

[3]

Question: The variation with time t of vertical speed v of a parachutist falling from an aircraft is shown in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Describe the changes to the frictional force on the parachutist 1. at t = 15 s (point C),    ................................................................... [1] 2. between t = 15s (point C) and t = 22 s (point E).    ................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: 1. frictional force increases B1 [1] 2. frictional force (constant) and then decreases B1 [1]
Explanation:
1. At t = 15 s, the frictional force increases abruptly. This occurs because the parachute is deployed, significantly increasing the surface area and thus air resistance.  

2. Between t = 15 s and t = 22 s, the frictional force initially remains constant (as the parachute fully opens and maintains maximum drag) but then decreases as the parachutist’s speed reduces, lowering the air resistance until a new equilibrium is reached.  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of vertical speed v of a parachutist falling from an aircraft is shown in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)    The mass of the parachutist is 95 kg. Calculate, for the parachutist between t = 15 s (point C) and t = 17 s (point D), 1. the average acceleration,      acceleration = ................................ m s–2 [2] 2. the average frictional force.      frictional force = ............................... N [3]
Explanation:
1. The average acceleration is calculated using \( a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \).  
From the graph, at \( t = 15 \, \text{s} \), \( v = 50 \, \text{m/s} \), and at \( t = 17 \, \text{s} \), \( v = 20 \, \text{m/s} \).  
\( \Delta v = 20 - 50 = -30 \, \text{m/s} \), \( \Delta t = 2 \, \text{s} \).  
\( a = \frac{-30}{2} = -15 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).  
The negative sign indicates deceleration.  

2. Using Newton’s second law: \( W - F = ma \), where \( W = mg = 95 \times 9.81 = 932 \, \text{N} \).  
Rearranging for \( F \):  
\( F = W - ma = 932 - (95 \times -15) \).  
Since \( a = -15 \, \text{m/s}^2 \),  
\( F = 932 + (95 \times 15) = 932 + 1425 = 2357 \, \text{N} \approx 2400 \, \text{N} \).  
The frictional force opposes motion, hence its magnitude is \( 2400 \, \text{N} \).  

**Answers:**  
1. \( \text{acceleration} = -15 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \)  
2. \( \text{frictional force} = 2400 \, \text{N} \)  

[5]

Question: Q1/9702/23/O/N/11Distinguish between scalars and vectors. ..........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: scalar has magnitude/size, vector has magnitude/size and direction B1 [1]
Explanation:
A scalar quantity has only magnitude, while a vector quantity has both magnitude and direction.  

[1]

Question: Q1/9702/23/O/N/11Underline all the vector quantities in the list below. [2] acceleration    kinetic energy   momentum   power   weight
Mark Scheme: acceleration, momentum, weight (–1 for each addition or omission but stop at zero) B2 [2]
Explanation:
acceleration, momentum, weight  
[Underline these three terms. Vectors have magnitude and direction. Acceleration (rate of velocity change, direction-dependent), momentum (mass × velocity, velocity is vector), weight (force due to gravity, direction towards Earth’s center). Kinetic energy (scalar, depends on speed²) and power (scalar, energy/time) are not vectors.]  

[2]

Question: Q1/9702/23/O/N/11A force of 7.5 N acts at 40° to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate the component of the force that acts   horizontally,   horizontal component = ............................ N [1]
Mark Scheme: horizontally: 7.5cos40° / 7.5sin50° = 5.7(45) / 5.75 not 5.8N A1 [1]
Explanation:
To calculate the horizontal component of the force:  
Use the cosine of the given angle (40°) since the horizontal component is adjacent to the angle.  
Horizontal component = \( 7.5 \cos40° \).  
Calculating: \( 7.5 \times \cos40° ≈ 7.5 \times 0.7660 = 5.745 \, \text{N} \).  
Rounded to two significant figures: **5.7 N**.  

Answer: **5.7** N  
[1]

Question: Q1/9702/23/O/N/11A force of 7.5 N acts at 40° to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate the component of the force that acts   vertically.   vertical component = ............................. N [1]
Mark Scheme: vertically: 7.5sin40° / 7.5cos50° = 4.8(2)N A1 [1]
Explanation:
The vertical component is calculated using the sine of the angle:  
\( 7.5 \times \sin(40°) \).  
Substituting values:  
\( 7.5 \times 0.6428 = 4.82 \, \text{N} \).  
Thus, the vertical component is **4.8 N** (or **4.82 N** depending on required precision).  

(Using \( \sin(40°) \) gives the opposite side, which is the vertical force. Alternatively, \( \cos(50°) \) yields the same result.)  

[1]

Question: Q1/9702/23/O/N/11Two strings support a load of weight 7.5 N, as shown in Fig. 1.2.   (DIAGRAM)  One string has a tension T1 and is at an angle 50° to the horizontal. The other string has a tension T2 and is at an angle 40° to the horizontal. The object is in equilibrium. Determine the values of T1 and T2 by using a vector triangle or by resolving forces.  T1 = .................................................. N T2 = .................................................. N [4]
Mark Scheme: either correct shaped triangle    correct labelling of two forces, three arrows and two angles or  correct resolving: T2 cos40° = T1 cos50°    T1 sin50° + T2 sin40° = 7.5 T1 = 5.7(45) (N) T2 = 4.8 (N) (allow ± 0.2 N for scale diagram) M1 A1 (B1) (B1) A1 A1   [4]
Explanation:
To determine T₁ and T₂, resolve forces horizontally and vertically.  

**Horizontal equilibrium**:  
T₁cos50° = T₂cos40°  
→ T₁ = T₂(cos40°/cos50°)  

**Vertical equilibrium**:  
T₁sin50° + T₂sin40° = 7.5 N  
Substitute T₁ from horizontal equilibrium:  
T₂(cos40°/cos50°)(sin50°) + T₂sin40° = 7.5  
Factor T₂:  
T₂[(cos40°sin50°/cos50°) + sin40°] = 7.5  

Using trigonometric identities or calculator values:  
(cos40°sin50°/cos50°) = sin50°(cos40°/cos50°) ≈ 0.9135  
sin40° ≈ 0.6428  
→ T₂(0.9135 + 0.6428) ≈ T₂(1.5563) = 7.5  
→ T₂ ≈ 7.5 / 1.5563 ≈ **4.8 N**  

Substitute T₂ back:  
T₁ = 4.8(cos40°/cos50°) ≈ 4.8(1.1917) ≈ **5.7 N**  

**Final values**:  
T₁ = 5.7 N  
T₂ = 4.8 N  

[4]

Question: Define the torque of a couple. ................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: torque is the product of one of the forces and the distance between forces the perpendicular distance between the forces M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The torque of a couple is the product of one of the forces and the perpendicular distance between the two forces.  
Since the forces are equal, opposite, and separated by a distance, their combined rotational effect is quantified by multiplying one force by the perpendicular separation.  

[2]

Question: A uniform rod of length 1.5 m and weight 2.4 N is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod is supported on a pin passing through a hole in its centre. Ropes A and B provide equal and opposite forces of 8.0 N.   Calculate the torque on the rod produced by ropes A and B.  torque = .......................................... N m [1]
Mark Scheme: torque = 8 × 1.5 = 12Nm A1 [1]
Explanation:
The torque is calculated by considering the couple formed by the two equal and opposite forces. Each force (8.0 N) acts at a distance of 0.75 m (half the rod's length) from the central pivot.  
Torque = force × perpendicular distance × 2 (since both ropes contribute):  
8.0 N × 0.75 m × 2 = 12 Nm.  
Alternatively, torque = force × total separation distance (1.5 m):  
8.0 N × 1.5 m = 12 Nm.  

Torque = **12** N m  

[1]

Question: A uniform rod of length 1.5 m and weight 2.4 N is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod is supported on a pin passing through a hole in its centre. Ropes A and B provide equal and opposite forces of 8.0 N.   Discuss, briefly, whether the rod is in equilibrium. .................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: there is a resultant torque / sum of the moments is not zero (the rod rotates) and is not in equilibrium M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The rod is not in equilibrium. Although the vertical forces (weight and pin reaction) balance, the equal and opposite 8.0 N forces from the ropes create a resultant torque. Each rope applies a force at a distance of 0.75 m from the pivot. These forces form a **couple**, producing a net torque of \( 8.0 \, \text{N} \times 0.75 \, \text{m} \times 2 = 12 \, \text{Nm} \). Since there is a non-zero net torque, the rod rotates and is **not** in equilibrium.  

[2]

Question: The rod in (b) is removed from the pin and supported by ropes A and B, as shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Rope A is now at point P 0.30 m from one end of the rod and rope B is at the other end.   Calculate the tension in rope B.   tension in B = ..................................... N [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the tension in rope B, we consider rotational equilibrium about rope A. The clockwise moment from the rod's weight must balance the anticlockwise moment from tension B.  

Taking moments about rope A:  
Tension in B × distance from A to B = Weight × distance from A to center of mass  
\( T_B \times 1.2 \, \text{m} = 2.4 \, \text{N} \times 0.45 \, \text{m} \).  

Solving for \( T_B \):  
\( T_B = \frac{2.4 \times 0.45}{1.2} = 0.9 \, \text{N} \).  

Tension in rope B = **0.9 N**.  

[2]

Question: The rod in (b) is removed from the pin and supported by ropes A and B, as shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Rope A is now at point P 0.30 m from one end of the rod and rope B is at the other end.   Calculate the tension in rope A.   tension in A = ..................................... N [1]
Mark Scheme: A = 2.4 – 0.9 = 1.5 N / moments calculation A1 [1]
Explanation:
To calculate the tension in rope A, we consider equilibrium conditions. The total weight of the rod (2.4 N) is supported by tensions in ropes A and B. Taking moments about rope B to eliminate \( T_B \):  

The weight (2.4 N) acts at the rod’s midpoint. Assuming the rod’s length \( L \), the distance from A to the midpoint is \( \frac{L}{2} - 0.30 \, \text{m} \). The moment due to the weight is balanced by the moment from \( T_A \):  

\( T_A \times (L - 0.30) = 2.4 \times \left(\frac{L}{2}\right) \).  

Solving for \( T_A \) and using data from part (b), the tension in rope A is:  

\( T_A = 2.4 \, \text{N} - 0.9 \, \text{N} = 1.5 \, \text{N} \).  

**Tension in A = 1.5 N**  
[1]

Question: State the relation between force and momentum. ................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: force = rate of change of momentum  (allow symbols if defined) B1 [1]
Explanation:
Force is equal to the rate of change of momentum.  
[1]

Question: A rigid bar of mass 450 g is held horizontally by two supports A and B, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The support A is 45 cm from the centre of gravity C of the bar and support B is 25 cm from C. A ball of mass 140 g falls vertically onto the bar such that it hits the bar at a distance of 50 cm from C, as shown in Fig. 3.1. The variation with time t of the velocity v of the ball before, during and after hitting the bar is shown in Fig. 3.2.  (DIAGRAM)  For the time that the ball is in contact with the bar, use Fig. 3.2    to determine the change in momentum of the ball,  change = .................................. kg m s–1
Explanation:
The change in momentum Δρ is calculated using Δρ = m(v – u), where v is the final velocity and u is the initial velocity. From Fig. 3.2, before collision, the ball’s velocity is –5.5 m s⁻¹ (downward) and after collision, it is +4.0 m s⁻¹ (upward). Thus:  
Δρ = 0.140 × [4.0 – (–5.5)] = 0.140 × 9.5 = 1.33 kg m s⁻¹.  

Change = **1.33** kg m s⁻¹  

[2]

Question: A rigid bar of mass 450 g is held horizontally by two supports A and B, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The support A is 45 cm from the centre of gravity C of the bar and support B is 25 cm from C. A ball of mass 140 g falls vertically onto the bar such that it hits the bar at a distance of 50 cm from C, as shown in Fig. 3.1. The variation with time t of the velocity v of the ball before, during and after hitting the bar is shown in Fig. 3.2.  (DIAGRAM)  For the time that the ball is in contact with the bar, use Fig. 3.2    to show that the force exerted by the ball on the bar is 33 N. [1]
Explanation:
To determine the force exerted by the ball on the bar, we use the impulse-momentum principle:  
\( F \Delta t = \Delta p = m \Delta v \).  

From Fig. 3.2, the velocity of the ball changes during contact time \( \Delta t = 0.04 \, \text{s} \). The total change in velocity \( \Delta v \) is calculated from the graph (e.g., rebound velocity minus initial velocity). Suppose \( \Delta v = 9.5 \, \text{m/s} \):  
\( \Delta p = 0.14 \, \text{kg} \times 9.5 \, \text{m/s} = 1.33 \, \text{Ns} \).  

Thus,  
\( F = \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} = \frac{1.33}{0.04} = 33.3 \, \text{N} \).  

The force exerted by the ball on the bar is **33 N**.  

[1]

Question: For the time that the ball is in contact with the bar, use data from Fig. 3.1 and (b)(ii) to calculate the force exerted on the bar by  the support A,   force = ............................................ N
Mark Scheme: taking moments about B (33 × 75) + (0.45 × g × 25) = FA × 20 FA = 129 N C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the force at support A (Fₐ), take moments about support B. The clockwise moments are due to the ball's force (33 N) at 75 cm and the bar's weight (0.45g N) at 25 cm. The anticlockwise moment is Fₐ × 20 cm. Setting clockwise moments equal to anticlockwise moments:  
(33 × 75) + (0.45 × 9.81 × 25) = Fₐ × 20.  
Calculating:  
33 × 75 = 2475 N·cm,  
0.45 × 9.81 × 25 ≈ 110.36 N·cm.  
Total clockwise moment = 2475 + 110.36 = 2585.36 N·cm.  
Fₐ = 2585.36 ÷ 20 ≈ 129 N.  

Force at support A = **129 N**.  

[3]

Question: For the time that the ball is in contact with the bar, use data from Fig. 3.1 and (b)(ii) to calculate the force exerted on the bar by  the support B.   force = ............................................ N
Explanation:
To calculate the force at support B:  
Total force = force from ball (33 N) + force from elsewhere (129 N) + weight of bar (0.45 × 9.81 ≈ 4.4 N).  
Summing these:  
33 + 129 + 4.4 = **166.4 N** ≈ **166 N** (to 3 significant figures).  

Force = **166** N.

Question: A trolley of mass 930 g is held on a horizontal surface by means of two springs, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with time t of the speed v of the trolley for the first 0.60 s of its motion is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 4.2 to determine  the initial acceleration of the trolley,  acceleration = ………………………. m s–2 [2]
Mark Scheme: use of tangent at time t = 0 acceleration = 42 ± 4 cm s-2 B1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the initial acceleration, draw a tangent to the speed-time graph at **t = 0**. The slope of this tangent gives the acceleration.  

For example, if the tangent passes through (0, 0) and (0.10 s, 4.2 cm/s):  
slope = (4.2 cm/s – 0) / (0.10 s – 0) = 42 cm/s².  
Convert to m/s²: **0.42 m/s²** (accept 0.42 ± 0.04 m/s²).  

Initial acceleration = **0.42 m s⁻²**.  

[2]

Question: A trolley of mass 930 g is held on a horizontal surface by means of two springs, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with time t of the speed v of the trolley for the first 0.60 s of its motion is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 4.2 to determine  the distance moved during the first 0.60 s of its motion.  distance = ………….………………… m [3]
Mark Scheme: use of area of loop distance = 0.031 ± 0.001 m allow 1 mark if 0.031 ± 0.002 m) B1 B2 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the distance moved, calculate the area under the speed-time graph (Fig. 4.2) from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 0.60 \, \text{s} \).  

(DIAGRAM: Imagine a graph with time on the x-axis (0 to 0.60 s) and speed on the y-axis. The graph forms a closed loop, likely resembling a symmetrical shape such as a semi-circle or a sinusoidal segment, entirely above the time axis.)  

By dividing the loop into small squares or approximating the shape (e.g., triangles, trapezoids), the total area represents the distance. Counting squares or using integration for the curve gives:  

**Distance = 0.031 m** (accepting ±0.001 m uncertainty).  

[3]

Question: A trolley of mass 930 g is held on a horizontal surface by means of two springs, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with time t of the speed v of the trolley for the first 0.60 s of its motion is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Use your answer to (a)(i) to determine the resultant force acting on the trolley at time t = 0.  force = …………………………….. N [2]
Mark Scheme: F = ma = 0.93 × 0.42  {allow e.c.f. from (a)(i)} = 0.39 N C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the resultant force at \( t = 0 \):  
Using \( F = ma \),  
Mass \( m = 930 \, \text{g} = 0.93 \, \text{kg} \).  
From part (a)(i), acceleration \( a = 0.42 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).  
Thus,  
\( F = 0.93 \times 0.42 = 0.3906 \, \text{N} \approx 0.39 \, \text{N} \).  

Resultant force = **0.39 N**.  

[2]

Question: A trolley of mass 930 g is held on a horizontal surface by means of two springs, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with time t of the speed v of the trolley for the first 0.60 s of its motion is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Describe qualitatively the variation with time of the resultant force acting on the trolley during the first 0.60 s of its motion.  .................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: force reduces to zero in first 0.3 s then increases again in next 0.3 s in the opposite direction B1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation: The resultant force on the trolley decreases linearly to zero during the first 0.3 seconds. At 0.3 s, the force becomes zero as the trolley reaches maximum speed (equilibrium position). Subsequently, the force increases in the opposite direction over the next 0.3 seconds, opposing the motion as the trolley decelerates. This follows from the changing slope of the speed-time graph, where acceleration (and thus force) is proportional to the gradient. [3]

Question: A stone on a string is made to travel along a horizontal circular path, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The stone has a constant speed.Define acceleration.  ........................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: change in velocity/time (taken) B1 [1]
Explanation:
Acceleration is the change in velocity per unit time.  

(Since velocity is a vector, acceleration accounts for changes in speed **or** direction. Even at constant speed, circular motion involves acceleration due to changing direction.)  

[1]

Question: A stone on a string is made to travel along a horizontal circular path, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The stone has a constant speed.Use your definition to explain whether the stone is accelerating.  ........................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: velocity is a vector/velocity has magnitude & direction direction changing so must be accelerating B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
Even though the stone moves at constant speed, it is accelerating. Acceleration is defined as the **change in velocity** (a vector quantity with magnitude **and** direction). Although the speed (magnitude) is constant, the **direction of velocity** continuously changes as the stone follows the circular path. This change in direction means the velocity vector is not constant, so there is a **centripetal acceleration** directed toward the center of the circle.  

[2]

Question: A stone on a string is made to travel along a horizontal circular path, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The stone has a constant speed.The stone has a weight of 5.0 N. When the string makes an angle of 35° to the vertical, the tension in the string is 6.1 N, as illustrated in Fig. 3.2.       (DIAGRAM)  Determine the resultant force acting on the stone in the position shown.  magnitude of force = ……………..…..……. N direction of force….………………..………….. [4]
Mark Scheme: either 6.1 × cos35 = 4.99 N    so no resultant vertical force   6.1 sin35 = 3.5 N   horizontally or scale shown   triangle of correct shape   resultant = 3.5 ± 0.2 N    horizontal ± 3° B1 B1 B1 B1      [4] allow answer based on centripetal force: resultant is centripetal force (which is horizontal) resultant is horizontal component of tension 6.1 sin35 = 3.5 N horizontally  (B1) (B1) (B1) (B1)
Explanation:
The resultant force is the horizontal component of the tension, as vertical forces (tension’s vertical component and weight) cancel.  

**Magnitude**:  
\( T \sin\theta = 6.1 \times \sin35° = 3.5 \, \text{N} \).  

**Direction**:  
Horizontally towards the centre of the circular path.  

(Calculation: Vertical component \( T \cos35° = 6.1 \times 0.819 ≈ 5.0 \, \text{N} \), balancing the 5.0 N weight. Horizontal component \( 6.1 \times 0.574 ≈ 3.5 \, \text{N} \) is the resultant centripetal force.)  

[4]

Question: Define the moment of a force. .......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: force x perpendicular distance (of the force) from the pivot M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The moment of a force is the product of the force and the perpendicular distance from the pivot (or axis of rotation) to the line of action of the force.  
This quantifies the turning effect of the force about the pivot.  

[2]

Question: State the two conditions necessary for a body to be in equilibrium. 1. ...................................................................... 2. ...................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: no resultant force (in any direction) no resultant moment (about any point) B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
1. The resultant force on the body is zero.  
2. The resultant moment about any point on the body is zero.  

[2]

Question: Two parallel strings S1 and S2 are attached to a disc of diameter 12 cm, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The disc is free to rotate about an axis normal to its plane. The axis passes through the centre C of the disc.| A lever of length 30 cm is attached to the disc. When a force F is applied at right angles to the lever at its end, equal forces are produced in S1 and S2. The disc remains in equilibrium.  On Fig. 3.1, show the direction of the force in each string that acts on the disc. [1]
Mark Scheme: correct direction in both B1 [1]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Two parallel strings S1 and S2 attached to opposite sides of the disc. Arrows drawn tangential to the disc’s edge at the points where S1 and S2 attach, both pointing in the same rotational direction (e.g., leftward if the lever applies clockwise torque).)  

Both strings exert forces tangential to the disc in the **opposite rotational direction** to the torque caused by force F. For equilibrium, these forces create a counter-torque balancing the applied torque.  

[1]

Question: Two parallel strings S1 and S2 are attached to a disc of diameter 12 cm, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The disc is free to rotate about an axis normal to its plane. The axis passes through the centre C of the disc.| A lever of length 30 cm is attached to the disc. When a force F is applied at right angles to the lever at its end, equal forces are produced in S1 and S2. The disc remains in equilibrium.  For a force F of magnitude 150 N, determine 1. the moment of force F about the centre of the disc,      moment = …………………………………… N m 2. the torque of the couple produced by the forces in the strings,      torque = …………………………………… N m 3. the force in S1.      force = ……………………………………. N [4]
Mark Scheme: 1. moment = 150 × 0.3 = 45 N m (1 sig. fig. -1) A1 [4] 2. torque = 45 N m i.e. same is (i) A1 3. 45 = 0.12 × T     T = 375 N C1 A1
Explanation:
1. The moment of force \( F \) is calculated as \( \text{force} \times \text{perpendicular distance} \):  
\( 150 \, \text{N} \times 0.3 \, \text{m} = 45 \, \text{N m} \).  

2. Since the disc is in equilibrium, the torque from the couple in the strings balances the applied moment. Thus, torque \( = 45 \, \text{N m} \).  

3. Torque from the couple is \( \text{force} \times \text{diameter of disc} \):  
\( 45 = T \times 0.12 \, \text{m} \)  
\( T = \frac{45}{0.12} = 375 \, \text{N} \).  

Answers:  
1. \( 45 \, \text{N m} \)  
2. \( 45 \, \text{N m} \)  
3. \( 375 \, \text{N} \)  

[4]

Mark Scheme: the total momentum of a system (of interacting bodies) remains constant  provided there are no resultant external forces / isolated system M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The principle of conservation of momentum states that the total momentum of a system of interacting bodies remains constant, provided there are no resultant external forces acting on the system.  

[2]

Question: State the difference between an elastic and an inelastic collision.  .....................................................................................................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: elastic: total kinetic energy is conserved, inelastic: loss of kinetic energy [allow elastic: relative speed of approach equals relative speed of separation] B1 [1]
Explanation:
In an elastic collision, the total kinetic energy of the system is conserved, whereas in an inelastic collision, there is a loss of kinetic energy.  

[1]

Question: An object A of mass 4.2 kg and horizontal velocity 3.6 m s–1 moves towards object B as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Object B of mass 1.5 kg is moving with a horizontal velocity of 1.2 m s–1 towards object A. The objects collide and then both move to the right, as shown in Fig. 3.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Object A has velocity v and object B has velocity 3.0 m s–1.   Calculate the velocity v of object A after the collision.      velocity = ........................................ m s–1 [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the velocity \( v \) of object A after the collision, we apply the principle of conservation of momentum.  

**Initial momentum** (before collision):  
\[
(4.2 \, \text{kg} \times 3.6 \, \text{m/s}) - (1.5 \, \text{kg} \times 1.2 \, \text{m/s}) = 15.12 - 1.8 = 13.32 \, \text{kg·m/s}.
\]  
The negative sign for object B’s momentum accounts for its opposite direction.  

**Final momentum** (after collision):  
\[
4.2v + (1.5 \, \text{kg} \times 3.0 \, \text{m/s}) = 4.2v + 4.5 \, \text{kg·m/s}.
\]  

Equating initial and final momentum:  
\[
13.32 = 4.2v + 4.5.
\]  
Solving for \( v \):  
\[
4.2v = 13.32 - 4.5 = 8.82 \quad \Rightarrow \quad v = \frac{8.82}{4.2} = 2.1 \, \text{m/s}.
\]  

**Final velocity of object A:**  
\( v = 2.1 \, \text{m/s} \).  

[3]

Mark Scheme: initial kinetic energy = ½ mA(vA)2 + ½ mB(vB)2    = 27.21 + 1.08 = 28(.28) final kinetic energy = 9.26 + 6.75 = 16 initial KE is not the same as final KE hence inelastic provided final KE less than initial KE [allow in terms of relative speeds of approach and separation]  M1 M1 A1    [3]
Explanation:
To determine if the collision is elastic or inelastic, calculate the total kinetic energy (KE) before and after the collision.  

**Initial KE**:  
For object A: \( \frac{1}{2} \times 4.2 \times (3.6)^2 = 27.22 \, \text{J} \).  
For object B: \( \frac{1}{2} \times 1.5 \times (1.2)^2 = 1.08 \, \text{J} \).  
Total initial KE = \( 27.22 + 1.08 = 28.3 \, \text{J} \).  

**Final KE**:  
After collision, object A’s velocity \( v \) is found using momentum conservation:  
Initial momentum = \( 4.2 \times 3.6 + 1.5 \times (-1.2) = 13.32 \, \text{kg·m/s} \).  
Final momentum = \( 4.2v + 1.5 \times 3.0 \).  
Equating: \( 13.32 = 4.2v + 4.5 \) → \( v = 2.1 \, \text{m/s} \).  

For object A: \( \frac{1}{2} \times 4.2 \times (2.1)^2 = 9.26 \, \text{J} \).  
For object B: \( \frac{1}{2} \times 1.5 \times (3.0)^2 = 6.75 \, \text{J} \).  
Total final KE = \( 9.26 + 6.75 = 16.01 \, \text{J} \).  

Since initial KE (\( 28.3 \, \text{J} \)) ≠ final KE (\( 16.0 \, \text{J} \)), the collision is **inelastic**.  

[3]

Question: Distinguish between mass and weight. mass: .......................................................................... weight: ....................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: mass is the property of a body resisting changes in motion / quantity of matter in a body / measure of inertia to changes in motion B1 [2] weight is the force due to the gravitational field/force due to gravity or gravitational force B1 Allow 1/2 for 'mass is scalar weight is vector'
Explanation:
Mass: Mass is the property of a body that resists changes in motion (inertia) and represents the quantity of matter it contains.  
Weight: Weight is the gravitational force acting on the body due to its presence in a gravitational field.  

[2]

Question: An object O of mass 4.9 kg is suspended by a rope A that is fixed at point P. The object is pulled to one side and held in equilibrium by a second rope B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Rope A is at an angle θ to the horizontal and rope B is horizontal. The tension in rope A is 69 N and the tension in rope B is T.   On Fig. 2.1, draw arrows to represent the directions of all the forces acting on object O. [2]
Mark Scheme: arrow vertically down through O tension forces in correct direction on rope B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Object O with three arrows: (1) Vertical downward arrow from O labeled "weight" (or W/mg). (2) Arrow along rope A pointing towards P (upwards at angle θ to horizontal) labeled "tension A (69 N)". (3) Horizontal arrow along rope B pointing away from O (opposite to the direction rope B is pulled) labeled "tension B (T)". All arrows originate from O.)  

[2]

Question: An object O of mass 4.9 kg is suspended by a rope A that is fixed at point P. The object is pulled to one side and held in equilibrium by a second rope B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Rope A is at an angle θ to the horizontal and rope B is horizontal. The tension in rope A is 69 N and the tension in rope B is T.   Calculate 1. the angle θ,   θ = ................................................°  2. the tension T.   T = .............................................. N
Mark Scheme: 1. weight = mg = 4.9 × 9.81 (= 48.07)   69 sin θ = mg   θ = 44.(1)°   scale drawing allow ± 2°   use of cos or tan 1/3 only  C1 C1 A1   [3] 2. T = 69 cos θ      = 49.6 / 50N  scale drawing 50 ±2 (2/2)  50 ±4 (1/2) C1 A1 [2] correct answers obtained using scale diagram or triangle of forces will score full marks cos in 1. then sin in 2. (2/2)
Explanation:
1. The vertical component of tension in rope A balances the object's weight.  
Weight \( W = mg = 4.9 \times 9.81 = 48.07 \, \text{N} \).  
Vertical force from rope A: \( 69 \sin\theta = 48.07 \).  
Solving: \( \sin\theta = \frac{48.07}{69} \approx 0.6967 \), so \( \theta = \sin^{-1}(0.6967) \approx 44.1^\circ \).  

2. The horizontal component of tension in rope A equals tension \( T \).  
Horizontal force: \( T = 69 \cos\theta \).  
Substituting \( \theta = 44.1^\circ \):  
\( \cos(44.1^\circ) \approx 0.717 \), so \( T = 69 \times 0.717 \approx 49.5 \, \text{N} \) (≈ 50 N).  

Answers:  
1. \( \theta = 44^\circ \)  
2. \( T = 50 \, \text{N} \)  

[Full marks: 5]

Question: A motor drags a log of mass 452 kg up a slope by means of a cable, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope is inclined at 14.0° to the horizontal.  Show that the component of the weight of the log acting down the slope is 1070 N. [1]
Mark Scheme: weight = 452 × 9.81 component down the slope = 452 × 9.81 × sin14° = 1072.7 = 1070N  M1 A0 [1]
Explanation:
The weight of the log is \( W = mg = 452 \times 9.81 = 4434.12 \, \text{N} \).  
The component of the weight acting **down the slope** is \( W \sin\theta \):  
\( 4434.12 \times \sin14.0° \).  
Using \( \sin14.0° \approx 0.2419 \):  
\( 4434.12 \times 0.2419 = 1072.7 \, \text{N} \),  
which rounds to **1070 N** as required.  

[1]

Question: A motor drags a log of mass 452 kg up a slope by means of a cable, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope is inclined at 14.0° to the horizontal.  The log starts from rest. A constant frictional force of 525 N acts on the log. The log accelerates up the slope at 0.130 m s–2.  Calculate the tension in the cable.     tension = ............................................. N [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the tension in the cable, we apply Newton’s second law along the slope. The forces opposing the motion are the frictional force (525 N) and the component of the log’s weight down the slope. The weight component is \( mg \sin \theta \):  
\( 452 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \times \sin 14.0^\circ \approx 1070 \, \text{N} \).  

The total opposing force is \( 1070 \, \text{N} + 525 \, \text{N} = 1595 \, \text{N} \).  

Using \( F = ma \), the net force up the slope is:  
\( T - 1595 = 452 \times 0.130 \).  
Calculating \( 452 \times 0.130 = 58.8 \, \text{N} \),  
so \( T = 1595 + 58.8 = 1654 \, \text{N} \).  

Rounded to three significant figures, the tension is **1650 N** (or **1653.76 N** unrounded).  

Tension = **1650 N**.  

[3]

Question: A motor drags a log of mass 452 kg up a slope by means of a cable, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope is inclined at 14.0° to the horizontal.  The log starts from rest. A constant frictional force of 525 N acts on the log. The log accelerates up the slope at 0.130 m s–2.  The log is initially at rest at point S. It is pulled through a distance of 10.0 m to point P. Calculate, for the log, 1. the time taken to move from S to P,       time = .............................................. s  [2] 2. the magnitude of the velocity at P.     velocity = ........................................ m s–1  [1]

A motor drags a log of mass 452 kg up a slope by means of a cable, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope is inclined at 14.0° to the horizontal.  The cable breaks when the log reaches point P. On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with time t of the velocity v of the log. The graph should show v from the start at S until the log returns to S. [4]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: straight line from the origin line down to zero velocity in short time compared to stage 1 line less steep negative gradient final velocity larger than final velocity in the first part – at least 2× B1 B1 B1 B1 [4]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Velocity (v) on vertical axis, time (t) on horizontal axis. Graph starts at origin.  
1. **First segment**: Straight line with positive gradient from (0,0) to (t₁, v_max) – log accelerates upward under motor force.  
2. **Second segment**: Steeper negative gradient line from (t₁, v_max) to (t₂, 0), where t₂ - t₁ < t₁ – cable breaks, log decelerates rapidly to rest.  
3. **Third segment**: Less steep negative gradient line from (t₂, 0) to (t₃, -v_final), where |v_final| > v_max – log accelerates downward with smaller magnitude acceleration.  
4. Final velocity at t₃ (return to S) is larger in magnitude than v_max.)  

[4]

Question: Explain the differences between the quantities distance and displacement. .............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: displacement is a vector, distance is a scalar displacement is straight line between two points / distance is sum of lengths moved / example showing difference (either one of the definitions for the second mark)  B1 B1 [2]
Explanation: Distance is a scalar quantity representing the total path length travelled, while displacement is a vector quantity representing the straight-line separation between initial and final positions, including direction. For example, moving in a circular path and returning to the start gives a distance equal to the circumference but zero displacement.

Question: State Newton's first law. .............................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: a body continues at rest or at constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant (external) force B1 [1]
Explanation:
Newton's first law states that a body remains at rest or moves with constant velocity unless acted upon by a resultant external force.  

[1]

Question: Two tugs pull a tanker at constant velocity in the direction XY, as represented in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Tug 1 pulls the tanker with a force T1 at 25.0° to XY. Tug 2 pulls the tanker with a force of T2 at 15.0° to XY. The resultant force R due to the two tugs is 25.0 × 103 N in the direction XY.   By reference to the forces acting on the tanker, explain how the tanker may be described as being in equilibrium. ...........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: sum of T1 and T2 equals frictional force these two forces are in opposite directions (allow for 1/2 for travelling in straight line hence no rotation / no resultant torque) B1 B1   [2]
Explanation: The tanker is in equilibrium because the resultant forward force from the two tugs (25.0 × 10³ N in direction XY) is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the frictional/drag force acting on the tanker. This balance of forces results in **zero net force**, satisfying translational equilibrium. Since the tanker moves at constant velocity (no acceleration) and does not rotate, there is also no resultant torque, ensuring rotational equilibrium.

Question: Two tugs pull a tanker at constant velocity in the direction XY, as represented in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Tug 1 pulls the tanker with a force T1 at 25.0° to XY. Tug 2 pulls the tanker with a force of T2 at 15.0° to XY. The resultant force R due to the two tugs is 25.0 × 103 N in the direction XY.   1. Complete Fig. 1.2 to draw a vector triangle for the forces R, T1 and T2.   (DIAGRAM)  2. Use your vector triangle in Fig. 1.2 to determine the magnitude of T1 and of T2.  T1 = ................................................... N T2 = .................................................. N
Mark Scheme: 1. scale vector triangle with correct orientation / vector triangle with correct orientation both with arrows scale given or mathematical analysis for tensions B1 B1 [2] 2. T1 = 10.1 × 103 (± 0.5 × 103)N     T2 = 16.4 × 103 (± 0.5 × 103)N A1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To complete the vector triangle (part 1):  
(DIAGRAM: Draw R (25.0×10³ N) horizontally right as the resultant. From the tail of R, draw T₁ at 25.0° above XY. From the head of T₁, draw T₂ at 15.0° below XY, such that the triangle closes with R. Arrows indicate directions.)

For part 2:  
Resolve forces horizontally and vertically.  
Horizontal:  
\( T_1 \cos25° + T_2 \cos15° = 25.0 \times 10^3 \, \text{N} \).  
Vertical (components cancel):  
\( T_1 \sin25° = T_2 \sin15° \).  

Solving:  
From vertical equation:  
\( T_1 = T_2 \frac{\sin15°}{\sin25°} \).  

Substitute into horizontal equation:  
\( T_2 \left( \frac{\sin15°}{\sin25°} \cos25° + \cos15° \right) = 25.0 \times 10^3 \).  

Calculate coefficients:  
\( \sin15° ≈ 0.2588, \, \sin25° ≈ 0.4226, \, \cos25° ≈ 0.9063, \, \cos15° ≈ 0.9659 \).  
\( T_2 ≈ \frac{25.0 \times 10^3}{1.5209} ≈ 16.4 \times 10^3 \, \text{N} \).  
\( T_1 ≈ 16.4 \times 10^3 \times \frac{0.2588}{0.4226} ≈ 10.1 \times 10^3 \, \text{N} \).  

**T₁ = 10.1 × 10³ N  
T₂ = 16.4 × 10³ N**

Question: State Newton's first law. .............................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: A body continues at rest or constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant  (external) force B1 [1]
Explanation:
Newton's first law states that a body remains at rest or moves with constant velocity unless acted upon by a resultant external force.  

[1]

Question: A log of mass 450 kg is pulled up a slope by a wire attached to a motor, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The angle that the slope makes with the horizontal is 12°. The frictional force acting on the log is 650 N. The log travels with constant velocity.   With reference to the motion of the log, discuss whether the log is in equilibrium. ..........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: constant velocity/zero acceleration and therefore no resultant force no resultant force (and no resultant torque) hence in equilibrium M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The log is moving at constant velocity, which means it has zero acceleration. According to Newton's first law, the resultant force acting on it must therefore be zero. Additionally, since there is no rotational motion (implied by the linear motion description), the resultant torque is also zero. Both conditions for equilibrium (no resultant force and no resultant torque) are satisfied. Hence, the log is in equilibrium.  

[2]

Question: A log of mass 450 kg is pulled up a slope by a wire attached to a motor, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The angle that the slope makes with the horizontal is 12°. The frictional force acting on the log is 650 N. The log travels with constant velocity.   Calculate the tension in the wire.  tension = ............................................. N [3]
Explanation:
The log moves at constant velocity, so the tension balances the component of weight down the slope and the frictional force.  
Component of weight parallel to slope:  
\( 450 \times 9.81 \times \sin 12^\circ = 917.8 \, \text{N} \).  
Total tension = component of weight + friction:  
\( T = 917.8 + 650 = 1567.8 \, \text{N} \).  
Rounded to three significant figures:  
Tension = **1570 N** (or **1600 N** to 2 s.f.).  

[3]

Question: A log of mass 450 kg is pulled up a slope by a wire attached to a motor, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The angle that the slope makes with the horizontal is 12°. The frictional force acting on the log is 650 N. The log travels with constant velocity.   State and explain whether the gain in the potential energy per unit time of the log is equal to the output power of the motor. ..........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: work done against frictional force or friction between log and slope output power greater than the gain in PE / s M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The gain in potential energy per unit time (power) is \( P_{\text{PE}} = mgv \sin\theta \), where \( v \) is the velocity. However, the motor’s output power must also overcome friction: \( P_{\text{motor}} = (mg \sin\theta + F_{\text{friction}})v \). Since \( F_{\text{friction}} \) is 650 N, the motor’s power includes work against friction. Therefore, the output power of the motor is **greater** than the gain in potential energy per unit time.  

[2]

Question: A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground with an initial velocity of 4.23 m s–1. The ball falls for a time of 1.51 s before hitting the ground. Air resistance is negligible.  Show that the downwards velocity of the ball when it hits the ground is 19.0 m s–1.  [2]
Mark Scheme: v = u + at    = 4.23 + 9.81 × 1.51    = 19.0(4) ms–1  (Allow 2 s.f.) (Use of –g max 1/2. Use of g = 10 max 1/2. Allow use of 9.8. Allow 19 ms–1) C1 M1 A0   [2]
Explanation:
To determine the final velocity, use the equation \( v = u + at \):  
Initial velocity \( u = 4.23 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \),  
Acceleration \( a = 9.81 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \),  
Time \( t = 1.51 \, \text{s} \).  

Substitute values:  
\( v = 4.23 + (9.81 \times 1.51) \).  
Calculate \( 9.81 \times 1.51 = 14.8131 \).  
Thus, \( v = 4.23 + 14.8131 = 19.0431 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  
Rounded to 3 significant figures: \( v = 19.0 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

[2]

Question: A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground with an initial velocity of 4.23 m s–1. The ball falls for a time of 1.51 s before hitting the ground. Air resistance is negligible.  Calculate, to three significant figures, the distance the ball falls to the ground.  distance = ............................................. m [2]
Mark Scheme: either s = ut + ½ at2 (or v2 = u2 + 2as etc.)    = 4.23 × 1.51 + 0.5 × 9.81 × (1.51)2    = 17.6m (or 17.5m) (Use of –g here wrong physics (0/2))  C1  A1   [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the distance the ball falls, we use the kinematic equation for constant acceleration:  
\( s = ut + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \).  
Here, \( u = 4.23 \, \text{m/s} \), \( a = 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), and \( t = 1.51 \, \text{s} \). Substituting:  
\( s = (4.23)(1.51) + 0.5(9.81)(1.51)^2 \).  

First term: \( 4.23 \times 1.51 = 6.3873 \, \text{m} \).  
Second term: \( 0.5 \times 9.81 \times (1.51)^2 \).  
Calculate \( (1.51)^2 = 2.2801 \), then:  
\( 0.5 \times 9.81 \times 2.2801 = 11.1839 \, \text{m} \).  

Total distance:  
\( 6.3873 + 11.1839 = 17.5712 \, \text{m} \).  
Rounded to three significant figures:  
**17.6 m**.  

[2]

Question: A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground with an initial velocity of 4.23 m s–1. The ball falls for a time of 1.51 s before hitting the ground. Air resistance is negligible.The ball makes contact with the ground for 12.5 ms and rebounds with an upwards velocity of 18.6 m s–1. The mass of the ball is 46.5 g.  Calculate the average force acting on the ball on impact with the ground.  magnitude of force = .................................................. N direction of force ......................................................  [4]
Mark Scheme: F = ∆P / ∆t  need idea of change in momentum    = [0.0465 × (18.6 + 19)] / 12.5 × 10–3    = 140N (Use of – sign max 2/4. Ignore –ve sign in answer) Direction: upwards C1 C1 A1  B1 [4]
Explanation:
To calculate the average force:  
First, determine the velocity just before impact. Using \( v = u + at \):  
\( v = 4.23 + (9.81 \times 1.51) = 19.0 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \) downward.  

Change in momentum \( \Delta p = m(v_{\text{final}} - v_{\text{initial}}) \):  
\( \Delta p = 0.0465 \times [18.6 - (-19.0)] = 0.0465 \times 37.6 = 1.75 \, \text{kg m s}^{-1} \).  

Average force \( F = \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} = \frac{1.75}{12.5 \times 10^{-3}} = 140 \, \text{N} \).  

**Magnitude of force:** 140 N  
**Direction:** Upwards  

[4]

Question: A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground with an initial velocity of 4.23 m s–1. The ball falls for a time of 1.51 s before hitting the ground. Air resistance is negligible.The ball makes contact with the ground for 12.5 ms and rebounds with an upwards velocity of 18.6 m s–1. The mass of the ball is 46.5 g.  Use conservation of energy to determine the maximum height the ball reaches after it hits the ground.   height = ............................................. m [2]
Explanation:
To determine the maximum height after rebound, equate the kinetic energy just after rebound to the gravitational potential energy at maximum height:  
\( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = mgh \).  

Mass \( m \) cancels, giving:  
\( h = \frac{v^2}{2g} = \frac{(18.6)^2}{2 \times 9.81} \).  

Calculating:  
\( h = \frac{345.96}{19.62} = 17.6 \, \text{m} \, (\text{2 s.f.}) \).  

The ball reaches a maximum height of **17.6 m**.  

[2]

Question: A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground with an initial velocity of 4.23 m s–1. The ball falls for a time of 1.51 s before hitting the ground. Air resistance is negligible.State and explain whether the collision the ball makes with the ground is elastic or inelastic. .............................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: either  kinetic energy of the ball is not conserved on impact or  speed before impact is not equal to speed after hence inelastic B1 [1]
Explanation: The collision is inelastic. When the ball hits the ground, its kinetic energy is not conserved because some energy is transferred into other forms (e.g., heat, sound, or deformation of the ball/ground). Additionally, the ball’s speed immediately after the collision is not equal to its speed just before impact (it may not rebound at all or with reduced speed), confirming the inelastic nature of the collision. [1]

Question: A helicopter has a cable hanging from it towards the sea below, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A man of mass 80 kg rescues a child of mass 50.5 kg. The two are attached to the cable and are lifted from the sea to the helicopter. The lifting process consists of an initial uniform acceleration followed by a period of constant velocity and then completed by a final uniform deceleration.Calculate the combined weight of the man and child.  weight = ............................................. N [1]
Explanation:
The combined weight is calculated by summing the masses and multiplying by gravitational acceleration.  

Total mass = 80 kg + 50.5 kg = **130.5 kg**.  
Weight = \( 130.5 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 1280 \, \text{N} \).  

**weight = 1280 N**  
[1]

Question: A helicopter has a cable hanging from it towards the sea below, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A man of mass 80 kg rescues a child of mass 50.5 kg. The two are attached to the cable and are lifted from the sea to the helicopter. The lifting process consists of an initial uniform acceleration followed by a period of constant velocity and then completed by a final uniform deceleration.Calculate the tension in the cable during  the initial acceleration of 0.570 m s–2,   tension = ............................................. N [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the tension in the cable during the initial acceleration:  

The total mass of the man and child is \( 80 \, \text{kg} + 50.5 \, \text{kg} = 130.5 \, \text{kg} \).  
Their weight is \( W = mg = 130.5 \times 9.81 = 1280 \, \text{N} \) (rounded).  

Using Newton’s second law for the upward acceleration (\( a = 0.570 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \)):  
\[ T - W = ma \]  
\[ T = W + ma = 1280 + (130.5 \times 0.570) \]  
\[ T = 1280 + 74.4 = 1350 \, \text{N} \]  

Tension = **1350 N**  

[2]

Question: A helicopter has a cable hanging from it towards the sea below, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A man of mass 80 kg rescues a child of mass 50.5 kg. The two are attached to the cable and are lifted from the sea to the helicopter. The lifting process consists of an initial uniform acceleration followed by a period of constant velocity and then completed by a final uniform deceleration.Calculate the tension in the cable during  the period of constant velocity of 2.00 m s–1.  tension = ............................................. N [1]
Explanation:
The tension in the cable during constant velocity is equal to the total weight of the man and child.  
Total mass = 80 kg + 50.5 kg = 130.5 kg.  
Weight = mass × gravitational field strength = 130.5 kg × 9.81 m s⁻² = 1280 N (to 3 significant figures).  

tension = **1280** N  

[1]

Question: A helicopter has a cable hanging from it towards the sea below, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A man of mass 80 kg rescues a child of mass 50.5 kg. The two are attached to the cable and are lifted from the sea to the helicopter. The lifting process consists of an initial uniform acceleration followed by a period of constant velocity and then completed by a final uniform deceleration.During the final deceleration the tension in the cable is 1240 N. Calculate this deceleration.  deceleration = ........................................ m s–2 [2]
Explanation:
The total mass of the man and child is \( 80 \, \text{kg} + 50.5 \, \text{kg} = 130.5 \, \text{kg} \).  
Their weight is \( 130.5 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{ms}^{-2} = 1280 \, \text{N} \).  

During deceleration, the net force is \( \text{Weight} - \text{Tension} = 1280 \, \text{N} - 1240 \, \text{N} = 40 \, \text{N} \) downward.  
Using \( F = ma \):  
\( a = \frac{40}{130.5} = 0.31 \, \text{ms}^{-2} \).  

Deceleration = **–0.31** ms⁻².  

[2]

Question: A helicopter has a cable hanging from it towards the sea below, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A man of mass 80 kg rescues a child of mass 50.5 kg. The two are attached to the cable and are lifted from the sea to the helicopter. The lifting process consists of an initial uniform acceleration followed by a period of constant velocity and then completed by a final uniform deceleration.  Calculate the time over which the man and child are 1. moving with uniform acceleration,     time = .............................................. s [1] 2. moving with uniform deceleration.     time = .............................................. s [1]
Explanation:
The times for uniform acceleration and deceleration are determined from the motion details provided in Fig. 3.1 (DIAGRAM: velocity-time graph showing acceleration phase as a straight line with positive gradient for 3.5 s, constant velocity as a horizontal line, and deceleration phase as a straight line with negative gradient for 6.5 s).  

1. Time for uniform acceleration = **3.5 s**  
2. Time for uniform deceleration = **6.5 s**  

[1] [1]

Question: A helicopter has a cable hanging from it towards the sea below, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A man of mass 80 kg rescues a child of mass 50.5 kg. The two are attached to the cable and are lifted from the sea to the helicopter. The lifting process consists of an initial uniform acceleration followed by a period of constant velocity and then completed by a final uniform deceleration.  The time over which the man and child are moving with constant velocity is 20 s. On Fig. 3.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time of the velocity of the man and child for the complete lifting process. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: basic shape basic shape M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Velocity (y-axis) vs. Time (x-axis). The graph starts at the origin with a straight line of positive slope (acceleration phase), transitions to a horizontal line (constant velocity for 20 s), then a straight line of negative slope (deceleration phase) back to zero velocity. All segments are connected smoothly with no gaps.)  

[2]

Question: A climber id supported by a rope on a vertical wall. as shown in Fig.2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The weight W of the climber is 520 N. The rope, of negligible weight, is attached to the climber and to a fixed point P where it makes an angle of 18° to the vertical. The reaction force R acts at right-angles to the wall.  The climber is in equilibrium.State the conditions necessary for the climber to be in equilibrium. ..............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: resultant moment = zero / sum of clockwise moments = sum of anticlockwise moments resultant force = 0 B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The climber being in equilibrium requires two conditions:  
1. The **resultant force** acting on the climber must be zero. This means all vertical and horizontal forces balance.  
2. The **resultant moment** about any point must be zero. This implies the total clockwise moments equal the total anticlockwise moments.  

[2]

Question: A climber id supported by a rope on a vertical wall. as shown in Fig.2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The weight W of the climber is 520 N. The rope, of negligible weight, is attached to the climber and to a fixed point P where it makes an angle of 18° to the vertical. The reaction force R acts at right-angles to the wall.  The climber is in equilibrium.Complete Fig. 2.2 by drawing a labelled vector triangle to represent the forces acting on the climber. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: shape and orientation correct and forces labelled and arrows correct angles correct / labelled M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A triangle with three vectors:  
1. **W** (520 N) vertically downward.  
2. **R** (reaction) horizontal rightward.  
3. **T** (tension) at 18° to the vertical, connecting the tip of **R** to the tail of **W**.  
All vectors labelled with arrows, angles marked (18° between **T** and vertical).)  

The vector triangle closes as the climber is in equilibrium. **W** acts downward, **R** acts horizontally (⊥ to wall), and **T** at 18° to vertical. The tip-to-tail arrangement ensures forces balance.  

[2]

Question: A climber id supported by a rope on a vertical wall. as shown in Fig.2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The weight W of the climber is 520 N. The rope, of negligible weight, is attached to the climber and to a fixed point P where it makes an angle of 18° to the vertical. The reaction force R acts at right-angles to the wall.  The climber is in equilibrium.Resolve forces or use your vector triangle to calculate  the tension T in the rope,  T = ............................................. N [2]
Mark Scheme: T cos18° = W                               Scale diagram:           T = 520 / cos18° = 547 N          ± 20 N C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the tension \( T \) in the rope:  
Since the climber is in equilibrium, the vertical component of \( T \) balances the weight \( W \).  
Resolving vertically:  
\[ T \cos 18^\circ = W \]  
\[ T = \frac{520}{\cos 18^\circ} \]  
Using \( \cos 18^\circ \approx 0.9511 \):  
\[ T \approx \frac{520}{0.9511} \approx 547 \, \text{N} \]  

**Tension \( T = 547 \, \text{N} \)**.  

[2]

Question: A climber id supported by a rope on a vertical wall. as shown in Fig.2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The weight W of the climber is 520 N. The rope, of negligible weight, is attached to the climber and to a fixed point P where it makes an angle of 18° to the vertical. The reaction force R acts at right-angles to the wall.  The climber is in equilibrium.Resolve forces or use your vector triangle to calculate  the reaction force R.  R = ............................................. N [1]
Explanation:
To find the reaction force **R**, we resolve forces horizontally since **R** acts perpendicular to the wall. The horizontal component of the tension **T** in the rope balances **R**.  

Vertically:  
\( T \cos 18° = W = 520 \, \text{N} \).  

Horizontally:  
\( R = T \sin 18° \).  

Substitute \( T = \frac{520}{\cos 18°} \) into the horizontal equation:  
\( R = \left( \frac{520}{\cos 18°} \right) \sin 18° = 520 \tan 18° \).  

Using \( \tan 18° \approx 0.3249 \):  
\( R = 520 \times 0.3249 = 169 \, \text{N} \).  

**R = 169 N**  
[1]

Question: A climber id supported by a rope on a vertical wall. as shown in Fig.2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The weight W of the climber is 520 N. The rope, of negligible weight, is attached to the climber and to a fixed point P where it makes an angle of 18° to the vertical. The reaction force R acts at right-angles to the wall.  The climber is in equilibrium.The climber moves up the wall and the angle the rope makes with the vertical increases. Explain why the magnitude of the tension in the rope increases. ................................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: θ is larger hence cosθ is smaller, T = W / cosθ hence T is larger  M1 A0 [1]
Explanation:
When the angle θ increases, the vertical component of the tension (Tcosθ) must still balance the climber’s weight (W = 520 N). Since cosθ decreases as θ increases, T must increase to maintain Tcosθ = W. Therefore, tension T = W / cosθ becomes larger when θ increases.  

[1]

Question: Q3/9702/21/M/J/11Explain what is meant by centre of gravity. ................................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: point where the weight of an object / gravitational force may be considered to act M1 A1 [2]
Explanation: The centre of gravity is the single point through which the entire weight of an object (or the resultant gravitational force acting on it) can be considered to act. This simplifies calculations involving the object’s motion or equilibrium under gravity.

Question: Q3/9702/21/M/J/11Define moment of a force. ................................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: product of the force and the perpendicular distance (to the pivot) B1 [1]
Explanation: The moment of a force is the product of the force and the perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force.

Question: Q3/9702/21/M/J/11A student is being weighed. The student, of weight W, stands 0.30 m from end A of a uniform plank AB, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The plank has weight 80 N and length 2.0 m. A pivot P supports the plank and is 0.50 m from end A. A weight of 70 N is moved to balance the weight of the student. The plank is in equilibrium when the weight is 0.20 m from end B.   State the two conditions necessary for the plank to be in equilibrium. 1. ...................................................................................... 2. ...................................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: 1. sum / net / resultant force is zero B1 [2] 2. net / resultant moment is zero   sum of clockwise moments = sum of anticlockwise moments B1
Explanation:
The two conditions necessary for equilibrium are:  
1. The resultant force acting on the plank is zero.  
2. The resultant moment about any point is zero (or the sum of clockwise moments equals the sum of anticlockwise moments).  

[2]

Question: Q3/9702/21/M/J/11A student is being weighed. The student, of weight W, stands 0.30 m from end A of a uniform plank AB, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The plank has weight 80 N and length 2.0 m. A pivot P supports the plank and is 0.50 m from end A. A weight of 70 N is moved to balance the weight of the student. The plank is in equilibrium when the weight is 0.20 m from end B.   Determine the weight W of the student.  W = ............................................. N [3]
Mark Scheme: W × 0.2 = 80 × 0.5 + 70 × 1.3      = 40 + 91 W = 655 N (allow 2/3 for one error in distance but 0/3 if two errors) C1 C1 C1 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the student's weight \( W \), we balance the moments about the pivot.  
- **Anticlockwise moment** from \( W \): \( W \times 0.20 \, \text{m} \) (distance from pivot: \( 0.50 - 0.30 = 0.20 \, \text{m} \)).  
- **Clockwise moments**:  
  - Plank’s weight (80 N) acts at its midpoint (1.0 m from A), so distance from pivot: \( 1.0 - 0.50 = 0.50 \, \text{m} \): \( 80 \times 0.50 = 40 \, \text{Nm} \).  
  - 70 N weight at 0.20 m from B (1.80 m from A), distance from pivot: \( 1.80 - 0.50 = 1.30 \, \text{m} \): \( 70 \times 1.30 = 91 \, \text{Nm} \).  

Equating moments:  
\[
W \times 0.20 = 40 + 91 \implies W = \frac{131}{0.20} = 655 \, \text{N}.
\]  

\( W = \boxed{655} \, \text{N} \).

Question: Q3/9702/21/M/J/11A student is being weighed. The student, of weight W, stands 0.30 m from end A of a uniform plank AB, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The plank has weight 80 N and length 2.0 m. A pivot P supports the plank and is 0.50 m from end A. A weight of 70 N is moved to balance the weight of the student. The plank is in equilibrium when the weight is 0.20 m from end B.   If only the 70 N weight is moved, there is a maximum weight of student that can be determined using the arrangement shown in Fig. 3.1. State and explain one change that can be made to increase this maximum weight. ......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: move pivot to left gives greater clockwise moment / smaller anticlockwise moment  or move W to right  gives smaller anticlockwise moment (M1)  (A1)  (M1) (A1) [2]
Explanation:
To increase the maximum measurable weight of the student, **move the pivot closer to end A (to the left)**.  
This increases the clockwise moment from the 70 N weight and the plank’s weight (as their distances from the pivot increase) while reducing the anticlockwise moment arm of the student’s weight.  
With a smaller anticlockwise moment and larger clockwise moment, a heavier student can be balanced before the 70 N weight reaches its maximum possible position.  

Alternatively, **move the student closer to the pivot (towards the right)**.  
This reduces their anticlockwise moment arm, requiring less clockwise moment to balance. Thus, a larger student weight can be measured without exceeding the system’s moment capacity.  

[2]

Question: Q2/9702/23/M/J/10State the two conditions that must be satisfied for a body to be in equilibrium. 1. ..................................................................... 2. ..................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: no resultant force/sum of forces zero no resultant moment/torque/sum of moments/torques zero B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
1. No resultant force / sum of forces (in all directions) is zero.  
2. No resultant moment/torque / sum of moments/torques (about any point) is zero.  

[2]

Question: Q2/9702/23/M/J/10Three co-planar forces act on a body that is in equilibrium.  Describe how to draw a vector triangle to represent these forces. .......................................................................[3]
Mark Scheme: each force is represented by the side of a triangle/by an arrow in magnitude and direction arrows joined, head to tail (could be shown on a sketch diagram) M1 A1 B1   [3]
Explanation:
To draw the vector triangle:  
1. **Represent each force** as an arrow, with length proportional to magnitude and direction matching the force.  
2. **Arrange the arrows head-to-tail** in any order (e.g., place the tail of the second force at the head of the first, and the tail of the third at the head of the second).  
3. **Close the triangle**: The head of the third arrow should meet the tail of the first, confirming equilibrium (resultant force = 0).  

(DIAGRAM: Three arrows forming a triangle; each arrow labeled with force magnitude/direction, connected head-to-tail.)  

[3]

Question: Q2/9702/23/M/J/10Three co-planar forces act on a body that is in equilibrium.  State how the triangle confirms that the forces are in equilibrium. .......................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: if the triangle is 'closed' (then the forces are in equilibrium) B1 [1]
Explanation:
The triangle confirms equilibrium because if the triangle formed by the three forces is **closed** (i.e., the vectors return to the starting point when drawn tip-to-tail), the resultant force is zero. This indicates the forces balance each other, satisfying the condition for equilibrium.  

[1]

Question: Q2/9702/23/M/J/10A weight of 7.0 N hangs vertically by two strings AB and AC, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  For the weight to be in equilibrium, the tension in string AB is T1 and in string AC it is T2. On Fig. 2.1, draw a vector triangle to determine the magnitudes of T1 and T2. T1 = ................................................... N T2 = ................................................... N [3]
Mark Scheme: triangle drawn with correct shape (incorrect arrows loses this mark) T1 = 5.4 ± 0.2N T2 = 4.0 ± 0.2N  B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A vector triangle with three sides: a vertical downward arrow labeled 7.0 N, and two other arrows forming a triangle. The arrow from the start point to the top of the 7.0 N vector is T1 ≈5.4 N at an angle, and the arrow from the top of the 7.0 N vector back to the start is T2 ≈4.0 N at a complementary angle.)  

T1 = 5.4 N  
T2 = 4.0 N  

[3]

Question: Q2/9702/23/M/J/10By reference to Fig. 2.1, suggest why the weight could not be supported with the strings AB and AC both horizontal. ...............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: forces in strings would be horizontal (so) no vertical force to support the weight B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
If both strings AB and AC are horizontal, the tensions in these strings would act purely horizontally. For equilibrium, the vertical component of forces must balance the weight. However, horizontal tensions provide no vertical component. Therefore, there is no upward force to counteract the downward weight, making it impossible to support the weight. 

[2]

Question: A rod AB is hinged to a wall at A. The rod is held horizontally by means of a cord BD, attached to the rod at end B and to the wall at D, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod has weight W and the centre of gravity of the rod is at C. The rod is held in equilibrium by a force T in the cord and a force F produced at the hinge.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/06Explain what is meant by  the centre of gravity of a body, ................................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: point at which whole weight of body may be considered to act M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The centre of gravity of a body is the single point through which the entire weight of the body can be considered to act. This means that, for the purpose of analysing forces and equilibrium, the gravitational force on all particles of the body is effectively concentrated at this point.  

[2]

Question: A rod AB is hinged to a wall at A. The rod is held horizontally by means of a cord BD, attached to the rod at end B and to the wall at D, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod has weight W and the centre of gravity of the rod is at C. The rod is held in equilibrium by a force T in the cord and a force F produced at the hinge.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/06Explain what is meant by  the equilibrium of a body. ................................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: sum of forces in any direction is zero sum of moments about any point is zero B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
Equilibrium of a body means that the body is in a state where:  
1. The **vector sum of all forces** acting on it is zero in any direction, so there is no linear acceleration.  
2. The **sum of all moments (torques)** about any point on the body is zero, so there is no rotational acceleration.  

[2]

Question: A rod AB is hinged to a wall at A. The rod is held horizontally by means of a cord BD, attached to the rod at end B and to the wall at D, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod has weight W and the centre of gravity of the rod is at C. The rod is held in equilibrium by a force T in the cord and a force F produced at the hinge.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/06The line of action of the weight W of the rod passes through the cord at point P Explain why, for the rod to be in equilibrium, the force F produced at the hinge must also pass through point P. ........................................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: either: T and W have zero moment about P so F must have zero moment, i.e. pass through P or: if all pass through P, distance from P is zero for all forces  (M1) so sum of moments about P is zero  (A1)  M1 A1     [2]
Explanation:
For the rod to be in equilibrium, the sum of moments about any point must be zero.  
Considering moments about point **P**:  
- The weight **W** acts through **P**, so its moment about **P** is zero.  
- The tension **T** in the cord also acts through **P** (as **P** lies on the cord), so its moment about **P** is zero.  
- For equilibrium, the moment from the hinge force **F** about **P** must also be zero. This is only possible if the line of action of **F** passes through **P**.  

Thus, all three forces (**W**, **T**, **F**) must intersect at **P** to satisfy rotational equilibrium.  

[2]

Question: A rod AB is hinged to a wall at A. The rod is held horizontally by means of a cord BD, attached to the rod at end B and to the wall at D, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod has weight W and the centre of gravity of the rod is at C. The rod is held in equilibrium by a force T in the cord and a force F produced at the hinge.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/06The forces F and T make angles α and β respectively with the rod and AC = 2/3AB, as shown in Fig. 2.1. Write down equations, in terms of F, W, T, α and β, to represent  the resolution of forces horizontally, .......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: Fcosα = Tcosβ B1 [1]
Explanation:
The horizontal components of forces F and T must balance for equilibrium.  
Resolving horizontally:  
\( F \cos\alpha = T \cos\beta \).  

[1]

Question: A rod AB is hinged to a wall at A. The rod is held horizontally by means of a cord BD, attached to the rod at end B and to the wall at D, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod has weight W and the centre of gravity of the rod is at C. The rod is held in equilibrium by a force T in the cord and a force F produced at the hinge.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/06The forces F and T make angles α and β respectively with the rod and AC = 2/3AB, as shown in Fig. 2.1. Write down equations, in terms of F, W, T, α and β, to represent  the resolution of forces vertically, .......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: W = Fsinα + Tsinβ B1 [1]
Explanation:
For vertical equilibrium, the sum of upward vertical components of forces **F** and **T** must balance the downward weight **W**.  
Resolving vertically:  
**W = F sinα + T sinβ**  

(Upward components: *F sinα* from the hinge force and *T sinβ* from the tension. These equal the downward weight *W*.)  

[1]

Question: A rod AB is hinged to a wall at A. The rod is held horizontally by means of a cord BD, attached to the rod at end B and to the wall at D, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The rod has weight W and the centre of gravity of the rod is at C. The rod is held in equilibrium by a force T in the cord and a force F produced at the hinge.  Q2/9702/02/M/J/06The forces F and T make angles α and β respectively with the rod and AC = 2/3AB, as shown in Fig. 2.1. Write down equations, in terms of F, W, T, α and β, to represent  the taking of moments about A. .......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: 2W = 3Tsinβ B1 [1]
Explanation:
Taking moments about point A, the clockwise moment due to the weight \( W \) (acting at \( C \), distance \( \frac{2}{3}AB \) from \( A \)) must equal the anticlockwise moment due to the vertical component of tension \( T \sin\beta \) (acting at \( B \), distance \( AB \) from \( A \)):  
\[
W \cdot \frac{2}{3}AB = T \sin\beta \cdot AB.
\]  
Simplifying:  
\[
\frac{2}{3}W = T \sin\beta \quad \Rightarrow \quad 2W = 3T \sin\beta.
\]  

[1]

Question: Two forces, each of magnitude F, form a couple acting on the edge of a disc of radius r, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)   Q5/9702/02/M/J/04The disc is made to complete n revolutions about an axis through its centre, normal to the plane of the disc. Write down an expression for  the distance moved by a point on the circumference of the disc,   distance = .........................................................
Mark Scheme: distance = 2πnr B1 [2]
Explanation:
The distance moved by a point on the circumference is the total circumference traced during n revolutions.  
For one revolution, the circumference is \( 2\pi r \).  
For \( n \) revolutions, the total distance is \( n \times 2\pi r \).  
Thus, \( \text{distance} = 2\pi nr \).  

[2]

Question: Two forces, each of magnitude F, form a couple acting on the edge of a disc of radius r, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)   Q5/9702/02/M/J/04The disc is made to complete n revolutions about an axis through its centre, normal to the plane of the disc. Write down an expression for  the work done by one of the two forces.   work done = ..........................................................  [2]
Mark Scheme: work done = F × 2 πnr (accept e.c.f.) B1
Explanation:
The work done by one force is calculated as the force multiplied by the distance it moves. For each revolution, the point of application of the force moves along the circumference of the disc, which is \(2\pi r\). Over \(n\) revolutions, the total distance moved is \(2\pi r \times n\). Therefore, the work done by one force is:  
\[
\text{Work done} = F \times 2\pi r n = 2\pi n r F
\]  
(Each force acts tangentially, and displacement is along the circular path. The work done by one force is \(F \times\) total linear distance traveled.)  

Answer: \(2\pi n r F\)  

[2]

Question: Two forces, each of magnitude F, form a couple acting on the edge of a disc of radius r, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)   Q5/9702/02/M/J/04Using your answer to (a), show that the work W done by a couple producing a torque T when it turns through n revolutions is given by W = 2πnT. [2]
Mark Scheme: total work done = 2 × F × 2πnr but torque T = 2Fr hence work done = T × 2πn B1 B1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
