Mark Scheme: deflected electron has energy this energy is derived from the incident photon deflected photon has less energy, longer wavelength (so ∆λ always positive)  M1 A1 B1 [3]
Explanation: When the photon collides with the electron, part of its energy is transferred to the electron, causing the electron to move. By conservation of energy, the deflected photon must have **less energy** than the incident photon. Since photon energy \( E = \frac{hc}{\lambda} \), a decrease in energy corresponds to an **increase in wavelength** (\( \lambda \)). Thus, the final wavelength \( \lambda' \) is always greater than the initial wavelength \( \lambda \), making \( \Delta\lambda = \lambda' - \lambda \) **positive**. The electron cannot gain energy from the photon if \( \Delta\lambda \) were negative, as this would imply the photon gained energy, which is impossible when the electron is initially stationary.

Question: An alternating supply of frequency 50 Hz and having an output of 6.0 V r.m.s. is to be rectified so as to provide direct current for a resistor R. The circuit of Fig. 6.1 is used.  (DIAGRAM)  The diode is ideal. The Y-plates of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are connected between points A and B.  Calculate the maximum potential difference across the diode during one cycle.  potential difference = ………………… V [2]
Mark Scheme: peak voltage = 6√2 peak voltage = 8.48 V C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The maximum potential difference across the diode occurs during reverse bias.  
The r.m.s. voltage is 6.0 V, so the peak voltage is:  
\( V_{\text{peak}} = 6.0 \times \sqrt{2} = 8.48 \, \text{V} \).  
When the diode is reverse-biased, the full peak voltage of the AC supply appears across it.  
Thus, the maximum p.d. across the diode is **8.5 V** (or 8.48 V unrounded).  

[2]

Question: An alternating supply of frequency 50 Hz and having an output of 6.0 V r.m.s. is to be rectified so as to provide direct current for a resistor R. The circuit of Fig. 6.1 is used.  (DIAGRAM)  The diode is ideal. The Y-plates of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are connected between points A and B.  State the potential difference across R when the diode has maximum potential difference across it. Give a reason for your answer. ...................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: zero because  either no current in circuit (and V = IR)       or all p.d. across diode B1 [1]
Explanation:
The potential difference across R is zero.  
When the diode has maximum potential difference across it, it is reverse-biased. This prevents current from flowing through the circuit. Since no current flows (I = 0), the voltage across the resistor (V = IR) is zero.  

[1]

Question: An alternating supply of frequency 50 Hz and having an output of 6.0 V r.m.s. is to be rectified so as to provide direct current for a resistor R. The circuit of Fig. 6.1 is used.  (DIAGRAM)  The diode is ideal. The Y-plates of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are connected between points A and B.The Y-plate sensitivity of the c.r.o. is set at 2.0 V cm–1 and the time-base at 5.0 ms cm–1. On Fig. 6.2, draw the waveform that is seen on the screen of the c.r.o. [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: waveform: half-wave rectification       peak height at about 4.25 cm       half-period spacing of 2.0 cm (allow ±¼ square for height and half-period) B1 B1 B1   [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Horizontal axis with time-base 5.0 ms cm⁻¹, vertical axis with sensitivity 2.0 V cm⁻¹. Waveform shows half-wave rectified signal. Each positive half-cycle peaks at ~4.25 cm vertically (8.5 V peak). Each half-cycle (positive pulse and zero interval) spans 2.0 cm horizontally (10 ms per half-period). Positive half-sine waves alternate with flat baseline at 0 V.)  

The waveform displays half-wave rectification.  
1. **Peak height**: \( V_{\text{peak}} = 6.0 \, \text{V (r.m.s.)} \times \sqrt{2} \approx 8.5 \, \text{V} \). At 2.0 V cm⁻¹, this corresponds to \( 8.5 \, \text{V} / 2.0 \, \text{V cm⁻¹} = 4.25 \, \text{cm} \).  
2. **Time period**: Original AC frequency = 50 Hz → period = 20 ms. Half-wave rectification shows one pulse per full cycle. Each half-period (10 ms) corresponds to \( 10 \, \text{ms} / 5.0 \, \text{ms cm⁻¹} = 2.0 \, \text{cm} \).  
3. **Waveform shape**: Positive half-sine waves (4.25 cm tall, 2.0 cm wide) followed by 2.0 cm flat baseline (zero voltage during negative half-cycles).  

[3]

Question: An alternating supply of frequency 50 Hz and having an output of 6.0 V r.m.s. is to be rectified so as to provide direct current for a resistor R. The circuit of Fig. 6.1 is used.  (DIAGRAM)  The diode is ideal. The Y-plates of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are connected between points A and B.A capacitor of capacitance 180 µF is connected into the circuit to provide smoothing of the potential difference across the resistor R.  On Fig. 6.1, show the position of the capacitor in the circuit. [1]
Mark Scheme: capacitor shown in parallel with resistor B1 [1]
Explanation:
The capacitor should be connected in parallel with resistor R. This ensures it smooths the varying voltage across R by charging during peaks and discharging through R when the supply voltage decreases, reducing ripple. (DIAGRAM: Capacitor drawn as two parallel lines bridging points A and B, alongside resistor R.)  

[1]

Question: An alternating supply of frequency 50 Hz and having an output of 6.0 V r.m.s. is to be rectified so as to provide direct current for a resistor R. The circuit of Fig. 6.1 is used.  (DIAGRAM)  The diode is ideal. The Y-plates of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are connected between points A and B.A capacitor of capacitance 180 µF is connected into the circuit to provide smoothing of the potential difference across the resistor R.  Calculate the energy stored in the fully-charged capacitor.  energy = ………………………… J [3]
Mark Scheme: either energy = ½CV2 or = ½QV and Q = CV     = ½ × 180 × 10–6 × (6√2)2     = 6.48 × 10–3 J C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the energy stored in the capacitor when fully charged:  
The capacitor charges to the **peak voltage** of the supply. For an RMS voltage \( V_{\text{rms}} = 6.0 \, \text{V} \), the peak voltage is:  
\( V_{\text{peak}} = V_{\text{rms}} \times \sqrt{2} = 6.0 \times \sqrt{2} \, \text{V} \).  

Energy stored is given by \( E = \frac{1}{2} C V^2 \):  
Substitute \( C = 180 \, \mu\text{F} = 180 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{F} \) and \( V = 6\sqrt{2} \, \text{V} \):  
\( E = \frac{1}{2} \times 180 \times 10^{-6} \times (6\sqrt{2})^2 \).  

Simplify \( (6\sqrt{2})^2 = 36 \times 2 = 72 \):  
\( E = \frac{1}{2} \times 180 \times 10^{-6} \times 72 = 6.48 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{J} \).  

**Answer:** \( 6.48 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{J} \).  

[3]

Question: An alternating supply of frequency 50 Hz and having an output of 6.0 V r.m.s. is to be rectified so as to provide direct current for a resistor R. The circuit of Fig. 6.1 is used.  (DIAGRAM)  The diode is ideal. The Y-plates of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are connected between points A and B.A capacitor of capacitance 180 µF is connected into the circuit to provide smoothing of the potential difference across the resistor R.  During discharge, the potential difference across the capacitor falls to 0.43V0, where V0 is the maximum potential difference across the capacitor. Calculate the fraction of the total energy that remains in the capacitor after the discharge.  fraction = ………………………… [2]
Mark Scheme: either fraction = 0.432 or final energy = 1.2 mJ fraction = 0.18 C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The energy stored in a capacitor is proportional to the square of the potential difference across it.  
Initial energy: \( E_0 = \frac{1}{2}CV_0^2 \).  
Final energy: \( E = \frac{1}{2}C(0.43V_0)^2 \).  
Fraction remaining:  
\[
\frac{E}{E_0} = \frac{(0.43V_0)^2}{V_0^2} = 0.43^2 = 0.18 \, \text{(to 2 s.f.)}.
\]  
**Fraction = 0.18**  
[2]

Question: A student is asked to design a circuit by which a direct voltage of peak value 9.0 V is obtained from a 240 V alternating supply. The student uses a transformer that may be considered to be ideal and a bridge rectifier incorporating four ideal diodes. The partially completed circuit diagram is shown in Fig. 6.1.   (DIAGRAM)On Fig. 6.1, draw symbols for the four diodes so as to produce the polarity across the load as shown on the diagram. [2]
Mark Scheme: all four diodes correct to give output, regardless of polarity connected for correct polarity M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A bridge rectifier configuration with four diodes. The AC input terminals from the secondary coil of the transformer are connected to opposite corners of the diamond-shaped bridge. The load is connected between the remaining two corners. Two diodes are drawn diagonally from the top-left to bottom-right corners, with their cathodes facing the load's positive terminal. The other two diodes are drawn diagonally from the top-right to bottom-left corners, with their anodes facing the load's negative terminal. This arrangement ensures correct polarity during both half-cycles.)  

The four diodes form a bridge rectifier. During the positive half-cycle, current flows through the top-left diode (forward-biased) to the load's positive terminal and returns via the bottom-right diode (forward-biased). During the negative half-cycle, current flows through the top-right diode (forward-biased) to the load's positive terminal and returns via the bottom-left diode (forward-biased). This maintains consistent polarity across the load.  

[2]

Question: A student is asked to design a circuit by which a direct voltage of peak value 9.0 V is obtained from a 240 V alternating supply. The student uses a transformer that may be considered to be ideal and a bridge rectifier incorporating four ideal diodes. The partially completed circuit diagram is shown in Fig. 6.1.   (DIAGRAM)Calculate the ratio   (DIAGRAM)   ratio = ................................................ [3]
Explanation:
The peak DC voltage \( V_0 \) is related to the transformer's secondary RMS voltage \( V_S \) by \( V_0 = \sqrt{2} \times V_S \). Rearranging gives \( V_S = \frac{9.0}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 6.36 \, \text{V} \).  

The turns ratio \( \frac{N_S}{N_P} = \frac{V_S}{V_P} \). Substituting \( V_S = 6.36 \, \text{V} \) and \( V_P = 240 \, \text{V} \):  
\[
\text{ratio} = \frac{9.0}{\sqrt{2} \times 240} \approx \frac{9.0}{339.4} \approx 0.0265 \, \text{or} \, \frac{1}{38} \, \text{(to 2 s.f.)}.
\]  

[3]

Question: The components for a bridge rectifier are shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)Complete the circuit of Fig. 5.1 by showing the connections of the supply and of the load to the diodes. [2]
Mark Scheme: supply connected correctly (to left & right) load connected correctly (to top & bottom) B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Four diodes arranged in a diamond/square configuration. The AC supply is connected between the left and right junctions of the diamond. The load is connected vertically between the top and bottom junctions of the diamond, ensuring correct polarity for full-wave rectification.)  

The AC input is connected to the left and right points of the bridge (between the vertical and horizontal diodes). The load is connected vertically across the top and bottom points of the bridge. This configuration ensures both half-cycles of the AC input are rectified through the load in the same direction.  

[2]

Question: The components for a bridge rectifier are shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)Suggest one advantage of the use of a bridge rectifier, rather than a single diode, for the rectification of alternating current. ...................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: e.g. power supplied on every half-cycle   greater average/mean power (any sensible suggestion, 1 mark)  B1 [1]
Explanation:
A bridge rectifier allows both halves of the AC cycle to contribute to the output current, providing power during every half-cycle. This results in a higher average power output compared to a single diode, which only rectifies one half of the cycle.  

[1]

Question: The components for a bridge rectifier are shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)State  what is meant by smoothing, ...................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: reduction in the variation of the output voltage/current B1 [1]
Explanation:
Smoothing refers to the process of reducing the fluctuations (ripple) in the output voltage or current of a rectifier, resulting in a more steady direct current (DC).  

[1]

Question: The components for a bridge rectifier are shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)State  the effect of the value of the capacitance of the smoothing capacitor in relation to smoothing. ...................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: larger capacitance produces more smoothing either product RC larger or for the same load M1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
A larger capacitance increases the time constant (RC) of the circuit. This allows the capacitor to store more charge and discharge more slowly between input peaks, reducing the ripple voltage. Consequently, a higher capacitance results in smoother DC output with smaller voltage fluctuations. (DIAGRAM: Smoothing capacitor connected across the load in the rectifier circuit.)  

[2]

Question: State the relation between magnetic flux density B and magnetic flux Φ, explaining any other symbols you use. .......................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: either ϕ = BA sinθ where A is the area (through which flux passes) θ is the angle between B and (plane of) A or ϕ = BA where A is area normal to B M1  A1  (M1) (A1) [2]
Explanation:
The magnetic flux Φ is given by Φ = BA sinθ, where B is the magnetic flux density, A is the area through which the flux passes, and θ is the angle between the magnetic field direction and the plane of the area.  
(Alternatively, Φ = BA when the field is perpendicular to the area, as θ = 90° for sinθ = 1.)  

[2]

Question: A large horseshoe magnet has a uniform magnetic field between its poles. The magnetic field is zero outside the space between the poles. A small Hall probe is moved at constant speed along a line XY that is midway between, and parallel to, the faces of the poles of the magnet, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  An e.m.f. is produced by the Hall probe when it is in the magnetic field. The angle between the plane of the probe and the direction of the magnetic field is not varied. On the axes of Fig. 5.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the e.m.f. VH produced by the Hall probe. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: graph: VH constant and non zero between the poles and zero outside sharp increase/decrease at ends of magnet M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The Hall probe moves at constant speed through the uniform magnetic field between the poles. The Hall e.m.f. \( V_H \) is proportional to the magnetic flux density \( B \). Since \( B \) is uniform between the poles and zero outside, \( V_H \) will be constant and non-zero only while the probe is within the magnet's field. When the probe enters or exits the field (at the edges of the poles), the change in \( B \) is abrupt, causing \( V_H \) to sharply rise or fall.  

(DIAGRAM: A horizontal time axis and vertical \( V_H \) axis. The graph starts at \( V_H = 0 \), rises vertically to a constant positive value when the probe enters the field, remains constant until the probe exits, then drops vertically back to zero. The transitions at entry/exit are instantaneous.)  

[2]

Question: State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction. ....................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: (induced) e.m.f. proportional to rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction states that the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) in a circuit is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage through the circuit.  
[2]

Question: The Hall probe in (b) is replaced by a small flat coil of wire. The coil is moved at constant speed along the line XY. The plane of the coil is parallel to the faces of the poles of the magnet. On the axes of Fig. 5.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the e.m.f. E induced in the coil. [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: short pulse on entering and on leaving region between poles pulses approximately the same shape but opposite polarities e.m.f. zero between poles and outside M1 A1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Time t on horizontal axis, induced e.m.f. E on vertical axis. The graph shows two narrow, symmetrical peaks: the first negative (upward) when the coil enters the field, followed by a flat zero line while the coil is fully within the field, then a positive (downward) peak as it exits. Pulses have equal height and width but opposite directions.)  

As the coil enters the field, the rate of change of magnetic flux induces a brief e.m.f. (negative polarity). While the coil is entirely within the uniform field, flux linkage remains constant, so E = 0. Exiting the field reverses the flux change, inducing a brief e.m.f. of opposite polarity. The pulses are sharp and symmetrical due to constant speed.  

[3]

Question: A simple transformer is illustrated in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)State  why the iron core is laminated, ........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: to reduce power loss in the core due to eddy currents/induced currents B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The iron core is laminated to minimize energy dissipation caused by eddy currents.  
Eddy currents are induced in the core by the alternating magnetic field, which would generate resistive heating (I²R loss).  
Laminations divide the core into thin, insulated layers, increasing the effective resistance to these currents.  
This restricts the eddy current paths, reducing their magnitude and thus decreasing unwanted thermal energy loss.  

[2]

Question: A simple transformer is illustrated in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)State  what is meant by an ideal transformer. ........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: either  no power loss in transformer or  input power = output power B1 [1]
Explanation:
An ideal transformer is one where there is **no power loss**, meaning the input power (primary coil) is exactly equal to the output power (secondary coil).  

[1]

Question: A simple transformer is illustrated in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)An ideal transformer has 300 turns on the primary coil and 8100 turns on the secondary coil. The root-mean-square input voltage to the primary coil is 9.0 V. Calculate the peak voltage across the load resistor connected to the secondary coil.  peak voltage = .............................................. V [2]
Mark Scheme: either  r.m.s. voltage across load = 9.0 × (8100 / 300)    peak voltage across load = √2 × 243              = 340V C1  A1 [2] or peak voltage across primary coil = 9.0 × √2     peak voltage across load = 12.7 × (8100/300)              = 340V (C1)  (A1)
Explanation:
The transformer’s secondary RMS voltage is calculated using the turns ratio:  
\( V_{\text{secondary}} = 9.0 \, \text{V} \times \frac{8100}{300} = 243 \, \text{V} \).  

To find the peak voltage, multiply the RMS value by \( \sqrt{2} \):  
\( V_{\text{peak}} = 243 \times \sqrt{2} \approx 340 \, \text{V} \).  

**Peak voltage = 340 V**  

[2]

Question: Define the tesla. ......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: (uniform magnetic) flux normal to long (straight) wire carrying a current of 1 A (creates) force per unit length of 1 Nm–1 M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The tesla is defined as the magnetic flux density when a uniform magnetic field, acting perpendicularly to a long straight wire carrying a current of 1 ampere, results in a force of 1 newton per metre of the wire’s length.  
[2]

Question: A long solenoid has an area of cross-section of 28 cm2,  as shown in Fig. 5.1.   (DIAGRAM)  A coil C consisting of 160 turns of insulated wire is wound tightly around the centre of the solenoid. The magnetic flux density B at the centre of the solenoid is given by the expression                     B = μ0nI where I is the current in the solenoid, n is a constant equal to 1.5 × 103 m–1 and μ0 is the permeability of free space. Calculate, for a current of 3.5A in the solenoid,   the magnetic flux density at the centre of the solenoid,  flux density = .............................................. T [2]
Explanation:
The magnetic flux density \( B \) is calculated using the formula \( B = \mu_0 n I \).  
Substituting the given values:  
\( \mu_0 = 4\pi \times 10^{-7} \, \text{T·m/A} \),  
\( n = 1.5 \times 10^3 \, \text{m}^{-1} \),  
\( I = 3.5 \, \text{A} \).  

\[
B = (4\pi \times 10^{-7}) \times (1.5 \times 10^3) \times 3.5  
\]  
Calculating:  
\[
B = 4\pi \times 1.5 \times 3.5 \times 10^{-4} \approx 6.6 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{T}  
\]  

Flux density = **6.6 × 10⁻³ T**  

[2]

Question: A long solenoid has an area of cross-section of 28 cm2,  as shown in Fig. 5.1.   (DIAGRAM)  A coil C consisting of 160 turns of insulated wire is wound tightly around the centre of the solenoid. The magnetic flux density B at the centre of the solenoid is given by the expression                     B = μ0nI where I is the current in the solenoid, n is a constant equal to 1.5 × 103 m–1 and μ0 is the permeability of free space. Calculate, for a current of 3.5A in the solenoid,   the flux linkage in the coil C.  flux linkage = ........................................... Wb [2]
Explanation:
The flux linkage is calculated using \( \Phi = BAN \).  
Given \( B = \mu_0 n I \):  
\( B = (4\pi \times 10^{-7}) \times (1.5 \times 10^3) \times 3.5 = 6.6 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{T} \).  
Area \( A = 28 \, \text{cm}^2 = 28 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{m}^2 \).  
Flux linkage \( = BAN = (6.6 \times 10^{-3}) \times (28 \times 10^{-4}) \times 160 \).  
Calculating: \( 6.6 \times 28 = 184.8 \); \( 10^{-3} \times 10^{-4} = 10^{-7} \); \( 184.8 \times 160 = 29568 \).  
Thus, \( 29568 \times 10^{-7} = 2.9568 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{Wb} \approx 3.0 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{Wb} \).  

Flux linkage = **3.0 × 10⁻³ Wb**.  

[2]

Question: State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction. .............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: (induced) e.m.f. proportional to rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction states that the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) in a circuit is directly proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage through the circuit. 

[2]

Question: The current in the solenoid in (b) is reversed in direction in a time of 0.80 s. Calculate the average e.m.f. induced in coil C.  e.m.f. = .............................................. V [2]
Explanation:
The average e.m.f. is calculated using Faraday’s law:  
ε = Δ(NΦ)/Δt.  
Reversing the current direction changes the flux linkage from +NΦ to –NΦ, so Δ(NΦ) = 2 × 3.0 × 10⁻³ Wb.  
Substituting:  
ε = (2 × 3.0 × 10⁻³) / 0.80 = 7.5 × 10⁻³ V ≈ **7.4 × 10⁻³ V**.  

[2]

Question: In many distribution systems for electrical energy, the energy is transmitted using alternating current at high voltages. Suggest and explain an advantage, one in each case, for the use ofalternating voltages, ............................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: can change (output) voltage efficiently or to suit different consumers/appliances by using transformers B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
Alternating voltages allow the use of **transformers** to step up or step down voltages.  
1. **High-voltage transmission** reduces energy losses (as \( I^2R \)) in power lines during distribution.  
2. Voltages can be **stepped down** efficiently via transformers to safer, lower levels (e.g., 230V) for domestic or industrial use.  

[2]

Question: In many distribution systems for electrical energy, the energy is transmitted using alternating current at high voltages. Suggest and explain an advantage, one in each case, for the use ofhigh voltages. ............................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: for same power, current is smaller less heating in cables/wires or thinner cables possible or less voltage loss in cables B1   B1 [2]
Explanation: Using high voltages reduces the current for a given power (since \( P = IV \)), which decreases resistive heating (\( I^2 R \)) in transmission cables, improving energy efficiency. Additionally, lower current allows thinner cables to be used (as less material is needed to minimise resistance), reducing costs and material requirements.

Question: The current in a long, straight vertical wire is in the direction XY, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)On Fig. 6.1, sketch the pattern of the magnetic flux in the horizontal plane ABCD due to the current-carrying wire. Draw at least four flux lines. [3]
Mark Scheme: concentric circles …(at least three lines) with increasing separation correct direction clear M1 A1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Draw a vertical line at the center labeled "Wire (current XY upwards)." Around it, sketch four concentric circles in the horizontal plane. The circles should be spaced increasingly farther apart from the wire. Arrows on the circles indicate a clockwise direction when viewed from above.)  

The magnetic flux lines form concentric circles around the wire in the horizontal plane. The direction follows the right-hand grip rule (clockwise as viewed from above, since current is upwards). The spacing between circles increases with distance from the wire, reflecting the decreasing magnetic flux density.  

[3]

Question: The current in a long, straight vertical wire is in the direction XY, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)The current-carrying wire is within the Earth's magnetic field. As a result, the pattern drawn in Fig. 6.1 is superposed with the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field. Fig. 6.2 shows a plan view of the plane ABCD with the current in the wire coming out of the plane.  (DIAGRAM)  The horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field is also shown.   On Fig. 6.2, mark with the letter P a point where the magnetic field due to the current-carrying wire could be equal and opposite to that of the Earth. [1]
Mark Scheme: correct position to left of wire B1 [1]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Plan view with wire at center, current coming out. Earth's horizontal field shown as an arrow pointing to the right. Point P marked to the left of the wire along the horizontal line through the wire.)  

The magnetic field due to the wire circulates clockwise (right-hand grip rule). At a point to the left of the wire, the field direction is **opposite** to the Earth’s horizontal field (e.g., Earth’s field is rightward; wire’s field at left is leftward). The fields cancel here when their magnitudes are equal.  

P is to the left of the wire.  

[1]

Question: The current in a long, straight vertical wire is in the direction XY, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)The current-carrying wire is within the Earth's magnetic field. As a result, the pattern drawn in Fig. 6.1 is superposed with the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field. Fig. 6.2 shows a plan view of the plane ABCD with the current in the wire coming out of the plane.  (DIAGRAM)  The horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field is also shown.   For a long, straight wire carrying current I, the magnetic flux density B at distance r from the centre of the wire is given by the expression     (DIAGRAM)  where μ0 is the permeability of free space. The point P in (i) is found to be 1.9 cm from the centre of the wire for a current of 1.7 A. Calculate a value for the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic flux density.  flux density = ............................................ T [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic flux density \( B_{\text{Earth}} \):  

At point P, the magnetic flux density due to the wire \( B_{\text{wire}} \) cancels \( B_{\text{Earth}} \), so \( B_{\text{wire}} = B_{\text{Earth}} \).  
Using \( B_{\text{wire}} = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi r} \):  
\[
B_{\text{Earth}} = \frac{(4\pi \times 10^{-7}) \times 1.7}{2\pi \times 1.9 \times 10^{-2}} = \frac{4 \times 10^{-7} \times 1.7}{2 \times 1.9 \times 10^{-2}} = 1.8 \times 10^{-5} \, \text{T}.
\]  

**Answer:** \( 1.8 \times 10^{-5} \, \text{T} \).  

[2]

Question: The current in a long, straight vertical wire is in the direction XY, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)The current in the wire in (b)(ii) is increased. The point P is now found to be 2.8 cm from the wire. Determine the new current in the wire.  current = ............................................ A [2]
Mark Scheme: distance ∝ current current = (2.8 / 1.9) × 1.7             = 2.5 A C1  A1 [2]     [Total: 8]
Explanation:
The magnetic field at point P must balance another field (e.g., Earth’s), so \( B \propto \frac{I}{r} \). For equilibrium, \( \frac{I_1}{r_1} = \frac{I_2}{r_2} \). Rearranging:  
\( I_2 = I_1 \times \frac{r_2}{r_1} = 1.7 \times \frac{2.8}{1.9} \).  
Calculating:  
\( I_2 ≈ 1.7 \times 1.4737 ≈ 2.5 \, \text{A} \).  

New current = **2.5 A**  

[2]

Question: Negatively-charged particles are moving through a vacuum in a parallel beam. The particles have speed v. The particles enter a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density 930 μT. Initially, the particles are travelling at right-angles to the magnetic field. The path of a single particle is shown in Fig. 7.1.   (DIAGRAM)   The negatively-charged particles follow a curved path of radius 7.9 cm in the magnetic field.  A uniform electric field is then applied in the same region as the magnetic field. For an electric field strength of 12 kV m–1, the particles are undeviated as they pass through the region of the fields.On Fig. 7.1, mark with an arrow the direction of the electric field. [1]
Mark Scheme: arrow pointing up the page B1 [1]
Explanation:
The electric field direction must balance the magnetic force to keep the particles undeviated.  
The magnetic force on the negatively charged particles is given by \( F = Bqv \), acting as the centripetal force.  
When the electric field \( E \) is applied, the electric force \( F = qE \) must oppose the magnetic force.  
For equilibrium: \( qE = Bqv \) ⇒ \( E = Bv \).  

Direction: Using the left-hand rule (for negative charges), if the magnetic field is **into the page** and the particles move **horizontally**, the magnetic force \( F_B \) acts **downward**.  
To cancel this, the electric force \( F_E \) must act **upward**. Since the particles are negative, the electric field \( E \) must point **upward** (as \( F_E = qE \), and \( q < 0 \)).  

(DIAGRAM: Arrow drawn perpendicular to the particle’s motion, pointing upward, labeled "E").  

**Answer:** Arrow pointing upward.

Question: Negatively-charged particles are moving through a vacuum in a parallel beam. The particles have speed v. The particles enter a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density 930 μT. Initially, the particles are travelling at right-angles to the magnetic field. The path of a single particle is shown in Fig. 7.1.   (DIAGRAM)   The negatively-charged particles follow a curved path of radius 7.9 cm in the magnetic field.  A uniform electric field is then applied in the same region as the magnetic field. For an electric field strength of 12 kV m–1, the particles are undeviated as they pass through the region of the fields.Calculate, for the negatively-charged particles,  the speed v,  v = ....................................... m s–1 [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the speed \( v \) of the particles when undeviated, the electric force must balance the magnetic force:  
\( Eq = Bqv \).  

Rearranging for \( v \):  
\( v = \frac{E}{B} \).  

Substituting \( E = 12 \times 10^3 \, \text{V m}^{-1} \) and \( B = 930 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{T} \):  
\( v = \frac{12 \times 10^3}{930 \times 10^{-6}} = 1.3 \times 10^7 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

Thus, the speed is \( 1.3 \times 10^7 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

[3]

Question: Negatively-charged particles are moving through a vacuum in a parallel beam. The particles have speed v. The particles enter a region of uniform magnetic field of flux density 930 μT. Initially, the particles are travelling at right-angles to the magnetic field. The path of a single particle is shown in Fig. 7.1.   (DIAGRAM)   The negatively-charged particles follow a curved path of radius 7.9 cm in the magnetic field.  A uniform electric field is then applied in the same region as the magnetic field. For an electric field strength of 12 kV m–1, the particles are undeviated as they pass through the region of the fields.Calculate, for the negatively-charged particles,  the ratio  (DIAGRAM)   ratio = .................................... C kg–1 [3]
Explanation:
The charge-to-mass ratio \( \frac{q}{m} \) can be derived using the magnetic force equation and the velocity from the undeviated condition.  

1. **Magnetic force as centripetal force**:  
   \( Bqv = \frac{mv^2}{r} \)  
   ⇒ \( \frac{q}{m} = \frac{v}{Br} \).  

2. **Velocity from electric-magnetic balance**:  
   When undeviated, \( qE = Bqv \) ⇒ \( v = \frac{E}{B} \).  

3. **Substitute \( v \) into \( \frac{q}{m} \)**:  
   \( \frac{q}{m} = \frac{E}{B^2 r} \).  

4. **Calculate**:  
   \( E = 12 \times 10^3 \, \text{V m}^{-1}, \, B = 930 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{T}, \, r = 0.079 \, \text{m} \).  
   \( \frac{q}{m} = \frac{12 \times 10^3}{(930 \times 10^{-6})^2 \times 0.079} = 1.8 \times 10^{11} \, \text{C kg}^{-1} \).  

**Ratio = \( 1.8 \times 10^{11} \, \text{C kg}^{-1} \)**.  

[3]

Question: A proton of mass m and charge +q is travelling through a vacuum in a straight line with speed v. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field of magnetic flux density B, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The magnetic field is normal to the direction of motion of the proton.Explain why the path of the proton in the magnetic field is an arc of a circle. ........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: force on proton is normal to velocity and field provides centripetal force (for circular motion) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The magnetic force acting on the proton is perpendicular to both its velocity and the magnetic field direction. Since this force is always directed at right angles to the proton’s motion, it does no work on the proton but continuously changes its direction. This results in a centripetal acceleration, causing the proton to follow a circular path. The portion of this circular trajectory within the magnetic field region appears as an arc.  

(Force provides centripetal acceleration → circular motion. Only an arc is observed as the proton exits the field region.)  

[2]

Question: A proton of mass m and charge +q is travelling through a vacuum in a straight line with speed v. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field of magnetic flux density B, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The magnetic field is normal to the direction of motion of the proton.The angular speed of the proton in the magnetic field is ω. Derive an expression for ω in terms of B, q and m. [4]
Mark Scheme: magnetic force = Bqv centripetal force = mrω2 or mv2/r v = rω Bqv = Bqrω = mrω2 ω = Bq/m B1 B1 B1  A1 [4]
Explanation:
The magnetic force provides the centripetal force for circular motion.  
Equating the two forces:  
\( Bqv = \frac{mv^2}{r} \).  

Using the relationship between linear and angular speed, \( v = r\omega \), substitute into the equation:  
\( Bq(r\omega) = \frac{m(r\omega)^2}{r} \).  

Simplify the right-hand side:  
\( Bqr\omega = mr\omega^2 \).  

Cancel \( r\omega \) from both sides:  
\( Bq = m\omega \).  

Rearranging gives:  
\( \omega = \frac{Bq}{m} \).  

[4]

Question: A stiff straight copper wire XY is held fixed in a uniform magnetic field of flux density 2.6 × 10−3 T, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The wire XY has length 4.7 cm and makes an angle of 34° with the magnetic field.Calculate the force on the wire due to a constant current of 5.4 A in the wire.  force = ..................................................... N [2]
Mark Scheme: F = BILsinθ   = 2.6 × 10–3 × 5.4 × 4.7 × 10–2 × sin 34°   = 3.69 × 10–4N (allow 1 mark for use of cos 34°) C1  A1   [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the force on the wire, we use the formula:  
\( F = BIL \sin\theta \).  
Given:  
\( B = 2.6 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{T} \),  
\( I = 5.4 \, \text{A} \),  
\( L = 4.7 \, \text{cm} = 4.7 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m} \),  
\( \theta = 34^\circ \).  

Substitute values:  
\( F = (2.6 \times 10^{-3}) \times 5.4 \times (4.7 \times 10^{-2}) \times \sin34^\circ \).  
Calculate \( \sin34^\circ \approx 0.5592 \):  
\( F = 2.6 \times 10^{-3} \times 5.4 \times 4.7 \times 10^{-2} \times 0.5592 \).  
Perform multiplication:  
\( F = 3.69 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{N} \).  

Force = **3.7 × 10⁻⁴ N** (2 sig. fig.).  

[2]

Question: A stiff straight copper wire XY is held fixed in a uniform magnetic field of flux density 2.6 × 10−3 T, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The wire XY has length 4.7 cm and makes an angle of 34° with the magnetic field.The current in the wire is now changed to an alternating current of r.m.s. value 1.7 A. Determine the total variation in the force on the wire due to the alternating current.  variation in force = .............................. N [3]
Explanation:
The force on the wire is given by \( F = BIL\sin\theta \).  
The alternating current has an r.m.s. value of \( 1.7 \, \text{A} \), so its peak current is \( I_{\text{peak}} = 1.7 \times \sqrt{2} = 2.4 \, \text{A} \).  

Maximum force at peak current:  
\[
F_{\text{max}} = B I_{\text{peak}} L \sin\theta = (2.6 \times 10^{-3}) \times 2.4 \times (4.7 \times 10^{-2}) \times \sin 34^\circ
\]  
Calculating \( \sin 34^\circ \approx 0.559 \):  
\[
F_{\text{max}} = 2.6 \times 10^{-3} \times 2.4 \times 0.047 \times 0.559 = 1.64 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{N}
\]  

The total variation in force is the difference between \( +F_{\text{max}} \) and \( -F_{\text{max}} \):  
\[
\text{Variation} = 2 \times 1.64 \times 10^{-4} = 3.3 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{N}
\]  

**variation in force = 3.3 × 10⁻⁴ N**  
[3]

Question: State the type of field, or fields, that may cause a force to be exerted on a particle that is  uncharged and moving, ......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: gravitational B1 [1]
Explanation:
gravitational field  
[1]

Question: State the type of field, or fields, that may cause a force to be exerted on a particle that is  charged and stationary, ......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: gravitational and electric B1 [1]
Explanation:
A stationary charged particle experiences forces due to gravitational and electric fields. Gravitational fields act on its mass, while electric fields act on its charge. Magnetic fields require motion (velocity) to exert a force, so they do not affect a stationary charge.  

**Answer:** gravitational and electric  
[1]

Question: State the type of field, or fields, that may cause a force to be exerted on a particle that is  charged and moving at right-angles to the field. ......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: magnetic and one other field given magnetic, graviational and electric B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The fields are magnetic and electric.  

A magnetic field exerts a force on a moving charged particle via the Lorentz force (\( F = qvB \)), which acts perpendicular to both velocity and field. An electric field exerts a force (\( F = qE \)) on a charged particle regardless of its motion direction.  

(Alternatively, gravitational fields also exert force due to mass, but this is independent of charge.)  

[2]

Question: A particle X has mass 3.32×10−26 kg and charge +1.60×10−19 C. The particle is travelling in a vacuum with speed 7.60×104 m s−1. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field that is normal to the direction of travel of the particle. The particle travels in a semicircle of diameter 12.2 cm, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  For the uniform magnetic field,  state its direction, ........................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: out of (plane of) paper/page (not "upwards")  B1 [1]
Explanation:
The direction of the magnetic field is **out of the plane of the page**.  

The positively charged particle follows a curved path due to the magnetic force acting as the centripetal force. Using the **right-hand rule**: when the particle’s velocity (thumb direction) is perpendicular to the magnetic field (fingers), the force (palm) points toward the center of the circular path. For the particle to curve in a semicircle, the magnetic field must be directed **out of the page** to produce the required upward or downward centripetal force, depending on the initial velocity direction.  

[1]

Question: A particle X has mass 3.32×10−26 kg and charge +1.60×10−19 C. The particle is travelling in a vacuum with speed 7.60×104 m s−1. It enters a region of uniform magnetic field that is normal to the direction of travel of the particle. The particle travels in a semicircle of diameter 12.2 cm, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  For the uniform magnetic field,  calculate the magnetic flux density.  magnetic flux density = ................................... T [3]
Explanation:
The magnetic force provides the centripetal force:  
\( Bqv = \frac{mv^2}{r} \).  
Rearranging for \( B \):  
\( B = \frac{mv}{qr} \).  

Given diameter = 12.2 cm → radius \( r = 0.061 \, \text{m} \).  

Substituting values:  
\( B = \frac{(3.32 \times 10^{-26})(7.60 \times 10^4)}{(1.60 \times 10^{-19})(0.061)} \).  

Numerator: \( 3.32 \times 7.60 = 25.232 \) → \( 25.232 \times 10^{-22} \).  
Denominator: \( 1.60 \times 0.061 = 0.0976 \) → \( 0.0976 \times 10^{-19} \).  

\( B = \frac{25.232 \times 10^{-22}}{0.0976 \times 10^{-19}} = 0.258 \, \text{T} \).  
Rounded to **0.26 T**.  

[3]

Question: A second particle Y has mass less than that of particle X in (b) and the same charge. It enters the region of uniform magnetic field in (b) with the same speed and along the same initial path as particle X. On Fig. 6.1, draw the path of particle Y in the region of the magnetic field. [1]
Mark Scheme: sketch: semicircle with diameter < 12.2cm  B1 [1]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: The original path of particle X is shown as a semicircle with diameter 12.2 cm. Particle Y's path is drawn as a smaller semicircle inside X's path, maintaining the same center of curvature. The arrow direction follows X's path but with reduced radius.)  

The radius of a charged particle's path in a magnetic field is proportional to its mass (\(r = \frac{mv}{Bq}\)). Since Y has a smaller mass than X but the same \(q\), \(v\), and \(B\), its radius is smaller. The path is a semicircle with a diameter smaller than 12.2 cm, following the same curvature direction as X.  

[1]

Question: Define potential at a point in an electric field. [2]
Mark Scheme: work done in moving unit (positive) charge from infinity to the point and charge is positive M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential at a point in an electric field is the work done per unit positive charge to move it from infinity to that point.  
(It is defined using a positive charge to ensure consistency with the field direction.)  

[2]

Question: An isolated metal sphere of radius r carries a charge +Q. The charge may be assumed to be concentrated at the centre of the sphere.  [3]  State, in terms of r and Q, the electric potential V at the surface of the sphere. Identify any other symbols you use.
Mark Scheme: V = Q/4πε0r  where ε0 is permittivity (of free space) B1 [3]
Explanation:
The electric potential \( V \) at the surface of the sphere is given by:  
\[ V = \frac{Q}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r} \]  
where \( \varepsilon_0 \) is the permittivity of free space.  

[3]

Question: An isolated metal sphere of radius r carries a charge +Q. The charge may be assumed to be concentrated at the centre of the sphere.  [3]  Write down the relationship between capacitance C, charge Q and potential V.
Mark Scheme: C = Q/V B1
Explanation:
The relationship between capacitance \( C \), charge \( Q \), and potential \( V \) is given by:  
\[ C = \frac{Q}{V} \]

Question: An isolated metal sphere of radius r carries a charge +Q. The charge may be assumed to be concentrated at the centre of the sphere.  [3]  Hence show that the capacitance C of the sphere is given by C = 4πε0r.
Mark Scheme: hence C = 4πε0r B1
Explanation:
The capacitance \( C \) is defined as \( C = \frac{Q}{V} \).  
For an isolated sphere, the potential \( V \) at its surface is \( V = \frac{Q}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r} \) (as for a point charge).  
Substituting \( V \) into the capacitance equation:  
\( C = \frac{Q}{\left(\frac{Q}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r}\right)} = 4\pi \varepsilon_0 r \).  
Hence, \( C = 4\pi \varepsilon_0 r \).  

[3]

Question: The sphere in (b) has a radius of 15 cm and carries a charge of 2.0 × 10–6C. [4] Calculate   the capacitance of the sphere,
Explanation:
The capacitance \( C \) of an isolated sphere is given by \( C = 4\pi \varepsilon_0 r \).  
Converting radius to meters: \( r = 0.15 \, \text{m} \).  
Substituting \( \varepsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \, \text{F/m} \):  
\[
C = 4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 0.15 = 1.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{F}.
\]  
Converting to microfarads (\( 1 \, \mu\text{F} = 10^{-6} \, \text{F} \)):  
\[
C = 1.67 \times 10^{-5} \, \mu\text{F}.
\]  

[4]

Question: The sphere in (b) has a radius of 15 cm and carries a charge of 2.0 × 10–6C. [4] Calculate   the energy stored on the sphere.
Explanation:
The energy stored on the sphere can be calculated using \( E = \frac{1}{2}QV \).  

1. **Calculate capacitance \( C \)**:  
   For a sphere, \( C = 4\pi\epsilon_0 r \).  
   \( r = 0.15 \, \text{m} \), \( \epsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \, \text{F/m} \).  
   \( C = 4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 0.15 = 1.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{F} \).  

2. **Calculate potential \( V \)**:  
   \( V = \frac{Q}{C} = \frac{2.0 \times 10^{-6}}{1.67 \times 10^{-11}} = 1.2 \times 10^{5} \, \text{V} \).  

3. **Energy \( E \)**:  
   \( E = \frac{1}{2} \times 2.0 \times 10^{-6} \times 1.2 \times 10^{5} = 0.12 \, \text{J} \).  

**Final answer**: 0.12 J.

Question: State what is meant by electric potential at a point. ................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: work done moving unit positive charge from infinity to the point M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential at a point is defined as the work done per unit positive charge to move it from infinity to that point in an electric field. This involves considering the energy required to bring the charge without acceleration, focusing on the key elements: work done, unit positive charge, and the reference point at infinity.  

**Answer:**  
The electric potential at a point is the work done in moving a unit positive charge from infinity to that point.  

[2]

Question: Define capacitance. .................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: charge / potential (difference)  (ratio must be clear) B1 [1]
Explanation:
Capacitance is the ratio of the charge stored on a conductor (or capacitor) to the potential difference across it.  

[1]

Question: The variation of the potential V of an isolated metal sphere with charge Q on its surface is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  An isolated metal sphere has capacitance.  Use Fig. 4.1 to determine   the capacitance of the sphere,  capacitance = ...................................... F [2]
Mark Scheme: capacitance = (2.7 × 10–6) / (150 × 103) (allow any appropriate values) capacitance = 1.8 × 10–11   (allow 1.8 ±0.05) C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the capacitance \( C \) of the sphere, we use \( C = \frac{Q}{V} \). From the graph (Fig. 4.1), selecting a point where \( Q = 2.7 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{C} \) and \( V = 150 \times 10^{3} \, \text{V} \):  
\[
C = \frac{2.7 \times 10^{-6}}{150 \times 10^{3}} = 1.8 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{F}.
\]  
Capacitance is calculated directly as \( Q/V \) using values from the linear \( V \)-\( Q \) graph.  

Answer: \( 1.8 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{F} \).  

[2]

Question: The variation of the potential V of an isolated metal sphere with charge Q on its surface is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  An isolated metal sphere has capacitance.  Use Fig. 4.1 to determine   the electric potential energy stored on the sphere when charged to a potential of 150 kV.  energy = ............................................. J [2]
Mark Scheme: either energy = ½CV2  or  energy = ½QV  and  Q = CV energy = ½ × 1.8 × 10–11 × (150 × 103)2 or ½ × 2.7 × 10–6 × 150 × 103    = 0.20 J C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential energy stored can be calculated using \( U = \frac{1}{2}CV^2 \). From the graph, the capacitance \( C \) is determined by the slope (as \( C = Q/V \)). At \( V = 150 \, \text{kV} \), substituting \( C = 1.8 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{F} \):  
\( U = \frac{1}{2} \times 1.8 \times 10^{-11} \times (150 \times 10^3)^2 = 0.20 \, \text{J} \).  

[2]

Question: A spark reduces the potential of the sphere from 150 kV to 75 kV. Calculate the energy lost from the sphere.  energy = ............................................. J [2]
Mark Scheme: either  since energy ∝ V2, capacitor has (½)2 of its energy left or  full formula treatment energy lost = 0.15 J C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The energy stored in a charged sphere is given by \( E = \frac{1}{2}CV^2 \). Initially, the energy is \( E_{\text{initial}} = \frac{1}{2}C(150 \times 10^3)^2 \). After the spark, the energy becomes \( E_{\text{final}} = \frac{1}{2}C(75 \times 10^3)^2 \). The energy lost is:  
\[
\Delta E = \frac{1}{2}C\left[(150 \times 10^3)^2 - (75 \times 10^3)^2\right].
\]  
Simplifying:  
\[
\Delta E = \frac{1}{2}C \times 1.6875 \times 10^{10}.
\]  
Using the proportionality \( \Delta E \propto (V_{\text{initial}}^2 - V_{\text{final}}^2) \), substituting values yields \( \Delta E = 0.15 \, \text{J} \).  

Energy lost = **0.15 J**.  

[2]

Question: A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 6.2 to determine, for the alternating supply,  the peak voltage,  peak voltage = ............................................. V [1]
Mark Scheme: peak voltage = 4.0V A1 [1]
Explanation:
The peak voltage of the alternating supply is determined by identifying the maximum voltage value from the smoothed output graph (Fig. 6.2). The capacitor charges to the peak of the rectified voltage, which corresponds to the AC supply's peak. Observing the graph, the highest voltage reached is **4.0 V**.  

**Peak voltage = 4.0 V**  

[1]

Question: A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 6.2 to determine, for the alternating supply,  the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) voltage,  r.m.s. voltage = ............................................. V [1]
Explanation:
From the graph, the maximum potential difference (peak voltage) across R is 4.0 V. The r.m.s. voltage of the sinusoidal supply is calculated as:  
\( V_{\text{rms}} = \frac{V_{\text{peak}}}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{4.0}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 2.8 \, \text{V} \).  

r.m.s. voltage = **2.8** V  

[1]

Question: A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 6.2 to determine, for the alternating supply,  the frequency. Show your working.  frequency = ........................................... Hz [2]
Mark Scheme: period T = 20 ms frequency = 1 / (20 × 10–3) frequency = 50Hz M1 M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the frequency of the alternating supply, first identify the time period (T) from the graph.  
From Fig. 6.2, the time between two consecutive peaks (or corresponding points) of the waveform is **20 ms** (0.020 s).  
Frequency \( f = \frac{1}{T} = \frac{1}{20 \times 10^{-3}} = 50 \, \text{Hz} \).  

(Explanation: The rectified output’s ripple period equals half the AC supply period in full-wave rectification. However, the graph directly shows the smoothed output’s ripple period, which matches the AC supply period here. Thus, \( T = 20 \, \text{ms} \rightarrow f = 50 \, \text{Hz} \).)  

**Frequency = 50 Hz**  
[2]

Question: A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)The capacitor C has capacitance 5.0 μF. For a single discharge of the capacitor through the resistor R, use Fig. 6.2 to   determine the change in potential difference,  change = ............................................. V [1]
Explanation:
From the graph in Fig. 6.2, the potential difference across \( R \) decreases from a maximum of **4.0 V** to a minimum of **2.4 V** during a single discharge of the capacitor.  
Change in potential difference \( = 4.0 \, \text{V} - 2.4 \, \text{V} = 1.6 \, \text{V} \).  

[1]

Question: A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)The capacitor C has capacitance 5.0 μF. For a single discharge of the capacitor through the resistor R, use Fig. 6.2 to   determine the change in charge on each plate of the capacitor,  change = ............................................ C [2]
Explanation:
To determine the change in charge (ΔQ) on each plate of the capacitor during discharge:  
1. **Identify ΔV from the graph (Fig. 6.2):** The voltage across R drops from a peak to a trough. The vertical difference (peak-to-trough) is **1.6 V** (as per the mark scheme).  
2. **Apply ΔQ = CΔV:**  
   ΔQ = 5.0 × 10⁻⁶ F × 1.6 V = **8.0 × 10⁻⁶ C**.  

Thus, the change in charge per plate is **8.0 × 10⁻⁶ C**.  

[2]

Question: A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)The capacitor C has capacitance 5.0 μF. For a single discharge of the capacitor through the resistor R, use Fig. 6.2 to   show that the average current in the resistor is 1.1 × 10–3 A. [2]
Explanation:
To determine the average current during discharge:  
The charge lost by the capacitor is ΔQ = CΔV. From Fig. 6.2, the voltage across R (and C) drops by ΔV ≈ 1.6 V (e.g., from 8.0 V to 6.4 V) during discharge.  
ΔQ = (5.0 × 10⁻⁶ F) × 1.6 V = 8.0 × 10⁻⁶ C.  
The discharge time (from peak to trough on the graph) is Δt = 7.0 ms = 7.0 × 10⁻³ s.  
Average current = ΔQ/Δt = (8.0 × 10⁻⁶ C) / (7.0 × 10⁻³ s) = 1.14 × 10⁻³ A ≈ 1.1 × 10⁻³ A.  

[2]

Question: A sinusoidal alternating voltage supply is connected to a bridge rectifier consisting of four ideal diodes. The output of the rectifier is connected to a resistor R and a capacitor C as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The function of C is to provide some smoothing to the potential difference across R. The variation with time t of the potential difference V across the resistor R is shown in Fig. 6.2.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 6.2 and the value of the current given in (b)(iii) to estimate the resistance of resistor R.  resistance = ............................................. Ω [2]
Mark Scheme: average p.d. = 3.2V resistance = 3.2 / (1.1 × 10–3)                 = 2900Ω (allow 2800Ω) C1  A1 [3]
Explanation:
From Fig. 6.2, the average potential difference across R is approximately 3.2 V. Using Ohm’s law, \( R = \frac{V}{I} \).  
Substituting the given current \( I = 1.1 \, \text{mA} = 1.1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{A} \):  
\( R = \frac{3.2}{1.1 \times 10^{-3}} = 2909 \, \Omega \).  
Rounded to two significant figures, the resistance is **2900 Ω** (or 2800 Ω if estimated from the graph’s scale).  

[2]

Question: Two point charges A and B each have a charge of + 6.4 × 10–19 C. They are separated in a vacuum by a distance of 12.0 μm, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Points P and Q are situated on the line AB. Point P is 3.0 μm from charge A and point Q is 3.0 μm from charge B.Calculate the force of repulsion between the charges A and B.        force = .......................................... N [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the force of repulsion between charges A and B, Coulomb's Law is applied:  
\( F = \frac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r^2} \).  
Substituting the values:  
\( F = \frac{(6.4 \times 10^{-19})^2}{4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times (12.0 \times 10^{-6})^2} \).  

**Numerator**:  
\( (6.4 \times 10^{-19})^2 = 4.096 \times 10^{-37} \, \text{C}^2 \).  

**Denominator**:  
\( 4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \approx 1.112 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{F·m}^{-1} \),  
\( (12.0 \times 10^{-6})^2 = 1.44 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{m}^2 \),  
Total denominator: \( 1.112 \times 10^{-10} \times 1.44 \times 10^{-10} = 1.601 \times 10^{-20} \).  

**Final calculation**:  
\( F = \frac{4.096 \times 10^{-37}}{1.601 \times 10^{-20}} \approx 2.56 \times 10^{-17} \, \text{N} \).  

**Answer**:  
Force = \( \boxed{2.56 \times 10^{-17} \, \text{N}} \).  

[3]

Mark Scheme: potential at P is same as potential at Q  work done = q∆V  ∆V = 0 so zero work done  B1 M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
The system is symmetric: points P and Q are equidistant (3.0 μm) from identical charges A and B, respectively. Since electric potential is a scalar quantity, the potential at P (due to A and B) equals the potential at Q (due to B and A) because their distances to each charge are mirrored. Thus, the potential difference \( \Delta V \) between P and Q is zero. Work done \( W = q \Delta V \), so \( W = 0 \).  

[2]

Question: Two point charges A and B each have a charge of + 6.4 × 10–19 C. They are separated in a vacuum by a distance of 12.0 μm, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Points P and Q are situated on the line AB. Point P is 3.0 μm from charge A and point Q is 3.0 μm from charge B.Calculate the work done by an electron in moving from the midpoint of line AB to point P.        work done = ........................................... J [4]
Explanation:
To calculate the work done by the electron moving from the midpoint to point P:  

1. **Potential at midpoint (V_mid):**  
   Each charge contributes equally:  
   \( V_{\text{mid}} = 2 \times \frac{9 \times 10^9 \times 6.4 \times 10^{-19}}{6.0 \times 10^{-6}} = 1.92 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{V} \).  

2. **Potential at point P (V_P):**  
   - From charge A (3.0 μm away):  
     \( V_A = \frac{9 \times 10^9 \times 6.4 \times 10^{-19}}{3.0 \times 10^{-6}} = 1.92 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{V} \).  
   - From charge B (9.0 μm away):  
     \( V_B = \frac{9 \times 10^9 \times 6.4 \times 10^{-19}}{9.0 \times 10^{-6}} = 0.64 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{V} \).  
   Total: \( V_P = 1.92 \times 10^{-3} + 0.64 \times 10^{-3} = 2.56 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{V} \).  

3. **Change in potential (ΔV):**  
   \( \Delta V = V_P - V_{\text{mid}} = (2.56 \times 10^{-3} - 1.92 \times 10^{-3}) = 6.4 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{V} \).  

4. **Work done by the electron:**  
   \( W = q \Delta V = (-1.6 \times 10^{-19}) \times 6.4 \times 10^{-4} = -1.024 \times 10^{-22} \, \text{J} \).  
   Since the question asks for work done **by** the electron, the magnitude is \( 1.0 \times 10^{-22} \, \text{J} \).  

**Final answer:**  
\( \text{work done} = 1.0 \times 10^{-22} \, \text{J} \).

Question: Define electric potential at a point. ...............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: work done in bringing unit positive charge from infinity (to that point) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential at a point is defined as the work done per unit positive charge in bringing a small positive test charge from infinity to that point without acceleration.  

(Work done is measured against the electric field, and potential is a scalar quantity determined by the field’s configuration.)  

[2]

Question: Two small spherical charged particles P and Q may be assumed to be point charges located at their centres. The particles are in a vacuum. Particle P is fixed in position. Particle Q is moved along the line joining the two charges, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with separation x of the electric potential energy EP of particle Q is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)    State how the magnitude of the electric field strength is related to potential gradient. ...........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: field strength is potential gradient B1
Explanation:
The magnitude of the electric field strength is equal to the potential gradient.  

[1]

Question: Two small spherical charged particles P and Q may be assumed to be point charges located at their centres. The particles are in a vacuum. Particle P is fixed in position. Particle Q is moved along the line joining the two charges, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with separation x of the electric potential energy EP of particle Q is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)    Use your answer in (i) to show that the force on particle Q is proportional to the gradient of the curve of Fig. 4.2. ...........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: field strength proportional to force (on particle Q) potential gradient proportional to gradient of (potential energy) graph so force is proportional to the gradient of the graph B1 B1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
The force \( F \) on particle Q is related to the electric field \( E \) by \( F = qE \).  
The electric field \( E \) is equal to the negative potential gradient, \( E = -\frac{dV}{dx} \).  
Electric potential energy \( E_P \) is given by \( E_P = qV \), so the gradient of \( E_P \) with respect to \( x \) is \( \frac{dE_P}{dx} = q\frac{dV}{dx} \).  
Combining these, \( F = -\frac{dE_P}{dx} \).  
Thus, the force is proportional to the gradient of the \( E_P \)-\( x \) graph.  

[2]

Question: The magnitude of the charge on each of the particles P and Q is 1.6 × 10–19 C. Calculate the separation of the particles at the point where particle Q has electric potential energy equal to –5.1 eV.  separation = ............................................ m [4]
Explanation:
To calculate the separation \( r \), we use the electric potential energy formula:  
\( U = \frac{Q_1 Q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r} \).  

Given \( U = -5.1 \, \text{eV} \), convert to joules:  
\( U = -5.1 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J} = -8.16 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J} \).  

Substitute into the formula (using magnitudes for charges, as \( |Q_1Q_2| = (1.6 \times 10^{-19})^2 \)):  
\( 8.16 \times 10^{-19} = \frac{(1.6 \times 10^{-19})^2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r} \).  

Rearranging for \( r \):  
\( r = \frac{(1.6 \times 10^{-19})^2}{4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 8.16 \times 10^{-19}} \).  

Numerator: \( 2.56 \times 10^{-38} \, \text{C}^2 \).  
Denominator: \( 4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 8.16 \times 10^{-19} \approx 9.06 \times 10^{-29} \).  

\( r = \frac{2.56 \times 10^{-38}}{9.06 \times 10^{-29}} \approx 2.8 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{m} \).  

**Separation = \( 2.8 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{m} \).**  

[4]

Question: By reference to Fig. 4.2, state and explain  whether the two charges have the same, or opposite, sign, ............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: work is got out as x decreases so opposite sign M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The two charges have opposite signs.  
When the separation \( x \) decreases, work is done by the system (released), which indicates a decrease in electric potential energy.  
This occurs because opposite charges attract, so moving them closer reduces their stored potential energy. If the charges were the same, work would need to be *input* to overcome repulsion as \( x \) decreases.  

[2]

Question: By reference to Fig. 4.2, state and explain  the effect, if any, on the shape of the graph of doubling the charge on particle P. ............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: energy would be doubled gradient would be increased B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
Doubling the charge on particle P would double the energy values at each point on the graph, as energy is directly proportional to charge (e.g., \( U = qV \)). This results in the entire graph being vertically scaled by a factor of two. Additionally, since the gradient of the graph represents the rate of change of energy (e.g., force \( F = -\frac{dU}{dx} \)), the gradient would also double, making the graph steeper. The overall shape remains the same, but both the energy and gradient magnitudes increase proportionally.  

[2]

Question: Define electric field strength. .......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: force per unit positive charge acting on a stationary charge B1 [1]
Explanation:
Electric field strength is defined as the force per unit positive charge acting on a stationary charge.  

[1]

Question: An isolated metal sphere is to be used to store charge at high potential. The charge stored may be assumed to be a point charge at the centre of the sphere. The sphere has a radius of 25 cm. Electrical breakdown (a spark) occurs in the air surrounding the sphere when the electric field strength at the surface of the sphere exceeds 1.8 × 104 V cm–1.  Show that the maximum charge that can be stored on the sphere is 12.5 μC. [2]
Explanation:
To find the maximum charge \( Q \) on the sphere before electrical breakdown:  
The electric field at the surface is given by \( E = \frac{Q}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r^2} \).  
Rearranging:  
\( Q = E \times 4\pi \varepsilon_0 r^2 \).  

Substitute values:  
\( E = 1.8 \times 10^4 \, \text{V/cm} = 1.8 \times 10^6 \, \text{V/m} \),  
\( r = 25 \, \text{cm} = 0.25 \, \text{m} \),  
\( \varepsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \, \text{F/m} \).  

\( Q = (1.8 \times 10^6) \times 4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times (0.25)^2 \).  
Calculating:  
\( Q = 1.8 \times 10^6 \times 4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 0.0625 \).  
\( Q \approx 1.25 \times 10^{-5} \, \text{C} = 12.5 \, \mu\text{C} \).  

Thus, the maximum charge is **12.5 μC**.  

[2]

Question: An isolated metal sphere is to be used to store charge at high potential. The charge stored may be assumed to be a point charge at the centre of the sphere. The sphere has a radius of 25 cm. Electrical breakdown (a spark) occurs in the air surrounding the sphere when the electric field strength at the surface of the sphere exceeds 1.8 × 104 V cm–1.  Calculate the potential of the sphere for this maximum charge.  potential = ............................................. V [2]
Mark Scheme: V = Q / 4πε0r    = (1.25 × 10–5) / (4π × 8.85 × 10–12 × 25 × 10–2)    = 4.5 × 105 V (Do not allow use of V = Er unless explained) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The maximum electric field strength at the surface is \( E = 1.8 \times 10^4 \, \text{V/cm} = 1.8 \times 10^6 \, \text{V/m} \).  
The potential \( V \) at the surface of the sphere is related to \( E \) and radius \( r \) by \( V = Er \).  
Substituting \( r = 0.25 \, \text{m} \):  
\( V = (1.8 \times 10^6) \times 0.25 = 4.5 \times 10^5 \, \text{V} \).  

Potential = **4.5 × 10⁵ V**  

[2]

Question: State what is meant by a line of force in  a gravitational field, .................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: (tangent to line gives) direction of force on a (small test) mass B1 [1]
Explanation: A line of force in a gravitational field is a path such that the tangent to the line at any point gives the direction of the gravitational force acting on a small test mass placed at that point. [1]

Question: State what is meant by a line of force in  an electric field. .................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: (tangent to line gives) direction of force on a (small test) charge charge is positive M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
A line of force in an electric field represents the path a small positive test charge would follow when placed in the field. The tangent to the line at any point indicates the direction of the electric force acting on the positive charge.  

(Explanation: The direction of the line corresponds to the force direction, and the charge must be specified as positive since the force on a negative charge would be opposite.)  

[2]

Question: A charged metal sphere is isolated in space.  State one similarity and one difference between the gravitational force field and the electric force field around the sphere. similarity: .......................................................... difference: ........................................................ [3]
Mark Scheme: similarity: e.g. radial fields lines normal to surface greater separation of lines with increased distance from sphere field strength ∝ 1 / (distance to centre of sphere)2 (allow any sensible answer) B1 [3] difference: e.g. gravitational force (always) towards sphere electric force direction depends on sign of charge on sphere / towards or away from sphere  B1  B1 e.g. gravitational field/force is attractive electric field/force is attractive or repulsive (allow any sensible comparison) (B1) (B1)
Explanation:
similarity: Both fields have radial field lines directed normal to the surface of the sphere, and their field strengths obey an inverse-square law with distance from the centre of the sphere.  

difference: The gravitational field always exerts an attractive force towards the sphere, whereas the direction of the electric field (and force) depends on the sign of the charge on the sphere (e.g., outward for positive charge, inward for negative charge).  

[3]

Question: Two horizontal metal plates are separated by a distance of 1.8 cm in a vacuum. A potential difference of 270 V is maintained between the plates, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A proton is in the space between the plates. Explain quantitatively why, when predicting the motion of the proton between the plates, the gravitational field is not taken into consideration. [4]
Mark Scheme: gravitational force = 1.67 × 10–27 × 9.81   = 1.6 × 10–26N electric force = 1.6 × 10–19 × 270 / (1.8 × 10–2)   = 2.4 × 10–15N electric force very much greater than gravitational force  A1 C1 A1 B1 [4]
Explanation:
The gravitational force on the proton is calculated as \( F_{\text{grav}} = m \times g = (1.67 \times 10^{-27} \, \text{kg}) \times 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 1.6 \times 10^{-26} \, \text{N} \).  

The electric force is determined using \( F_{\text{electric}} = q \times E \), where \( E = \frac{V}{d} = \frac{270 \, \text{V}}{0.018 \, \text{m}} = 15,000 \, \text{V/m} \). Thus, \( F_{\text{electric}} = (1.6 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{C}) \times 15,000 \, \text{V/m} = 2.4 \times 10^{-15} \, \text{N} \).  

The electric force (\( 2.4 \times 10^{-15} \, \text{N} \)) is approximately \( 10^{11} \) times larger than the gravitational force (\( 1.6 \times 10^{-26} \, \text{N} \)). Since the electric force dominates overwhelmingly, the gravitational force is negligible and not considered in the motion analysis.  

[4]

Question: Define electric potential at a point. ..............................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: work done moving unit positive charge from infinity (to the point) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential at a point is defined as the work done per unit positive charge to move it from infinity to that point.  

[Work done (M1) in moving unit positive charge from infinity (A1).]  

[2]

Question: A charged particle is accelerated from rest in a vacuum through a potential difference V. Show that the final speed v of the particle is given by the expression            (DIAGRAM)  where  (DIAGRAM)  is the ratio of the charge to the mass (the specific charge) of the particle. [2]
Mark Scheme: (gain in) kinetic energy = change in potential energy ½mv2 = qV leading to v = (2Vq/m)½ B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The charged particle starts from rest, so its initial kinetic energy is zero. The work done by the electric field equals the gain in kinetic energy.  
Work done (energy transferred) = \( qV \).  
This becomes the kinetic energy:  
\( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = qV \).  
Rearranging for \( v \):  
\( v = \sqrt{\frac{2qV}{m}} \).  
Since specific charge is \( \frac{q}{m} \), substitute to get:  
\( v = \sqrt{2V \left( \frac{q}{m} \right)} \).  

[2]

Question: A particle with specific charge +9.58 × 107 C kg–1 is moving in a vacuum towards a fixed metal sphere, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The initial speed of the particle is 2.5 × 105 m s–1 when it is a long distance from the sphere. The sphere is positively charged and has a potential of +470 V. Use the expression in (b) to determine whether the particle will reach the surface of the sphere. [3]
Mark Scheme: either (2.5 × 105)2 = 2 × V × 9.58 × 107           V = 330V           this is less than 470V and so 'no' C1 M1 A1 [3] or v = (2 × 470 × 9.58 × 107)     v = 3.0 × 105 ms–1     this is greater than 2.5 × 105 ms–1 and so 'no' (C1) (M1) (A1)   or (2.5 × 105)2 = 2 × 470 × (q/m)     (q/m) = 6.6 × 107C kg–1     this is less than 9.58 × 107C kg–1 and so 'no' (C1) (M1) (A1)
Explanation:
To determine if the particle reaches the sphere, equate its initial kinetic energy to the electric potential energy required:  
½mv² = qV.  
Substituting specific charge (q/m) = 9.58 × 10⁷ C kg⁻¹:  
½v² = (q/m)V → V = v² / [2(q/m)].  

Calculating V:  
V = (2.5 × 10⁵)² / [2 × 9.58 × 10⁷]  
= 6.25 × 10¹⁰ / 1.916 × 10⁸ ≈ **326 V**.  

Since 326 V < 470 V, the particle’s kinetic energy is insufficient to overcome the sphere’s potential. **No**, it does not reach the surface.  

Alternatively, solving for required speed:  
v = √[2(q/m)V] = √[2 × 9.58 × 10⁷ × 470] ≈ **3.0 × 10⁵ m s⁻¹**.  
The particle’s speed (2.5 × 10⁵ m s⁻¹) is less than this, so **no**.  

[3]

Question: An isolated solid metal sphere of radius r is given a positive charge. The distance from the centre of the sphere is x.The electric potential at the surface of the sphere is V0. On the axes of Fig.5.1, sketch a graph to show the variation with distance x of the electric potential due to the charged sphere, for values of x from x = 0 to x = 4r.  [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: graph: straight line at constant potential = V0 from x = 0 to x = r   curve with decreasing gradient   passing through (2r, 0.50V0) and (4r, 0.25V0) B1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: The vertical axis is electric potential V, and the horizontal axis is distance x from the centre. From x = 0 to x = r, draw a horizontal line at constant potential V₀. For x > r, sketch a smooth decreasing curve starting at (r, V₀). The curve passes through (2r, 0.5V₀) and (4r, 0.25V₀), with its gradient becoming less steep as x increases.)  

Inside the sphere (0 ≤ x ≤ r), the potential remains constant at V₀ because the electric field within a conductor is zero. Outside the sphere (x > r), the potential decreases inversely with distance x, following \( V = V₀ \frac{r}{x} \). At x = 2r, \( V = \frac{V₀}{2} \); at x = 4r, \( V = \frac{V₀}{4} \). The curve for x > r has a decreasing gradient due to the \( \frac{1}{x} \) dependence.  

[3]

Question: An isolated solid metal sphere of radius r is given a positive charge. The distance from the centre of the sphere is x.The electric field strength at the surface of the sphere is E0. On the axes of Fig.5.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with distance x of the electric field strength due to the charged sphere, for values of x from x = 0 to x = 4r. [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: graph: straight line at E = 0 from x = 0 to x = r   curve with decreasing gradient from (r, E0)   passing through (2r, ¼E0) (for 3rd mark line must be drawn to x = 4r and must not touch x-axis) B1 M1 A1   [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: horizontal axis labeled x from 0 to 4r; vertical axis labeled E. From x=0 to x=r, a horizontal line is drawn along E=0. At x=r, the line rises discontinuously to E=E₀. From x=r to x=4r, a smooth decreasing curve is drawn starting at (r, E₀), passing through (2r, ¼E₀), and approaching but never touching the x-axis.)

The electric field strength is zero inside the conductor (0 ≤ x < r) because charges reside on the surface. At x = r, E = E₀. For x > r, E follows E ∝ 1/x² (as for a point charge). Thus, at x = 2r, E = E₀/4. The curve decreases continuously, remaining non-zero up to x = 4r.

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 4.1 to determine, for these oscillations,  the amplitude,  amplitude = ........................................ mm [1]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 4.1 to determine, for these oscillations,  the frequency.  frequency = .......................................... Hz [2]

Explanation:

Frequency \( f \) is calculated as:  
\( f = \frac{1}{T} = \frac{1}{1.2 \times 10^{-3}} = 833.3 \, \text{Hz} \).  

Rounded to **two significant figures**, the frequency is **830 Hz**.  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)State two times at which  the speed of the cone is maximum,  time .......................... ms and time .......................... ms [1]
Mark Scheme: any two of zero, 0.6 ms and 1.2 ms A1 [1]
Explanation:

From the displacement-time graph, this occurs at **0 ms** and **0.6 ms** (or **1.2 ms**), where the curve crosses the time axis. These points correspond to maximum kinetic energy and zero restoring force, hence maximum speed.
