Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)State two times at which  the acceleration of the cone is maximum.  time .......................... ms and time .......................... ms [1]
Mark Scheme: any two of 0.3 ms, 0.9 ms, 1.5 ms A1 [1]
Explanation:

[Any two correct times: 0.3 ms, 0.9 ms, 1.5 ms.]  

[1]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)The effective mass of the cone is 2.5 g. Use your answers in (a) to determine the maximum kinetic energy of the cone.  kinetic energy = ...................................... J [3]
Explanation:
To determine the maximum kinetic energy of the cone:  
The maximum velocity \( v_{\text{max}} \) occurs when the displacement \( x = 0 \). For SHM, \( v_{\text{max}} = \omega x_0 \). From part (a), the amplitude \( x_0 = 0.2 \, \text{mm} = 0.2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m} \) and frequency \( f = 830 \, \text{Hz} \).  
Angular frequency \( \omega = 2\pi f = 2\pi \times 830 = 5215 \, \text{rad s}^{-1} \).  
Thus, \( v_{\text{max}} = 5215 \times 0.2 \times 10^{-3} = 1.043 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

Kinetic energy \( E_k = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \):  
\( E_k = \frac{1}{2} \times 2.5 \times 10^{-3} \times (1.043)^2 \approx 1.4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{J} \).  

Maximum kinetic energy = **1.4 × 10⁻³ J**.  

[3]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)The loudspeaker must be designed so that resonance of the cone is avoided.  State what is meant by resonance. .................................................................... [2]

Explanation: Resonance occurs when the frequency of an external force (or impressed frequency) matches the natural frequency of the loudspeaker cone, resulting in vibrations with maximum amplitude. [2]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the cone of a loudspeaker is shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)The loudspeaker must be designed so that resonance of the cone is avoided.  State and briefly explain one other situation in which resonance should be avoided. .................................................................... [2]

Explanation:
One example is the vibration of car suspension systems. If the frequency of bumps on a road matches the natural frequency of the suspension, resonance occurs. This leads to large, potentially damaging oscillations, reducing control and comfort.  
(M1: car suspension as example. A1: explanation linking road bumps’ frequency to resonance.)

Question: State what is meant by  oscillations,  ...............................................................................................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: to-and-fro / backward and forward motion (between two limits) B1 [1]
Explanation:
Oscillations refer to a repetitive to-and-fro motion of an object or system between two fixed limits or positions.  

[1]

Question: State what is meant by  free oscillations,  ...............................................................................................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: no energy loss or gain / no external force acting / constant energy / constant amplitude B1 [1]
Explanation:
Free oscillations occur when a system oscillates without any external forces acting on it and with no energy loss, resulting in a constant amplitude.  

[1]

Mark Scheme: acceleration directed towards a fixed point acceleration proportional to distance from the fixed point / displacement B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
Simple harmonic motion is a type of oscillatory motion where the acceleration of an object is always directed towards a fixed equilibrium position. Additionally, the magnitude of this acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement of the object from that equilibrium position.  

[2]

Mark Scheme: acceleration is constant (magnitude)  so cannot be s.h.m. M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The motion is not simple harmonic.  
When the ball moves along each inclined plane, the component of gravitational acceleration along the plane is **constant** (since the gradient is fixed). This constant acceleration does **not** depend on the ball's displacement from the equilibrium (lowest) point. For simple harmonic motion, the acceleration must be **proportional** to the displacement and directed towards the equilibrium position. Here, the acceleration magnitude remains the same regardless of displacement, so the motion cannot be SHM.  

[2]

Mark Scheme: acceleration / force proportional to displacement from a fixed point acceleration / force (always) directed towards that fixed point / in opposite direction to displacement  M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Simple harmonic motion is a type of oscillatory motion where the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to its displacement from a fixed equilibrium position and is always directed towards that position. This means the acceleration acts in the opposite direction to the displacement, causing the object to oscillate periodically around the equilibrium point.  

[2]

Question: A tube, sealed at one end, has a total mass m and a uniform area of cross-section A. The tube floats upright in a liquid of density ρ with length L submerged, as shown in Fig. 3.1a.  (DIAGRAM)  The tube is displaced vertically and then released. The tube oscillates vertically in the liquid. At one time, the displacement is x, as shown in Fig. 3.1b.  Theory shows that the acceleration a of the tube is given by the expression  (DIAGRAM)         Explain how it can be deduced from the expression that the tube is moving with simple harmonic motion.  .................................................................................................................................. .................................................................................................................................. ..............................................................................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: Aρg / m is a constant and so acceleration proportional to x negative sign shows acceleration towards a fixed point / in opposite direction to displacement B1  B1 [2]
Explanation:
The expression for acceleration is \( a = -\left( \frac{A\rho g}{m} \right)x \). Since \( \frac{A\rho g}{m} \) is a constant, the acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement \( x \). The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is directed towards the equilibrium position (opposite to the displacement). These two conditions—proportionality to displacement and opposite direction—satisfy the defining equation of simple harmonic motion (\( a = -\omega^2 x \)).  

[2]

Question: A tube, sealed at one end, has a total mass m and a uniform area of cross-section A. The tube floats upright in a liquid of density ρ with length L submerged, as shown in Fig. 3.1a.  (DIAGRAM)  The tube is displaced vertically and then released. The tube oscillates vertically in the liquid. At one time, the displacement is x, as shown in Fig. 3.1b.  Theory shows that the acceleration a of the tube is given by the expression  (DIAGRAM)         The tube, of area of cross-section 4.5 cm2, is floating in water of density 1.0 × 103 kg m–3. Calculate the mass of the tube that would give rise to oscillations of frequency 1.5 Hz.       mass = ............................................. g [4]
Explanation:
To calculate the mass \( m \) of the tube for oscillations of frequency \( 1.5 \, \text{Hz} \):  
1. Angular frequency \( \omega = 2\pi f = 2\pi \times 1.5 \).  
2. From the given relation \( \omega^2 = \frac{A \rho g}{m} \):  
   \[
   (2\pi \times 1.5)^2 = \frac{(4.5 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{m}^2)(1.0 \times 10^3 \, \text{kg/m}^3)(9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2)}{m}
   \]  
3. Simplify the numerator:  
   \[
   4.5 \times 10^{-4} \times 10^3 \times 9.81 = 4.4145 \, \text{N/m}.
   \]  
4. Calculate the left-hand side:  
   \[
   (3\pi)^2 = 9\pi^2 \approx 88.826 \, \text{s}^{-2}.
   \]  
5. Solve for \( m \):  
   \[
   m = \frac{4.4145}{88.826} \approx 0.0497 \, \text{kg} = 50 \, \text{g} \, (\text{to 2 s.f.}).
   \]  
**mass = 50 g**  

[4]

Question: A small metal ball is suspended from a fixed point by means of a string, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is pulled a small distance to one side and then released. The variation with time t of the horizontal displacement x of the ball is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The motion of the ball is simple harmonic.   Use data from Fig. 4.2 to determine the horizontal acceleration of the ball for a displacement x of 2.0 cm.          acceleration = ....................................... m s–2 [3]
Explanation:
The horizontal acceleration in SHM is given by \( a = -\omega^2 x \).  
From the displacement-time graph (Fig. 4.2), the period \( T \) is 0.60 s (time for one full oscillation).  
Angular frequency \( \omega = \frac{2\pi}{T} = \frac{2\pi}{0.60} \).  
Substituting into \( a = \omega^2 x \):  
\( a = \left(\frac{4\pi^2}{(0.60)^2}\right) \times 2.0 \times 10^{-2} = \frac{4\pi^2 \times 0.020}{0.36} \approx 2.2 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \).  

Acceleration = **2.2 m s⁻²**  
[3]

Question: A small metal ball is suspended from a fixed point by means of a string, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is pulled a small distance to one side and then released. The variation with time t of the horizontal displacement x of the ball is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The motion of the ball is simple harmonic.   The maximum kinetic energy of the ball is EK.  On the axes of Fig. 4.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the kinetic energy of the ball for the first 1.0 s of its motion.    (DIAGRAM) [3]
Mark Scheme: sinusoidal wave with all values positive all values positive, all peaks at EK and energy = 0 at t = 0 period = 0.30 s B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: On the kinetic energy-time axes, draw a smooth curve starting at (0,0). It rises to a peak of EK at t=0.15 s, returns to zero at t=0.30 s, rises again to EK at t=0.45 s, back to zero at t=0.60 s, peaks at t=0.75 s, and approaches zero near t=1.0 s. Each arch is symmetrical, with a period of 0.30 s between successive zeros.)  

The kinetic energy oscillates between 0 and EK, reaching maxima when the ball passes through equilibrium (max speed) and zeros at maximum displacement. The graph has a **sinusoidal shape** (all positive), **peaks at EK**, and a **period of 0.30 s**, repeating every 0.30 s.  

[3]

Mark Scheme: displacement (directly) proportional to acceleration/force either displacement and acceleration in opposite directions or acceleration (always) towards a (fixed) point M1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
Simple harmonic motion is a type of oscillatory motion where the **acceleration** of an object is **directly proportional** to its **displacement** from a fixed equilibrium position. The acceleration is always directed **towards the equilibrium point** and is in the **opposite direction** to the displacement.  

[Example: A mass-spring system or pendulum exhibits SHM when acceleration ∝ -displacement.]  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of two oscillators P and Q is shown in Fig. 4.1.   (DIAGRAM)  The two oscillators each have the same mass.  Use Fig. 4.1 to determine   the phase difference between the two oscillators,      phase difference = .................................... rad [1]
Mark Scheme: ⅓π rad or 1.05 rad (allow 60° if unit clear) A1 [1]
Explanation:
To determine the phase difference:  
1. **Identify one complete cycle (period T)** from the graph. Suppose the time between two consecutive peaks for one oscillator is T.  
2. **Compare corresponding points** (e.g., peaks or zero-crossings) of P and Q. For instance, if a peak of Q occurs Δt after P’s peak:  
   Phase difference = \( \frac{2πΔt}{T} \).  
3. From Fig. 4.1, if Q lags P by **T/6** (e.g., 1 division on the time axis corresponds to T/6), then:  
   Phase difference = \( \frac{2π}{6} = \frac{π}{3} \, \text{rad} \).  

Answer: \( \frac{π}{3} \, \text{rad} \)  
[1]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of two oscillators P and Q is shown in Fig. 4.1.   (DIAGRAM)  The two oscillators each have the same mass.  Use Fig. 4.1 to determine   the maximum acceleration of oscillator Q,          maximum acceleration = ........................... m s–2 [2]
Mark Scheme: a0 = –ω2 x0    = (–) (2π / 1.2)2 × 0.030    = (–) 0.82 ms–2 (special case: using oscillator P gives x0 = 1.7cm and a0 = 0.47 ms–1 for 1/2) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the maximum acceleration of oscillator Q:  

The maximum acceleration \( a_0 \) in SHM is given by \( a_0 = \omega^2 x_0 \), where \( \omega \) is angular frequency and \( x_0 \) is amplitude.  

From the graph for Q:  
- Amplitude \( x_0 = 0.030 \, \text{m} \) (3.0 cm).  
- Period \( T = 1.2 \, \text{s} \) (time for one complete oscillation).  

Angular frequency \( \omega = \frac{2\pi}{T} = \frac{2\pi}{1.2} \, \text{rad s}^{-1} \).  

Substitute into \( a_0 = \omega^2 x_0 \):  
\( a_0 = \left( \frac{2\pi}{1.2} \right)^2 \times 0.030 = 0.82 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \).  

Maximum acceleration = **0.82 m s⁻²**.  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of two oscillators P and Q is shown in Fig. 4.1.   (DIAGRAM)  The two oscillators each have the same mass.  Use Fig. 4.1 to determine   the ratio  (DIAGRAM)         ratio = .......................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: max. energy ∝ x02 ratio = 3.02 / 1.72     = 3.1 (at least 2 s.f.) (if has inverse ratio but has stated max. energy ∝ x02 then allow 1/2) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
From the displacement-time graphs, the amplitude of oscillator P is 3.0 units and that of Q is 1.7 units.  
The maximum energy of an oscillator is proportional to the square of its amplitude (\(E \propto x_0^2\)).  
Calculating the ratio of their maximum energies:  
\[
\text{Ratio} = \frac{(3.0)^2}{(1.7)^2} = \frac{9.0}{2.89} ≈ 3.1  
\]  
Thus, the ratio is **3.1**.  

[2]

Question: Use data from (b) to sketch, on the axes of Fig. 4.2, the variation with displacement x of the acceleration a of oscillator Q.  (DIAGRAM) [2]
Mark Scheme: graph: straight line through (0,0) with negative gradient correct end-points (–3.0, +0.82) and (+3.0, –0.82) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A pair of axes with 'a' on the vertical and 'x' on the horizontal. A straight line is drawn from the point (-3.0, +0.82) through the origin (0,0) to the point (+3.0, -0.82). The line has a constant negative gradient.)  

[The graph is a straight line passing through the origin with a negative slope. It starts at (–3.0, +0.82) and ends at (+3.0, –0.82), reflecting the proportionality \( a = -\omega^2 x \).]

Question: For an oscillating body, state what is meant by  forced frequency, ......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: frequency at which object is made to vibrate/oscillate B1 [1]
Explanation:
Forced frequency is the frequency at which an external force or driving agent causes the oscillating body to vibrate.  

[1]

Question: For an oscillating body, state what is meant by  natural frequency of vibration, ......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: frequency at which object vibrates when free to do so B1 [1]
Explanation:
The natural frequency of vibration is the frequency at which an object oscillates when it is displaced and then allowed to vibrate freely without any external forces acting on it.  

[1]

Question: For an oscillating body, state what is meant by  resonance. ......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: maximum amplitude of vibration of oscillating body when forced frequency equals natural frequency (of vibration) B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
Resonance occurs when an oscillating body reaches its **maximum amplitude** of vibration. This happens precisely when the frequency of the externally applied force (forced frequency) matches the **natural frequency** of the oscillating body. 

[2]

Question: State and explain one situation where resonance is useful. ................................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: e.g. vibration of quartz/piezoelectric crystal (what is vibrating)   either for accurate timing   or maximise amplitude of ultrasound waves (why it is useful) M1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
Resonance is useful in quartz crystal oscillators used in watches. The quartz crystal vibrates at its natural resonant frequency when an electric field is applied. This produces a highly stable and precise frequency, which is used to accurately regulate the timekeeping mechanism in clocks and electronic devices.  

[2]

Question: In some situations, resonance should be avoided.  State one such situation and suggest how the effects of resonance are reduced. .................................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: e.g. vibrating metal panels (what is vibrating)   either place strengthening struts across the panel   or change shape/area of panel (how it is reduced) M1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
Resonance can cause issues in vibrating metal panels, such as those in machinery or vehicles. To reduce resonance effects, stiffening struts can be added across the panels to alter their natural frequency and prevent resonant vibrations.  

[2]

Mark Scheme: temperature scale calibrated assuming linear change of property with temperature neither property varies linearly with temperature B1 B1 [2]
Explanation: Both thermometers rely on a physical property (resistance and voltage) that changes with temperature. Their calibrations assume these properties vary linearly with temperature. However, in reality, the actual variation may be non-linear. If the non-linearity differs between the two devices, their readings will diverge even when correctly calibrated and at equilibrium. [2]

Mark Scheme: does not depend on the property of a substance B1 [1]
Explanation: The absolute (Kelvin) temperature scale is independent of the physical properties (e.g., expansion/contraction) of any specific substance, unlike other scales such as Celsius or Fahrenheit which are defined using properties like the freezing/boiling points of water. [1]

Mark Scheme: temperature at which atoms have minimum/zero energy B1 [1]
Explanation:
Absolute zero is the temperature at which atoms (or particles) possess the minimum possible energy, with no remaining thermal energy available for transfer.  

[1]

Question: The temperature of a water bath increases from 50.00 °C to 80.00 °C.  Determine, in kelvin and to an appropriate number of significant figures,  the temperature 50.00 °C,      temperature = ..................................... K [1]
Explanation:
To convert 50.00°C to kelvin, use the formula:  
\( T_{\text{K}} = T_{\text{°C}} + 273.15 \).  
Substituting the value:  
\( T_{\text{K}} = 50.00 + 273.15 = 323.15 \, \text{K} \).  

The temperature 50.00°C corresponds to **323.15 K** (4 significant figures, matching the precision of the given Celsius value).  

[1]

Question: The temperature of a water bath increases from 50.00 °C to 80.00 °C.  Determine, in kelvin and to an appropriate number of significant figures,  the change in temperature of the water bath.      temperature change = ............................... K [1]
Explanation:
The temperature change in Celsius is 80.00 °C – 50.00 °C = 30.00 °C.  
Since a **change** in temperature in Celsius equals the change in kelvin,  
ΔT = 30.00 K.  

(As the initial temperatures are given to 4 significant figures, the change is also stated to 4 significant figures.)  

**Final Answer:**  
30.00 K  

[1]

Question: State what is meant by the internal energy of a system. ...........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: sum of potential energy and kinetic energy of atoms/molecules/particles reference to random (distribution) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The internal energy of a system is the total sum of the **random** kinetic energies (due to the motion of particles) and potential energies (due to interactions between particles) of all the atoms, molecules, or particles within the system. 

[2]

Question: State and explain qualitatively the change, if any, in the internal energy of the following systems:  a lump of ice at 0 °C melts to form liquid water at 0 °C, ...........................................................................[3]
Mark Scheme: as lattice structure is 'broken'/bonds broken/forces between molecules reduced (not molecules separate) no change in kinetic energy, potential energy increases internal energy increases  B1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The internal energy of the system increases. During melting, the ice's rigid lattice structure breaks as intermolecular bonds (hydrogen bonds) are overcome. The temperature (and thus the average kinetic energy of molecules) remains constant at 0°C. However, the potential energy of the molecules increases because work is done against intermolecular forces to allow greater molecular mobility in the liquid phase. Since internal energy is the sum of kinetic and potential energies, the overall internal energy rises.  

[3]

Question: State and explain qualitatively the change, if any, in the internal energy of the following systems:  a cylinder containing gas at constant volume is in sunlight so that its temperature rises from 25°C to 35 °C. ...........................................................................[3]
Mark Scheme: either  molecules/atoms/particles move faster/ <c2> is increasing or  kinetic energy increases with temperature (increases) no change in potential energy, kinetic energy increases internal energy increases  B1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The internal energy of the gas increases.  
When the temperature rises from 25°C to 35°C, the average kinetic energy of the gas molecules increases because kinetic energy is proportional to temperature.  
In an ideal gas (or where intermolecular forces are negligible), there is no potential energy change as the volume remains constant.  
Since internal energy is the sum of kinetic and potential energies, and only kinetic energy increases, the total internal energy of the system rises.  

[3]

Question: Define specific latent heat. ........................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: (numerically equal to) quantity of (thermal) energy required to change the state of unit mass of a substance without any change of temperature (Allow 1 mark for definition of specific latent heat of fusion/vaporisation)  M1 A1   [2]
Explanation:
Specific latent heat is the quantity of thermal energy required to change the state of **unit mass** of a substance **without a change in temperature**.  
(For example, during melting or vaporisation, this energy breaks intermolecular bonds while keeping temperature constant.)  

[2]

Question: The heater in an electric kettle has a power of 2.40 kW.  When the water in the kettle is boiling at a steady rate, the mass of water evaporated in 2.0 minutes is 106 g.  The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water is 2260 J g–1.  Calculate the rate of loss of thermal energy to the surroundings of the kettle during the boiling process.  rate of loss = ............................................ W [3]
Mark Scheme: either  energy supplied = 2400 × 2 × 60 = 288000J    energy required for evaporation = 106 × 2260 = 240000J    difference = 48000J    rate of loss = 48000 / 120 = 400W C1 C1  A1 [3] or  energy required for evaporation = 106 × 2260 = 240000J    power required for evaporation = 240000 / (2 × 60) = 2000W    rate of loss = 2400 – 2000 = 400W (C1) (C1) (A1)
Explanation:
The heater provides power \( P = 2400 \, \text{W} \). Over \( t = 2.0 \, \text{minutes} = 120 \, \text{s} \), the total energy supplied is:  
\[
E_{\text{supplied}} = 2400 \times 120 = 288{,}000 \, \text{J}.
\]  
Energy required to evaporate \( m = 106 \, \text{g} \) of water (using \( L = 2260 \, \text{J g}^{-1} \)):  
\[
E_{\text{vaporisation}} = 106 \times 2260 = 240{,}000 \, \text{J}.
\]  
Energy lost to surroundings:  
\[
288{,}000 - 240{,}000 = 48{,}000 \, \text{J}.
\]  
Rate of energy loss (power):  
\[
\frac{48{,}000}{120} = 400 \, \text{W}.
\]  
**Rate of loss = 400 W**  

[3]

Question: State what is meant by the internal energy of a system. [2]
Mark Scheme: sum of kinetic and potential energies of the molecules reference to random distribution M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The internal energy of a system is the **total sum** of the **random** kinetic energies (due to motion like vibration, rotation, or translation) and potential energies (from intermolecular forces) of all the molecules within the system. 

[2]

Question: Explain why, for an ideal gas, the internal energy is equal to the total kinetic energy of the molecules of the gas. [2]
Mark Scheme: for ideal gas, no intermolecular forces so no potential energy (only kinetic) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
For an ideal gas, there are no intermolecular forces between the molecules. This absence of forces means there is no potential energy associated with their interactions. Therefore, the internal energy of the gas consists solely of the total kinetic energy of all the molecules due to their random motion. 

[2]

Question: The mean kinetic energy <Ek> of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by the expression           <Ek> =  (DIAGRAM) kT where k is the Boltzmann constant and T is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas. A cylinder contains 1.0 mol of an ideal gas. The gas is heated so that its temperature changes from 280 K to 460 K.   Calculate the change in total kinetic energy of the gas molecules.  change in energy = ................................. J [2]
Explanation:
The total kinetic energy of the gas is given by \( \frac{3}{2}nRT \). For 1.0 mol, the change in kinetic energy is:  
\( \Delta KE = \frac{3}{2} \times 1.0 \times 8.31 \times (460 - 280) \).  
Calculating:  
\( \Delta KE = \frac{3}{2} \times 8.31 \times 180 = 2240 \, \text{J} \).  

Change in energy = **2240 J**  

[2]

Question: The mean kinetic energy <Ek> of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by the expression           <Ek> =  (DIAGRAM) kT where k is the Boltzmann constant and T is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas. A cylinder contains 1.0 mol of an ideal gas. The gas is heated so that its temperature changes from 280 K to 460 K.   During the heating, the gas expands, doing 1.5 × 103 J of work. State the first law of thermodynamics. Use the law and your answer in (i) to determine the total energy supplied to the gas.  total energy = ............................................. J [3]
Mark Scheme: increase in internal energy = heat supplied + work done on system 2240 = energy supplied – 1500 energy supplied = 3740J B1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The first law of thermodynamics states that the increase in internal energy (ΔU) of a system equals the heat supplied (Q) to the system plus the work done **on** the system (W):  
ΔU = Q + W.  

For the ideal gas, the increase in internal energy is calculated using ΔU = (3/2)nRΔT.  
Given n = 1.0 mol, R = 8.31 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹, ΔT = 460 K – 280 K = 180 K:  
ΔU = 1.5 × 1.0 × 8.31 × 180 = **2240 J**.  

The gas does **1.5 × 10³ J** of work (W = –1500 J, as work is done **by** the system). Rearranging the first law:  
Q = ΔU – W = 2240 – (–1500) = **3740 J**.  

Total energy supplied = **3740 J**.  

[3]

Question: A constant mass of an ideal gas has a volume of 3.49×103 cm3 at a temperature of 21.0 °C. When the gas is heated, 565 J of thermal energy causes it to expand to a volume of 3.87×103 cm3 at 53.0 °C. This is illustrated in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)Show that the initial and final pressures of the gas are equal. [2]
Mark Scheme: use of kelvin temperatures both values of (V/T) correct (11.87), V/T is constant so pressure is constant (allow use of n =1. Do not allow other values of n.) B1 M1   [2]
Explanation:
To show the pressures are equal, use the ideal gas law \( PV = nRT \). Since \( n \) and \( R \) are constant, \( \frac{V}{T} \) must be constant if \( P \) is constant.  

Convert temperatures to Kelvin:  
Initial \( T_1 = 21.0 + 273.15 = 294.15 \, \text{K} \),  
Final \( T_2 = 53.0 + 273.15 = 326.15 \, \text{K} \).  

Calculate \( \frac{V}{T} \):  
Initial: \( \frac{3.49 \times 10^3 \, \text{cm}^3}{294.15 \, \text{K}} = 11.87 \, \text{cm}^3 \, \text{K}^{-1} \),  
Final: \( \frac{3.87 \times 10^3 \, \text{cm}^3}{326.15 \, \text{K}} = 11.87 \, \text{cm}^3 \, \text{K}^{-1} \).  

Since \( \frac{V}{T} \) is constant, \( P \) remains unchanged.  

[2]

Question: A constant mass of an ideal gas has a volume of 3.49×103 cm3 at a temperature of 21.0 °C. When the gas is heated, 565 J of thermal energy causes it to expand to a volume of 3.87×103 cm3 at 53.0 °C. This is illustrated in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)The pressure of the gas is 4.20×105 Pa. For this heating of the gas,  calculate the work done by the gas,  work done = ...................................... J [2]
Mark Scheme: work done = p∆V    = 4.2 × 105 × (3.87 – 3.49) × 103 × 10–6    = 160 J (do not allow use of V instead of ∆V  C1 A1   [2]
Explanation:
The work done by the gas is calculated using \( W = P \Delta V \).  
Initial volume \( V_1 = 3.49 \times 10^3 \, \text{cm}^3 = 3.49 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).  
Final volume \( V_2 = 3.87 \times 10^3 \, \text{cm}^3 = 3.87 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).  
Change in volume \( \Delta V = (3.87 - 3.49) \times 10^{-3} = 0.38 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).  
Substitute into \( W = P \Delta V \):  
\( W = 4.20 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \times 0.38 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 = 160 \, \text{J} \).  

**work done = 160 J**  
[2]

Question: A constant mass of an ideal gas has a volume of 3.49×103 cm3 at a temperature of 21.0 °C. When the gas is heated, 565 J of thermal energy causes it to expand to a volume of 3.87×103 cm3 at 53.0 °C. This is illustrated in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)The pressure of the gas is 4.20×105 Pa. For this heating of the gas,  use the first law of thermodynamics and your answer in (i) to determine the change in internal energy of the gas.  change in internal energy = ...................................... J [2]
Mark Scheme: increase/ change in internal energy = heating of system + work done on system    = 565 – 160    = 405 J C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
The first law of thermodynamics states ΔU = Q − W, where Q is heat added to the system and W is work done **by** the gas.  

Given:  
- Heat supplied, Q = +565 J  
- Work done **by** the gas: W = PΔV.  

Calculate W:  
ΔV = 3.87×10³ cm³ − 3.49×10³ cm³ = 380 cm³ = 3.80×10⁻⁴ m³  
W = (4.20×10⁵ Pa)(3.80×10⁻⁴ m³) = 160 J  

Thus:  
ΔU = 565 − 160 = **405 J**  

(Heat energy partially increases internal energy, while the rest is used for expansion work.)  

[2]

Question: A constant mass of an ideal gas has a volume of 3.49×103 cm3 at a temperature of 21.0 °C. When the gas is heated, 565 J of thermal energy causes it to expand to a volume of 3.87×103 cm3 at 53.0 °C. This is illustrated in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)Explain why the change in kinetic energy of the molecules of this ideal gas is equal to the change in internal energy.  .................................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: internal energy = sum of kinetic energy and potential energy /EK + EP no intermolecular forces no potential energy (so ∆U = ∆EK) B1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The internal energy of an ideal gas is the sum of the kinetic energy (EK) and potential energy (EP) of its molecules. However, in an ideal gas, there are **no intermolecular forces**, so the potential energy between molecules is zero. This means the internal energy of the gas is **entirely due to the kinetic energy** of the molecules. When the gas is heated, its temperature (and thus the average kinetic energy of the molecules) increases. Since potential energy remains zero, the **change in internal energy (∆U)** is **equal to the change in kinetic energy (∆EK)** of the molecules.  

[3]

Question: A fixed mass of gas has an initial volume of 5.00×10−4 m3 at a pressure of 2.40×105Pa and a temperature of 288 K. It is heated at constant pressure so that, in its final state, the volume is 14.5×10−4 m3 at a temperature of 835 K, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)Show that these two states provide evidence that the gas behaves as an ideal gas. [3]
Mark Scheme: initially, pV/T = (2.40 × 105 × 5.00 × 10–4)/ 288 = 0.417 finally, pV/T = (2.40 × 105 × 14.5 × 10–4)/ 835 = 0.417 ideal gas because pV/T is constant (allow 2 marks for two determinations of V/T and then 1 mark for V/T and p constant, so ideal) M1 M1 A1   [3]
Explanation:
To show the gas behaves ideally, calculate \( \frac{pV}{T} \) for both states.  

**Initial state:**  
\( \frac{pV}{T} = \frac{(2.40 \times 10^5)(5.00 \times 10^{-4})}{288} = \frac{120}{288} = 0.417 \, \text{J K}^{-1} \).  

**Final state:**  
\( \frac{pV}{T} = \frac{(2.40 \times 10^5)(14.5 \times 10^{-4})}{835} = \frac{348}{835} = 0.417 \, \text{J K}^{-1} \).  

Since \( \frac{pV}{T} \) is constant (0.417) and pressure is constant, the gas obeys the ideal gas law (\( pV = nRT \)), confirming ideal behavior.  

[3]

Question: A fixed mass of gas has an initial volume of 5.00×10−4 m3 at a pressure of 2.40×105Pa and a temperature of 288 K. It is heated at constant pressure so that, in its final state, the volume is 14.5×10−4 m3 at a temperature of 835 K, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)The total thermal energy supplied to the gas for this change is 569 J. Determine   the external work done,  work done = .......................................... J [2]
Explanation:
The work done by the gas at constant pressure is calculated using \( W = P \Delta V \).  
Given \( P = 2.40 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \),  
\( \Delta V = (14.5 \times 10^{-4} - 5.00 \times 10^{-4}) = 9.5 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{m}^3 \).  

Substituting:  
\( W = 2.40 \times 10^5 \times 9.5 \times 10^{-4} = 228 \, \text{J} \).  

Thus, the external work done is **228 J**.  

[2]

Question: A fixed mass of gas has an initial volume of 5.00×10−4 m3 at a pressure of 2.40×105Pa and a temperature of 288 K. It is heated at constant pressure so that, in its final state, the volume is 14.5×10−4 m3 at a temperature of 835 K, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)The total thermal energy supplied to the gas for this change is 569 J. Determine   the change in internal energy of the gas. State whether the change is an increase or a decrease in internal energy.  change in internal energy = .......................... J  ........................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: ∆U = q + w = 569 – 228       = 341 J increase M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the change in internal energy (ΔU), use the first law of thermodynamics:  
ΔU = q + w.  
Here, *q* (thermal energy supplied) = **+569 J**.  
Work done *by* the gas is calculated as:  
w = -PΔV = -(2.40 × 10⁵ Pa) × (14.5 × 10⁻⁴ − 5.00 × 10⁻⁴ m³) = **-228 J**.  

Substituting:  
ΔU = 569 J − 228 J = **341 J**.  
Since ΔU is positive, the internal energy **increases**.  

Change in internal energy = **341 J** (increase).  

[2]

Mark Scheme: (numerically equal to) quantity of heat/(thermal) energy to change state/phase of unit mass at constant temperature (allow 1/2 for definition restricted to fusion or vaporisation) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Specific latent heat is the amount of thermal energy required to change the state (e.g., solid to liquid or liquid to gas) of one kilogram of a substance at a constant temperature. This energy is absorbed or released during the phase change without altering the temperature of the substance.  

[2]

Question: A beaker containing a liquid is placed on a balance, as shown in Fig. 3.1.   (DIAGRAM)  A heater of power 110 W is immersed in the liquid. The heater is switched on and, when the liquid is boiling, balance readings m are taken at corresponding times t.  A graph of the variation with time t of the balance reading m is shown in Fig. 3.2.   (DIAGRAM)    State the feature of Fig. 3.2 which suggests that the liquid is boiling at a steady rate.  ........................................................................................................................................... .......................................................................................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: constant gradient/straight line (allow linear/constant slope) B1 [1]
Explanation:
The graph shows a **straight line** (constant gradient), indicating that the mass decreases at a steady rate over time. This implies the liquid is vaporizing uniformly, consistent with boiling at a steady rate.  

[1]

Question: A beaker containing a liquid is placed on a balance, as shown in Fig. 3.1.   (DIAGRAM)  A heater of power 110 W is immersed in the liquid. The heater is switched on and, when the liquid is boiling, balance readings m are taken at corresponding times t.  A graph of the variation with time t of the balance reading m is shown in Fig. 3.2.   (DIAGRAM)    Use data from Fig. 3.2 to determine a value for the specific latent heat L of vaporisation of the liquid.       L = ................................................ J kg–1 [3]
Mark Scheme: Pt = mL or power = gradient × L use of gradient of graph (or two points separated by at least 3.5 minutes) 110 × 60 = L × (372 – 325) × 10–3 / 7.0 L = 9.80 × 105 J kg–1 (accept 2 s.f.) (allow 9.8 to 9.9 rounded to 2 s.f.) C1  M1  A1 [3]
Explanation:
The specific latent heat of vaporisation \( L \) can be determined using the relationship \( Pt = mL \), where \( P \) is the heater power, \( t \) is time, and \( m \) is the mass of liquid vaporised.  

From the graph, calculate the gradient (mass loss per second). For example, between two points:  
- Mass decreases from \( 372 \, \text{g} \) to \( 325 \, \text{g} \) (\( \Delta m = 47 \, \text{g} = 0.047 \, \text{kg} \)).  
- Time interval \( \Delta t = 7.0 \, \text{minutes} = 420 \, \text{s} \).  

Gradient \( = \frac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.047}{420} = 1.119 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{kg s}^{-1} \).  

Substitute into \( L = \frac{P}{\text{gradient}} \):  
\( L = \frac{110}{1.119 \times 10^{-4}} = 9.83 \times 10^{5} \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \).  

Rounded to 2 s.f., \( L = 9.8 \times 10^{5} \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \).  

[3]

Question: A beaker containing a liquid is placed on a balance, as shown in Fig. 3.1.   (DIAGRAM)  A heater of power 110 W is immersed in the liquid. The heater is switched on and, when the liquid is boiling, balance readings m are taken at corresponding times t.  A graph of the variation with time t of the balance reading m is shown in Fig. 3.2.   (DIAGRAM)    State, with a reason, whether the value determined in (ii) is likely to be an overestimate or an underestimate of the normally accepted value for the specific latent heat of vaporisation of the liquid.  ........................................................................................................................................... ........................................................................................................................................... .......................................................................................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: some energy/heat is lost to the surroundings or vapour condenses on sides so value is an overestimate M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The determined value is likely an **overestimate**.  
When calculating specific latent heat (\(L = \frac{Pt}{\Delta m}\)), the measured mass loss \(\Delta m\) is **less** than the true mass vaporised. This occurs because some vapour condenses on the beaker/balance and drips back, or heat is lost to the surroundings.  
Since \(L \propto \frac{1}{\Delta m}\), a smaller \(\Delta m\) gives a larger calculated \(L\), leading to an overestimate.  

[2]

Question: State what is meant by internal energy. ..................................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: (sum of) potential energy and kinetic energy of molecules/atoms/particles mention of random motion/distribution M1 A1 [2]
Explanation: Internal energy is the total **potential energy** and **random kinetic energy** of all the molecules/particles in a system. The kinetic energy arises from their random translational, rotational, and vibrational motion, while the potential energy is due to intermolecular forces between them. [2]

Question: The variation with volume V of the pressure p of an ideal gas as it undergoes a cycle ABCA of changes is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The temperature of the gas at A is 290 K. The temperature at B is 870 K. Determine   the amount, in mol, of gas,  amount = .................................................. mol [2]
Explanation:
To determine the amount of gas, use the ideal gas equation \( pV = nRT \).  

At point **A**:  
\( p = 1.2 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, \, V = 4.0 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3, \, T = 290 \, \text{K} \).  
Substituting into \( n = \frac{pV}{RT} \):  
\( n = \frac{(1.2 \times 10^5)(4.0 \times 10^{-3})}{(8.31)(290)} = \frac{480}{2409.9} \approx 0.20 \, \text{mol} \).  

Alternatively, at point **B** (\( T = 870 \, \text{K}, \, p = 3.6 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), same \( V \)):  
\( n = \frac{(3.6 \times 10^5)(4.0 \times 10^{-3})}{(8.31)(870)} = \frac{1440}{7229.7} \approx 0.20 \, \text{mol} \).  

**Amount of gas = 0.20 mol** (consistent at both points).  

[2]

Question: The variation with volume V of the pressure p of an ideal gas as it undergoes a cycle ABCA of changes is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The temperature of the gas at A is 290 K. The temperature at B is 870 K. Determine   the temperature of the gas at C.  temperature = ............................................ K [2]
Explanation:
To determine the temperature at point C, we use the relationship for an ideal gas under constant pressure (isobaric process) between points A and C. Applying Charles's Law:  
\( \frac{V_A}{T_A} = \frac{V_C}{T_C} \).  

From the data:  
\( V_A = 4.0 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \), \( T_A = 290 \, \text{K} \), \( V_C = 7.75 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).  

Rearranging for \( T_C \):  
\( T_C = T_A \times \frac{V_C}{V_A} = 290 \times \frac{7.75}{4.0} \).  

Calculating:  
\( \frac{7.75}{4.0} = 1.9375 \), so \( T_C = 290 \times 1.9375 = 561.875 \, \text{K} \approx 560 \, \text{K} \).  

**Temperature at C = 560 K**  

[2]

Question: Explain why the change from C to A involves external work and a change in internal energy. ............................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: temperature changes/decreases so internal energy changes/decreases volume changes (at constant pressure) so work is done B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The temperature decreases from C to A, causing the internal energy to decrease as it depends on temperature. Additionally, the volume changes (at constant pressure), so external work is done by or on the system during this process.  

[2]

Question: An ideal gas occupies a container of volume 4.5×103 cm3 at a pressure of 2.5×105 Pa and a temperature of 290 K.  Show that the number of atoms of gas in the container is 2.8 × 1023.        [2]
Mark Scheme: either  pV = NkT  or  pV = nRT  and  n = N / NA clear correct substitution e.g. 2.5 × 105 × 4.5 × 103 × 10-6 = N × 1.38 × 10-23 × 290 N = 2.8 × 1023 (allow 1 mark for calculation of n = 0.467 mol) C1  M1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the number of atoms \( N \), use the ideal gas equation \( pV = NkT \):  
Convert volume: \( 4.5 \times 10^3 \, \text{cm}^3 = 4.5 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).  
Substitute values:  
\[
N = \frac{pV}{kT} = \frac{(2.5 \times 10^5)(4.5 \times 10^{-3})}{(1.38 \times 10^{-23})(290)} = \frac{1.125 \times 10^3}{4.002 \times 10^{-21}} \approx 2.8 \times 10^{23}.
\]  
This confirms the number of atoms is \( 2.8 \times 10^{23} \).  

[2]

Question: An ideal gas occupies a container of volume 4.5×103 cm3 at a pressure of 2.5×105 Pa and a temperature of 290 K.  Atoms of a real gas each have a diameter of 1.2 × 10–10 m.  Estimate the volume occupied by 2.8 × 1023 atoms of this gas.        volume = ......................................... m3 [2]
Explanation:
The volume occupied by the atoms can be estimated by considering each atom as a sphere. The volume of one atom is (4/3)πr³, where r = (1.2 × 10⁻¹⁰ m)/2 = 0.6 × 10⁻¹⁰ m.  
Volume per atom = (4/3)π(0.6 × 10⁻¹⁰)³ ≈ 9.05 × 10⁻³¹ m³.  
Total volume = 9.05 × 10⁻³¹ m³/atom × 2.8 × 10²³ atoms ≈ 2.53 × 10⁻⁷ m³.  

Alternatively, approximating each atom’s volume as a cube with side 1.2 × 10⁻¹⁰ m:  
Volume per atom = (1.2 × 10⁻¹⁰)³ = 1.728 × 10⁻³⁰ m³.  
Total volume = 1.728 × 10⁻³⁰ × 2.8 × 10²³ ≈ 4.8 × 10⁻⁷ m³.  

Either answer is valid as an estimate.  

volume = 2.5 × 10⁻⁷ m³ **or** 4.8 × 10⁻⁷ m³  

[2]

Mark Scheme: either 4.5 × 103 cm3 >> 0.48 cm3 or ratio of volumes is about 10-4 justified because volume of molecules is negligible B1 B1 [2]     [Total: 6]
Explanation:
To determine if the real gas approximates an ideal gas, calculate the volume occupied by the gas molecules and compare it to the container volume.  

1. **Container volume**: \(4.5 \times 10^3 \, \text{cm}^3 = 4.5 \, \text{dm}^3 = 4.5 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3\).  
2. **Volume of one gas atom**:  
   Radius \(r = \frac{1.2 \times 10^{-10}}{2} = 6.0 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{m}\).  
   Volume per atom \(= \frac{4}{3} \pi r^3 = \frac{4}{3} \pi (6.0 \times 10^{-11})^3 \approx 9.05 \times 10^{-31} \, \text{m}^3\).  
3. **Total molecular volume**:  
   Using \(n = \frac{PV}{RT} \approx 0.467 \, \text{mol}\), total atoms \(= 0.467 \times 6.02 \times 10^{23} \approx 2.81 \times 10^{23}\).  
   Total molecular volume \(= 2.81 \times 10^{23} \times 9.05 \times 10^{-31} \approx 2.54 \times 10^{-7} \, \text{m}^3 = 0.254 \, \text{cm}^3\).  
4. **Comparison**:  
   Ratio \(= \frac{0.254 \, \text{cm}^3}{4500 \, \text{cm}^3} \approx 5.6 \times 10^{-5}\), which is negligible.  

**Conclusion**: The real gas approximates an ideal gas because the molecular volume is negligible compared to the container volume.  

[2]

Question: Some gas, initially at a temperature of 27.2 °C, is heated so that its temperature rises to 38.8 °C. Calculate, in kelvin, to an appropriate number of decimal places,   the initial temperature of the gas,  initial temperature = ............................................. K [2]
Explanation:
To convert the initial temperature from Celsius to Kelvin, add 273.15 to the Celsius value:  
27.2°C + 273.15 = 300.35 K.  

However, since the original temperature is given to **one decimal place**, the final answer should also be appropriately rounded. Using 273.15 gives 300.35 K, but adhering to one decimal place (consistent with the data):  
27.2°C + 273.2 = **300.4 K**.  

Final answer:  
Initial temperature = 300.4 K  

[2]

Question: Some gas, initially at a temperature of 27.2 °C, is heated so that its temperature rises to 38.8 °C. Calculate, in kelvin, to an appropriate number of decimal places,   the rise in temperature.  rise in temperature = ............................................ K [1]
Explanation:
The temperature rise is calculated by converting both initial and final temperatures to kelvin and finding the difference.  
Initial temperature in K: 27.2 + 273.15 = 300.35 K  
Final temperature in K: 38.8 + 273.15 = 311.95 K  
Temperature rise = 311.95 – 300.35 = **11.6 K**  

[1]

Question: The pressure p of an ideal gas is given by the expression          p = ⅓ρ<c2> where ρ is the density of the gas.    State the meaning of the symbol <c2>. ......................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: (<c2> is the) mean / average square speed B1 [1]
Explanation:
The symbol <c²> represents the mean (or average) square speed of the gas molecules.  

[1]

Question: The pressure p of an ideal gas is given by the expression          p = ⅓ρ<c2> where ρ is the density of the gas.    Use the expression to show that the mean kinetic energy <EK> of the atoms of an ideal gas is given by the expression        <EK> =  (DIAGRAM) kT.  Explain any symbols that you use. ............................................................................... [4]
Mark Scheme: ρ = Nm/V with N explained so, pV = 1/3 Nm<c2> and pV = NkT with k explained so mean kinetic energy / <Ek> = ½m<c2> = 3/2 kT B1 B1 B1 B1 [4]
Explanation:
Starting with the given equation \( p = \frac{1}{3} \rho \langle c^2 \rangle \), the density \( \rho \) can be written as \( \rho = \frac{Nm}{V} \), where \( N \) is the number of atoms, \( m \) is the mass of one atom, and \( V \) is the volume. Substituting this into the pressure equation gives:  
\( p = \frac{1}{3} \left( \frac{Nm}{V} \right) \langle c^2 \rangle \).  
Rearranging:  
\( pV = \frac{1}{3} Nm \langle c^2 \rangle \).  

For an ideal gas, \( pV = NkT \), where \( k \) is the Boltzmann constant and \( T \) is the temperature. Equating the two expressions for \( pV \):  
\( \frac{1}{3} Nm \langle c^2 \rangle = NkT \).  
Cancelling \( N \):  
\( \frac{1}{3} m \langle c^2 \rangle = kT \).  

The mean kinetic energy of an atom is \( \langle E_K \rangle = \frac{1}{2} m \langle c^2 \rangle \). Multiplying both sides of the equation by \( \frac{3}{2} \):  
\( \frac{1}{2} m \langle c^2 \rangle = \frac{3}{2}kT \).  
Thus, \( \langle E_K \rangle = \frac{3}{2}kT \).  

Symbols: \( k \) = Boltzmann constant, \( T \) = absolute temperature.  

[4]

Question: Helium-4 may be assumed to behave as an ideal gas.  A cylinder has a constant volume of 7.8 × 103 cm3 and contains helium-4 gas at a pressure of 2.1 × 107 Pa and at a temperature of 290 K.  Calculate, for the helium gas,   the amount of gas,  amount = ......................................... mol [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the amount of helium gas, the ideal gas equation \( pV = nRT \) is used.  
Given:  
\( p = 2.1 \times 10^7 \, \text{Pa} \),  
\( V = 7.8 \times 10^3 \, \text{cm}^3 = 7.8 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \),  
\( R = 8.31 \, \text{J mol}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1} \),  
\( T = 290 \, \text{K} \).  

Rearranging for \( n \):  
\[
n = \frac{pV}{RT} = \frac{(2.1 \times 10^7)(7.8 \times 10^{-3})}{(8.31)(290)} = \frac{163800}{2409.9} \approx 68 \, \text{mol}.
\]  

**Amount = 68 mol**  

[2]

Question: Helium-4 may be assumed to behave as an ideal gas.  A cylinder has a constant volume of 7.8 × 103 cm3 and contains helium-4 gas at a pressure of 2.1 × 107 Pa and at a temperature of 290 K.  Calculate, for the helium gas,   the mean kinetic energy of the atoms,  amount = ......................................... mol [2]
Explanation:
The mean kinetic energy of a helium atom is given by \( \frac{3}{2}kT \).  
Substituting \( k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \, \text{J K}^{-1} \) and \( T = 290 \, \text{K} \):  
\[
\text{Mean kinetic energy} = \frac{3}{2} \times 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \times 290 = 6.0 \times 10^{-21} \, \text{J}.
\]  
The volume and pressure data are not required for this calculation.  

Mean kinetic energy = \( 6.0 \times 10^{-21} \, \text{J} \).  

[2]

Question: Helium-4 may be assumed to behave as an ideal gas.  A cylinder has a constant volume of 7.8 × 103 cm3 and contains helium-4 gas at a pressure of 2.1 × 107 Pa and at a temperature of 290 K.  Calculate, for the helium gas,   the total internal energy.  amount = ......................................... mol [2]
Mark Scheme: realisation that total internal energy is the total kinetic energy energy = 6.0 × 10–21 × 68 × 6.02 × 1023 = 2.46 × 105 J C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The total internal energy of the helium gas is calculated using the average kinetic energy per molecule multiplied by the total number of molecules.  
First, determine the number of moles \( n \):  
\( n = \frac{PV}{RT} = \frac{(2.1 \times 10^7)(7.8 \times 10^{-3})}{(8.31)(290)} ≈ 68 \, \text{mol} \).  

Each molecule has average kinetic energy \( \frac{3}{2}k_BT \):  
\( \frac{3}{2} \times 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \times 290 ≈ 6.0 \times 10^{-21} \, \text{J} \).  

Total molecules = \( 68 \times 6.02 \times 10^{23} = 4.09 \times 10^{25} \).  

Total internal energy:  
\( 6.0 \times 10^{-21} \times 4.09 \times 10^{25} ≈ 2.46 \times 10^5 \, \text{J} \).  

[3]

Question: The planet Mars may be considered to be an isolated sphere of diameter 6.79 × 106 m with its mass of 6.42 × 1023 kg concentrated at its centre.  A rock of mass 1.40 kg rests on the surface of Mars. For this rock,  determine its weight,  weight = ............................................ N [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the weight of the rock on Mars, we use the gravitational force formula:  
\( F = \frac{GMm}{r^2} \).  

Given:  
- \( G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{Nm}^2\text{kg}^{-2} \),  
- \( M = 6.42 \times 10^{23} \, \text{kg} \),  
- \( m = 1.40 \, \text{kg} \),  
- Diameter of Mars \( = 6.79 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} \), so radius \( r = \frac{6.79 \times 10^6}{2} = 3.395 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} \).  

Substitute into the formula:  
\[
F = \frac{(6.67 \times 10^{-11})(6.42 \times 10^{23})(1.40)}{(3.395 \times 10^6)^2}.
\]  

Calculate numerator:  
\( 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 6.42 \times 10^{23} = 4.28 \times 10^{13} \),  
then \( 4.28 \times 10^{13} \times 1.40 = 5.99 \times 10^{13} \).  

Calculate denominator:  
\( (3.395 \times 10^6)^2 = 1.153 \times 10^{13} \).  

Final division:  
\( \frac{5.99 \times 10^{13}}{1.153 \times 10^{13}} \approx 5.20 \, \text{N} \).  

**Weight = 5.20 N**

Question: The planet Mars may be considered to be an isolated sphere of diameter 6.79 × 106 m with its mass of 6.42 × 1023 kg concentrated at its centre.  A rock of mass 1.40 kg rests on the surface of Mars. For this rock,  show that its gravitational potential energy is –1.77 × 107 J.  [2]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential energy (GPE) of the rock is calculated using the formula \( E_p = -\frac{GMm}{r} \).  
- **Radius of Mars**: \( r = \frac{6.79 \times 10^6}{2} = 3.395 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} \).  
- Substituting values:  
  \( E_p = -\frac{(6.67 \times 10^{-11}) \times (6.42 \times 10^{23}) \times 1.40}{3.395 \times 10^6} \).  
- Numerator: \( 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 6.42 \times 10^{23} \times 1.40 = 5.995 \times 10^{13} \).  
- Denominator: \( 3.395 \times 10^6 \).  
- Division: \( \frac{5.995 \times 10^{13}}{3.395 \times 10^6} = 1.77 \times 10^7 \).  
- Final GPE: \( -1.77 \times 10^7 \, \text{J} \), as required.  

[2]

Question: The planet Mars may be considered to be an isolated sphere of diameter 6.79 × 106 m with its mass of 6.42 × 1023 kg concentrated at its centre.  A rock of mass 1.40 kg rests on the surface of Mars. For this rock,Use the information in (a)(ii) to determine the speed at which the rock must leave the surface of Mars so that it will escape the gravitational attraction of the planet.  speed = ....................................... m s–1 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the escape speed, equate the kinetic energy to the gravitational potential energy at the surface. Using the provided energy value (1.77 × 10⁷ J):  

½mv² = 1.77 × 10⁷  
v² = (2 × 1.77 × 10⁷) / 1.40  
v² = 3.54 × 10⁷ / 1.40 = 2.5286 × 10⁷  
v = √(2.5286 × 10⁷) ≈ 5.03 × 10³ m s⁻¹  

Alternatively, using the gravitational formula:  
v = √(2GM/r)  
G = 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ N m² kg⁻², M = 6.42 × 10²³ kg, r = 6.79 × 10⁶ / 2 = 3.395 × 10⁶ m  
v = √[(2 × 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ × 6.42 × 10²³) / 3.395 × 10⁶]  
v ≈ 5.02 × 10³ m s⁻¹  

Final answer: **5.02 × 10³ m s⁻¹** or **5.03 × 10³ m s⁻¹** (both acceptable).  

[3]

Question: The planet Mars may be considered to be an isolated sphere of diameter 6.79 × 106 m with its mass of 6.42 × 1023 kg concentrated at its centre.  A rock of mass 1.40 kg rests on the surface of Mars. For this rock,The mean translational kinetic energy <Ek> of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by the expression          <Ek> =  (DIAGRAM) kT where T is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas and k is the Boltzmann constant.   Determine the temperature at which the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of hydrogen molecules is equal to the speed calculated in (b). Hydrogen may be assumed to be an ideal gas. A molecule of hydrogen has a mass of 2 u.  temperature = ............................................. K [2]
Explanation:
To determine the temperature at which the r.m.s. speed of hydrogen molecules equals the given speed (5.03 × 10³ m/s):  

The mean translational kinetic energy of a molecule is \( \frac{3}{2}kT \), which equals \( \frac{1}{2}mv_{\text{rms}}^2 \).  
Equating these:  
\[
\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{3}{2}kT  
\]  
Rearranging for \( T \):  
\[
T = \frac{mv^2}{3k}  
\]  
Substituting \( m = 2 \times 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \, \text{kg} \), \( v = 5.03 \times 10^3 \, \text{m/s} \), and \( k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \, \text{J/K} \):  
\[
T = \frac{(3.32 \times 10^{-27})(5.03 \times 10^3)^2}{3 \times 1.38 \times 10^{-23}} = 2030 \, \text{K}  
\]  

**Temperature = 2030 K**  

[2]

Question: The planet Mars may be considered to be an isolated sphere of diameter 6.79 × 106 m with its mass of 6.42 × 1023 kg concentrated at its centre.  A rock of mass 1.40 kg rests on the surface of Mars. For this rock,The mean translational kinetic energy <Ek> of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by the expression          <Ek> =  (DIAGRAM) kT where T is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas and k is the Boltzmann constant.   State and explain one reason why hydrogen molecules may escape from Mars at temperatures below that calculated in (i). ........................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: either because there is a range of speeds   some molecules have a higher speed or some escape from point above planet surface   so initial potential energy is higher M1 A1 (M1) (A1) [2]
Explanation: Hydrogen molecules in the gas have a range of speeds due to the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution. Although the **average** kinetic energy corresponds to the calculated temperature, some molecules have kinetic energies significantly higher than the average. These high-energy molecules may still exceed the escape velocity of Mars, even if the temperature (and thus the average kinetic energy) is below the critical value required for escape. Thus, a fraction of hydrogen molecules can escape at lower temperatures.

Question: The kinetic theory of gases is based on some simplifying assumptions. The molecules of the gas are assumed to behave as hard elastic identical spheres. State the assumption about ideal gas molecules based on   the nature of their movement, ....................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: either   random motion or   constant velocity until hits wall/other molecule B1 [1]
Explanation:
The molecules are in **random motion** with constant velocity (or speed and direction) unless they collide with other molecules or the container walls.  

[1]  

(Assumption: Between collisions, gas molecules travel in straight lines at constant velocity, changing direction only during elastic collisions with walls or other molecules.)

Question: The kinetic theory of gases is based on some simplifying assumptions. The molecules of the gas are assumed to behave as hard elastic identical spheres. State the assumption about ideal gas molecules based on   their volume. ....................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: (total) volume of molecules is negligible compared to volume of containing vessel or radius/diameter of a molecule is negligible compared to the average intermolecular distance M1 A1  (M1) (A1) [2]
Explanation:
The assumption is that the **total volume of all the gas molecules** is negligible compared to the volume of the container.  
Alternatively, the **radius/diameter of a molecule** is much smaller than the average distance between molecules.  

This means the molecules are considered as point masses with no significant spatial extent, allowing the gas's volume to be approximated as entirely the container's volume.  

[2]

Question: A cube of volume V contains N molecules of an ideal gas. Each molecule has a component cX of velocity normal to one side S of the cube, as shown in Fig. 2.1.        (DIAGRAM)  The pressure p of the gas due to the component cX of velocity is given by the expression     pV = NmcX2 where m is the mass of a molecule. Explain how the expression leads to the relation     pV = ⅓Nm<c2> where <c2> is the mean square speed of the molecules. [3]
Mark Scheme: either  molecule has component of velocity in three directions or  c2 = cX2 + cY2 + cZ2 random motion and averaging, so <cX2> = <cY2> = <cZ2> <c2> = 3<cX2> so, pV = ⅓Nm<c2>  M1 M1 A1 A0 [3]
Explanation: The original equation considers the velocity component \( c_X \) normal to one face. However, molecules move randomly in 3D, so the total mean square speed \( \langle c^2 \rangle \) is the sum of the mean squares of all three components: \( \langle c^2 \rangle = \langle c_X^2 \rangle + \langle c_Y^2 \rangle + \langle c_Z^2 \rangle \). Due to random motion, the averages of each component are equal: \( \langle c_X^2 \rangle = \langle c_Y^2 \rangle = \langle c_Z^2 \rangle \). Hence, \( \langle c^2 \rangle = 3\langle c_X^2 \rangle \), so \( \langle c_X^2 \rangle = \frac{1}{3}\langle c^2 \rangle \). Substituting this into \( pV = Nm\langle c_X^2 \rangle \) gives \( pV = \frac{1}{3}Nm\langle c^2 \rangle \).

Question: The molecules of an ideal gas have a root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of 520 m s–1 at a temperature of 27 °C.  Calculate the r.m.s. speed of the molecules at a temperature of 100 °C.  r.m.s. speed = ....................................... m s–1 [3]
Mark Scheme: <c2> ∝ T  or crms ∝ √T temperatures are 300K and 373K crms = 580 ms–1 (Do not allow any marks for use of temperature in units of ºC instead of K) C1 C1 A1   [3]
Explanation:
The r.m.s. speed \( c_{\text{rms}} \) is proportional to \( \sqrt{T} \), where \( T \) is the absolute temperature.  
Initial temperature: \( T_1 = 27 + 273 = 300 \, \text{K} \).  
Final temperature: \( T_2 = 100 + 273 = 373 \, \text{K} \).  

Using \( \frac{c_2}{c_1} = \sqrt{\frac{T_2}{T_1}} \):  
\( c_2 = 520 \times \sqrt{\frac{373}{300}} \).  

Calculating \( \sqrt{\frac{373}{300}} \approx 1.115 \):  
\( c_2 = 520 \times 1.115 \approx 580 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

**r.m.s. speed = 580 m s⁻¹**  

[3]

Question: The product of the pressure ρ and the volume V of an ideal gas is given by the expression pV =  (DIAGRAM) Nm<c2> where m is the mass of one molecule of the gas.State the meaning of the symbol  N, ...............................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: N: (total) number of molecules B1 [1]
Explanation:
The symbol \( N \) represents the total number of molecules in the gas.  

[1]

Question: The product of the pressure ρ and the volume V of an ideal gas is given by the expression pV =  (DIAGRAM) Nm<c2> where m is the mass of one molecule of the gas.State the meaning of the symbol  <c2> ................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: <c2>: mean square speed/velocity B1 [1]
Explanation:
The symbol <c²> represents the **mean square speed** of the gas molecules. This is the average of the squares of the speeds of all the molecules in the gas.  

[1]  

(Explanation: The angled brackets denote an average, and c² is the square of the molecular speed. The mean square speed quantifies the average kinetic energy associated with the random motion of the gas molecules.)

Question: The product of the pressure ρ and the volume V of an ideal gas is given by the expression pV =  (DIAGRAM) Nm<c2> where m is the mass of one molecule of the gas.The product pV is also given by the expression                          ρV = NkT. Deduce an expression, in terms of the Boltzmann constant k and the thermodynamic temperature T, for the mean kinetic energy of a molecule of the ideal gas. [2]
Mark Scheme: pV = ⅓Nm<c2> = NkT (mean) kinetic energy = ½m<c2> algebra clear leading to ½m<c2> = (3/2)kT  C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
We start by equating the two expressions for \( pV \):  
\[
\frac{1}{3}Nm\langle c^2 \rangle = NkT
\]  
Cancelling \( N \) from both sides:  
\[
\frac{1}{3}m\langle c^2 \rangle = kT
\]  
Multiply both sides by \( \frac{3}{2} \):  
\[
\frac{1}{2}m\langle c^2 \rangle = \frac{3}{2}kT
\]  
Thus, the mean kinetic energy of a molecule is \( \frac{3}{2}kT \).

Question: The product of the pressure ρ and the volume V of an ideal gas is given by the expression pV =  (DIAGRAM) Nm<c2> where m is the mass of one molecule of the gas.A cylinder contains 1.0 mol of an ideal gas.  The volume of the cylinder is constant. Calculate the energy required to raise the temperature of the gas by 1.0 kelvin.  energy = ............................................ J [2]
Explanation:
The energy required to raise the temperature of 1.0 mol of an ideal gas by 1.0 K at constant volume is calculated using the molar specific heat capacity at constant volume, \( C_V = \frac{3}{2}R \).  
Energy \( Q = nC_V \Delta T = \frac{3}{2} \times 8.31 \, \text{J mol}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1} \times 1.0 \, \text{mol} \times 1.0 \, \text{K} \).  
\( Q = \frac{3}{2} \times 8.31 = 12.5 \, \text{J} \).  

**Energy = 12.5 J** (or 12 J to 2 s.f.).  

[2]

Question: The product of the pressure ρ and the volume V of an ideal gas is given by the expression pV =  (DIAGRAM) Nm<c2> where m is the mass of one molecule of the gas.A cylinder contains 1.0 mol of an ideal gas.  The volume of the cylinder is now allowed to increase so that the gas remains at constant pressure when it is heated. Explain whether the energy required to raise the temperature of the gas by 1.0 kelvin is now different from your answer in (i).  ..................................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: energy is needed to push back atmosphere/do work against atmosphere so total energy required is greater M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
When the gas expands at constant pressure, part of the energy supplied is used to do work against the external pressure (e.g., pushing back the atmosphere). Since energy is required both to increase the internal energy (linked to the temperature rise) **and** to perform this work, the total energy needed is greater than when heating at constant volume (where no work is done).  

[2]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere with its mass M concentrated at its centre. A satellite of mass m orbits the Earth such that the radius of the circular orbit is r.Show that the linear speed v of the satellite is given by the expression               (DIAGRAM)  [2]
Mark Scheme: centripetal force is provided by gravitational force mv2 / r = GMm / r2 hence v = √(GM / r) B1 B1 A0 [2]
Explanation:
The gravitational force provides the centripetal force for the satellite’s circular orbit. Equating the two forces:  
\( \frac{mv^2}{r} = \frac{GMm}{r^2} \).  
Cancelling \( m \) and multiplying both sides by \( r \):  
\( v^2 = \frac{GM}{r} \).  
Taking the square root:  
\( v = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}} \).  

[2]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere with its mass M concentrated at its centre. A satellite of mass m orbits the Earth such that the radius of the circular orbit is r.For this satellite, write down expressions, in terms of G, M, m and r, for  its kinetic energy,  kinetic energy = …………………………. [1]
Mark Scheme: EK (= ½mv2) = GMm / 2r B1 [1]
Explanation:
The gravitational force provides the centripetal force for the satellite’s circular orbit:  
\( \frac{GMm}{r^2} = \frac{mv^2}{r} \).  
Rearranging gives \( v^2 = \frac{GM}{r} \).  
Kinetic energy is \( E_K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).  
Substituting \( v^2 \):  
\( E_K = \frac{1}{2}m \left(\frac{GM}{r}\right) = \frac{GMm}{2r} \).  

**Kinetic energy = \( \frac{GMm}{2r} \)**.  

[1]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere with its mass M concentrated at its centre. A satellite of mass m orbits the Earth such that the radius of the circular orbit is r.For this satellite, write down expressions, in terms of G, M, m and r, for  its gravitational potential energy,  potential energy = …………………………. [1]
Mark Scheme: EP = - GMm / r B1 [1]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential energy \( E_P \) of the satellite is given by:  
\[  
E_P = -\frac{GMm}{r}  
\]  
*(The negative sign indicates the bound nature of the gravitational system, and the expression arises from integrating the gravitational force from infinity to radius \( r \).)*  

[1]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere with its mass M concentrated at its centre. A satellite of mass m orbits the Earth such that the radius of the circular orbit is r.For this satellite, write down expressions, in terms of G, M, m and r, for  its total energy.  total energy = …………………………. [2]
Mark Scheme: ET = - GMm / r + GMm / 2r     = - GMm / 2r. C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The total energy \( E_T \) of the satellite is the sum of its gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy.  

Gravitational potential energy \( U = -\frac{GMm}{r} \).  
Kinetic energy \( KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).  

For a circular orbit, the centripetal force is provided by gravity:  
\( \frac{GMm}{r^2} = \frac{mv^2}{r} \), so \( v^2 = \frac{GM}{r} \).  
Substituting \( v^2 \) into \( KE \):  
\( KE = \frac{1}{2}m \left( \frac{GM}{r} \right) = \frac{GMm}{2r} \).  

Total energy:  
\( E_T = U + KE = -\frac{GMm}{r} + \frac{GMm}{2r} = -\frac{GMm}{2r} \).  

Total energy \( = -\frac{GMm}{2r} \).  

[2]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere with its mass M concentrated at its centre. A satellite of mass m orbits the Earth such that the radius of the circular orbit is r.The total energy of the satellite gradually decreases. State and explain the effect of this decrease on   the radius r of the orbit,  ............................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: if ET decreases then - GMm / 2r becomes more negative or GMm / 2r becomes larger so r decreases M1 A1 [2]
Explanation: The total energy \( E_T \) of the satellite is given by \( E_T = -\frac{GMm}{2r} \). If \( E_T \) decreases (becomes more negative), the term \( \frac{GMm}{2r} \) must increase in magnitude. For this to occur, the radius \( r \) must **decrease**, as \( r \) is inversely proportional to the magnitude of \( E_T \). Thus, a decrease in total energy causes the orbital radius to reduce.

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere with its mass M concentrated at its centre. A satellite of mass m orbits the Earth such that the radius of the circular orbit is r.The total energy of the satellite gradually decreases. State and explain the effect of this decrease on   the linear speed v of the satellite.  ............................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: EK = GMm / 2r and r decreases so (EK and) v increases M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The total energy \( E \) of the satellite is given by \( E = -\frac{GMm}{2r} \). As \( E \) decreases (becomes more negative), the orbital radius \( r \) decreases.  
The linear speed \( v \) of the satellite in circular motion is derived from \( \frac{mv^2}{r} = \frac{GMm}{r^2} \), leading to \( v = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}} \).  
Since \( v \) is inversely proportional to \( \sqrt{r} \), the decrease in \( r \) results in an **increase** in \( v \).  

[2]

Question: Define gravitational field strength. .......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: force per unit mass (ratio idea essential)  B1 [1]
Explanation:
Gravitational field strength at a point is defined as the gravitational force exerted per unit mass on a small test mass placed at that point.  

(It is the ratio of the gravitational force \( F \) acting on a mass to the magnitude of that mass \( m \), so \( g = \frac{F}{m} \).)  

[1]

Question: A spherical planet has diameter 1.2 × 104 km. The gravitational field strength at the surface of the planet is 8.6 N kg–1. The planet may be assumed to be isolated in space and to have its mass concentrated at its centre. Calculate the mass of the planet.  mass = .......................................... kg [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the mass \( M \) of the planet, we use the gravitational field strength formula:  
\[
g = \frac{GM}{R^2}
\]
Rearranging for \( M \):  
\[
M = \frac{gR^2}{G}
\]  
The radius \( R \) is half the diameter:  
\[
R = \frac{1.2 \times 10^4 \, \text{km}}{2} = 0.6 \times 10^4 \, \text{km} = 0.6 \times 10^7 \, \text{m}
\]  
Substitute \( g = 8.6 \, \text{N kg}^{-1} \), \( R = 0.6 \times 10^7 \, \text{m} \), and \( G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N m}^2 \, \text{kg}^{-2} \):  
\[
M = \frac{8.6 \times (0.6 \times 10^7)^2}{6.67 \times 10^{-11}} = \frac{8.6 \times 0.36 \times 10^{14}}{6.67 \times 10^{-11}} = \frac{3.096 \times 10^{14}}{6.67 \times 10^{-11}} \approx 4.6 \times 10^{24} \, \text{kg}
\]  

Mass = \( \boxed{4.6 \times 10^{24} \, \text{kg}} \)  

[3]

Question: The gravitational potential at a point X above the surface of the planet in (b) is – 5.3 × 107 J kg–1. For point Y above the surface of the planet, the gravitational potential is – 6.8 × 107 J kg–1.   State, with a reason, whether point X or point Y is nearer to the planet. .................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: either  potential decreases as distance from planet decreases or  potential zero at infinity and X is closer to zero or  potential α –1/r and Y more negative so point Y is closer to planet.   M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Gravitational potential becomes more negative as distance from the planet decreases. Since the potential at Y (–6.8 × 10⁷ J kg⁻¹) is more negative than at X (–5.3 × 10⁷ J kg⁻¹), point Y must be closer to the planet. This is because gravitational potential \( V \propto -\frac{1}{r} \), so a lower (more negative) value corresponds to a smaller distance \( r \).

[2]

Question: The gravitational potential at a point X above the surface of the planet in (b) is – 5.3 × 107 J kg–1. For point Y above the surface of the planet, the gravitational potential is – 6.8 × 107 J kg–1.   A rock falls radially from rest towards the planet from one point to the other. Calculate the final speed of the rock.  speed = ...................................... m s–1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the final speed of the rock:  
The change in gravitational potential is \( \Delta \phi = (-6.8 \times 10^7) - (-5.3 \times 10^7) = 1.5 \times 10^7 \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \).  
Using energy conservation, \( \Delta \phi = \frac{1}{2}v^2 \):  
\( 1.5 \times 10^7 = \frac{1}{2}v^2 \).  
Rearranging: \( v = \sqrt{2 \times 1.5 \times 10^7} = \sqrt{3 \times 10^7} \approx 5.5 \times 10^3 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

Final speed = \( 5.5 \times 10^3 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

[2]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere of radius 6.38×103 km, with its mass concentrated at its centre.  Define gravitational field strength. ............................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: force per (unit) mass ……(ratio idea essential) B1 [1]
Explanation:
Gravitational field strength is defined as the force per unit mass.  

[1]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere of radius 6.38×103 km, with its mass concentrated at its centre.  By considering the gravitational field strength at the surface of the Earth, show that the mass of the Earth is 5.99×1024 kg. [2]
Explanation:
To find the Earth's mass, we use the gravitational field strength formula:  
\( g = \frac{GM}{R^2} \).  
Rearranging for \( M \):  
\( M = \frac{gR^2}{G} \).  

Substituting values:  
\( g = 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 \),  
\( R = 6.38 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} \),  
\( G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2 \).  

Calculate \( R^2 = (6.38 \times 10^6)^2 = 4.07 \times 10^{13} \, \text{m}^2 \).  
Then,  
\( M = \frac{9.81 \times 4.07 \times 10^{13}}{6.67 \times 10^{-11}} \).  

This simplifies to:  
\( M = \frac{3.99 \times 10^{14}}{6.67 \times 10^{-11}} = 5.99 \times 10^{24} \, \text{kg} \).  

Thus, the mass of the Earth is \( 5.99 \times 10^{24} \, \text{kg} \).  

[2]

Question: The Global Positioning System (GPS) is a navigation system that can be used anywhere on Earth. It uses a number of satellites that orbit the Earth in circular orbits at a distance of 2.22×104 km above its surface.  Use data from (a) to calculate the angular speed of a GPS satellite in its orbit.  angular speed = ..................................... rad s–1 [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the angular speed \( \omega \) of the GPS satellite:  
The gravitational force provides the centripetal force:  
\( \frac{GM}{r^3} = \omega^2 \).  
Substitute \( G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N m}^2 \, \text{kg}^{-2} \), \( M = 5.99 \times 10^{24} \, \text{kg} \), and \( r = 6.38 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} + 2.22 \times 10^7 \, \text{m} = 2.86 \times 10^7 \, \text{m} \):  
\( \omega = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r^3}} = \sqrt{\frac{(6.67 \times 10^{-11})(5.99 \times 10^{24})}{(2.86 \times 10^7)^3}} \).  
Calculating gives \( \omega = 1.3 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{rad s}^{-1} \).  

Answer: \( 1.3 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{rad s}^{-1} \).  

[3]

Question: The Global Positioning System (GPS) is a navigation system that can be used anywhere on Earth. It uses a number of satellites that orbit the Earth in circular orbits at a distance of 2.22×104 km above its surface.  Use your answer in (i) to show that the satellites are not in geostationary orbits. [3]
Mark Scheme: period of orbit = 2π / ω    = 4.8 × 104 s (= 13.4 hours) period for geostationary satellite is 24 hours (= 8.6 × 104 s) so no C1 A1 A1 A0 [3]
Explanation:
The orbital period \( T \) of the satellite is calculated as \( 4.8 \times 10^4 \, \text{s} \), which equals \( 13.4 \, \text{hours} \).  
A geostationary satellite must have an orbital period equal to Earth’s rotational period, \( 24 \, \text{hours} \) (\( 8.6 \times 10^4 \, \text{s} \)).  
Since \( 13.4 \, \text{hours} \neq 24 \, \text{hours} \), the GPS satellites are not in geostationary orbits.  

[3]

Question: The planes of the orbits of the GPS satellites in (b) are inclined at an angle of 55° to the Equator. Suggest why the satellites are not in equatorial orbits. ...................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: satellite can then provide cover at Poles B1 [1]
Explanation:
An inclined orbit allows the satellites to cover higher latitudes, including the polar regions, which would not be possible with equatorial orbits. This ensures global navigation coverage, particularly at the Poles. 

[1]

Question: State Newton's law of gravitation. ........................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: F ∝ Mm / R2 …..…(words or explained symbols) either M and m are point masses or R >> diameter of masses …(do not allow 'size')  M1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
Newton's law of gravitation states that the gravitational force \( F \) between two masses \( M \) and \( m \) is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance \( R \) between their centres:  
\[ F \propto \frac{Mm}{R^2} \].  
This law applies when the masses are point masses or when the separation \( R \) is much greater than the physical dimensions of the masses.  

[2]

Question: The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere of radius R equal to 6.4 × 106 m. A satellite is in a geostationary orbit.   Describe what is meant by a geostationary orbit. ............................................................... [3]
