Electrons deeper in the material require energy to reach the surface (e.g., overcoming collisions with atoms), reducing their remaining kinetic energy upon emission. Thus, only surface electrons attain the full \( E_{\text{max}} \), while others lose energy during travel to the surface. [2]

Question: For a particular metal surface, it is observed that there is a minimum frequency of light below which photoelectric emission does not occur. This observation provides evidence for a particulate nature of electromagnetic radiation.Some data for the variation with frequency f of the maximum kinetic energy EMAX of electrons emitted from a metal surface are shown in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Use Fig. 9.1 to determine 1. the threshold frequency,     threshold frequency = ................................. Hz [1] 2. the work function energy, in eV, of the metal surface.     work function energy = ............................... eV [3]
Mark Scheme: 1. threshold frequency = 5.8 × 1014 Hz A1 [1] 2. Φ = hf0       = 6.63 × 10–34 × 5.8 × 1014       = 3.84 × 10–19 (J)       = (3.84 × 10–19)/(1.6 × 10–19)       = 2.4 eV C1  C1  A1 [3] or   hf = Φ + EMAX   chooses point on line and substitutes values EMAX, f and h into   equation with the units of the hf term converted from J to eV   Φ = 2.4 eV  (C1)  (C1) (A1)
Explanation:
1. The threshold frequency is the frequency at which the maximum kinetic energy \( E_{\text{MAX}} \) of emitted electrons becomes zero. From the graph (Fig. 9.1), this occurs where the line intersects the frequency axis. By inspection, this is at **\( 5.8 \times 10^{14} \, \text{Hz} \)**.  

2. The work function \( \Phi \) is calculated using \( \Phi = h f_0 \), where \( h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \, \text{J s} \) and \( f_0 = 5.8 \times 10^{14} \, \text{Hz} \):  
\[
\Phi = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \times 5.8 \times 10^{14} = 3.84 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J}.
\]  
To convert to electron volts:  
\[
\Phi = \frac{3.84 \times 10^{-19}}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}} = 2.4 \, \text{eV}.
\]  

**Threshold frequency = \( 5.8 \times 10^{14} \, \text{Hz} \)**  
**Work function energy = \( 2.4 \, \text{eV} \)**  

[1][3]

Question: A solenoid is connected in series with a battery and a switch. A Hall probe is placed close to one end of the solenoid, as illustrated in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The current in the solenoid is switched on. The Hall probe is adjusted in position to give the maximum reading. The current is then switched off.The current in the solenoid is now switched on again. Several seconds later, it is switched off. The Hall probe is not moved. On the axes of Fig. 7.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the Hall voltage VH. [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: graph: VH increases from zero when current switched on    VH then non-zero constant    VH returns to zero when current switched off B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
When the current is initially switched on, the Hall voltage \( V_H \) rapidly rises from zero to a constant maximum value as the solenoid’s magnetic field is established. This constant \( V_H \) corresponds to the steady magnetic field produced by the solenoid’s current. When the current is switched off after several seconds, the magnetic field collapses, causing \( V_H \) to drop immediately back to zero.  

(DIAGRAM: A graph with time \( t \) on the x-axis and \( V_H \) on the y-axis. The graph starts at \( V_H = 0 \). At \( t = 0 \), a vertical line rises to a constant horizontal line. At a later time \( t \), when the current is switched off, a vertical line drops back to \( V_H = 0 \). The graph has no gradual slopes—only sharp, vertical transitions between states.)  

[3]

Question: A solenoid is connected in series with a battery and a switch. A Hall probe is placed close to one end of the solenoid, as illustrated in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The current in the solenoid is switched on. The Hall probe is adjusted in position to give the maximum reading. The current is then switched off.The Hall probe is now replaced by a small coil. The plane of the coil is parallel to the end of the solenoid.  State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction. .......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: (induced) e.m.f. proportional to rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Faraday's law states that the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) in a circuit is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage through the circuit.  

[2]

Question: A solenoid is connected in series with a battery and a switch. A Hall probe is placed close to one end of the solenoid, as illustrated in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The current in the solenoid is switched on. The Hall probe is adjusted in position to give the maximum reading. The current is then switched off.The Hall probe is now replaced by a small coil. The plane of the coil is parallel to the end of the solenoid.  On the axes of Fig. 7.3, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the e.m.f. E induced in the coil when the current in the solenoid is switched on and then switched off. [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: pulse as current is being switched on zero e.m.f. when current in coil pulse in opposite direction when switching off B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Time on x-axis, e.m.f. E on y-axis. At t=0, a short positive rectangular pulse (spike) upwards. Between t=0 and t=toff, E=0. At t=toff, a short negative rectangular pulse (spike) downwards.)

When the current is switched on, the sudden increase in magnetic flux through the coil induces a brief e.m.f. (positive spike). While the current is steady, flux is constant → no induced e.m.f. (E=0). When switched off, the rapid flux decrease induces an e.m.f. in the opposite direction (negative spike). Pulses are momentary and sharp. 

[3]

Question: An uncharged capacitor is connected in series with a battery, a switch and a resistor, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has e.m.f. 9.0 V and negligible internal resistance. The capacitance of the capacitor is 4700 μF. The switch is closed at time t = 0. During the time interval t = 0 to t = 4.0 s, the charge passing through the resistor is 22 mC.  Calculate the energy transfer in the battery during the time interval t = 0 to t = 4.0 s.   energy transfer = ....................................... J [2]
Explanation:
The energy transferred by the battery is the product of its e.m.f. and the total charge that flows through it.  
Charge, \( Q = 22 \, \text{mC} = 22 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{C} \).  
Energy transfer \( = E \times Q = 9.0 \, \text{V} \times 22 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{C} = 0.198 \, \text{J} \).  
Rounded to two significant figures: **0.20 J**.  

[2]

Question: An uncharged capacitor is connected in series with a battery, a switch and a resistor, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has e.m.f. 9.0 V and negligible internal resistance. The capacitance of the capacitor is 4700 μF. The switch is closed at time t = 0. During the time interval t = 0 to t = 4.0 s, the charge passing through the resistor is 22 mC.  Determine, for the capacitor at time t = 4.0 s, 1. the potential difference V across the capacitor,     V = ........................................ V [2] 2. the energy stored in the capacitor.     energy = ......................................... J [2]
Explanation:
1. The potential difference \( V \) across the capacitor is calculated using \( V = \frac{Q}{C} \).  
Given \( Q = 22 \, \text{mC} = 22 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{C} \) and \( C = 4700 \, \mu\text{F} = 4700 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{F} \):  
\[
V = \frac{22 \times 10^{-3}}{4700 \times 10^{-6}} = 4.7 \, \text{V}.
\]  

2. The energy stored in the capacitor is calculated using \( E = \frac{1}{2}CV^2 \):  
\[
E = \frac{1}{2} \times 4700 \times 10^{-6} \times (4.7)^2 = \frac{1}{2} \times 4700 \times 10^{-6} \times 22.09 = 5.1 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{J}.
\]  

(Alternatively, using \( E = \frac{1}{2}QV \):  
\[
E = \frac{1}{2} \times 22 \times 10^{-3} \times 4.7 = 5.1 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{J}.)
\]  

**Final Answers:**  
1. \( V = 4.7 \, \text{V} \)  
2. Energy \( = 5.1 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{J} \)  

[4]

Question: An uncharged capacitor is connected in series with a battery, a switch and a resistor, as shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery has e.m.f. 9.0 V and negligible internal resistance. The capacitance of the capacitor is 4700 μF. The switch is closed at time t = 0. During the time interval t = 0 to t = 4.0 s, the charge passing through the resistor is 22 mC.Suggest why your answers in (a)(i) and (a)(ii) part 2 are different. ................................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: energy lost (as thermal energy) in resistance/wires/battery/resistor (award only if answer in (a)(i) > answer in (a)(ii)2) B1 [1]
Explanation:
The energy calculated in (a)(i) (stored in the capacitor) is less than the energy supplied by the battery in (a)(ii) part 2 because some energy is dissipated as heat in the resistor during charging. The resistor converts electrical energy into thermal energy due to the current flow, resulting in the difference between the two values.  

[1]

Question: A student investigates the energy changes of a mass oscillating on a vertical spring, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The student draws a graph of the variation with displacement x of energy E of the oscillation, as shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)State whether the energy E represents the total energy, the potential energy or the kinetic energy of the oscillations. ................................................................................ [1]
Mark Scheme: kinetic (energy)/KE/EK B1 [1]
Explanation:
The energy E represents the **kinetic energy** of the oscillations.  
At displacement x = 0 (equilibrium position), kinetic energy is maximum (as velocity is maximum), and it decreases to zero at maximum displacement (x = ±A). The graph of kinetic energy versus displacement is parabolic, peaking at x = 0, which matches the described variation of E with x.  

[1]

Question: A student investigates the energy changes of a mass oscillating on a vertical spring, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The student draws a graph of the variation with displacement x of energy E of the oscillation, as shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)The student repeats the investigation but with a smaller amplitude. The maximum value of E is now found to be 1.8 mJ. Use Fig. 4.2 to determine the change in the amplitude. Explain your working.  change in amplitude = .................................... cm [3]
Mark Scheme: either change in energy = 0.60 mJ or  max E proportional to (amplitude)2/equivalent numerical working new amplitude is 1.3 cm change in amplitude = 0.2 cm  B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
From the graph (Fig. 4.2), the original maximum energy is 2.4 mJ. The new maximum energy is 1.8 mJ.  

Since energy \( E \propto (\text{amplitude})^2 \):  
\[
\frac{E_2}{E_1} = \left(\frac{A_2}{A_1}\right)^2 \implies \frac{1.8}{2.4} = \left(\frac{A_2}{A_1}\right)^2 \implies \frac{A_2}{A_1} = \sqrt{0.75} \approx 0.866.
\]  

From the graph, the original amplitude \( A_1 \) is 1.5 cm.  
New amplitude:  
\[
A_2 = 0.866 \times 1.5 \approx 1.3 \, \text{cm}.
\]  

Change in amplitude:  
\[
1.5 \, \text{cm} - 1.3 \, \text{cm} = 0.2 \, \text{cm}.
\]  

Change in amplitude = **0.2 cm**.  

[3]

Question: The volume of 1.00 kg of water in the liquid state at 100 °C is 1.00×10−3 m3. The volume of 1.00 kg of water vapour at 100 °C and atmospheric pressure 1.01×105 Pa is 1.69 m3.Show that the work done against the atmosphere when 1.00 kg of liquid water becomes water vapour is 1.71×105 J. [2]
Mark Scheme: either change in volume = (1.69 – 1.00 × 10–3) or  liquid volume << volume of vapour work done = 1.01 × 105 × 1.69 = 1.71 × 105 (J)  M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The work done against atmospheric pressure is calculated using \( W = P \Delta V \).  
The change in volume \( \Delta V = V_{\text{vapour}} - V_{\text{liquid}} = 1.69 \, \text{m}^3 - 1.00 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \approx 1.69 \, \text{m}^3 \), as the liquid volume is negligible.  
Substituting into the formula:  
\[
W = (1.01 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}) \times 1.69 \, \text{m}^3 = 1.71 \times 10^5 \, \text{J}.
\]  
Thus, the work done is \( 1.71 \times 10^5 \, \text{J} \).  

[2]

Question: The volume of 1.00 kg of water in the liquid state at 100 °C is 1.00×10−3 m3. The volume of 1.00 kg of water vapour at 100 °C and atmospheric pressure 1.01×105 Pa is 1.69 m3.  The first law of thermodynamics may be given by the expression       ΔU = + q + w where ΔU is the increase in internal energy of the system. State what is meant by 1. + q, ......................................................................... [1]  2. + w. ......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: 1. heating of system/thermal energy supplied to the system B1 [1] 2. work done on the system B1 [1]
Explanation:
1. +q refers to thermal energy/heat transferred **to** the system from the surroundings.  
2. +w refers to mechanical work done **on** the system by the surroundings.  

[2]

Question: The volume of 1.00 kg of water in the liquid state at 100 °C is 1.00×10−3 m3. The volume of 1.00 kg of water vapour at 100 °C and atmospheric pressure 1.01×105 Pa is 1.69 m3.  The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water at 100 °C is 2.26×106 J kg−1. A mass of 1.00 kg of liquid water becomes water vapour at 100 °C. Determine, using your answer in (a), the increase in internal energy of this mass of water during vaporisation.  increase in internal energy = ................................ J [2]
Explanation:
The increase in internal energy is calculated using the first law of thermodynamics:  
ΔU = Q − W.  
Here, Q is the heat supplied during vaporisation, which equals the specific latent heat:  
Q = 2.26 × 10⁶ J.  
Work done **by** the system is W = PΔV.  
ΔV = (1.69 m³ − 1.00 × 10⁻³ m³) ≈ 1.69 m³.  
Thus,  
W = (1.01 × 10⁵ Pa)(1.69 m³) = 1.71 × 10⁵ J.  
Substituting into ΔU:  
ΔU = 2.26 × 10⁶ J − 1.71 × 10⁵ J = 2.09 × 10⁶ J.  

Increase in internal energy = **2.09 × 10⁶ J**.  

[2]

Question: Explain what is meant by the Avogadro constant. ................................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: the number of atoms in 12 g of carbon-12 M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The Avogadro constant is the number of atoms present in exactly 12 grams of carbon-12.  
This value defines the mole, allowing the linking of macroscopic mass to microscopic particle counts.  

[2]

Question: Argon-40 (4018Ar) may be assumed to be an ideal gas. A mass of 3.2 g of argon-40 has a volume of 210 cm3 at a temperature of 37 °C. Determine, for this mass of argon-40 gas,  the amount, in mol,  amount = ................................................. mol [1]
Explanation:
The amount of argon-40 in moles is calculated using \( \text{amount} = \frac{\text{mass}}{\text{molar mass}} \).  
Given mass = 3.2 g and molar mass of argon-40 = 40 g/mol:  
\( \text{amount} = \frac{3.2}{40} = 0.080 \, \text{mol} \).  

**Answer**: 0.080 mol.

Question: Argon-40 (4018Ar) may be assumed to be an ideal gas. A mass of 3.2 g of argon-40 has a volume of 210 cm3 at a temperature of 37 °C. Determine, for this mass of argon-40 gas,  the pressure,  pressure = ................................................... Pa [2]
Mark Scheme: pV = nRT p × 210 × 10–6 = 0.080 × 8.31 × 310 p = 9.8 × 105 Pa (do not credit if T in °C not K)  C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the pressure, use the ideal gas equation \( pV = nRT \).  
First, convert units:  
- Volume \( V = 210 \, \text{cm}^3 = 210 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{m}^3 \).  
- Temperature \( T = 37^\circ \text{C} = 310 \, \text{K} \).  

Calculate moles of Argon-40:  
Molar mass \( = 40 \, \text{g/mol} \), so \( n = \frac{3.2 \, \text{g}}{40 \, \text{g/mol}} = 0.080 \, \text{mol} \).  

Substitute into \( pV = nRT \):  
\( p \times 210 \times 10^{-6} = 0.080 \times 8.31 \times 310 \).  
Solving for \( p \):  
\( p = \frac{0.080 \times 8.31 \times 310}{210 \times 10^{-6}} = 9.8 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).  

[2]

Question: Argon-40 (4018Ar) may be assumed to be an ideal gas. A mass of 3.2 g of argon-40 has a volume of 210 cm3 at a temperature of 37 °C. Determine, for this mass of argon-40 gas,  the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of an argon atom.  r.m.s. speed = ............................................... m s−1 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the r.m.s. speed of an argon atom:  
Using the equation for average kinetic energy:  
\( \frac{1}{2}m\langle c^2 \rangle = \frac{3}{2}kT \).  
Rearranging for \( \langle c^2 \rangle \):  
\( \langle c^2 \rangle = \frac{3kT}{m} \).  

**Calculations:**  
- **Temperature in Kelvin:**  
  \( T = 37 + 273 = 310 \, \text{K} \).  
- **Mass of one Ar atom:**  
  \( m = 40 \times 1.66 \times 10^{-27} = 6.64 \times 10^{-26} \, \text{kg} \).  
- **Substitute values:**  
  \( \langle c^2 \rangle = \frac{3 \times 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \times 310}{6.64 \times 10^{-26}} \).  
  Numerator: \( 3 \times 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \times 310 = 1.283 \times 10^{-20} \).  
  \( \langle c^2 \rangle = \frac{1.283 \times 10^{-20}}{6.64 \times 10^{-26}} = 1.93 \times 10^{5} \, \text{m}^2 \, \text{s}^{-2} \).  
- **r.m.s. speed:**  
  \( c_{\text{rms}} = \sqrt{1.93 \times 10^{5}} \approx 440 \, \text{m} \, \text{s}^{-1} \).  

**Answer:**  
\( c_{\text{rms}} = 440 \, \text{m} \, \text{s}^{-1} \).  

[3]

Question: Define gravitational potential at a point. ................................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: work done bringing unit mass from infinity (to the point) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential at a point is defined as the **work done per unit mass** to move a small test mass from **infinity** to that point in a gravitational field, without acceleration.  

(Work done against gravitational forces is considered, and potential is a scalar quantity measured in joules per kilogram.)  

[2]

Question: A stone of mass m has gravitational potential energy EP at a point X in a gravitational field. The magnitude of the gravitational potential at X is ϕ. State the relation between m, EP and ϕ. ................................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: EP = –mϕ B1 [1]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential energy \( E_P \) of the stone is equal to the product of its mass \( m \) and the gravitational potential \( \phi \) at point X, with a negative sign indicating the binding nature of the potential energy in the field. Thus,  
\( E_P = -m\phi \).  

[1]

Question: An isolated spherical planet of radius R may be assumed to have all its mass concentrated at its centre. The gravitational potential at the surface of the planet is −6.30 × 107 J kg−1. A stone of mass 1.30 kg is travelling towards the planet such that its distance from the centre of the planet changes from 6R to 5R. Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy of the stone.  change in energy = ...................................... J [4]
Mark Scheme: ϕ ∝ 1/x either at 6R from centre, potential is (6.3 × 107)/6 (= 1.05 × 107 J kg–1)  and at 5R from centre, potential is (6.3 × 107)/5 (= 1.26 × 107 J kg–1)  change in energy = (1.26 – 1.05) × 107 × 1.3    = 2.7 × 106 J C1  C1 C1 A1 [4] or change in potential = (1/5 – 1/6) × (6.3 × 107)    change in energy = (1/5 – 1/6) × (6.3 × 107) × 1.3     = 2.7 × 106 J (C1) (C1) (A1)
Explanation:
The gravitational potential at a distance \( x \) from the planet’s centre is given by \( \phi = -\frac{GM}{x} \). Since the potential at the surface (\( R \)) is \( -6.30 \times 10^7 \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \), the potential at \( 6R \) and \( 5R \) is inversely proportional to their distances.  

At \( 6R \):  
\( \phi_1 = \frac{-6.30 \times 10^7}{6} = -1.05 \times 10^7 \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \).  

At \( 5R \):  
\( \phi_2 = \frac{-6.30 \times 10^7}{5} = -1.26 \times 10^7 \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \).  

Change in gravitational potential:  
\( \Delta \phi = \phi_2 - \phi_1 = (-1.26 \times 10^7) - (-1.05 \times 10^7) = -0.21 \times 10^7 \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \).  

Change in gravitational potential energy:  
\( \Delta U = m \Delta \phi = 1.30 \, \text{kg} \times (-2.1 \times 10^6 \, \text{J kg}^{-1}) = -2.73 \times 10^6 \, \text{J} \).  

However, following the mark scheme’s approach (magnitude only):  
\( \Delta \phi = \left( \frac{1}{5} - \frac{1}{6} \right) \times 6.30 \times 10^7 = \frac{1}{30} \times 6.30 \times 10^7 = 2.1 \times 10^6 \, \text{J kg}^{-1} \).  

\( \Delta U = 1.30 \times 2.1 \times 10^6 = 2.7 \times 10^6 \, \text{J} \).  

**Final answer:**  
change in energy = \( 2.7 \times 10^6 \, \text{J} \).  

[4]

Question: Define, for a wave, 1. wavelength λ, .................................................................[1] 2. frequency f. .................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: 1. wavelength: minimum distance between two points moving in phase  OR distance between neighbouring or consecutive peaks or troughs  OR wavelength is the distance moved by a wavefront in time T or one  oscillation/cycle or period (of source) B1 [1] 2. frequency: number of wavefronts / (unit) time  OR number of oscillations per unit time or oscillations/time B1 [1]
Explanation:
1. Wavelength λ: The minimum distance between two consecutive points in phase on a wave, such as adjacent peaks or troughs.  
2. Frequency f: The number of complete oscillations or wave cycles passing a fixed point per unit time.  

[2]

Question: Use your definitions to deduce the relationship between λ, f and the speed v of the wave. [1]
Mark Scheme: speed = distance / time = wavelength / time period    = λ / T = λf M1 A0 [1]
Explanation:
The speed \( v \) of a wave is the distance it travels per unit time.  
In one full period \( T \), the wave travels one wavelength \( \lambda \).  
Thus, \( v = \frac{\lambda}{T} \).  
Since frequency \( f = \frac{1}{T} \), substituting gives:  
\( v = \lambda f \).  

[1]

Question: Plane waves on the surface of water are represented by Fig. 5.1 at one particular instant of time.  (DIAGRAM)  The waves have frequency 2.5Hz. Determine, for the waves,   the amplitude,  amplitude = ......................................... mm [1]
Mark Scheme: amplitude = 4.0 mm   (allow 1 s.f.) A1 [1]
Explanation:
The amplitude is the maximum displacement from the equilibrium position. From the diagram (not shown), the vertical distance between a crest and trough (peak-to-trough) is twice the amplitude. If the diagram indicates this total distance as 8.0 mm, the amplitude is half of this:  
Amplitude = 8.0 mm / 2 = **4.0 mm**.  

Answer: 4.0 mm  
[1]

Question: Plane waves on the surface of water are represented by Fig. 5.1 at one particular instant of time.  (DIAGRAM)  The waves have frequency 2.5Hz. Determine, for the waves,   the speed,  speed = ....................................... ms–1 [2]
Mark Scheme: wavelength = 18 / 3.75 (= 4.8) speed = 2.5 × 4.8 × 10–2 = 12 × 10–2 ms–1 unit consistent with numerical answer, e.g. in cms–1 if cm used for λ and unit changed on answer line [if 18 cm = 3.5λ used giving speed 13 (12.9) cms–1 allow max. 1]. C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the speed of the waves:  
First, calculate the wavelength. If 3.75 wavelengths span 18 cm, then:  
\( \lambda = \frac{18 \, \text{cm}}{3.75} = 4.8 \, \text{cm} = 0.048 \, \text{m} \).  

Using the wave equation \( v = f \lambda \):  
\( v = 2.5 \, \text{Hz} \times 0.048 \, \text{m} = 0.12 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  

Speed = **0.12** m s⁻¹.  

[2]

Question: Plane waves on the surface of water are represented by Fig. 5.1 at one particular instant of time.  (DIAGRAM)  The waves have frequency 2.5Hz. Determine, for the waves,   the phase difference between points A and B.  phase difference = ...................... unit ......... [1]
Mark Scheme: 180º or π rad A1 [1]
Explanation:
The phase difference between points A and B is π rad.  
(Assuming A and B are separated by half a wavelength, as they are on adjacent crest and trough in the diagram. Phase difference = (distance/wavelength) × 2π = (λ/2)/λ × 2π = π rad.)  

unit: rad  
[1]

Question: The wave in (b) was produced in a ripple tank. Describe briefly, with the aid of a sketch diagram, how the wave may be observed. [2]
Mark Scheme: light and screen and correct positions above and below ripple tank strobe or video camera B1  B1  [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A ripple tank with water, showing a light source positioned directly above the tank and a white screen placed below the tank. Arrows indicate light passing through the water surface to project wave patterns onto the screen.)  

The wave can be observed by directing a bright light source above the ripple tank, which projects shadows of the water waves onto a screen placed beneath the tank. To clearly visualise the wave motion, a strobe light (synchronised to the wave frequency) or a video camera (recording at high frame rates) is used to "freeze" or capture the wave pattern effectively.

Question: Distinguish between gravitational potential energy and elastic potential energy. .....................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: gravitational PE is energy of a mass due to its position in a gravitational field elastic PE energy stored (in an object) due to (a force) changing its shape / deformation / being compressed / stretched / strained B1  B1 [2]
Explanation:
Gravitational potential energy is the energy possessed by a mass due to its position in a gravitational field. Elastic potential energy is the energy stored in an object when it is deformed, such as being stretched, compressed, or strained.  

[2]

Question: A ball of mass 65g is thrown vertically upwards from ground level with a speed of 16ms–1. Air resistance is negligible.  Calculate, for the ball,  1. the initial kinetic energy,      kinetic energy = ....................................... J [2] 2. the maximum height reached.     maximum height = ................................. m [2]
Explanation:
1. The initial kinetic energy is calculated using \( KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).  
   Convert mass to kg: \( 65 \, \text{g} = 0.065 \, \text{kg} \).  
   \( KE = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.065 \times 16^2 = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.065 \times 256 = 8.32 \, \text{J} \).  

2. For maximum height, equate kinetic energy to gravitational potential energy (\( mgh \)):  
   \( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = mgh \Rightarrow h = \frac{v^2}{2g} \).  
   \( h = \frac{16^2}{2 \times 9.81} = \frac{256}{19.62} \approx 13.05 \, \text{m} \).  

**Answers:**  
1. Kinetic energy = 8.3 J  
2. Maximum height = 13 m  

[4]

Question: A ball of mass 65g is thrown vertically upwards from ground level with a speed of 16ms–1. Air resistance is negligible.  The ball takes time t to reach maximum height. For time t/2 after the ball has been thrown, calculate the ratio       (DIAGRAM)   ratio = ................................................ [3]
Mark Scheme: speed at t = ½ total time = 8 (ms–1)  KE is ¼ and PE is ¾ of max   ratio = 3 C1 C1 A1 [3] or  total t =1.63  or  t1/2 = 0.815 s    h at t1/2 = 9.78 (m)    ratio = 9.78 / 3.26 = 3
Explanation:
To determine the ratio of potential energy (PE) to kinetic energy (KE) at time \( t/2 \):  

1. **Calculate total time \( t \) to reach maximum height**:  
   Using \( v = u + at \), where final velocity \( v = 0 \), initial velocity \( u = 16 \, \text{ms}^{-1} \), and acceleration \( a = -9.81 \, \text{ms}^{-2} \):  
   \[
   t = \frac{u}{g} = \frac{16}{9.81} \approx 1.63 \, \text{s}.  
   \]  
   At \( t/2 = 0.815 \, \text{s} \), the velocity is:  
   \[
   v = u - g(t/2) = 16 - (9.81 \times 0.815) \approx 8 \, \text{ms}^{-1}.  
   \]  

2. **Energy analysis**:  
   - Initial KE: \( \frac{1}{2}mu^2 = \frac{1}{2}m(16)^2 \).  
   - KE at \( t/2 \): \( \frac{1}{2}m(8)^2 = \frac{1}{4} \times \text{Initial KE} \).  
   - PE at \( t/2 \): Total energy (constant) – KE at \( t/2 \):  
     \[
     \text{PE} = \frac{1}{2}m(16)^2 - \frac{1}{2}m(8)^2 = \frac{3}{4} \times \text{Initial KE}.  
     \]  

3. **Ratio \( \frac{\text{PE}}{\text{KE}} \)** at \( t/2 \):  
   \[
   \frac{\frac{3}{4} \times \text{Initial KE}}{\frac{1}{4} \times \text{Initial KE}} = 3.  
   \]  

**Answer**: 3.

Question: A ball of mass 65g is thrown vertically upwards from ground level with a speed of 16ms–1. Air resistance is negligible.  State and explain the effect of air resistance on the time taken for the ball to reach maximum height. .................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: time is less because (average) acceleration is greater OR average force is greater  B1 [1]
Explanation:
When air resistance is present, the time taken for the ball to reach maximum height **decreases**. This is because air resistance provides an additional downward force, increasing the average deceleration (net acceleration greater than \( g \)) acting on the ball. The greater acceleration causes the ball to lose speed more rapidly, reaching its peak sooner compared to a scenario with negligible air resistance.  

[1]

Question: The time T for a satellite to orbit the Earth is given by  (DIAGRAM)  where R is the distance of the satellite from the centre of the Earth,           M is the mass of the Earth,  and   K is a constant.Determine the SI base units of K.  SI base units of K .......................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: SI units for T: s, R: m and M: kg (or seen clearly in formula) K = T2 M / R3 units: s2 kg m–3  (allow s2 kg / m3 or ) C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the SI base units of \( K \), start with the equation \( T^2 = \frac{K R^3}{M} \), rearranged to \( K = \frac{T^2 M}{R^3} \).  

Substitute the SI units for each quantity:  
- \( T \) (time) → seconds (\( \text{s} \))  
- \( M \) (mass) → kilograms (\( \text{kg} \))  
- \( R \) (distance) → meters (\( \text{m} \))  

Thus, the units of \( K \) are:  
\[
\frac{(\text{s}^2)(\text{kg})}{\text{m}^3} = \text{s}^2 \, \text{kg} \, \text{m}^{-3}.
\]  

**SI base units of \( K \):** \( \text{s}^2 \, \text{kg} \, \text{m}^{-3} \)  

[2]

Question: The time T for a satellite to orbit the Earth is given by  (DIAGRAM)  where R is the distance of the satellite from the centre of the Earth,           M is the mass of the Earth,  and   K is a constant.Data for a particular satellite are given in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate K and its actual uncertainty in SI units.  K = ................................. ± ............................ SI units [4]
Mark Scheme: % uncertainty in K: 1% (for T) + 3% (for R) + 2% (for M) OR = 6% K = [(86400)2 × 6 × 1024] / (4.23 × 107)3 = 5.918 × 1011 6% of K = 0.355 × 1011 K = (5.9 ± 0.4) × 1011 (SI units) correct power of ten required for both [incorrect % value then max. 1] C1 C1 C1 A1   [4]
Explanation:
K = (T² × M) / R³  
= (86400² × 6 × 10²⁴) / (4.23 × 10⁷)³  
= 5.9 × 10¹¹ SI units  

Percentage uncertainties:  
T: 1%, R: 3%, M: 2% → total 6%  
Uncertainty = 0.06 × 5.9 × 10¹¹ = 0.4 × 10¹¹  

Final answer:  
K = (5.9 ± 0.4) × 10¹¹ SI units  

[4]

Question: Explain the main principles behind the use of ultrasound to obtain diagnostic information about internal body stiUctures. ................................................................. [6]
Mark Scheme: pulse (of ultrasound) produced by quartz / piezo-electric crystal (1) reflected from boundaries (between media) reflected pulse detected by the ultrasound transmitter (1) signal processed and displayed intensity of reflected pulse gives information about the boundary (1) time delay gives information about depth (1) (four B marks plus any two from the four, max. 6) B1  B1 B1  B1   B2 [6]
Explanation: Ultrasound imaging works by emitting high-frequency sound pulses into the body using a piezoelectric crystal in the transducer. When the ultrasound pulse encounters a boundary between tissues (e.g., muscle and organ), a portion reflects as an echo. The transducer detects these echoes, and the time delay between emission and detection is used to calculate the depth of the boundary (since speed of sound in tissue is ~1540 m/s). The intensity of the reflected pulse depends on the difference in acoustic impedance between tissues, with larger differences (e.g., bone/fluid) producing stronger echoes. A computer processes the time delays and intensities to generate real-time 2D images, mapping the position and nature of internal structures. Multiple pulses are sent from varying angles to build a detailed cross-sectional view.

Question: State and explain one advantage of the use of high frequency ultrasound as compared with low frequency ultrasound for medical diagnosis. ................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: shorter wavelength smaller structures resolved / detected (not more sharpness) B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
High frequency ultrasound has a shorter wavelength than low frequency ultrasound.  
The shorter wavelength allows smaller structures to be resolved (detected) as the resolution of the image depends on the wavelength.  
This enables finer details in tissues or organs to be distinguished during medical imaging.  

[2]

Question: The absorption (attenuation) coefficient for ultrasound in muscle is 23 m-1. A parallel beam of ultrasound is passed through a muscle of thickness 6.4 cm.  Calculate the ratio     (DIAGRAM)   ratio = ..................................................[3]
Explanation:
The ratio of transmitted to initial intensity is calculated using \( \frac{I}{I_0} = e^{-\mu x} \).  
First, convert thickness \( x = 6.4 \, \text{cm} = 0.064 \, \text{m} \).  
Substitute into the equation:  
\( \mu x = 23 \times 0.064 = 1.472 \).  
Thus,  
\( \frac{I}{I_0} = e^{-1.472} \approx 0.23 \).  

**Ratio = 0.23**  

[3]

Question: The absorption (attenuation) coefficient for ultrasound in muscle is 23 m-1. A parallel beam of ultrasound is passed through a muscle of thickness 6.4 cm.  An ultrasound transmitter emits a pulse. Suggest why, when the signal from the pulse is processed, any signal received later at the detector is usually amplified more than that received at an earlier time. ...................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: later signal has passed through greater thickness of medium so has greater attenuation / greater absorption / smaller intensity M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Later-arriving signals have travelled through a larger thickness of the muscle tissue. As ultrasound waves propagate through the medium, their intensity decreases exponentially due to absorption (attenuation). The longer the path length, the greater the energy loss. To compensate for this weaker intensity, the processing system amplifies later signals more than earlier ones, ensuring detectable and comparable signal strengths for accurate interpretation. 

[2]

Question: A charged particle of mass m and charge –q is travelling through a vacuum at constant speed v. It enters a uniform magnetic field of flux density B. The initial angle between the direction of motion of the particle and the direction of the magnetic field is 90°.Explain why the path of the particle in the magnetic field is the arc of a circle. .......................................................................[3]
Mark Scheme: force due to magnetic field is constant force is (always) normal to direction of motion this force provides the centripetal force B1  A1 [3]
Explanation: The charged particle enters the magnetic field at 90°, so the magnetic force \( F = Bqv \) acts perpendicular to its velocity. This force direction is always normal to the motion (as \( \vec{F} \propto \vec{v} \times \vec{B} \)), causing the particle’s path to continuously curve. Since the force remains perpendicular and constant in magnitude (as speed \( v \) is unchanged), it provides the centripetal force required for circular motion: \( Bqv = \frac{mv^2}{r} \). The radius \( r \) adjusts to satisfy this, resulting in a circular arc. No work is done by the magnetic force, so kinetic energy and speed remain constant. [3]

Question: A charged particle of mass m and charge –q is travelling through a vacuum at constant speed v. It enters a uniform magnetic field of flux density B. The initial angle between the direction of motion of the particle and the direction of the magnetic field is 90°.The radius of the arc in (a) is r. Show that the ratio  (DIAGRAM)  for the particle is given by the expression         (DIAGRAM)  [1]
Mark Scheme: mv2 / r = Bqv hence q / m = v / Br M1 A0 [1]
Explanation:
The magnetic force provides the centripetal force for circular motion:  
\( Bqv = \frac{mv^2}{r} \).  
Dividing both sides by \( mv \):  
\( Bq = \frac{mv}{r} \).  
Rearranging gives:  
\( \frac{q}{m} = \frac{v}{Br} \).  

[1]

Question: A charged particle of mass m and charge –q is travelling through a vacuum at constant speed v. It enters a uniform magnetic field of flux density B. The initial angle between the direction of motion of the particle and the direction of the magnetic field is 90°.The initial speed v of the particle is 2.0 × 107 m s–1. The magnetic flux density B is 2.5 × 10–3 T. The radius r of the arc in the magnetic field is 4.5 cm.  Use these data to calculate the ratio  (DIAGRAM) .  ratio = ...................................... C kg–1 [2]
Explanation:
The charged particle follows a circular path in the magnetic field. The magnetic force provides centripetal force:  
\( Bqv = \frac{mv^2}{r} \).  
Rearranging gives \( \frac{q}{m} = \frac{v}{Br} \).  
Substituting values:  
\( \frac{q}{m} = \frac{2.0 \times 10^7}{2.5 \times 10^{-3} \times 4.5 \times 10^{-2}} \).  
Calculating denominator: \( 2.5 \times 4.5 = 11.25 \), \( 10^{-3} \times 10^{-2} = 10^{-5} \).  
Thus, \( \frac{q}{m} = \frac{2.0 \times 10^7}{11.25 \times 10^{-5}} = \frac{2.0}{11.25} \times 10^{12} ≈ 1.8 \times 10^{11} \, \text{C kg}^{-1} \).  

**Ratio = 1.8 × 10¹¹ C kg⁻¹**  

[2]

Question: A charged particle of mass m and charge –q is travelling through a vacuum at constant speed v. It enters a uniform magnetic field of flux density B. The initial angle between the direction of motion of the particle and the direction of the magnetic field is 90°.The initial speed v of the particle is 2.0 × 107 m s–1. The magnetic flux density B is 2.5 × 10–3 T. The radius r of the arc in the magnetic field is 4.5 cm.  The path of the negatively-charged particle before it enters the magnetic field is shown in Fig. 6.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The direction of the magnetic field is into the plane of the paper. On Fig. 6.1, sketch the path of the particle in the magnetic field and as it emerges from the field. [2]
Mark Scheme: sketch: curved path, constant radius, in direction towards bottom of page tangent to curved path on entering and on leaving the field M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: The particle's initial path is horizontal, entering the magnetic field region (marked with '×' symbols indicating B into the page). Inside the field, the path curves downward in a circular arc of constant radius, maintaining 4.5 cm. Upon exiting the field, the path continues as a straight line tangent to the arc at the exit point, directed downward.)  

The negatively charged particle follows a circular path in the magnetic field due to the perpendicular force \( F = Bqv \). Using the left-hand rule (since charge is −q), the force direction is downward, causing the particle to curve toward the bottom of the page. The radius remains constant as \( v \), \( B \), and \( m \) are unchanged. Upon leaving the field, the particle continues moving tangentially to its circular arc.  

[2]

Question: An incomplete diagram for the magnetic flux pattern due to a current-carrying solenoid is illustrated in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM)    On Fig.5.1, draw arrows on the field lines to show the direction of the magnetic field. [1]
Mark Scheme: field shown as right to left B1 [1]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Arrows drawn on the magnetic field lines inside the solenoid, pointing from right to left. The field lines inside the solenoid are parallel and uniformly spaced, with arrows consistently indicating the direction of the magnetic field from one end to the other along the axis.)  

[1]

Question: An incomplete diagram for the magnetic flux pattern due to a current-carrying solenoid is illustrated in Fig.5.1.  (DIAGRAM)    State the feature of Fig.5.1 that indicates that the magnetic field strength at each end of the solenoid is less than that at the centre. ..................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: lines are more spaced out at ends B1 [1]
Explanation:
The magnetic field lines are more spaced out (less dense) at the ends of the solenoid than at the centre.  
[1]

Question: A Hall probe is placed near one end of the solenoid in (a), as shown in Fig.5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The Hall probe is rotated about the axis XY. State and explain why the magnitude of the Hall voltage varies. .........................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: Hall voltage depends on angle either between field and plane of probe or maximum when field normal to plane of probe or zero when field parallel to plane of probe M1   A1 [2]
Explanation:
The Hall voltage depends on the angle between the magnetic field and the plane of the Hall probe. When the probe is rotated, the component of the magnetic field perpendicular to the probe’s plane changes. The Hall voltage is maximum when the field is perpendicular (normal) to the plane, and zero when the field is parallel to it. Thus, rotating the probe alters this angle, varying the Hall voltage.  

[2]

Question: State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction. ....................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: (induced) e.m.f. proportional to rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage) (allow rate of cutting of flux)  M1 A1   [2]
Explanation:
Faraday's law states that the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) in a circuit is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage through the circuit.  

[2]

Mark Scheme: e.g. move coil towards/away from solenoid  rotate coil  e.g. vary current in solenoid  e.g. insert iron core into solenoid (any three sensible suggestions, 1 each)  B3 [3]
Explanation:
1. Move the coil towards or away from the solenoid to change the magnetic flux linkage.  
2. Rotate the coil within the magnetic field to alter the angle between the coil's plane and the field lines.  
3. Vary the current in the solenoid to change the strength of the magnetic field passing through the coil.  

[3]

Mark Scheme: work done in moving unit mass  from infinity (to the point) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential at a point is defined as the work done per unit mass to move a small test mass from infinity to that point in a gravitational field, without acceleration.  

(Work done per unit mass ensures the definition accounts for the energy required, and specifying "from infinity" establishes the reference point where potential is zero.)  

[2]

Question: The Moon may be considered to be an isolated sphere of radius 1.74 × 103 km with its mass of 7.35 × 1022 kg concentrated at its centre.  A rock of mass 4.50 kg is situated on the surface of the Moon. Show that the change in gravitational potential energy of the rock in moving it from the Moon's surface to infinity is 1.27 × 107 J.       [1]
Mark Scheme: gravitational potential energy = GMm / x energy = (6.67 × 10–11 × 7.35 × 1022 × 4.5) / (1.74 × 106) energy = 1.27 × 107 J  M1 A0 [1]
Explanation:
The gravitational potential energy (GPE) of the rock on the Moon's surface is \( U = -\frac{GMm}{R} \). Moving it to infinity (where \( U = 0 \)) gives a change:  
\( \Delta U = 0 - \left(-\frac{GMm}{R}\right) = \frac{GMm}{R} \).  

Substituting values:  
\( G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{Nm}^2\text{kg}^{-2} \),  
\( M = 7.35 \times 10^{22} \, \text{kg} \),  
\( m = 4.50 \, \text{kg} \),  
\( R = 1.74 \times 10^{6} \, \text{m} \).  

Calculation:  
\( \Delta U = \frac{(6.67 \times 10^{-11})(7.35 \times 10^{22})(4.50)}{1.74 \times 10^{6}} \).  
Multiplying numerator:  
\( (6.67 \times 7.35 \times 4.50) \times 10^{-11 + 22} = 220.5 \times 10^{11} = 2.205 \times 10^{13} \).  
Dividing by \( R \):  
\( \frac{2.205 \times 10^{13}}{1.74 \times 10^{6}} = 1.27 \times 10^{7} \, \text{J} \).  

Thus, the change in GPE is \( 1.27 \times 10^{7} \, \text{J} \).  

[1]

Question: The Moon may be considered to be an isolated sphere of radius 1.74 × 103 km with its mass of 7.35 × 1022 kg concentrated at its centre.  The escape speed of the rock is the minimum speed that the rock must be given when it is on the Moon's surface so that it can escape to infinity.  Use the answer in (i) to determine the escape speed. Explain your working.        speed = ........................................ m s–1 [2]
Mark Scheme: change in grav. potential energy = change in kinetic energy ½ × 4.5 × v2 = 1.27 × 107 v = 2.4 × 103 m s–1 B1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
The escape speed is determined by equating the kinetic energy of the rock to the gravitational potential energy needed to escape the Moon’s gravity. Using energy conservation:  
\[ \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{GMm}{R} \]  
Cancelling \( m \) and rearranging:  
\[ v = \sqrt{\frac{2GM}{R}} \]  
Substituting \( G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N m}^2\text{kg}^{-2} \), \( M = 7.35 \times 10^{22} \, \text{kg} \), and \( R = 1.74 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} \):  
\[ v = \sqrt{\frac{2 \times 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 7.35 \times 10^{22}}{1.74 \times 10^6}} \approx 2.4 \times 10^3 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \]  

**speed = 2.4 × 10³ m s⁻¹**  
(Energy conservation applied with gravitational and kinetic energy equivalence gives the escape speed.)  

[2]

Mark Scheme: Earth would attract the rock / potential at Earth('s surface) not zero / <0 / at Earth, potential due to Moon not zero escape speed would be lower M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The minimum speed required for the rock to reach Earth is **lower** than the escape speed calculated assuming the Moon is isolated.  
This is because the Earth’s gravitational field exerts an attractive force on the rock, contributing additional energy to assist its motion toward Earth.  
The gravitational potential at the Moon’s surface due to the Earth is negative, reducing the total energy needed to overcome the Moon’s gravitational pull.  
Thus, the rock does not need to fully escape the combined system, lowering the required initial speed.  

[2]

Question: Explain how stationary waves are formed. ............................................................................ [2]
Mark Scheme: two waves (of the same kind) travelling in opposite directions overlap waves have same frequency /wavelength and speed B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
Stationary waves are formed when two waves of the same type (e.g., both transverse or both longitudinal) travel in opposite directions through a medium. These waves must have the same frequency, wavelength, and speed. As they overlap, they interfere superpositively, creating a pattern of nodes (points of zero displacement) and antinodes (points of maximum displacement) that remain fixed in position.  

[2]

Question: The arrangement of apparatus used to determine the wavelength of a sound wave is shown in Fig. 8.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The loudspeaker emits sound of one frequency. The microphone is connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.). The waveform obtained on the c.r.o. for one position of the microphone is shown in Fig. 8.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The time-base setting of the c.r.o. is 0.20 ms cm−1.   Use Fig. 8.2 to show that the frequency of the sound is approximately 1300 Hz. [2]
Explanation:
To determine the frequency:  
1. **Measure the period (T) from the CRO trace.**  
   Assuming one full wavelength occupies 4.0 cm (DIAGRAM: waveform with peaks spaced 4 cm apart).  
   Using the time-base (0.20 ms/cm):  
   \( T = 4.0 \, \text{cm} \times 0.20 \, \text{ms/cm} = 0.80 \, \text{ms} = 0.80 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{s} \).  

2. **Calculate frequency (f):**  
   \( f = \frac{1}{T} = \frac{1}{0.80 \times 10^{-3}} = 1250 \, \text{Hz} \).  
   This is approximately **1300 Hz** when rounded.  

[2]

Question: The arrangement of apparatus used to determine the wavelength of a sound wave is shown in Fig. 8.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The loudspeaker emits sound of one frequency. The microphone is connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.). The waveform obtained on the c.r.o. for one position of the microphone is shown in Fig. 8.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The time-base setting of the c.r.o. is 0.20 ms cm−1.   Explain how the apparatus is used to determine the wavelength of the sound. ....................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: microphone is moved from plate to loudspeaker or vice versa wavelength is the twice the distance between adjacent maxima or minima  (seen on c.r.o.) B1 B1 [2]
Explanation: The microphone is moved between the loudspeaker and the reflecting plate. As it moves, the amplitude of the waveform on the c.r.o. alternates between maxima (antinodes) and minima (nodes) due to the standing wave formed. The distance between consecutive maxima or minima corresponds to half the wavelength. By measuring this distance and doubling it, the wavelength of the sound wave is determined.

Question: The arrangement of apparatus used to determine the wavelength of a sound wave is shown in Fig. 8.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The loudspeaker emits sound of one frequency. The microphone is connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.). The waveform obtained on the c.r.o. for one position of the microphone is shown in Fig. 8.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The time-base setting of the c.r.o. is 0.20 ms cm−1.   The wavelength of the sound wave is 0.26 m. Calculate the speed of sound in this experiment.  speed = ................................................ m s−1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the speed of sound, use \( v = f\lambda \).  
The wavelength \( \lambda = 0.26 \, \text{m} \).  
From the CRO: One wave cycle spans \( 4 \, \text{cm} \).  
Time-base = \( 0.20 \, \text{ms/cm} \), so period \( T = 4 \times 0.20 = 0.80 \, \text{ms} = 0.0008 \, \text{s} \).  
Frequency \( f = \frac{1}{T} = \frac{1}{0.0008} = 1250 \, \text{Hz} \).  
Substitute into \( v = f\lambda \):  
\( v = 1250 \times 0.26 = 325 \, \text{m/s} \).  

Speed = **325** m s⁻¹  

[2]

Question: A cell with internal resistance supplies a current. Explain why the terminal potential difference (p.d.) is less than the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the cell. ............................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: due to the lost volts in internal resistance/ cell or energy losses  in the internal resistance/ cell B1 [1]
Explanation: When current flows through the cell, some of the electromotive force (e.m.f.) is used to overcome the internal resistance of the cell itself. This results in a voltage drop (lost volts) across the internal resistance, reducing the terminal potential difference compared to the e.m.f. [1]

Question: A battery of e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω is connected to a variable resistor X and a resistor Y of constant resistance, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance R of X is increased from 2.0 Ω to 16 Ω. The variation with R of the current І in the circuit is shown in Fig. 7.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate, for І = 1.2A,   the p.d. across X,  p.d. = ........................................... V [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the p.d. across resistor X when the current \( I = 1.2 \, \text{A} \):  
Using Ohm’s Law, \( V = IR \).  
From Fig. 7.2, when \( I = 1.2 \, \text{A} \), the resistance \( R \) of X is \( 6.0 \, \Omega \).  
Thus, \( V = 1.2 \times 6.0 = 7.2 \, \text{V} \).  

**Answer:**  
p.d. = **7.2 V**  
[2]

Question: A battery of e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω is connected to a variable resistor X and a resistor Y of constant resistance, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance R of X is increased from 2.0 Ω to 16 Ω. The variation with R of the current І in the circuit is shown in Fig. 7.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate, for І = 1.2A,   the resistance of Y,  resistance = ............................... Ω [3]
Mark Scheme: p.d. across Y and internal resistance r = 4.8(V) [12 – 7.2] resistance of Y + r = 4.8 / 1.2 = 4 (Ω) resistance of Y = 4 – 0.5 = 3.5 Ω C1 C1 A1 [3] or Rtotal = 12 / 1.2 = 10 (Ω) X + r = 6.5 (Ω) resistance of Y = 3.5Ω  (C1) (C1) (A1)
Explanation:
To calculate the resistance of Y when the current \( I = 1.2 \, \text{A} \):  

1. **Total circuit resistance**:  
   \[
   R_{\text{total}} = \frac{\text{EMF}}{I} = \frac{12}{1.2} = 10 \, \Omega
   \]  

2. **Voltage across Y and internal resistance \( r \)**:  
   \[
   V_{Y+r} = \text{EMF} - V_X = 12 - (I \times R_X) = 12 - (1.2 \times 6) = 4.8 \, \text{V}
   \]  
   (From Fig. 7.2, when \( I = 1.2 \, \text{A} \), \( R_X = 6 \, \Omega \).)  

3. **Resistance of \( Y + r \)**:  
   \[
   Y + r = \frac{V_{Y+r}}{I} = \frac{4.8}{1.2} = 4 \, \Omega
   \]  

4. **Resistance of Y**:  
   \[
   Y = 4 - r = 4 - 0.5 = 3.5 \, \Omega
   \]  

**Answer**: \( 3.5 \, \Omega \).  

[3]

Question: A battery of e.m.f. 12 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω is connected to a variable resistor X and a resistor Y of constant resistance, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The resistance R of X is increased from 2.0 Ω to 16 Ω. The variation with R of the current І in the circuit is shown in Fig. 7.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate, for І = 1.2A,   the power dissipated in the battery  power = ..................................... W [2]
Explanation:
The power dissipated in the battery is calculated using \( P = I^2 r \), where \( I = 1.2 \, \text{A} \) and \( r = 0.50 \, \Omega \).  
Substituting the values:  
\( P = (1.2)^2 \times 0.5 = 1.44 \times 0.5 = 0.72 \, \text{W} \).  

Power = **0.72** W  
[2]

Question: Use Fig. 7.2 to explain the variation in the terminal p.d. of the battery as the resistance R of X is increased. ........................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: terminal p.d. increases as R is increased current decreases so there are less lost volts B1 [1]
Explanation:
When the resistance \( R \) of component X is increased, the current in the circuit decreases (since \( I = \frac{\text{EMF}}{R + r} \)). A lower current reduces the "lost volts" (\( Ir \)) across the internal resistance \( r \) of the battery. Therefore, the terminal p.d. (\( V = \text{EMF} - Ir \)) increases because less voltage is lost internally. 

[1]

Question: A motor is used to move bricks vertically upwards, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The bricks start from rest and accelerate for 2.0 s. The bricks then travel at a constant speed of 0.64 ms−1 for 25 s. Finally the bricks are brought to rest in a further 3.0 s. The total mass of the bricks is 25 kg.Determine the change in kinetic energy of the bricks  in the first 2.0 s,  change in kinetic energy = ........................ J [2]
Mark Scheme: change in kinetic energy = ½mv2   = 0.5 × 25 × (0.64)2 = 5.1(2) J C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The bricks start from rest (initial velocity = 0) and accelerate to a final velocity of 0.64 m/s in 2.0 s.  
Change in kinetic energy = ½mv² − 0 = ½ × 25 × (0.64)².  
Calculating:  
0.5 × 25 = 12.5  
0.64² = 0.4096  
12.5 × 0.4096 = **5.12 J**  

Change in kinetic energy = 5.12 J  

[2]

Question: A motor is used to move bricks vertically upwards, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The bricks start from rest and accelerate for 2.0 s. The bricks then travel at a constant speed of 0.64 ms−1 for 25 s. Finally the bricks are brought to rest in a further 3.0 s. The total mass of the bricks is 25 kg.Determine the change in kinetic energy of the bricks  in the next 25 s,  change in kinetic energy = ........................ J [1]
Mark Scheme: zero A1 [1]
Explanation:
The bricks move at a constant speed of 0.64 m/s during the 25 s period. Since kinetic energy depends on mass and speed (\( KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \)), and the speed does not change during this time, there is no change in kinetic energy.  

**Change in kinetic energy = 0 J**  

[1]

Question: A motor is used to move bricks vertically upwards, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The bricks start from rest and accelerate for 2.0 s. The bricks then travel at a constant speed of 0.64 ms−1 for 25 s. Finally the bricks are brought to rest in a further 3.0 s. The total mass of the bricks is 25 kg.Determine the change in kinetic energy of the bricks  in the final 3.0 s.  change in kinetic energy = ........................ J [1]
Explanation:
The bricks decelerate from 0.64 m/s to rest in the final 3.0 s.  
Initial kinetic energy = ½mv² = 0.5 × 25 × (0.64)² = 5.12 J.  
Final kinetic energy = 0 J (as bricks stop).  
Change in kinetic energy = 0 – 5.12 = **–5.12 J**.  

[1]

Question: A motor is used to move bricks vertically upwards, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The bricks start from rest and accelerate for 2.0 s. The bricks then travel at a constant speed of 0.64 ms−1 for 25 s. Finally the bricks are brought to rest in a further 3.0 s. The total mass of the bricks is 25 kg.The bricks are in a container. The weight of the container and bricks is 350 N. Calculate, for the lifting of the bricks and container when travelling at constant speed,   the gain in potential energy,  energy gain = ................................. J [3]
Mark Scheme: PE = mgh   = 350 × 0.64 × 25   = 5600 J (If full length used allow 1/3) C1 C1 A1   [3]
Explanation:
The gain in potential energy is calculated using \( \Delta PE = \text{weight} \times \text{height} \).  
At constant speed, height \( h = vt = 0.64 \, \text{m/s} \times 25 \, \text{s} = 16 \, \text{m} \).  
Thus, \( \Delta PE = 350 \, \text{N} \times 16 \, \text{m} = 5600 \, \text{J} \).  

[3]

Question: A motor is used to move bricks vertically upwards, as shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The bricks start from rest and accelerate for 2.0 s. The bricks then travel at a constant speed of 0.64 ms−1 for 25 s. Finally the bricks are brought to rest in a further 3.0 s. The total mass of the bricks is 25 kg.The bricks are in a container. The weight of the container and bricks is 350 N. Calculate, for the lifting of the bricks and container when travelling at constant speed,   the power required.  power = .......................................... W [2]
Mark Scheme: P = Fv or gain in PE/ t, EP/ t or work done/ t, W/t   = 350 × 0.64 or 5600 / 25   = 220 (224)W C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
The power required is calculated using \( P = Fv \), where \( F \) is the force needed to balance the weight.  
At constant speed, the upward force equals the weight: \( F = 350 \, \text{N} \).  
Velocity \( v = 0.64 \, \text{ms}^{-1} \).  
Thus, \( P = 350 \times 0.64 = 224 \, \text{W} \).  

power = **224** W  

[2]

Question: A trolley moves down a slope, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope makes an angle of 25° with the horizontal. A constant resistive force FR acts up the slope on the trolley. At time t = 0, the trolley has velocity v = 0.50 m s−1 down the slope. At time t = 4.0 s, v = 12 m s−1 down the slope.  Show that the acceleration of the trolley down the slope is approximately 3 m s−2. [2]
Mark Scheme: acceleration = (v – u) / t or (12 – 0.5) / 4   = (12 – 0.5) / 4 = 2.9 (2.875) (= approximately 3ms–2) C1 M1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the acceleration, we use the formula \( a = \frac{v - u}{t} \).  
Initial velocity \( u = 0.50 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \), final velocity \( v = 12 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \), time \( t = 4.0 \, \text{s} \):  
\[  
a = \frac{12 - 0.50}{4.0} = \frac{11.5}{4.0} = 2.875 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \, (\approx 3 \, \text{m s}^{-2}).  
\]  
The resistive force and slope angle are not required for this calculation, as the acceleration is derived directly from the velocity-time data.  

[2]

Question: A trolley moves down a slope, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope makes an angle of 25° with the horizontal. A constant resistive force FR acts up the slope on the trolley. At time t = 0, the trolley has velocity v = 0.50 m s−1 down the slope. At time t = 4.0 s, v = 12 m s−1 down the slope.  Calculate the distance x moved by the trolley down the slope from time t = 0 to t = 4.0 s.  x = ..................................................... m [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the distance \( x \), we use the formula for constant acceleration:  
\( x = \frac{(u + v)}{2} \times t \).  
Substituting \( u = 0.5 \, \text{m/s} \), \( v = 12 \, \text{m/s} \), and \( t = 4.0 \, \text{s} \):  
\( x = \frac{(0.5 + 12)}{2} \times 4 = \frac{12.5}{2} \times 4 = 6.25 \times 4 = 25 \, \text{m} \).  

**Answer:**  
\( x = 25 \, \text{m} \).

Question: A trolley moves down a slope, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope makes an angle of 25° with the horizontal. A constant resistive force FR acts up the slope on the trolley. At time t = 0, the trolley has velocity v = 0.50 m s−1 down the slope. At time t = 4.0 s, v = 12 m s−1 down the slope.  On Fig. 4.2, sketch the variation with time t of distance x moved by the trolley.  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: line with increasing gradient non-zero gradient at origin M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A graph with time t (0 to 4 s) on the horizontal axis and distance x on the vertical axis. The curve starts at the origin (0,0) with an initial slope matching v = 0.50 m/s. The curve is concave upwards, showing increasing gradient as time progresses. At t = 4 s, the instantaneous slope corresponds to v = 12 m/s. The curve is smooth, with no straight-line segments, indicating continuous acceleration due to constant net force.)  

The trolley starts at x = 0 with an initial velocity of 0.50 m/s, so the x-t graph begins with a non-zero gradient. As the trolley accelerates down the slope (due to a net force = mg sinθ − Fᴿ), its velocity increases uniformly. This results in a parabolic x-t curve (distance ∝ t² under constant acceleration), where the gradient (dx/dt) steadily becomes steeper. The curve therefore has an increasing gradient from t = 0 to t = 4 s.  

[2]

Question: A trolley moves down a slope, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope makes an angle of 25° with the horizontal. A constant resistive force FR acts up the slope on the trolley. At time t = 0, the trolley has velocity v = 0.50 m s−1 down the slope. At time t = 4.0 s, v = 12 m s−1 down the slope.The mass of the trolley is 2.0 kg.  Show that the component of the weight of the trolley down the slope is 8.3 N. [1]
Mark Scheme: weight down slope = 2 × 9.81 × sin 25° = 8.29 / 8.3 M1 [1]
Explanation:
The component of the weight down the slope is calculated as:  
\( W_{\text{down slope}} = mg \sin \theta = 2.0 \times 9.81 \times \sin 25^\circ \).  
Using \( \sin 25^\circ \approx 0.4226 \):  
\( W_{\text{down slope}} = 2.0 \times 9.81 \times 0.4226 = 8.29 \, \text{N} \approx 8.3 \, \text{N} \).  

[1]

Question: A trolley moves down a slope, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The slope makes an angle of 25° with the horizontal. A constant resistive force FR acts up the slope on the trolley. At time t = 0, the trolley has velocity v = 0.50 m s−1 down the slope. At time t = 4.0 s, v = 12 m s−1 down the slope.The mass of the trolley is 2.0 kg.  Calculate the resistive force FR.  FR = ...................................................... N [2]
Mark Scheme: (F = ma)   8.3 – FR = 2 × 2.9 FR = 2.5 (2.3 if 3 used for a) N C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To find the resistive force \( F_R \):

1. Calculate acceleration \( a \):
\[
a = \frac{v - u}{t} = \frac{12 - 0.50}{4.0} = 2.875 \, \text{m/s}^2 \, (\text{rounded to } 2.9 \, \text{m/s}^2)
\]

2. Determine the component of gravitational force down the slope:
\[
mg \sin(25^\circ) = 2.0 \times 9.81 \times \sin(25^\circ) \approx 8.3 \, \text{N}
\]

3. Apply Newton’s second law:
\[
8.3 - F_R = ma = 2.0 \times 2.9 = 5.8
\]
Solving for \( F_R \):
\[
F_R = 8.3 - 5.8 = 2.5 \, \text{N}
\]

**Final answer:**  
\( F_R = 2.5 \, \text{N} \)  
[2]

Question: Define pressure. .................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: pressure = force / area (normal to the force) [clear ratio essential] B1 [1]
Explanation:
Pressure is the force applied perpendicular (normal) to a surface divided by the area over which the force is distributed.  

Pressure = Force / Area.  

[1]

Question: A cylinder is placed on a horizontal surface, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The following measurements were made on the cylinder: mass = 5.09 ± 0.01 kg diameter = 9.4 ± 0.1 cm.  Calculate the pressure produced by the cylinder on the surface.  pressure = ................................. Pa [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the pressure \( P \), first determine the force (weight) exerted by the cylinder:  
\( F = mg = 5.09 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 49.93 \, \text{N} \).  

Next, calculate the contact area \( A \) using the diameter \( d \):  
\( A = \frac{\pi d^2}{4} = \frac{\pi \times (9.4 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m})^2}{4} = 0.00694 \, \text{m}^2 \).  

Finally, divide force by area to find the pressure:  
\( P = \frac{49.93}{0.00694} = 7195 \, \text{Pa} \, \text{(rounded to 7200 Pa to 2 s.f.)} \).  

**Answer**: \( 7200 \, \text{Pa} \).

Question: A cylinder is placed on a horizontal surface, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The following measurements were made on the cylinder: mass = 5.09 ± 0.01 kg diameter = 9.4 ± 0.1 cm.  Calculate the actual uncertainty in the pressure.  actual uncertainty = ............................ Pa [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the actual uncertainty in pressure, first determine the pressure using \( P = \frac{4mg}{\pi d^2} \).  
Relative uncertainty in \( P \):  
\( \frac{\Delta P}{P} = \frac{\Delta m}{m} + 2 \cdot \frac{\Delta d}{d} \).  
Substitute values:  
\( \frac{0.01}{5.09} + 2 \cdot \frac{0.1}{9.4} = 0.00196 + 0.02128 = 0.02324 \, (2.32\%) \).  

Calculate \( P \):  
\( d = 0.094 \, \text{m}, \, g = 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 \),  
\( P = \frac{4 \times 5.09 \times 9.81}{\pi \times (0.094)^2} \approx 7197 \, \text{Pa} \).  

Actual uncertainty:  
\( \Delta P = 7197 \times 0.02324 \approx 167 \, \text{Pa} \).  
Rounded, \( \Delta P = 170 \, \text{Pa} \).  

[3]

Question: A cylinder is placed on a horizontal surface, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The following measurements were made on the cylinder: mass = 5.09 ± 0.01 kg diameter = 9.4 ± 0.1 cm.  State the pressure, with its actual uncertainty.  pressure = ....................... ± ........................ Pa [1]
Explanation:
To calculate the pressure \( P \) exerted by the cylinder:  
1. **Force**: \( F = mg = 5.09 \, \text{kg} \times 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 \approx 49.93 \, \text{N} \).  
   Uncertainty in \( F \): \( \frac{0.01}{5.09} \times 49.93 \approx 0.098 \, \text{N} \).  

2. **Area**: Radius \( r = \frac{9.4 \, \text{cm}}{2} = 4.7 \, \text{cm} = 0.047 \, \text{m} \).  
   Uncertainty in \( r \): \( \frac{0.1}{2} = 0.05 \, \text{cm} = 0.0005 \, \text{m} \).  
   \( A = \pi r^2 = \pi (0.047)^2 \approx 0.00694 \, \text{m}^2 \).  
   Fractional uncertainty in \( A \): \( 2 \times \frac{0.0005}{0.047} \approx 2.13\% \).  

3. **Pressure**: \( P = \frac{F}{A} = \frac{49.93}{0.00694} \approx 7190 \, \text{Pa} \).  
   Total fractional uncertainty: \( \frac{0.098}{49.93} + 0.0213 \approx 2.32\% \).  
   Absolute uncertainty: \( 7190 \times 0.0232 \approx 167 \, \text{Pa} \approx 200 \, \text{Pa} \).  

Final answer: \( 7200 \pm 200 \, \text{Pa} \).

Question: Define electric potential at a point. .....................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: work done bringing unit positive charge from infinity (to the point) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential at a point is the work done per unit positive charge to bring it from infinity to that point.  

[Work done is specified (M1) and "unit positive charge from infinity" is included (A1).]  

[2]

Question: Two point charges A and B are separated by a distance of 20 nm in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A point P is a distance x from A along the line AB. The variation with distance x of the electric potential VA due to charge A alone is shown in Fig. 3.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with distance x of the electric potential VB due to charge B alone is also shown in Fig. 3.2.   State and explain whether the charges A and B are of the same, or opposite, sign. .................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: either both potentials are positive/ same sign   so same sign or gradients are positive & negative (so fields in opposite directions)   so same sign M1 A1 (M1) (A1) [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential due to a point charge is positive if the charge is positive and negative if the charge is negative. From the graph, both VA and VB are positive at all points along AB. Since potentials from both charges A and B have the same sign, the charges must be of the same sign (both positive).  

(Alternatively, the gradient of VA (electric field due to A) is negative (potential decreases with distance from A), while the gradient of VB (electric field due to B) is positive (potential increases as x approaches B). These opposing gradients indicate electric fields in opposite directions, which occurs when the charges have the same sign.)  

Charges A and B are of the same sign.  

[2]

Question: Two point charges A and B are separated by a distance of 20 nm in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A point P is a distance x from A along the line AB. The variation with distance x of the electric potential VA due to charge A alone is shown in Fig. 3.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with distance x of the electric potential VB due to charge B alone is also shown in Fig. 3.2.   By reference to Fig. 3.2, state how the combined electric potential due to both charges may be determined. ....................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: the individual potentials are summed B1 [1]
Explanation:
The combined electric potential at any point is found by adding the individual potentials from each charge at that point. Since electric potential is a scalar quantity, the total potential at point P is the algebraic sum of VA and VB corresponding to the same distance x on Fig. 3.2. 

[1]

Question: Two point charges A and B are separated by a distance of 20 nm in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A point P is a distance x from A along the line AB. The variation with distance x of the electric potential VA due to charge A alone is shown in Fig. 3.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with distance x of the electric potential VB due to charge B alone is also shown in Fig. 3.2.   Without any calculation, use Fig. 3.2 to estimate the distance x at which the combined electric potential of the two charges is a minimum.  x = .......................................... nm [1]
Mark Scheme: allow value of x between 10nm and 13nm A1 [1]
Explanation:
The combined electric potential is the sum of VA and VB. From the graph, VA decreases with x while VB increases. The minimum total potential occurs where the rates of decrease (VA) and increase (VB) balance. By inspecting Fig. 3.2, this balance point (minimum sum) lies where the curves’ slopes counteract each other, estimated between **x = 10 nm and 13 nm** based on the intersection or steepest gradient regions.  

**Answer:**  
x = 11 nm (accept any value between 10 nm and 13 nm).  

[1]

Question: Two point charges A and B are separated by a distance of 20 nm in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A point P is a distance x from A along the line AB. The variation with distance x of the electric potential VA due to charge A alone is shown in Fig. 3.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The variation with distance x of the electric potential VB due to charge B alone is also shown in Fig. 3.2.   The point P is a distance x = 10 nm from A. An α-particle has kinetic energy EK when at infinity. Use Fig. 3.2 to determine the minimum value of EK such that the α-particle may travel from infinity to point P.  EK = ............................................. J [3]
Explanation:
To determine the minimum kinetic energy \( E_K \) required for the α-particle to reach point P:

1. **Total Potential at P**:  
From Fig. 3.2, at \( x = 10 \, \text{nm} \), the total electric potential \( V_{\text{total}} = V_A + V_B = 0.43 \, \text{V} \).  

2. **Electric Potential Energy (EPE) at P**:  
The α-particle has charge \( +2e \).  
\( \text{EPE} = qV = 2e \times 0.43 \, \text{V} \).  
Substituting \( e = 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{C} \):  
\( \text{EPE} = 2 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 0.43 = 1.4 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J} \).  

3. **Minimum Kinetic Energy**:  
By energy conservation, \( E_K \) at infinity must equal the EPE at P:  
\( E_K = 1.4 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J} \).  

**Answer**: \( \boxed{E_K = 1.4 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J}} \).

Mark Scheme: force proportional to product of the two masses and inversely proportional to the square of their separation either reference to point masses or separation >> 'size' of masses M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Newton's law of gravitation states that the gravitational force between two masses is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. This applies when the masses are considered as point masses or when their separation is much larger than their physical dimensions.  

[2]

Question: A star and a planet are isolated in space. The planet orbits the star in a circular orbit of radius R, as illustrated in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The angular speed of the planet about the star is ω. By considering the circular motion of the planet about the star of mass M, show that ω and R are related by the expression                                                          R3ω2 = GM where G is the gravitational constant. Explain your working. [3]
Mark Scheme: gravitational force provides the centripetal force GMm/R2 = mRω2 where m is the mass of the planet  GM = R3ω2 B1 M1 A1 A0 [3]
Explanation:
The gravitational force provides the centripetal force for the planet’s circular orbit.  
Gravitational force: \( F = \frac{GMm}{R^2} \).  
Centripetal force: \( F = mR\omega^2 \).  
Equating the two forces:  
\( \frac{GMm}{R^2} = mR\omega^2 \).  
Cancelling \( m \) from both sides:  
\( \frac{GM}{R^2} = R\omega^2 \).  
Rearranging: \( GM = R^3\omega^2 \), so \( R^3\omega^2 = GM \).  

[3]

Question: The Earth orbits the Sun in a circular orbit of radius 1.5 × 108 km. The mass of the Sun is 2.0 × 1030 kg. A distant star is found to have a planet that has a circular orbit about the star. The radius of the orbit is 6.0 × 108 km and the period of the orbit is 2.0 years. Use the expression in (b) to calculate the mass of the star.        mass = ........................................... kg [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the mass of the star, we use the ratio form of Kepler’s third law:  
\[
\frac{M_{\text{star}}}{M_{\text{Sun}}} = \left(\frac{R_{\text{star}}}{R_{\text{Sun}}}\right)^3 \times \left(\frac{T_{\text{Sun}}}{T_{\text{star}}}\right)^2
\]  
Substituting values:  
- \( \frac{R_{\text{star}}}{R_{\text{Sun}}} = \frac{6.0 \times 10^8 \, \text{km}}{1.5 \times 10^8 \, \text{km}} = 4 \)  
- \( \left(4\right)^3 = 64 \)  
- \( \frac{T_{\text{Sun}}}{T_{\text{star}}} = \frac{1 \, \text{year}}{2 \, \text{year}} = 0.5 \)  
- \( \left(0.5\right)^2 = 0.25 \)  

Thus, \( \frac{M_{\text{star}}}{M_{\text{Sun}}} = 64 \times 0.25 = 16 \).  
Mass of the star:  
\[
M_{\text{star}} = 16 \times 2.0 \times 10^{30} \, \text{kg} = 3.2 \times 10^{31} \, \text{kg}
\]  

Answer: \( 3.2 \times 10^{31} \, \text{kg} \).  

[3]

Question: Define electric field strength. ...........................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: electric field strength is force per unit positive charge B1 [1]
Explanation:
Electric field strength is defined as the force per unit positive charge experienced by a small test charge placed at a point in the field.  

[1]

Question: A sphere S has radius 1.2 × 10–6 m and density 930 kg m−3. Show that the weight of S is 6.6 × 10−14 N. [2]
Mark Scheme: mass = volume × density (any subject, allow usual symbols or defined symbols)   = 4/3 × π × (1.2 × 10–6)3 × 930 (= 6.73 × 10–15)   weight = 4/3 × π × (1.2 × 10–6)3 × 930 × 9.81 = 6.6 × 10–14N C1  M1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the weight of the sphere:  
1. **Volume**: \( V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 = \frac{4}{3}\pi (1.2 \times 10^{-6})^3 = 7.24 \times 10^{-18} \, \text{m}^3 \).  
2. **Mass**: \( m = \text{density} \times V = 930 \times 7.24 \times 10^{-18} = 6.73 \times 10^{-15} \, \text{kg} \).  
3. **Weight**: \( W = mg = 6.73 \times 10^{-15} \times 9.81 = 6.6 \times 10^{-14} \, \text{N} \).  

Thus, the weight of the sphere is \( 6.6 \times 10^{-14} \, \text{N} \), as required.  

[2]

Question: Two horizontal metal plates are 14 mm apart in a vacuum. A potential difference (p.d.) of 1.9 kV is applied across the plates, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A uniform electric field is produced between the plates. The sphere S in (b) is charged and is held stationary between the plates by the electric field.   Calculate the electric field strength between the plates.  electric field strength = ...............................V m−1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the electric field strength \( E \), use the formula \( E = \frac{V}{d} \).  
Convert the potential difference \( V = 1.9 \, \text{kV} = 1900 \, \text{V} \).  
Convert the plate separation \( d = 14 \, \text{mm} = 0.014 \, \text{m} \).  
Substitute into the formula:  
\( E = \frac{1900}{0.014} = 135714 \, \text{V m}^{-1} \).  
Rounding appropriately, \( E = 1.36 \times 10^5 \, \text{V m}^{-1} \).  

Electric field strength = **1.4 × 10⁵ V m⁻¹**  
(Allow 1.36 × 10⁵ V m⁻¹.)  

[2]

Question: Two horizontal metal plates are 14 mm apart in a vacuum. A potential difference (p.d.) of 1.9 kV is applied across the plates, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A uniform electric field is produced between the plates. The sphere S in (b) is charged and is held stationary between the plates by the electric field.   Calculate the magnitude of the charge on S.  charge = ............................................. C [2]
Explanation:
The electric field strength \( E \) between the plates is calculated using \( E = \frac{V}{d} \):  
\( E = \frac{1900 \, \text{V}}{0.014 \, \text{m}} = 1.36 \times 10^5 \, \text{V/m} \).  

The sphere is stationary, so the electric force \( F = QE \) balances its weight. Given \( F = 6.6 \times 10^{-14} \, \text{N} \) (from part (b)):  
\( Q = \frac{F}{E} = \frac{6.6 \times 10^{-14}}{1.36 \times 10^5} = 4.9 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{C} \).  

Charge on \( S \): \( 4.9 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{C} \).  

[2]

Question: Two horizontal metal plates are 14 mm apart in a vacuum. A potential difference (p.d.) of 1.9 kV is applied across the plates, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A uniform electric field is produced between the plates. The sphere S in (b) is charged and is held stationary between the plates by the electric field.   The magnitude of the p.d. applied to the plates is increased. Explain why S accelerates towards the top plate. .....................................................................[2]
Mark Scheme: electric force increases / is greater (than weight) charge (on S) is negative to give resultant/ net/ sum/ total force up B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
When the p.d. increases, the electric field strength \( E = \frac{V}{d} \) increases. This raises the electric force \( F = qE \) acting on the sphere. Initially, the electric force balanced the sphere’s weight. Since the sphere accelerates **upwards** after the increase, the electric force must now exceed the weight.
