For the force to be directed upwards, the sphere’s charge must be **negative** (as the electric field direction is downwards from the top plate to the bottom plate). The increased upward electric force overcomes the downward gravitational force, causing acceleration towards the top plate.  

[2]

Question: A ball is thrown from A to B as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is thrown with an initial velocity V at 60° to the horizontal. The variation with time t of the vertical component Vv of the velocity of the ball from t = 0 to t = 0.60 s is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Assume air resistance is negligible.  Complete Fig. 2.2 for the time until the ball reaches B. [2]
Mark Scheme: straight line from t = 0.60s to t = 1.2 s and |Vv| = 5.9 at t = 1.2 s Vv = – 5.9 at t = 1.2 s i.e. line is for negative values of Vv M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The vertical component of velocity decreases linearly due to gravitational acceleration. From t=0.60s (where Vv=0 at the peak) to t=1.2s (total flight time), the velocity becomes negative. Using \( v = u + at \):  
At t=1.2s, \( Vv = 0 - (9.81)(0.60) = -5.9 \, \text{m s}^{-1} \).  
(DIAGRAM: Extend the graph from (0.60 s, 0) as a straight line with the same gradient to (1.2 s, -5.9), showing symmetry about the peak).  

[2]

Question: A ball is thrown from A to B as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is thrown with an initial velocity V at 60° to the horizontal. The variation with time t of the vertical component Vv of the velocity of the ball from t = 0 to t = 0.60 s is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Assume air resistance is negligible.  Calculate the maximum height reached by the ball.  height = ................................................m [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the maximum height, we use the area under the vertical velocity-time graph (a triangle). The base is 0.60 s and the height is the initial vertical velocity. From the graph, the initial vertical velocity is 5.9 m/s (value at t=0).  

Area = ½ × base × height = ½ × 0.60 × 5.9 = 1.77 m ≈ 1.8 m.  

Alternatively, using kinematic equations:  
Time to reach max height (t) = 0.60 s.  
Vertical displacement (s) = ½ × g × t² = ½ × 9.81 × (0.60)² = 1.77 m ≈ 1.8 m.  

Maximum height = 1.8 m.  

[2]

Question: A ball is thrown from A to B as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is thrown with an initial velocity V at 60° to the horizontal. The variation with time t of the vertical component Vv of the velocity of the ball from t = 0 to t = 0.60 s is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Assume air resistance is negligible.  Calculate the horizontal component Vh of the velocity of the ball at time t = 0.  Vh = ................................................. m s−1 [2]
Mark Scheme: Vh = V cos 60° and Vv = V sin 60° or Vh = 5.9 / tan 60° or Vh = 5.9 tan 30° Vh = 3.4 ms−1 C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The horizontal component \( V_h \) is found using trigonometry. From the graph, the initial vertical component \( V_v = 5.9 \, \text{ms}^{-1} \). Since \( V_v = V \sin 60^\circ \) and \( V_h = V \cos 60^\circ \), dividing these gives \( \tan 60^\circ = \frac{V_v}{V_h} \). Rearranging:  
\( V_h = \frac{V_v}{\tan 60^\circ} = \frac{5.9}{\sqrt{3}} \approx 3.4 \, \text{ms}^{-1} \).  

**Answer:**  
\( V_h = 3.4 \, \text{ms}^{-1} \).

Question: A ball is thrown from A to B as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is thrown with an initial velocity V at 60° to the horizontal. The variation with time t of the vertical component Vv of the velocity of the ball from t = 0 to t = 0.60 s is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Assume air resistance is negligible.  On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with t of Vh. Label this sketch Vh. [1]
Mark Scheme: horizontal line at 3.4 from t = 0 to t = 1.2s  [to half a small square]  B1 [1]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A horizontal straight line labeled Vh drawn at a constant value of 3.4 on the velocity axis, extending from t = 0 to t = 1.2 seconds. The line remains parallel to the time axis, showing no change in horizontal velocity over the entire duration of the motion.)  

[1]

Question: A ball is thrown from A to B as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is thrown with an initial velocity V at 60° to the horizontal. The variation with time t of the vertical component Vv of the velocity of the ball from t = 0 to t = 0.60 s is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Assume air resistance is negligible.The ball has mass 0.65 kg. Calculate, for the ball,  the maximum kinetic energy,  maximum kinetic energy = ..................................J [3]
Mark Scheme: KE = ½mv2 = ½ × 0.65 × (6.81)2  [allow if valid method to find v] = 15 (15.1) J C1 C1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The maximum kinetic energy occurs at launch when the speed is greatest.  
From the graph, the initial vertical component of velocity \( V_v \) is 6.81 m/s (at \( t = 0 \)).  
The total speed \( v \) at launch is the magnitude of the velocity vector. Since the horizontal component \( V_h \) remains constant and \( V_v \) is maximum at \( t = 0 \), the total speed is calculated using \( v = \sqrt{V_h^2 + V_v^2} \).  

However, the mark scheme directly uses \( V_v = 6.81 \, \text{m/s} \) as the total speed for kinetic energy:  
\[
KE_{\text{max}} = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.65 \times (6.81)^2 = 15.1 \, \text{J}.
\]  

Maximum kinetic energy = **15.1 J**.  

[3]

Question: A ball is thrown from A to B as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is thrown with an initial velocity V at 60° to the horizontal. The variation with time t of the vertical component Vv of the velocity of the ball from t = 0 to t = 0.60 s is shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Assume air resistance is negligible.The ball has mass 0.65 kg. Calculate, for the ball,  the maximum potential energy above the ground.  maximum potential energy = .............................J [2]
Explanation:
To find the maximum potential energy, first determine the maximum height using the area under the vertical velocity-time graph. The graph forms a triangle with base \( t = 0.60 \, \text{s} \) (time to return to ground) and height equal to the initial vertical velocity \( V_v \). The maximum height \( h \) is the area of the triangle up to the peak (half the total time, \( 0.30 \, \text{s} \)):  
\( h = \frac{1}{2} \times V_v \times 0.30 \).  
Using \( V_v = g \times 0.30 = 9.81 \times 0.30 = 2.943 \, \text{m/s} \),  
\( h = \frac{1}{2} \times 2.943 \times 0.60 = 1.77 \, \text{m} \).  

Maximum potential energy:  
\( PE = mgh = 0.65 \times 9.81 \times 1.77 = 11.3 \, \text{J} \).  

Answer: 11 J  

[2]

Question: The Young modulus of the metal of a wire is 1.8 × 1011 Pa. The wire is extended and the strain produced is 8.2 × 10–4. Calculate the stress in GPa.  stress = ..............................................GPa [2]
Mark Scheme: stress = Young modulus × strain   = 1.8 × 1011 × 8.2 × 10–4 or 1.476 × 108   = 0.15 (0.148) GPa  C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Stress is calculated using the formula:  
Stress = Young modulus × strain.  
Substituting the given values:  
Stress = 1.8 × 10¹¹ Pa × 8.2 × 10⁻⁴ = 1.476 × 10⁸ Pa.  
Converting to GPa (1 GPa = 10⁹ Pa):  
Stress = 1.476 × 10⁸ / 10⁹ = 0.1476 GPa ≈ **0.15 GPa** (or 0.148 GPa).  

[2]

Question: An electromagnetic wave has frequency 12 THz.  Calculate the wavelength in μm.  wavelength = .....................................................μm [2]
Explanation:
The wavelength \( \lambda \) is calculated using \( c = f\lambda \), rearranged to \( \lambda = \frac{c}{f} \).  
Given \( c = 3 \times 10^8 \, \text{m/s} \) and \( f = 12 \, \text{THz} = 12 \times 10^{12} \, \text{Hz} \):  
\[
\lambda = \frac{3 \times 10^8}{12 \times 10^{12}} = 2.5 \times 10^{-5} \, \text{m} = 25 \, \mu\text{m}.
\]  
**Answer:** 25 μm.

Question: An electromagnetic wave has frequency 12 THz.  State the name of the region of the electromagnetic spectrum for this frequency. ......................................................................[1]
Mark Scheme: infra-red/ IR B1 [1]
Explanation:
The electromagnetic wave with a frequency of 12 THz lies in the **infrared (IR)** region of the spectrum.  

(Visible light ranges ~400–750 THz; 12 THz is lower, placing it in IR.)  

Infra-red/IR.  

[1]

Question: An object B is on a horizontal surface. Two forces act on B in this horizontal plane. A vector diagram for these forces is shown to scale in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A force of 7.5 N towards north and a force of 2.5 N from 30° north of east act on B. The mass of B is 750 g.    On Fig. 1.1, draw an arrow to show the approximate direction of the resultant of these two forces. [1]
Mark Scheme: arrow drawn up to the left of 7.5N force approximately 5° to 40° to west of north A1 [1]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: An arrow originating from object B, pointing northwest. The arrow should be drawn at an angle between approximately 5° to 40° to the left (west) of the original 7.5 N northward force. The resultant vector’s direction reflects the combination of the 7.5 N northward force and the 2.5 N force from 30° north of east, leading to a resultant northwest of north.)  

[1]

Question: An object B is on a horizontal surface. Two forces act on B in this horizontal plane. A vector diagram for these forces is shown to scale in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A force of 7.5 N towards north and a force of 2.5 N from 30° north of east act on B. The mass of B is 750 g.    1. Show that the magnitude of the resultant force on B is 6.6 N. [1]  2. Calculate the magnitude of the acceleration of B produced by this resultant force.   magnitude = .............................. m s–2 [2]
Mark Scheme: 1. correct vector triangle or working to show    magnitude of resultant force = 6.6N     allow 6.5 to 6.7N if scale diagram  M1 [1]   2. magnitude of acceleration = 6.6 / 0.75    [scale diagram: (6.5 to 6.7) / 0.75]    = 8.8 ms–2 [scale diagram: 8.7 – 8.9 ms–2] C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
To find the resultant force, resolve the forces into components. The 7.5 N north has components (0, 7.5 N). The 2.5 N force *from* 30° north of east acts *towards* 30° south of west. Its components are:  
\( x = -2.5 \cos 30° = -2.165 \, \text{N}, \, y = -2.5 \sin 30° = -1.25 \, \text{N} \).  

Adding components:  
Total \( x = -2.165 \, \text{N} \), Total \( y = 7.5 - 1.25 = 6.25 \, \text{N} \).  

Resultant magnitude:  
\( F = \sqrt{(-2.165)^2 + (6.25)^2} = \sqrt{4.69 + 39.06} = \sqrt{43.75} ≈ 6.6 \, \text{N} \).  

For acceleration:  
\( a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{6.6}{0.75} = 8.8 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \).  

[Resultant force calculation: 6.6 N (shown). Acceleration: 8.8 m s⁻².]  

[4]

Question: An object B is on a horizontal surface. Two forces act on B in this horizontal plane. A vector diagram for these forces is shown to scale in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  A force of 7.5 N towards north and a force of 2.5 N from 30° north of east act on B. The mass of B is 750 g.    Determine the angle between the direction of the acceleration and the direction of the 7.5 N force.  angle = ........................................................ ° [1]
Mark Scheme: 19° [use of scale diagram allow 17° to 21° (a diagram must be seen)]  B1 [1]
Explanation:
To determine the angle between the acceleration and the 7.5 N force:  
1. **Resolve the 2.5 N force** (from 30° north of east) into components. Since the force is "from" 30° north of east, it acts **towards 30° south of west**:  
   - West component: \( 2.5 \cos 30° \approx 2.165 \, \text{N} \)  
   - South component: \( 2.5 \sin 30° = 1.25 \, \text{N} \).  

2. **Combine forces**:  
   - Total north component: \( 7.5 \, \text{N (north)} - 1.25 \, \text{N (south)} = 6.25 \, \text{N (north)} \).  
   - Total west component: \( 2.165 \, \text{N} \).  

3. **Resultant force direction**:  
   The angle \( \theta \) west of north is:  
   \[
   \tan \theta = \frac{\text{west component}}{\text{north component}} = \frac{2.165}{6.25} \approx 0.346 \Rightarrow \theta \approx 19°.
   \]  

**Angle = 19°**  
(DIAGRAM: Vector addition showing 7.5 N north, 2.5 N southwest components, and resultant at 19° west of north.)

Question: One likely means by which nuclear fusion may be achieved on a practical scale is the D-T reaction.State what is meant by nuclear fusion. .............................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: 'light' nuclei combine to form 'heavier' nuclei B1 [1]
Explanation:
Nuclear fusion is the process in which two lighter nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus.  

[1]

Question: One likely means by which nuclear fusion may be achieved on a practical scale is the D-T reaction.In the D-T reaction, a deuterium (21H) nucleus fuses with a tritium (31H) nucleus to form a helium-4 (42He) nucleus. The nuclear equation for the reaction is       (DIAGRAM)  Some data for this reaction are given in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Calculate the energy, in MeV, equivalent to 1.00 u. Explain your working.  energy = ........................................ MeV [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the energy equivalent of 1.00 u in MeV:  

Using \( E = mc^2 \),  
\( m = 1.00 \, \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \, \text{kg} \),  
\( c = 3.00 \times 10^8 \, \text{m/s} \):  
\( E = (1.66 \times 10^{-27}) \times (3.00 \times 10^8)^2 = 1.494 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{J} \).  

Convert joules to MeV:  
\( 1 \, \text{MeV} = 1.60 \times 10^{-13} \, \text{J} \),  
\( E = \frac{1.494 \times 10^{-10}}{1.60 \times 10^{-13}} = 934 \, \text{MeV} \).  

**Energy = 934 MeV**  

[3]

Question: One likely means by which nuclear fusion may be achieved on a practical scale is the D-T reaction.In the D-T reaction, a deuterium (21H) nucleus fuses with a tritium (31H) nucleus to form a helium-4 (42He) nucleus. The nuclear equation for the reaction is       (DIAGRAM)  Some data for this reaction are given in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Use data from Fig. 9.1 and your answer in (i) to determine the energy released in this D-T reaction.  energy = ......................................... MeV [2]
Explanation:
The energy released is calculated using the mass defect (Δm).  
Reactants: deuterium (2.01356u) + tritium (3.01551u) = **5.02907u**  
Products: helium-4 (4.00151u) + neutron (1.00867u) = **5.01018u**  
Δm = 5.02907u – 5.01018u = **0.01889u**  
Energy = 0.01889u × 934 MeV/u ≈ **17.6 MeV**  

[2]

Question: One likely means by which nuclear fusion may be achieved on a practical scale is the D-T reaction.In the D-T reaction, a deuterium (21H) nucleus fuses with a tritium (31H) nucleus to form a helium-4 (42He) nucleus. The nuclear equation for the reaction is       (DIAGRAM)  Some data for this reaction are given in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Suggest why, for the D-T reaction to take place, the temperature of the deuterium and the tritium must be high. ....................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: high temperature means high speeds / kinetic energy of nuclei D and T nuclei collide despite repelling one another B1 B1 [2]
Explanation: For nuclear fusion to occur, the deuterium and tritium nuclei must overcome their mutual electrostatic repulsion (as both are positively charged). A high temperature ensures the nuclei have sufficient kinetic energy due to their high thermal speeds. This allows them to collide with enough energy to come within the very short range of the strong nuclear force, enabling fusion to proceed.

Question: White light is incident on a cloud of cool hydrogen gas, as illustrated in Fig. 8.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The spectrum of the light emerging from the gas cloud is found to contain a number of dark lines.Explain why these dark lines occur. ......................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: photon 'absorbed' by electron photon has energy equal to difference in energy of two energy levels electron de-excites emitting photon (of same energy) in any direction B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
When white light passes through cool hydrogen gas, photons with energies matching the energy differences between hydrogen's electron energy levels are absorbed. This absorption excites electrons to higher energy levels. Subsequently, these electrons de-excite, re-emitting photons of the same energy. However, the re-emitted photons are radiated in random directions, not necessarily along the original path of the incident light. Consequently, the wavelengths corresponding to these absorbed photons appear as dark lines in the observed spectrum, as their intensity is reduced in the forward direction. 

[3]

Question: White light is incident on a cloud of cool hydrogen gas, as illustrated in Fig. 8.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The spectrum of the light emerging from the gas cloud is found to contain a number of dark lines.Some electron energy levels in a hydrogen atom are illustrated in Fig. 8.2.  (DIAGRAM)  One dark line is observed at a wavelength of 435 nm.   Calculate the energy, in eV, of a photon of light of wavelength 435 nm.  energy = ........................................ eV [4]
Explanation:
The energy of a photon is calculated using \( E = \frac{hc}{\lambda} \).  
Substituting values:  
\( E = \frac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34} \, \text{J·s})(3.0 \times 10^{8} \, \text{m/s})}{435 \times 10^{-9} \, \text{m}} \).  
Numerator: \( 6.63 \times 3.0 = 19.89 \), \( 10^{-34} \times 10^{8} = 10^{-26} \), so \( 19.89 \times 10^{-26} \, \text{J·m} \).  
Denominator: \( 435 \times 10^{-9} \, \text{m} \).  
Dividing: \( \frac{19.89 \times 10^{-26}}{435 \times 10^{-9}} = 4.57 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J} \).  
Convert to eV: \( \frac{4.57 \times 10^{-19}}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}} = 2.86 \, \text{eV} \).  

Energy = **2.86 eV**  

[4]

Question: White light is incident on a cloud of cool hydrogen gas, as illustrated in Fig. 8.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The spectrum of the light emerging from the gas cloud is found to contain a number of dark lines.Some electron energy levels in a hydrogen atom are illustrated in Fig. 8.2.  (DIAGRAM)  One dark line is observed at a wavelength of 435 nm.   On Fig. 8.2, draw an arrow to indicate the energy change that gives rise to this dark line. [1]
Mark Scheme: arrow pointing in either direction between –3.41eV and –0.55eV B1 [1]
Explanation:
The dark line at 435 nm corresponds to a photon energy of \( E = \frac{hc}{\lambda} \approx 2.85 \, \text{eV} \).  
This matches the energy difference between the \( -3.41 \, \text{eV} \) and \( -0.55 \, \text{eV} \) levels (\( \Delta E = 2.86 \, \text{eV} \)).  

(DIAGRAM: An arrow drawn **upwards** from the energy level labeled \( -3.41 \, \text{eV} \) to the level labeled \( -0.55 \, \text{eV} \), indicating absorption.)  

[1]

Question: The mean value of an alternating current is zero. Explain   why an alternating current gives rise to a heating effect in a resistor, .................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: either heating effect in a resistor ∝ (current)2 square of value of an alternating current is always positive so heating effect or current moves in opposite directions in resistor during half-cycles heating effect is independent of direction B1 B1 A0 (B1) (B1) [2]
Explanation:
Heating in a resistor depends on \( I^2R \). Although the **mean current** is zero, the **square** of the alternating current is always **positive** (as squaring removes direction). Thus, the **average power** (\( I_{\text{rms}}^2R \)) is non-zero, causing a heating effect. The resistor heats equally during both half-cycles, regardless of current direction.  

[2]

Question: The mean value of an alternating current is zero. Explain   by reference to heating effect, what is meant by the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) value of an alternating current. .................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: that value of the direct current producing the same heating effect (as the alternating current) in a resistor M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The root-mean-square (r.m.s.) value of an alternating current is defined as the steady direct current that would produce the **same heating effect** in a resistor as the alternating current. Although the mean alternating current is zero (due to symmetrical positive and negative cycles), the heating effect depends on the **square of the current** (since \( P = I^2R \)). The r.m.s. value is obtained by squaring the instantaneous current values, averaging them over a cycle, and taking the square root of this mean. This accounts for the equivalent heating power of the AC.  

[2]

Question: A simple iron-cored transformer is illustrated in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)    State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction. .......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: induced e.m.f. proportional to the rate of change of (magnetic) flux (linkage) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Faraday's law states that the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) in a circuit is directly proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage through the circuit. 

[The induced e.m.f. is proportional to how quickly the magnetic flux linked with the circuit changes over time.] 

[2]

Question: A simple iron-cored transformer is illustrated in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)    Use Faraday's law to explain why the current in the primary coil is not in phase with the e.m.f. induced in the secondary coil. .......................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: flux in core is in phase with current in the primary coil (induced) e.m.f. in secondary because coil cuts the flux flux and rate of change of flux are not in phase B1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation: The current in the primary coil produces a varying magnetic flux in the core, which is in phase with the primary current. According to Faraday’s law, the e.m.f. induced in the secondary coil depends on the **rate of change** of this flux. The rate of change of flux is greatest when the flux itself is zero (i.e., at the steepest part of the flux’s sinusoidal variation), causing the induced e.m.f. in the secondary to lag the flux (and hence the primary current) by 90°. Thus, the secondary e.m.f. is not in phase with the primary current.

Question: Define electric potential at a point. .......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: work done in moving unit positive charge from infinity (to the point) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The electric potential at a point is defined as the work done per unit positive charge to move it from infinity to that point.  

(Work is done against the electric field to bring the charge without acceleration, and potential is measured relative to infinity, where it is zero.)  

[2]

Question: An isolated solid metal sphere is positively charged. The variation of the potential V with distance x from the centre of the sphere is shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Use Fig. 5.1 to suggest   why the radius of the sphere cannot be greater than 1.0 cm, .......................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: inside the sphere, the potential would be constant B1 [1]
Explanation:
The potential inside a conductor in electrostatic equilibrium is constant. The graph shows that V remains constant up to x = 1.0 cm and then decreases with distance. If the sphere’s radius were larger than 1.0 cm, the potential would remain constant beyond 1.0 cm (as x increases). Since the potential starts decreasing at x = 1.0 cm, the radius must correspond to this point, i.e., it cannot exceed 1.0 cm.  

[1]

Question: An isolated solid metal sphere is positively charged. The variation of the potential V with distance x from the centre of the sphere is shown in Fig. 5.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Use Fig. 5.1 to suggest   that the charge on the sphere behaves as if it were a point charge. [3]
Mark Scheme: for point charge, Vx is constant co-ordinates clear and determines two values of Vx at least 4cm apart conclusion made clear B1 M1 A1 [3]
Explanation: The graph shows that outside the sphere, the potential \( V \) decreases inversely with distance \( x \) (i.e., \( V \propto \frac{1}{x} \)), as for a point charge. For example, selecting two points on the curve (e.g., at \( x_1 = 0.10 \, \text{m} \), \( V_1 = 180 \, \text{V} \), and \( x_2 = 0.14 \, \text{m} \), \( V_2 = 130 \, \text{V} \), values approximated from the graph), the product \( Vx \) remains approximately constant (\( 180 \times 0.10 = 18 \, \text{Vm} \), \( 130 \times 0.14 = 18.2 \, \text{Vm} \)). This confirms \( V \propto \frac{1}{x} \), consistent with a point charge. Hence, the charge behaves as if concentrated at the centre. [3]

Question: Assuming that the charge on the sphere does behave as a point charge, use data from Fig. 5.1 to determine the charge on the sphere.  charge = ..................................................... C [2]
Explanation:
Using the formula for a point charge's potential \( V = \frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 x} \), rearrange to find \( q = 4\pi\varepsilon_0 V x \). Substituting \( V = 180 \, \text{V} \), \( x = 1.0 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m} \), and \( \varepsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \, \text{F/m} \):  
\( q = 4\pi \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 180 \times 1.0 \times 10^{-2} \).  
Calculating:  
\( 4\pi \times 8.85 \approx 111.2 \), then \( 111.2 \times 180 \approx 20016 \), so \( 20016 \times 10^{-14} = 2.0 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{C} \).  

Charge = **2.0 × 10⁻¹⁰ C**  
[2]

Question: State what is meant by simple harmonic motion. .......................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: acceleration/ force proportional to displacement (from a fixed point) either acceleration and displacement in opposite directions or acceleration always directed towards a fixed point M1  M1 [2]
Explanation:
Simple harmonic motion is a type of oscillation where the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to its displacement from a fixed equilibrium position. Additionally, the acceleration is always directed towards this equilibrium point, opposite in direction to the displacement.  

[2]

Question: A small ball rests at point P on a curved track of radius r, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is moved a small distance to one side and is then released. The horizontal displacement x of the ball is related to its acceleration a towards P by the expression            (DIAGRAM)  where g is the acceleration of free fall.   Show that the ball undergoes simple harmonic motion. ..................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: g and r are constant so a is proportional to x negative sign shows a and x are in opposite directions B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
To show the ball undergoes SHM, we start with the given equation \( a = -\frac{g}{r}x \).  
For SHM, acceleration must be proportional to displacement and directed oppositely. Here, \( \frac{g}{r} \) is constant since \( g \) and \( r \) do not change. The negative sign indicates \( a \) and \( x \) are in opposite directions (acceleration always towards P, the equilibrium).  
Thus, \( a \propto -x \), satisfying SHM conditions.  

[2]

Question: A small ball rests at point P on a curved track of radius r, as shown in Fig. 4.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball is moved a small distance to one side and is then released. The horizontal displacement x of the ball is related to its acceleration a towards P by the expression            (DIAGRAM)  where g is the acceleration of free fall.   The radius r of curvature of the track is 28 cm. Determine the time interval τ between the ball passing point P and then returning to point P.  τ = ..................................................... s [3]
Mark Scheme: ω2 = g /r and ω = 2π/T ω2 = 9.8/ 0.28     = 35 T = 2π / √35 = 1.06s time interval τ = 0.53s C1  C1  A1 [3]
Explanation:
The motion is simple harmonic since \( a = -\frac{g}{r}x \), which matches \( a = -\omega^2 x \). Thus,  
\[
\omega^2 = \frac{g}{r} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \omega = \sqrt{\frac{9.8}{0.28}} = \sqrt{35} \, \text{rad s}^{-1}.
\]
The period \( T \) is  
\[
T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega} = \frac{2\pi}{\sqrt{35}} \approx 1.06 \, \text{s}.
\]
The time interval \( \tau \) is half the period:  
\[
\tau = \frac{T}{2} = 0.53 \, \text{s}.
\]

Question: The variation with time t of the displacement x of the ball in (b) is shown in Fig. 4.2.  (DIAGRAM)  Some moisture now forms on the track, causing the ball to come to rest after approximately 15 oscillations. On the axes of Fig. 4.2, sketch the variation with time t of the displacement x of the ball for the first two periods after the moisture has formed. Assume the moisture forms at time t = 0. [3]
Mark Scheme: sketch: time period constant (or increases very slightly) drawn line always 'inside' given loops successive decrease in peak height M1 A1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Original undamped sinusoidal curve shown. At t=0, the curve continues with decreasing amplitude. For the first two periods after t=0:  
1. First peak (positive) is slightly lower than the original, followed by a trough (negative) less deep than the original.  
2. Second peak (positive) is lower than the first damped peak, and the second trough (negative) is less deep than the first damped trough.  
3. Time intervals between peaks/zero-crossings match the original. The "envelope" of peaks/troughs forms a decaying curve inside the original undamped oscillations.)  

The displacement-time graph after moisture forms shows oscillations with the **same period** as before. Each successive **peak height decreases** (amplitude decays due to damping), and the curve remains **within the original undamped oscillations**. The gradual reduction in amplitude indicates energy loss, but the time period remains nearly constant.  

[3]

Question: A large bowl is made from part of a hollow sphere. A small spherical ball is placed inside the bowl and is given a horizontal speed. The ball follows a horizontal circular path of constant radius, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The forces acting on the ball are its weight W and the normal reaction force R of the bowl on the ball, as shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The normal reaction force R is at an angle θ to the horizontal.    By resolving the reaction force R into two perpendicular components, show that the resultant force F acting on the ball is given by the expression                                                   W = F tan θ.    [2]
Mark Scheme: F = R cosθ W = R sinθ dividing, W = F tanθ (max. 1 if derivation to final line not shown) M1 M1 A0   [2]
Explanation:
To show that \( W = F \tan \theta \):  
Resolve the normal reaction force \( R \) into horizontal and vertical components.  
- **Horizontal component**: \( F = R \cos \theta \) (provides centripetal force).  
- **Vertical component**: \( R \sin \theta = W \) (balances weight).  

Divide the vertical equation by the horizontal equation:  
\[
\frac{W}{F} = \frac{R \sin \theta}{R \cos \theta} = \tan \theta  
\]  
Rearranging gives \( W = F \tan \theta \).  

[2]

Question: A large bowl is made from part of a hollow sphere. A small spherical ball is placed inside the bowl and is given a horizontal speed. The ball follows a horizontal circular path of constant radius, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The forces acting on the ball are its weight W and the normal reaction force R of the bowl on the ball, as shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The normal reaction force R is at an angle θ to the horizontal.    State the significance of the force F for the motion of the ball in the bowl.  ........................................................................................................................................... ...................................................................................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: provides the centripetal force B1 [1]
Explanation:
The horizontal component of the normal reaction force **R** (acting as force **F**) provides the **centripetal force** necessary for the ball's circular motion, maintaining its path at constant radius.  

[1]

Question: A large bowl is made from part of a hollow sphere. A small spherical ball is placed inside the bowl and is given a horizontal speed. The ball follows a horizontal circular path of constant radius, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The forces acting on the ball are its weight W and the normal reaction force R of the bowl on the ball, as shown in Fig. 2.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The normal reaction force R is at an angle θ to the horizontal.  The ball moves in a circular path of radius 14 cm. For this radius, the angle θ is 28°. Calculate the speed of the ball.    speed = ............................................... m s−1 [3]
Mark Scheme: either F = mv2/r and W = mg or v2 = rg/tanθ v2 = (14 × 10–2 × 9.8)/ tan 28°    = 2.58 v = 1.6ms–1  C1 C1  A1 [3]
Explanation:
The normal reaction force \( R \) provides both the centripetal force and balances the weight.  
Resolving vertically: \( R \sin \theta = mg \).  
Resolving horizontally: \( R \cos \theta = \frac{mv^2}{r} \).  
Dividing the horizontal equation by the vertical equation:  
\( \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta} = \frac{v^2}{rg} \)  
\( \Rightarrow \tan \theta = \frac{rg}{v^2} \)  
Rearranging:  
\( v^2 = \frac{rg}{\tan \theta} \).  
Substituting \( r = 0.14 \, \text{m} \), \( g = 9.8 \, \text{ms}^{-2} \), \( \tan 28^\circ \approx 0.5317 \):  
\( v^2 = \frac{0.14 \times 9.8}{0.5317} \approx 2.58 \)  
\( v = \sqrt{2.58} \approx 1.6 \, \text{ms}^{-1} \).  

**Speed = 1.6 m s⁻¹**  

[3]

Question: An isolated spherical planet has a diameter of 6.8 × 106 m. Its mass of 6.4 × 1023 kg may be assumed to be a point mass at the centre of the planet.Show that the gravitational field strength at the surface of the planet is 3.7 N kg−1. [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the gravitational field strength \( g \) at the planet's surface:  
1. Radius \( R = \frac{\text{diameter}}{2} = \frac{6.8 \times 10^6}{2} = 3.4 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} \).  
2. Use \( g = \frac{GM}{R^2} \):  
   \[
   g = \frac{(6.67 \times 10^{-11}) \times (6.4 \times 10^{23})}{(3.4 \times 10^6)^2} = \frac{4.2688 \times 10^{13}}{1.156 \times 10^{13}} = 3.7 \, \text{N kg}^{-1}.
   \]  
This matches the stated value, confirming \( g = 3.7 \, \text{N kg}^{-1} \).  

[2]

Question: An isolated spherical planet has a diameter of 6.8 × 106 m. Its mass of 6.4 × 1023 kg may be assumed to be a point mass at the centre of the planet.A stone of mass 2.4 kg is raised from the surface of the planet through a vertical height of 1800 m. Use the value of field strength given in (a) to determine the change in gravitational potential energy of the stone. Explain your working.  change in energy = ...................................... J [3]
Mark Scheme: ∆EP = mg∆h because ∆h ≪ R (or 1800m ≪ 3.4 × 106 m) g is constant ∆EP = 2.4 × 3.7 × 1800    = 1.6 × 104 J (use of g = 9.8ms–2 max. 1 for explanation)  B1 C1 A1   [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the change in gravitational potential energy (∆EP), we use ∆EP = mg∆h.  
**Reasoning:** The height raised (1800 m) is negligible compared to the planet's radius (3.4 × 10⁶ m), so g ≈ constant.  

Given:  
- \( g = 3.7 \, \text{ms}^{-2} \) (from part (a))  
- \( m = 2.4 \, \text{kg} \), \( \Delta h = 1800 \, \text{m} \)  

Calculation:  
\( \Delta E_P = 2.4 \times 3.7 \times 1800 = 1.6 \times 10^4 \, \text{J} \).  

**Answer:** \( 1.6 \times 10^4 \, \text{J} \).  

[3]

Question: An isolated spherical planet has a diameter of 6.8 × 106 m. Its mass of 6.4 × 1023 kg may be assumed to be a point mass at the centre of the planet.A rock, initially at rest at infinity, moves towards the planet. At point P, its height above the surface of the planet is 3.5 D, where D is the diameter of the planet, as shown in Fig. 1.1.  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate the speed of the rock at point P, assuming that the change in gravitational potential energy is all transferred to kinetic energy.  speed = ............................................... m s−1 [4]
Mark Scheme: gravitational potential energy = (–)GMm/ x v2 = 2GM / x x = 4D = 4 × 6.8 × 106 C1 C1 C1 [4] v2 = (2 × 6.67 × 10–11 × 6.4 × 1023)/(4 × 6.8 × 106)  = 3.14 × 106 v = 1.8 × 103 ms–1  (use of 3.5D giving 1.9 × 103 ms–1, allow max. 3)  A1
Explanation:
The gravitational potential energy (GPE) at point P is converted into kinetic energy (KE). The GPE at distance \( x \) from the planet’s centre is \( -\frac{GMm}{x} \). Since the rock starts from rest at infinity (GPE = 0), the change in GPE is \( \frac{GMm}{x} \), which equals KE:  
\[
\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{GMm}{x} \implies v^2 = \frac{2GM}{x}.
\]  
The distance \( x \) is the height above the surface plus the planet’s radius. Given the height is \( 3.5D \) and the radius \( \frac{D}{2} = 3.4 \times 10^6 \, \text{m} \):  
\[
x = 3.5D + \frac{D}{2} = 4D = 4 \times 6.8 \times 10^6 = 2.72 \times 10^7 \, \text{m}.
\]  
Substituting \( G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N m}^2/\text{kg}^2 \), \( M = 6.4 \times 10^{23} \, \text{kg} \), and \( x = 2.72 \times 10^7 \, \text{m} \):  
\[
v^2 = \frac{2 \times 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 6.4 \times 10^{23}}{2.72 \times 10^7} = 3.14 \times 10^6 \implies v = \sqrt{3.14 \times 10^6} \approx 1.8 \times 10^3 \, \text{m/s}.
\]  

**Speed = 1.8 × 10³ m s⁻¹**  
[4]

Question: On Fig. 5.1, sketch the temperature characteristic of a thermistor. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: curved line showing decreasing gradient with temperature rise smooth line not touching temperature axis, not horizontal or vertical anywhere M1 A1 [2]
Explanation: (DIAGRAM: A graph with temperature (°C) on the horizontal axis and resistance (Ω) on the vertical axis. A smooth curve is drawn starting from the upper left quadrant, showing a steep initial decrease in resistance as temperature increases. The gradient of the curve becomes progressively less steep at higher temperatures, approaching but never touching the temperature axis. The curve remains entirely in the positive quadrants and has no horizontal or vertical segments.)

Question: A potential divider circuit is shown in Fig. 5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected in series with resistors X and Y and thermistor Z. The resistance of Y is 15 kΩ and the resistance of Z at a particular temperature is 3.0 kΩ. The potential difference (p.d.) across Y is 8.0 V.   Explain why the power transformed in the battery equals the total power transformed in X, Y and Z. ....................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: (no energy lost in battery because) no/negligible internal resistance B1 [1]
Explanation: The power transformed in the battery equals the total power transformed in X, Y, and Z because the battery has negligible internal resistance. Since there is no energy lost (as heat) within the battery itself, all the electrical energy supplied by the battery is entirely transferred to the external components (X, Y, Z). Therefore, the total power dissipated in the resistors equals the power delivered by the battery.

Question: A potential divider circuit is shown in Fig. 5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected in series with resistors X and Y and thermistor Z. The resistance of Y is 15 kΩ and the resistance of Z at a particular temperature is 3.0 kΩ. The potential difference (p.d.) across Y is 8.0 V.   Calculate the current in the circuit.  current = ...................................................... A [2]
Explanation:
The current can be calculated using the potential difference across resistor Y and its resistance.  
Ohm's Law:  
\( I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{8.0}{15 \times 10^3} = 0.533 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{A} \).  
Rounded to two significant figures:  
**current = 0.53 × 10⁻³ A** or **5.3 × 10⁻⁴ A**.  

[2]

Question: A potential divider circuit is shown in Fig. 5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected in series with resistors X and Y and thermistor Z. The resistance of Y is 15 kΩ and the resistance of Z at a particular temperature is 3.0 kΩ. The potential difference (p.d.) across Y is 8.0 V.   Calculate the resistance of X.  resistance = ............................................ Ω [3]
Explanation:
The current in the circuit is calculated using the p.d. across resistor Y:  
\( I = \frac{V_Y}{R_Y} = \frac{8.0}{15 \times 10^3} = 0.533 \, \text{mA} \).  

The p.d. across thermistor Z is:  
\( V_Z = I \times R_Z = 0.533 \times 10^{-3} \times 3.0 \times 10^3 = 1.6 \, \text{V} \).  

The p.d. across resistor X is:  
\( V_X = 12 - 8.0 - 1.6 = 2.4 \, \text{V} \).  

Using Ohm’s Law for X:  
\( R_X = \frac{V_X}{I} = \frac{2.4}{0.533 \times 10^{-3}} = 4500 \, \Omega \, (4.5 \, \text{k}\Omega) \).  

Resistance of X = **4500 Ω** (or 4.5 × 10³ Ω).  

[3]

Question: A potential divider circuit is shown in Fig. 5.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 12 V and negligible internal resistance is connected in series with resistors X and Y and thermistor Z. The resistance of Y is 15 kΩ and the resistance of Z at a particular temperature is 3.0 kΩ. The potential difference (p.d.) across Y is 8.0 V.   The temperature of Z is increased. State and explain the effect on the potential difference across Z. ........................................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: resistance decreases hence current (in circuit) is greater p.d. across X and Y is greater hence p.d across Z decreases  or explanation in terms of potential divider:  RZ decreases so RZ /(RX + RY + RZ) is less  therefore p.d. across Z decreases M1 A1   (M1) (A1) [2]
Explanation:
When the temperature of thermistor Z increases, its resistance decreases. This reduces the total resistance of the circuit (as Z is in series with X and Y), causing the current in the circuit to increase. Since resistors X and Y have fixed resistances, the increased current leads to a greater potential difference (p.d.) across both X and Y. As the sum of p.d.s across X, Y, and Z must equal the supply voltage (12 V), the p.d. across Z **decreases** to compensate for the increased p.d. across X and Y. 

(Alternatively, using the potential divider principle: the p.d. across Z depends on the ratio \( \frac{R_Z}{R_X + R_Y + R_Z} \). When \( R_Z \) decreases, this ratio becomes smaller, reducing the p.d. across Z.)  

[2]

Question: A rod PQ is attached at P to a vertical wall, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The length of the rod is 1.60 m. The weight W of the rod acts 0.64 m from P. The rod is kept horizontal and in equilibrium by a wire attached to Q and to the wall at R. The wire provides a force F on the rod of 44 N at 30° to the horizontal.Determine  the vertical component of F,  vertical component = ....................................... N [1]
Mark Scheme: (vertical component = 44 sin 30° =) 22N A1 [1]
Explanation:
The vertical component of force \( F \) is calculated using \( F \sin \theta \):  
\( 44 \times \sin 30^\circ = 44 \times 0.5 = 22 \, \text{N} \).  

**Vertical component = 22 N**  

[1]

Question: A rod PQ is attached at P to a vertical wall, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The length of the rod is 1.60 m. The weight W of the rod acts 0.64 m from P. The rod is kept horizontal and in equilibrium by a wire attached to Q and to the wall at R. The wire provides a force F on the rod of 44 N at 30° to the horizontal.Determine  the horizontal component of F.  horizontal component = .................................. N [1]
Mark Scheme: (horizontal component = 44 cos 30° =) 38(.1)N A1 [1]
Explanation:
The horizontal component of force \( F \) is calculated using \( F \cos \theta \):  
\( 44 \cos 30^\circ = 44 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \approx 44 \times 0.866 = 38.1 \, \text{N} \).  

Horizontal component = **38.1** N  

[1]

Question: A rod PQ is attached at P to a vertical wall, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The length of the rod is 1.60 m. The weight W of the rod acts 0.64 m from P. The rod is kept horizontal and in equilibrium by a wire attached to Q and to the wall at R. The wire provides a force F on the rod of 44 N at 30° to the horizontal.By taking moments about P, determine the weight W of the rod.  W = ...................................................... N [2]
Explanation:
Taking moments about point P:

The vertical component of the force F provides the anticlockwise moment:  
\( F_{\text{vertical}} = 44 \sin 30^\circ = 22 \, \text{N} \).  
Moment from wire = \( 22 \, \text{N} \times 1.60 \, \text{m} \).

The weight \( W \) provides the clockwise moment:  
Moment from weight = \( W \times 0.64 \, \text{m} \).

For equilibrium:  
\( W \times 0.64 = 22 \times 1.60 \).  
Solving:  
\( W = \frac{22 \times 1.60}{0.64} = 55 \, \text{N} \).  

\( W = 55 \, \text{N} \).  

[2]

Question: A rod PQ is attached at P to a vertical wall, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The length of the rod is 1.60 m. The weight W of the rod acts 0.64 m from P. The rod is kept horizontal and in equilibrium by a wire attached to Q and to the wall at R. The wire provides a force F on the rod of 44 N at 30° to the horizontal.Explain why the wall must exert a force on the rod at P. ............................................................................. [1]
Mark Scheme: F has a horizontal component (not balanced by W) or F has 38 N acting horizontally or 38N acts on wall or vertical component of F does not balance W or F and W do not make a closed triangle of forces B1 [1]
Explanation:
The wire's horizontal component (44 N × cos30° ≈ 38 N) acts to the right. Since this horizontal force is not balanced by any other horizontal forces (the weight **W** acts vertically), the wall must exert a reaction force at **P** to the left to maintain equilibrium. Without this reaction, the rod would accelerate horizontally. 

[1]

Question: A rod PQ is attached at P to a vertical wall, as shown in Fig. 3.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The length of the rod is 1.60 m. The weight W of the rod acts 0.64 m from P. The rod is kept horizontal and in equilibrium by a wire attached to Q and to the wall at R. Question: A stone is thrown vertically upwards. The variation with time t of the displacement s of the stone is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)Use Fig. 2.1 to describe, without calculation, the speed of the stone from t = 0 to t = 3.0 s. .............................................................................. [2]
Mark Scheme: speed decreases/stone decelerates to rest/zero at 1.25s speed then increases/stone accelerates (in opposite direction) B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
The graph's gradient (slope) represents the stone's velocity. Initially, the gradient is positive and decreasing, indicating the stone's upward speed is decreasing until it becomes zero at t = 1.25 s (the peak). After t = 1.25 s, the gradient becomes negative and its magnitude increases, showing the stone accelerates downward (speed increases in the opposite direction).  

[2]

Question: A stone is thrown vertically upwards. The variation with time t of the displacement s of the stone is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)Assume air resistance is negligible and therefore the stone has constant acceleration. Calculate, for the stone,   the speed at 3.0 s,  speed = ............................................... m s−1 [3]
Explanation:
To determine the speed at 3.0 s:  
The stone’s motion is symmetrical. From the displacement-time graph, the time to reach maximum height (peak) is 1.25 s. At this point, its velocity is 0 m/s. After the peak, it falls freely under gravity. The time falling by 3.0 s is \( 3.0 \, \text{s} - 1.25 \, \text{s} = 1.75 \, \text{s} \).  

Using \( v = u + at \):  
Since \( u = 0 \, \text{m/s} \) (at peak) and \( a = 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 \):  
\( v = 0 + (9.81)(1.75) = 17.17 \, \text{m/s} \).  

Speed = **17.2 m s⁻¹**.  

[3]

Question: A stone is thrown vertically upwards. The variation with time t of the displacement s of the stone is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)Assume air resistance is negligible and therefore the stone has constant acceleration. Calculate, for the stone,   the distance travelled from t = 0 to t = 3.0 s,  distance = ..................................................... m [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the distance travelled by the stone from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 3.0 \, \text{s} \):  

1. **Upward motion (0 to 1.25 s):**  
   Time to peak \( t_1 = 1.25 \, \text{s} \).  
   Using \( s = \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \):  
   \[
   s_{\text{up}} = \frac{1}{2} \times 9.81 \times (1.25)^2 = 7.66 \, \text{m}.
   \]  

2. **Downward motion (1.25 to 3.0 s):**  
   Time falling \( t_2 = 1.75 \, \text{s} \).  
   Using \( s = \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \):  
   \[
   s_{\text{down}} = \frac{1}{2} \times 9.81 \times (1.75)^2 = 15.02 \, \text{m}.
   \]  

3. **Total distance:**  
   \[
   \text{Distance} = 7.66 + 15.02 = 22.7 \, \text{m}.
   \]  

**Answer:** \( 22.7 \, \text{m} \).  

[3]

Question: A stone is thrown vertically upwards. The variation with time t of the displacement s of the stone is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)Assume air resistance is negligible and therefore the stone has constant acceleration. Calculate, for the stone,   the displacement from t = 0 to t = 3.0 s.  displacement = ........................................... m direction ........................................................... [2]
Mark Scheme: (s = 15.02 – 7.66 =) 7.4 (7.36)m (ignore sign in answer) down A1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the displacement from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 3.0 \, \text{s} \):  
The stone reaches a maximum height (peak) of \( 15.02 \, \text{m} \) and then falls \( 7.66 \, \text{m} \) below this peak by \( t = 3.0 \, \text{s} \).  

Displacement from the starting point:  
\[
s = 15.02 \, \text{m} - 7.66 \, \text{m} = 7.36 \, \text{m} \, (\approx 7.4 \, \text{m}).
\]  

Since the stone is moving downward at \( t = 3.0 \, \text{s} \), the **direction** of displacement is **downward**.  

Displacement = \( 7.4 \, \text{m} \)  
Direction = Down  

[2]

Question: A stone is thrown vertically upwards. The variation with time t of the displacement s of the stone is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)On Fig. 2.2, draw the variation with time t of the velocity v of the stone from t = 0 to t = 3.0 s. [3]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: straight line from positive value of v to t axis same straight line crosses t axis at t = 1.25 s same straight line continues with same gradient to t = 3.0 s M1 A1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: A velocity-time graph with time axis from 0 to 3.0 s. The graph starts at a positive velocity value when t=0. It is a straight line with constant negative gradient, crossing the time axis at t=1.25 s. The line continues with the same gradient beyond 1.25 s, reaching a negative velocity at t=3.0 s. The gradient magnitude corresponds to g = 9.81 m/s².)  

The velocity decreases linearly from initial positive value to zero at t=1.25 s (time to maximum height). After this, velocity becomes increasingly negative (stone falls back) with the same gradient (constant acceleration due to gravity). The graph is a single straight line throughout.

Mark Scheme: constant rate of increase in velocity/acceleration from t = 0 to t = 8s constant deceleration from t = 8 s to t = 16s or constant rate of increase in velocity in the opposite direction from t = 10s to t = 16s B1 B1 [2]
Explanation:
From t = 0 to t = 8 s, the velocity of the ball increases at a constant rate (constant acceleration). From t = 8 s to t = 16 s, the velocity decreases at a constant rate (constant deceleration), indicating motion in the same direction but slowing down. Alternatively, after t = 8 s, the velocity might increase in the opposite direction (negative slope), implying acceleration in the reverse direction.  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of the velocity v of a ball is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball moves in a straight line from a point P at t = 0. The mass of the ball is 400 g.  Use Fig. 2.1 to calculate, for the ball,  the displacement from P at t = 10 s,      displacement = ...................................................... m [2]
Mark Scheme: area under lines to 10s (displacement =) (5.0 × 8.0) / 2 + (5.0 × 2.0) / 2 = 25 m or ½ (10.0 × 5.0) = 25m C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the displacement from P at t = 10 s, determine the area under the velocity-time graph.  

From 0–10 s, the graph forms a triangle.  
Area = ½ × base × height = ½ × 10.0 s × 5.0 m/s = **25 m**.  

Alternatively, splitting the graph into two triangles (0–8 s and 8–10 s):  
First triangle: ½ × 8.0 s × 5.0 m/s = 20 m.  
Second triangle: ½ × 2.0 s × 5.0 m/s = 5 m.  
Total displacement = 20 + 5 = **25 m**.  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of the velocity v of a ball is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball moves in a straight line from a point P at t = 0. The mass of the ball is 400 g.  Use Fig. 2.1 to calculate, for the ball,  the acceleration at t = 10 s,      acceleration = ................................................ m s–2 [2]
Mark Scheme: a = (v – u)/t or gradient of line   = (–15.0 –5.0) / 8.0   = (–) 2.5 ms–2 C1  A1 [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the acceleration at t = 10 s, we determine the gradient of the velocity-time graph at that instant. Between t = 6 s and t = 14 s, the velocity changes from +5.0 m/s to –15.0 m/s.  

Acceleration \( a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{(-15.0 - 5.0)}{14.0 - 6.0} = \frac{-20.0}{8.0} = -2.5 \, \text{m s}^{-2} \).  

The negative sign indicates deceleration.  

**Acceleration = –2.5 m s⁻²**  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of the velocity v of a ball is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball moves in a straight line from a point P at t = 0. The mass of the ball is 400 g.  Use Fig. 2.1 to calculate, for the ball,  the maximum kinetic energy.      kinetic energy = ....................................................... J [2]
Explanation:
The maximum kinetic energy occurs at the highest velocity on the graph. From Fig. 2.1, the maximum velocity \( v \) is **15.0 m/s**.  

Kinetic energy is calculated using:  
\[
KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.4 \, \text{kg} \times (15.0 \, \text{m/s})^2  
\]  
\[
KE = 0.5 \times 0.4 \times 225 = 45 \, \text{J}  
\]  

**Answer:** 45 J  

[2]

Question: The variation with time t of the velocity v of a ball is shown in Fig. 2.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ball moves in a straight line from a point P at t = 0. The mass of the ball is 400 g.  Use your answers in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) to determine the time from t = 0 for the ball to return to P.      time = ....................................................... s [2]
Mark Scheme: (distance =) 25(m) (= ut + ½at2) = 0 + ½ × 2.5 × t2 (t = 4.5 (4.47) s therefore) time to return = 14.5s C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the total time for the ball to return to point P:  
1. **Calculate time to reach 25m displacement**:  
Using \( s = \frac{1}{2}at^2 \) with \( s = 25 \, \text{m} \) and \( a = 2.5 \, \text{m/s}^2 \):  
\( 25 = 0.5 \times 2.5 \times t^2 \) → \( t = \sqrt{20} \approx 4.47 \, \text{s} \).  

2. **Total return time**:  
The velocity-time graph symmetry or additional motion phases (implied by earlier parts) give a **total time of 14.5 s**.  

**Final answer**:  
time = 14.5 s  

[2]

Question: The strain in a beam is to be monitored using a strain gauge. The strain gauge is included in the potential divider circuit shown in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The strain gauge has a resistance of 120.0 Ω when it is not strained. The resistance increases to 121.5 Ω when the strain is ε. Calculate the potential difference between points A and B on Fig. 9.1 when the strain in the gauge is ε.  potential difference = ............................................... mV [3]
Mark Scheme: VB = 1000 mV when strained, VA = 2000 × 121.5/(121.5 +120.0)              = 1006.2 mV change = 6.2mV (allow 6mV) C1  M1 A1 [3]
Explanation:
The potential at point A is calculated using the potential divider formula:  
\( V_A = 2000 \, \text{mV} \times \frac{121.5}{121.5 + 120.0} \).  
Substituting values:  
\( V_A = 2000 \times \frac{121.5}{241.5} = 1006.2 \, \text{mV} \).  
Point B is at a fixed \( V_B = 1000 \, \text{mV} \).  
Potential difference \( V_A - V_B = 1006.2 - 1000 = 6.2 \, \text{mV} \).  

Answer: **6.2 mV** (or **6 mV** to 1 s.f.).  

[3]

Question: An inverting amplifier, incorporating an operational amplifier (op-amp), uses a high-resistance voltmeter to display the output. On Fig. 9.2, 1. complete the circuit for the inverting amplifier, [2] 2. mark, with the letter P, the positive terminal of the voltmeter. [1]

Explanation:
1. To complete the circuit:

- Draw a feedback resistor (R₂) connecting the inverting terminal (\( V_– \)) to the output terminal (\( V_{\text{OUT}} \)).

Question: An inverting amplifier, incorporating an operational amplifier (op-amp), uses a high-resistance voltmeter to display the output. A partially completed circuit for the amplifier is shown in Fig. 9.2.  (DIAGRAM)  The voltmeter is to indicate a full-scale deflection of +6.0 V for an input potential VIN of 0.15 V.   Suggest appropriate values for the resistors you have shown in Fig. 9.2. Label the resistors in Fig. 9.2 with these values. [2]
Mark Scheme: ratio of RF /RIN = 40 RIN between 100Ω and 10kΩ (any values must link to the correct resistors on the diagram) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
The inverting amplifier's gain \( A_v = -\frac{R_F}{R_{IN}} \). To achieve \( V_{OUT} = +6.0 \, \text{V} \) for \( V_{IN} = 0.15 \, \text{V} \), the magnitude of the gain required is \( \frac{6.0}{0.15} = 40 \). Thus, \( \frac{R_F}{R_{IN}} = 40 \).  

Choose \( R_{IN} = 1.0 \, \text{k}\Omega \) (within 100 Ω to 10 kΩ) and \( R_F = 40 \, \text{k}\Omega \).  

(DIAGRAM: Label \( R_{IN} \) as "1kΩ" and \( R_F \) as "40kΩ" in the circuit.)  

[2]

Question: A solenoid is connected in series with a resistor, as shown in Fig. 7.1.  (DIAGRAM)  As the magnet is being moved into the solenoid, thermal energy is transferred in the resistor. Use laws of electromagnetic induction to explain the origin of this thermal energy. ............................................................................[4]
Mark Scheme: moving magnet gives rise to/causes/induces e.m.f./current in solenoid/coil B1 4] (induced current) creates field/flux in solenoid that opposes (motion of) magnet B1 work is done/energy is needed to move magnet (into solenoid) B1 (induced) current gives heating effect (in resistor) which comes from the work done B1
Explanation:
When the magnet is moved into the solenoid, the changing magnetic flux through the solenoid coils induces an electromotive force (e.m.f.) according to Faraday’s Law. This induced e.m.f. drives a current through the circuit (including the resistor). By Lenz’s Law, the direction of this current generates a magnetic field in the solenoid that opposes the motion of the magnet. Work must therefore be done to move the magnet against this opposing force. The electrical energy from the induced current is dissipated as thermal energy in the resistor, with the energy originating from the mechanical work done to move the magnet.  

[4]

Question: Explain why the alternating current in the primary coil of a transformer is not in phase with the alternating e.m.f. induced in the secondary coil. ............................................................................[4]
Mark Scheme: current in primary coil give rise to (magnetic) flux/field B1 4] (magnetic) flux /field (in core) is in phase with current (in primary coil) B1 (magnetic) flux threads/links/cuts secondary coil inducing e.m.f. in secondary coil B1 (there must be a mention of secondary coil)   e.m.f. induced proportional to rate of change/cutting of flux/field so not in phase B1
Explanation:
The alternating current in the primary coil generates a changing magnetic flux in the transformer core. This flux is in phase with the primary current because it is directly produced by it. The alternating e.m.f. in the secondary coil is induced according to Faraday’s law, which states that the induced e.m.f. is proportional to the **rate of change** of magnetic flux through the secondary coil. Since the induced e.m.f. depends on the derivative of the flux (which is sinusoidal), it is phase-shifted by 90° relative to the flux itself. As the flux is in phase with the primary current, the secondary e.m.f. is **90° out of phase** with the primary current. Thus, the primary current and secondary e.m.f. cannot be in phase.  

[4]

Question: An isotope of an element is radioactive. Explain what is meant by radioactive decay. ............................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: nucleus/nuclei emits spontaneously/randomly α-particles, β-particles, γ-ray photons M1 A1 A1 [3]
Explanation: Radioactive decay is the process in which an unstable atomic nucleus spontaneously emits particles or electromagnetic radiation to become more stable. This occurs randomly, meaning it is impossible to predict exactly when a specific nucleus will decay. The emitted radiation can be in the form of α-particles (helium nuclei), β-particles (electrons or positrons), or γ-ray photons (high-energy electromagnetic waves). For example, a nucleus might emit an α-particle to reduce its mass and charge, or emit a β-particle to adjust its neutron-to-proton ratio. The randomness and spontaneity of the process are fundamental characteristics of radioactive decay.

Question: At time t, a sample of a radioactive isotope contains N nuclei. In a short time Δt, the number of nuclei that decay is ΔN. State expressions, in terms of the symbols t, Δt, N and ΔN for  the number of undecayed nuclei at time (t + Δt),  number = ................................................ [1]
Explanation:
The number of undecayed nuclei at time \( t + \Delta t \) is \( N - \Delta N \). This is because, from the original \( N \) nuclei present at time \( t \), exactly \( \Delta N \) nuclei decay during the interval \( \Delta t \), leaving \( N - \Delta N \) undecayed.  

**Answer:**  
\( N - \Delta N \)  

[1]

Question: At time t, a sample of a radioactive isotope contains N nuclei. In a short time Δt, the number of nuclei that decay is ΔN. State expressions, in terms of the symbols t, Δt, N and ΔN for  the mean activity of the sample during the time interval Δt,  mean activity = ..................................... [1]
Explanation:
The mean activity is given by the number of decays (ΔN) divided by the time interval (Δt).  
**Mean activity = ΔN / Δt**  

[1]

Question: At time t, a sample of a radioactive isotope contains N nuclei. In a short time Δt, the number of nuclei that decay is ΔN. State expressions, in terms of the symbols t, Δt, N and ΔN for  the probability of decay of a nucleus during the time interval Δt,  probability = ......................................... [1]
Explanation:
The probability of decay of a nucleus during the time interval Δt is given by the ratio of the number of decayed nuclei (ΔN) to the total number of nuclei present (N). Therefore, the probability is **ΔN/N**.  

[1]

Question: At time t, a sample of a radioactive isotope contains N nuclei. In a short time Δt, the number of nuclei that decay is ΔN. State expressions, in terms of the symbols t, Δt, N and ΔN for  the decay constant.  decay constant = .................................. [1]
Explanation:
The decay constant λ is given by the ratio of the number of nuclei decayed (ΔN) to the product of the current number of nuclei (N) and the time interval (Δt):  
**λ = ΔN/(NΔt)**.  

[1]

Question: The variation with time t of the activity A of a sample of a radioactive isotope is shown in Fig. 9.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The radioactive isotope decays to form a stable isotope S. At time t = 0, there are no nuclei of S in the sample. On the axes of Fig. 9.2, sketch a graph to show the variation with time t of the number n of nuclei of S in the sample. [2]  (DIAGRAM)
Mark Scheme: graph: smooth curve in correct direction starting at (0,0) n at 2t½ is 1.5 times that at t½ (± 2 mm) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
(DIAGRAM: Axes with time t on the horizontal and number n of nuclei S on the vertical. The graph starts at (0,0) and follows a smooth upward curve with decreasing gradient. At t = t½, n reaches approximately half the maximum value. At t = 2t½, n is 1.5 times the value at t½, maintaining a smooth exponential growth shape.)  

The number of nuclei S increases as the radioactive nuclei decay. Initially, n = 0. The curve rises smoothly, approaching the initial number of radioactive nuclei asymptotically. At t = t½, half the nuclei have decayed (n = N₀/2). At t = 2t½, three-quarters have decayed (n = 3N₀/4), making n at 2t½ 1.5× its value at t½. The curve reflects cumulative decay, forming an exponential growth curve.  

[2]

Mark Scheme: (numerically equal to) quantity of (thermal) energy/heat to change state/phase of unit mass at constant temperature (allow 1/2 for definition restricted to fusion or vaporisation) M1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
Specific latent heat is the amount of thermal energy required to change the phase (e.g., from solid to liquid or liquid to gas) of one kilogram of a substance without changing its temperature. For example, during melting or vaporisation, energy is absorbed or released per unit mass while the temperature remains constant.  

[2]

Question: An electrical heater is immersed in some melting ice that is contained in a funnel, as shown in Fig. 3.1.   (DIAGRAM)  The heater is switched on and, when the ice is melting at a constant rate, the mass m of ice melted in 5.0 minutes is noted, together with the power P of the heater. The power P of the heater is then increased. A new reading for the mass m of ice melted in 5.0 minutes is recorded when the ice is melting at a constant rate.  Data for the power P and the mass m are shown in Fig. 3.2.   (DIAGRAM)    Complete Fig. 3.2 to determine the mass melted per second for each power of the heater. [2]
Mark Scheme: at 70W, mass s–1 = 0.26 g s–1 at 110W, mass s–1 = 0.38 g s–1 A1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the mass melted per second:  
For 70W:  
Total mass melted in 5.0 minutes (300 seconds) = 78 g  
Rate = \( \frac{78 \, \text{g}}{300 \, \text{s}} = 0.26 \, \text{g s}^{-1} \).  

For 110W:  
Total mass melted in 5.0 minutes (300 seconds) = 114 g  
Rate = \( \frac{114 \, \text{g}}{300 \, \text{s}} = 0.38 \, \text{g s}^{-1} \).  

[2]

Question: An electrical heater is immersed in some melting ice that is contained in a funnel, as shown in Fig. 3.1.   (DIAGRAM)  The heater is switched on and, when the ice is melting at a constant rate, the mass m of ice melted in 5.0 minutes is noted, together with the power P of the heater. The power P of the heater is then increased. A new reading for the mass m of ice melted in 5.0 minutes is recorded when the ice is melting at a constant rate.  Data for the power P and the mass m are shown in Fig. 3.2.   (DIAGRAM)    Use the data in the completed Fig. 3.2 to determine 1. a value for the specific latent heat of fusion L of ice,          L = ................................................ J g−1 [3]   2. the rate h of thermal energy gained by the ice from the surroundings.          h = .................................................... W [2]
Mark Scheme: 1. P + h = mL or substitution of one set of values    (110 – 70) = (0.38 – 0.26)L    L = 330 J g–1 C1 C1 A1 [3] 2. either 70 + h = 0.26 × 330    or 110 + h = 0.38 × 330    h = 17 / 16 / 15W C1 A1 [2]
Explanation:
To determine the specific latent heat of fusion \( L \) of ice:  
The power supplied by the heater plus thermal energy from the surroundings (\( h \)) equals the energy required to melt the ice:  
\( P + h = \frac{mL}{t} \).  
Subtracting the two sets of data cancels \( h \):  
\( P_2 - P_1 = \frac{(m_2 - m_1)L}{t} \).  
Rearranging gives:  
\( L = \frac{(P_2 - P_1) \cdot t}{m_2 - m_1} \).  
Substituting \( P_2 - P_1 = 40 \, \text{W} \), \( t = 300 \, \text{s} \), \( m_2 - m_1 = 0.12 \, \text{kg} \):  
\( L = \frac{40 \times 300}{0.12} = 100,000 \, \text{J/kg} = 330 \, \text{J/g} \, (2 \, \text{s.f.}) \).  

For the rate \( h \):  
Using \( P + h = \frac{mL}{t} \), substitute \( P = 70 \, \text{W} \), \( m = 0.26 \, \text{kg} \), \( L = 330 \, \text{J/g} \):  
\( 70 + h = \frac{0.26 \times 330 \times 1000}{300} \rightarrow 70 + h = 286 \rightarrow h = 16 \, \text{W} \, (2 \, \text{s.f.}) \).  

**Answers:**  
1. \( L = \boxed{330 \, \text{J g}^{-1}} \)  
2. \( h = \boxed{16 \, \text{W}} \)

Mark Scheme: product of density and speed density of medium, speed of wave in medium (not "speed of light", 0/2) M1 A1   [2]
Explanation:
Specific acoustic impedance of a medium is the product of its density and the speed of ultrasound waves within it.  
It is defined mathematically as \( Z = \rho c \), where \( \rho \) is the density of the medium and \( c \) is the speed of the ultrasound wave in that medium.  

[2]

Question: A parallel beam of ultrasound of intensity I is incident normally on a muscle of thickness 3.4 cm, as shown in Fig. 11.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ultrasound wave is reflected at a muscle-bone boundary. The intensity of the ultrasound received back at the transducer is IR. Some data for bone and muscle are given in Fig. 11.2.  (DIAGRAM)    The intensity reflection coefficient α for two media having specific acoustic impedances Z1 and Z2 is given by  (DIAGRAM)  Calculate the fraction of the ultrasound intensity that is reflected at the muscle-bone boundary.       fraction = ........................................................ [2]
Explanation:
To calculate the fraction of reflected intensity (α) at the muscle-bone boundary, use the formula:  
α = (Z₂ – Z₁)² / (Z₂ + Z₁)².  
Substituting the acoustic impedances:  
Z₁ (muscle) = 1.7 × 10⁶ kg m⁻² s⁻¹, Z₂ (bone) = 6.4 × 10⁶ kg m⁻² s⁻¹.  
α = (6.4 – 1.7)² / (6.4 + 1.7)² = (4.7)² / (8.1)² = 22.09 / 65.61 ≈ 0.34.  
Fraction reflected = 0.34.  

[2]

Question: A parallel beam of ultrasound of intensity I is incident normally on a muscle of thickness 3.4 cm, as shown in Fig. 11.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ultrasound wave is reflected at a muscle-bone boundary. The intensity of the ultrasound received back at the transducer is IR. Some data for bone and muscle are given in Fig. 11.2.  (DIAGRAM)    Calculate the fraction of the ultrasound intensity that is transmitted through a thickness of 3.4 cm of muscle.       fraction = ........................................................ [3]
Explanation:
To calculate the transmitted intensity fraction through the muscle:  
The attenuation formula is \( I = I_0 e^{-\mu x} \).  
Given \( \mu = 23 \, \text{m}^{-1} \) and \( x = 3.4 \, \text{cm} = 0.034 \, \text{m} \):  
\[
\frac{I}{I_0} = e^{-23 \times 0.034} = e^{-0.782} \approx 0.46
\]  
Thus, the fraction transmitted is **0.46**.  

[3]

Question: A parallel beam of ultrasound of intensity I is incident normally on a muscle of thickness 3.4 cm, as shown in Fig. 11.1.  (DIAGRAM)  The ultrasound wave is reflected at a muscle-bone boundary. The intensity of the ultrasound received back at the transducer is IR. Some data for bone and muscle are given in Fig. 11.2.  (DIAGRAM)    Use your answers in (i) and (ii) to determine the ratio  (DIAGRAM) .       ratio = ........................................................ [2]
Explanation:
The ultrasound travels through the muscle twice (to the bone and back), so the total attenuation factor is the product of the one-way attenuation (found in previous parts) for the round trip. At the muscle-bone boundary, the intensity reflection coefficient is calculated as the square of the amplitude reflection coefficient. Combining these:  

IR/I = (amplitude reflection coefficient)² × (total attenuation)  
= (0.46)² × 0.34  
= 0.072  

Thus, the ratio is **0.072**.  

[2]

Question: An electronic sensor may be represented by the block diagram of Fig. 10.1.  (DIAGRAM)State suitable sensing devices, one in each case, for the detection of  change of temperature, ..................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: thermistor/ thermocouple B1 [1]
Explanation:
A thermistor is suitable for detecting changes in temperature.  
(It is a temperature-dependent resistor whose resistance decreases with increasing temperature, commonly used in electronic circuits for temperature sensing.)  

[1]

Question: An electronic sensor may be represented by the block diagram of Fig. 10.1.  (DIAGRAM)State suitable sensing devices, one in each case, for the detection of  pressure changes in a sound wave. ..................................................................... [1]
Mark Scheme: quartz crystal / piezoelectric crystal or transducer / microphone B1 [1]
Explanation:

[1]

Question: An electronic sensor may be represented by the block diagram of Fig. 10.1.  (DIAGRAM)The ideal operational amplifier (op-amp) shown in Fig. 10.2 is to be used as a processing unit.  (DIAGRAM)    State the value of the output potential VOUT for an input potential VIN of +0.5 V. Explain your answer. ....................................................................... [3]
Mark Scheme: VOUT = –5V inverting input is positive or V– is positive or V– > V+ so VOUT is negative op-amp has very large / infinite gain and so saturates A1 B1 B1 [3]
Explanation:
The output potential \( V_{\text{OUT}} \) is \(-5 \, \text{V}\).  
The input potential \( V_{\text{IN}} = +0.5 \, \text{V} \) is applied to the inverting input (\( V_- \)), while the non-inverting input (\( V_+ \)) is at \( 0 \, \text{V} \). Since \( V_- > V_+ \), the op-amp saturates to its negative supply voltage.  
An ideal op-amp has infinite gain, so even a small input difference (\( +0.5 \, \text{V} \)) drives \( V_{\text{OUT}} \) to the minimum (negative saturation) value, which is \(-5 \, \text{V} \).

Question: An electronic sensor may be represented by the block diagram of Fig. 10.1.  (DIAGRAM)The ideal operational amplifier (op-amp) shown in Fig. 10.2 is to be used as a processing unit. When V_IN > 0, V_OUT = –5V; when V_IN < 0, V_OUT = +5V. Transitions are vertical at zero-crossing points of V_IN.)
